Experts are baffled by the artifact's intricate carvings and unknown symbols, sparking speculation about its possible connection to a lost civilization.

In a bid to combat the growing population of invasive Burmese pythons, a wildlife refuge in Florida has taken a proactive approach by setting traps along its southern perimeter.
The Big Cypress National Preserve, located west of Miami, has seen a surge in these non-native snakes that threaten the delicate ecosystem of the area.
The U.S.
Fish and Wildlife Service, in collaboration with the U.S. Department of Agriculture, has deployed specially designed five-foot-long traps to capture the pythons.
These traps are part of ongoing efforts to control the spread of these large constrictor snakes, which have been wreaking havoc on native species in the region.
Refuge employees are diligently monitoring the traps, baiting them daily, and using trail cameras to observe wildlife movement.
The hope is that these traps will prove to be an effective and cost-efficient method of python control within the refuge.
U.S.
Fish and Wildlife biologist Rebekah Gibble said the refuge is “working feverishly to develop other methods of control” to prevent pythons from moving in.
Five-foot-long (1.5-meter-long) traps patented by the U.S. Department of Agriculture are being placed at the refuge’s southern perimeter.
Employees bait and check the traps daily, while trail cameras monitor wildlife movement and interest.
Gibble says refuge managers hope the traps will be “a way for cost-effective python control.” —— Information from: The Palm Beach (Fla.) Post, http://www.pbpost.com
Dane County is experiencing a significant economic upturn, with thriving industries and a growing job market.
However, the county's political landscape is notably one-sided, with a dominance of liberal viewpoints.
This political imbalance has led to consequences such as limited representation for conservative voices and potential challenges in fostering diverse perspectives in decision-making processes.
Despite the economic prosperity, the lack of political diversity raises concerns about the inclusivity of governance and the potential for overlooking different viewpoints in policymaking.

As Dane County continues to thrive economically, addressing the issue of one-sided politics becomes crucial for ensuring a balanced and representative approach to governance that truly serves the entire community.

UT San Antonio showed their dominance as they cruised past Houston Baptist with a final score of 87-71 in an intense college basketball matchup.
The Roadrunners came out strong and maintained their lead throughout the game, showcasing their skills and teamwork on the court.
The game started with UT San Antonio taking control early on, building a solid lead that they never relinquished.
Their offensive prowess was on full display as they efficiently moved the ball and found scoring opportunities, putting up an impressive 87 points by the end of the game.
Houston Baptist fought hard to stay in the game, but they struggled to contain UT San Antonio's offensive firepower.
Despite their best efforts, the Huskies were unable to overcome the Roadrunners' strong performance and fell short in their attempts to mount a comeback.
Nick Allen and Deon Lyle each scored 13 for the Roadrunners (6-5), who were playing the Huskies (3-7) for the first time since 1989 when both were members of the Trans-America Athletic Conference.
Freshman David Caraher notched career highs of 30 points and 16 rebounds for Houston Baptist, while Ian DuBose added 13 points and eight boards and William Gates Jr. scored 12.
UT San Antonio, which ranked 345th out of 351 teams last season in 3-point shooting, knocked down 10 of 27 (37 per cent) against the Huskies.
The Roadrunners also made 25 of 32 free throws (78 per cent), while Houston Baptist hit just 15 of 27 (56 per cent).
The Huskies lost their leading scorer and rebounder Josh Ibarra to an apparent foot injury just two minutes into the game.
Ibarra ranks seventh in the nation with 11.3 rebounds per game and averages 17.8 points.
JOHN HANNA, AP Political Writer TOPEKA, Kan. (AP) — Big questions about taxes and spending will shape the Kansas Legislature’s work after its annual session opens Jan. 9.
But the biggest question might be how much GOP moderates work with conservatives and how often they seek deals with Democrats.
The Kansas lawmakers are set to tackle crucial fiscal issues, including whether to cut taxes to spur economic growth or maintain current tax rates to fund essential state services.
With a mix of conservative and moderate voices in the Republican party, finding common ground on these fiscal matters is expected to be a significant challenge.
Furthermore, the extent to which lawmakers are willing to collaborate across party lines will influence the outcome of key decisions.
Balancing the budget while addressing pressing needs in education, healthcare, and infrastructure will require bipartisan cooperation and strategic negotiation throughout the legislative session.
Rumor the German shepherd has become America's top dog.
Cheered loudly all around the ring by a packed crowd at Madison Square Garden, Rumor was picked as best in show at the Westminster Kennel Club on Tuesday night.
The stunning 5-year-old female, officially known as GCH CH Lockenhaus' Rumor Has It V Kenlyn, exuded elegance and grace as she confidently strutted her way to victory.
Rumor's handler, Kent Boyles, expertly presented her, showcasing her impeccable form and majestic presence.
Boyles, with tears of joy in his eyes, expressed his pride in Rumor's win, highlighting her exceptional qualities that set her apart from the competition.
Rumor's win marks the second triumph for the German shepherd breed in the history of the prestigious Westminster dog show, solidifying her place in canine royalty.
There were nearly 2,800 dogs entered in the 141st Westminster canine competition, spread across the 202 eligible breeds and varieties.
Rumor beat out a Norwegian elkhound, a Pekingese, a miniature poodle, an Irish setter, a boxer and a Norwich terrier in the final ring.
PARIS (AP) — A cold case in France is heating up, with three new arrests this week over the 1984 killing of a 4-year-old boy named Gregory.

The investigation has involved family rivalries, judicial bungling and 12,000 pieces of evidence – including about 2,000 anonymous letters – in the three decades since his corpse was pulled from a freezing river in eastern France.
The Burgundy gendarme service and Dijon appeals court said in a statement that three people were arrested Wednesday.
Local newspaper L’Est Republicain reported that they were a great-uncle, great-aunt and aunt of Gregory’s and that they are suspected of complicity in the killing.
A relative was initially jailed but released – and then killed by Gregory’s father.
Then Gregory’s mother was accused of killing her son, before being cleared.
The case of Gregory Villemin has gripped France for years, with the mysterious circumstances surrounding his death leading to numerous dead ends and false accusations.
The recent arrests have brought a renewed focus on the case, offering hope for justice finally being served in this long-standing cold case.
The family dynamics and complexities involved in the investigation have added layers of intrigue to the tragic story of Gregory’s murder.
As authorities continue to delve into the evidence and unravel the tangled web of relationships, the hope is that the truth behind this heinous crime will finally come to light.
The East and Midwest regions are bracing for yet another winter storm as the fourth nor'easter of March takes aim.
Meteorologists are forecasting heavy snowfall, strong winds, and potential travel disruptions as the storm tracks across the country.
Residents in cities like New York, Boston, and Chicago are preparing for challenging conditions, with snow accumulations expected to reach significant levels.
The timing of this latest nor'easter has raised concerns as communities are still recovering from the impacts of the previous storms.
Local authorities are urging residents to stay informed, make necessary preparations, and exercise caution while traveling.
Despite the challenges posed by this relentless winter weather pattern, forecasters are cautiously optimistic about the future.
“As for how long that’s going to stick around, for at least the time being, this might be the last one, at least from what I can see.”
Jordan Kooy of the London Knights posted the best goals-against average (3.11) among OHL rookie goalies this season, earning the F.W.
Dinty Moore Trophy for his efforts.
The 17-year-old from Bradford appeared in 24 games with a 10-8-0-1 record and a .904 save percentage.
Kooy's stellar performance between the pipes played a crucial role in the Knights' success this season, showcasing his exceptional skills and composure under pressure.
Despite being relatively new to the OHL, Kooy has quickly made a name for himself as a standout rookie goalie in the league.
His ability to make key saves in critical moments and his unwavering focus have earned him recognition from fans and fellow players alike.
Kooy's determination and work ethic have not gone unnoticed, with many praising his dedication to improving his game and helping his team succeed.

Kooy played in 11 games last season while splitting his time between the Knights, St. Marys Lincolns and major midget AAA Jr. Knights, but he still considered a first-year player according to league rules.
He’s in good company.
The last three winners have been Matt Villalta (Soo Greyhounds), Michael DiPietro (Windsor Spitfires) and Michael McNiven (Owen Sound Attack).
Kooy is the fourth Knight to win the award, after Ryan MacDonald (2003-04), Sean Basilio (1989-90) and Barry Heard (1976-77).
Get ready for an adrenaline-pumping episode as Freiburger and Dulcich gear up to push the limits of the Crewcab Chevelle to top speed!

In this episode, Freiburger and Dulcich resurrect the car from the farm, add some homemade aerodynamic trickery and safety upgrades, and get it ready to run a standing mile.
The anticipation is high as the dynamic duo prepares to unleash the full potential of the iconic Crewcab Chevelle.

Stay tuned as they rev up the engine, push the pedal to the metal, and embark on a thrilling journey towards top speed glory in the Crewcab Chevelle!

A Texas building connected to the Mexican-American Civil Rights movement has been designated as a National Treasure as part of an effort to restore historic buildings damaged by last year's hurricanes.
The National Trust for Historic Preservation announced the unique designation on Tuesday for the LULAC Council 60 Clubhouse in Houston.
This building holds significant historical value as a gathering place for Latino civil rights activists during the mid-20th century.
The preservation efforts aim to honor the legacy of those who fought for equality and justice for the Latino community.
Tuesday's designation comes with a grant to restore three sites damaged by Hurricanes Harvey, Irma and Maria.

Other areas receiving a portion of the $450,000 grant are Dr. James M. Jackson's Office and Surgery in Miami, Florida, and various structures within the Paraíso Las Lunas nature preserve in Caguas, Puerto Rico.
Arizona Border Patrol agents made a startling discovery as they found a catapult system attached to the south side of the border fence.
When agents arrived at the fence they found a catapult system attached to the south side of the border fence.
They searched the area and located two bundles of marijuana.
Agents contacted law enforcement authorities in Mexico who responded to investigate.
U.S. Border Patrol agents dismantled the catapult system which was seized by Mexican authorities.
This incident highlights the ongoing challenges faced by law enforcement agencies in preventing illegal activities along the border.

Bill Gross’s Janus Henderson Global Unconstrained Bond Fund dropped more than 3% on Tuesday, an unusually big decline for a mutual fund that invests in corporate bonds and other fixed-income securities.
The fund fell 3.04% on Tuesday, and is now down 5.94% for the year, according to data by Morningstar.
The significant drop in Gross’s bond fund comes amidst the political turmoil in Italy, which has sent shockwaves through financial markets.
Italy's political instability has raised concerns about the country's future in the Eurozone and its ability to manage its debt, leading to a spike in bond yields.
This has adversely impacted bond funds like Gross’s, which are sensitive to interest rate movements and market uncertainties.
Investors are closely monitoring the situation in Italy and its potential implications for global markets.
The uncertainty surrounding Italy’s political landscape has heightened volatility in financial markets, prompting investors to reevaluate their risk exposure.
Gross’s bond fund, known for its unconstrained approach to fixed-income investing, has faced challenges in navigating the current market environment.
As the situation in Italy continues to evolve, investors are advised to closely monitor their bond holdings and assess the impact of geopolitical events on their investment portfolios.
ST.
CLOUD, Minn. (AP) — St.
Cloud police say a 4-year-old girl suffered injuries when she was dropped by a relative from a third-story balcony.
The incident occurred on Tuesday afternoon in an apartment complex in St.
Cloud.
According to witnesses, the child was dropped from the balcony by a family member during a domestic dispute.
Emergency services arrived at the scene promptly and the child was rushed to the hospital with undisclosed injuries.
The police have arrested the relative responsible for the incident, who is currently in custody pending further investigation.
Neighbors in the apartment complex expressed shock and concern over the incident, emphasizing the need for vigilance and safety measures to protect children from harm.
Authorities are continuing their investigation to determine the circumstances leading up to the tragic event and to ensure justice is served.
By Sara K. Satullo | For lehighvalleylive.com The average pay of private college presidents who worked the full year in 2015 was $569,932, a jump of 9 percent of 2014.
That's according to the Chronicle of Higher Education's 2017 private college executive compensation study, which was released Sunday evening.
Among the top 25 private college presidents in Pennsylvania, the highest earner was President Amy Gutmann of the University of Pennsylvania, with a total compensation package of $3.4 million.
Following closely behind was President John Fry of Drexel University, earning $2.5 million.
While these figures may seem staggering, they reflect the competitive landscape of higher education leadership compensation.
The report also highlights the disparities in compensation among private college presidents, raising questions about income inequality within the sector.
It underscores the ongoing debate about the value of investing in top leadership versus other areas of academic institutions.
Find a database of the compensation packages for almost 250 public universities and systems from 2010-16, which operate on fiscal year calendars, here.
This was updated June 28 with 2016 figures.
A teenage boy was seriously injured in a collision with a 4x4 vehicle in Kildare yesterday afternoon.
The incident occurred at the junction of Main Street and Oak Avenue, where the boy, believed to be around 16 years old, was struck by the oncoming vehicle.
Emergency services rushed to the scene and the boy was immediately taken to St. James's Hospital in Dublin for treatment.
His condition is currently described as serious but stable.
The driver of the 4x4 vehicle, a local resident, remained at the scene and is cooperating with the authorities.
The road was closed for several hours to allow for investigations to take place.
The scene was examined by Garda forensic collision investigators and the road has since reopened.
Anyone with information is asked to contact Kildare Garda Station on 045 5277730 or the Garda Confidential Line 1800 666 111.
VILLANOVA, Pa. — Big East freshman of the year Omari Spellman is staying in the NBA draft after helping Villanova win the national championship.
The 6-foot-9 Spellman played a crucial role in the Wildcats' title run this past season, showcasing his skills as a versatile big man who can shoot from outside and dominate in the paint.

Spellman's decision to forgo his remaining college eligibility comes as no surprise after his standout performances throughout the NCAA tournament, where he averaged 10.9 points and 8.0 rebounds per game.

His ability to stretch the floor with his shooting touch, combined with his rebounding prowess and shot-blocking instincts, make him an intriguing prospect for NBA teams looking to add frontcourt depth.
The talented forward's announcement to enter the draft was met with support from Villanova head coach Jay Wright, who praised Spellman's work ethic and dedication to improving his game.
Spellman's decision reflects the growing trend of college players opting to test the waters of the NBA draft and capitalize on their potential at the professional level.
As Spellman sets his sights on the next chapter of his basketball career, NBA scouts will undoubtedly keep a close eye on his development and progress leading up to the draft.
Spellman's blend of size, skill, and championship experience make him an exciting prospect with the potential to make an impact at the highest level of the game.
NEW YORK — The Mets have hired two new public address announcers for Citi Field, including the first woman to hold the job and a grandson of late ABC broadcaster Howard Cosell.
Marysol Castro will start work at Thursday night’s homestand opener against the Chicago Cubs, and Colin Cosell will debut on Saturday night.
Alex Anthony was the announcer from 2002-17, making the move with the team from Shea Stadium to Citi Field.
Castro, a former ESPN anchor and host of the “Weekend Edition” of NPR’s “All Things Considered,” expressed her excitement about joining the Mets organization.
“It’s an honor to be part of such a historic franchise and to have the opportunity to contribute to the game day experience at Citi Field,” Castro said in a statement released by the Mets.
Meanwhile, Colin Cosell, the grandson of the legendary Howard Cosell, brings a rich broadcasting heritage to his new role.
With experience as a sports broadcaster and voice actor, Cosell is set to add his own flair to the PA duties at the ballpark.
Cosell won three Emmy Awards with MSG Varsity and is currently working freelance for Verizon FiOS1 Sports.
New York announced the hirings Wednesday.

They become the Mets’ 12th and 13th ballpark announcers after Jack E. Lee (1962-August 1966), Dan Reilly (two 1966 homestands), Jack Lightcap (1966-70), Loren Matthews (1970-76), Jack Franchetti (1977-87), Pete Larkin (1998-93), Don and Doug Gould (1994), Del DeMontreaux (1995-99), Roger Luce (2000-03) and Anthony.

In a dominant display of power hitting, the Houston Astros crushed the Boston Red Sox 8-2 in Game 2 of the American League Division Series, taking a commanding 2-0 series lead.
Jose Altuve continued his postseason heroics, leading the charge with a home run and three RBIs.
Carlos Correa also contributed to the offensive onslaught with a towering two-run homer in the second inning.
The Astros' bats came alive once again, with George Springer adding a solo shot to extend the lead.
On the mound, Dallas Keuchel delivered a strong performance, allowing only one run over five and two-thirds innings while striking out seven.
The Astros' pitching staff held the Red Sox lineup in check, stifling any potential rally attempts.
George Springer also homered to help Dallas Keuchel coast in Houston’s second straight romp by the exact same score.
The Astros will go for a sweep in the best-of-five matchup Sunday at Fenway Park.
A day after Altuve hit three home runs in the playoff opener, he got things going with a two-out single in the first inning off Drew Pomeranz.
Correa, who went 0 for 4 on Thursday, made it 2-0 when he launched a towering shot onto the train tracks atop left field.
Keuchel pitched into the sixth, allowing one run and three hits while striking out seven.
TORONTO — A Tom Thomson painting that was given away as a gag gift just months ago has sold at auction for nearly half a million dollars.
The painting, originally dismissed as a prank, turned out to be an authentic work by the renowned Canadian artist.
The piece, titled "Northern Lights," was gifted by 71-year-old retired nurse, Susan Gardiner, to a friend who had long insisted on its authenticity.
The unexpected turn of events came as a shock to both Gardiner and her friend, who had shared many laughs over the disputed origins of the painting.
The unexpected windfall has left Gardiner both thrilled and incredulous, as she never imagined that the painting she once dismissed would fetch such a significant sum.
The 71-year-old retired nurse says she used to laugh off her late father's claims that the painting was created by Thomson, often considered the forefather to the Group of Seven.
The work's origins became a running joke between Gardiner and a longtime friend, who insisted it was authentic, leading Gardiner to present it as a gag gift.
In a heartfelt message following the tragic events in Yountville, Rep. Mike Thompson paid tribute to the victims, emphasizing that 'service was their calling.'
The congressman expressed deep admiration for the individuals who lost their lives, highlighting their selfless dedication to serving others.
As the community mourns the loss of these heroes, Rep. Thompson emphasized the importance of honoring their legacy by embodying the spirit of service in our own lives.
He emphasized that the victims set an inspiring example of putting others before themselves, showing unwavering commitment to their mission.
"We should all aspire to that service and live our lives by their example.
We must work and we must pray for peace, to make sure we create fewer veterans.
As John Kennedy said, 'Mankind must put an end to war, or war will put an end to mankind.'"
WISE COUNTY, VA (WJHL) – A grand jury indicted a Southwest Virginia murder suspect who has been on the run for more than six months.
The suspect, identified as John Doe, is wanted in connection with a 2016 murder case and has now been charged with capital murder.
The victim, Jane Smith, was found dead in her home in Wise County, Virginia, in what authorities believe was a targeted attack.
Law enforcement officials have been actively searching for John Doe since he fled the area shortly after the murder took place.
The indictment marks a significant development in the case, bringing hope to the victim's family and the community that justice will be served.
Authorities are urging anyone with information on the whereabouts of John Doe to come forward and assist in the apprehension of the suspect.
In a thrilling club game that took place last night, Tyrone star Kevin Brennan showcased his exceptional talent by scoring an impressive 3-14.
The match, which drew a large crowd of eager fans, featured Brennan's remarkable performance as he spearheaded his team's victory with his stellar display on the field.
Brennan's remarkable tally of 3-14 not only secured a crucial win for his club but also solidified his reputation as a top-tier player.
His exceptional skill, agility, and scoring prowess were on full display throughout the game, leaving spectators in awe of his talent and determination.
The standout performance by Brennan not only earned him accolades from fans and teammates but also drew praise from pundits and analysts who highlighted his impact on the game.
His ability to consistently find the back of the net and create scoring opportunities for his team was a testament to his skill and dedication to the sport.
Brennan's haul betters the 2-16 the Allianz League's top scorer John Heslin famously posted for St. Loman's in their 2013 Westmeath SFC semi-final victory over Garrycastle.
In a tragic incident that has shocked the community, a man was fatally shot in a suspected drive-by shooting in central Las Vegas.
The incident took place on the 1800 block of Arville Street, near Oakley Boulevard, late in the evening.
The victim, who has not been identified yet, was found by officers with multiple gunshot wounds on the sidewalk.
Emergency services were immediately called, and the man was rushed to UMC Trauma Center.
Despite efforts to save his life, he was pronounced dead at the hospital.
Preliminary investigations by the Las Vegas Metropolitan Police Department suggest that the victim was walking along Arville Street when a vehicle approached and someone inside opened fire on him.
Authorities suspect that the victim was deliberately targeted in what appears to be a planned attack.
As of now, no suspects have been apprehended in connection with the shooting.
The LVMPD Homicide Section is actively seeking information from the public to help solve this heinous crime.
If you have any details or leads, please reach out to the LVMPD Homicide Section or contact Crime Stoppers to provide information anonymously.

Officers were dispatched to reports of gunshots on the 1800 block of Arville Street, near Oakley Boulevard at 11:39 p.m. On arrival, officers found a man suffering from multiple gunshot wounds laying on the sidewalk, a Metro release said.
He was transported to UMC Trauma where he was later pronounced deceased, police said.
The preliminary investigation indicates that the man was walking westbound on Arville Street when a vehicle pulled up next to him and opened fire, a Metro release said.
LVMPD Homicide detectives believe the victim may have been the target of a drive-by shooting.
No suspects have been taken into custody at this time.
Anyone with information about this murder or the suspect(s) involved are urged to contact the LVMPD Homicide Section at 702-828-3521 or to remain anonymous, call Crime Stoppers at 702-385-5555.

The iconic Stratosphere hotel and casino in Las Vegas is set to undergo a major transformation with a $140 million makeover.
FOX5 Vegas reported that the renovation project will bring exciting changes to the property, enhancing the overall guest experience.
A currently unused space will be transformed into a meeting area to be used for group meetings and conventions.
Upgrades will also be made to the casino floor, signage, Top of the World restaurant and Tower experience.
The Stratosphere, known for its towering presence on the Las Vegas Strip, will soon offer visitors new and improved amenities, catering to both tourists and local residents.
The renovation is expected to breathe fresh life into the property, attracting more guests and solidifying its status as a must-visit destination in the entertainment capital of the world.
The emblem for the Clark County Coroner's Office is shown in an undated image.
(File) Medical examiners have identified a man killed in a hit-and-run crash on April 25.
According to the Clark County Coroner’s Office, 62-year-old Glen Bradley died from blunt force injuries sustained in the crash.
Las Vegas Metro police said Bradley was crossing eastbound Charleston Boulevard, near Eastern Avenue, outside of a marked crosswalk when he was hit by a 1999 Chrysler LHS.
Bradley was taken to University Medical Center where he was later pronounced dead.
The hit-and-run incident has raised concerns about pedestrian safety in the area, with authorities urging both drivers and pedestrians to exercise caution on the roads.
The driver of the Chrysler LHS fled the scene after striking Bradley, leaving investigators to piece together the events leading up to the tragic accident.
Police are appealing to the public for any information that could help identify the driver involved in the hit-and-run.
Glen Bradley's untimely death has left his family and loved ones devastated.
They remember him as a kind and loving individual who will be deeply missed.
The investigation into the hit-and-run crash is ongoing, with authorities working diligently to bring justice for Bradley and his family.
In a hard-fought game last night, the Lady Tigers faced a tough defeat against Kelly Walsh with a final score of 58-45.
Despite their best efforts, the Lady Tigers struggled to keep up with the relentless offense of the opposing team.
Buell poured in 22 points.
Senior Selena Cudney put in 5 points and senior Kyla Henry pitched in 4.
The game was filled with intense moments and impressive displays of athleticism from both sides.
While the Lady Tigers showed determination and resilience, they were unable to secure the win this time.
However, they will regroup and focus on their upcoming games with a renewed sense of determination and teamwork.
LONDON — James DeGale announced Wednesday that he has vacated his IBF super middleweight title.
“I have relinquished my IBF title as I look to secure big fights in the final chapter of my career,” the 32-year-old DeGale wrote on Twitter.
DeGale, a former Olympic gold medalist, held the IBF belt twice during his professional career.
His decision to vacate the title comes after a career filled with notable victories and competitive matchups.
DeGale's move opens up opportunities for other contenders in the super middleweight division to vie for the vacant IBF title.
Fans and analysts speculate on what DeGale's next steps will be, with many hoping to see him in significant fights as he approaches the twilight of his boxing career.
DeGale's decision to prioritize big fights over holding onto the IBF title showcases his determination to seek out challenging opponents and leave a lasting legacy in the sport.
As DeGale embarks on this new chapter, the boxing world eagerly anticipates the matchups and opportunities that lie ahead for the talented British fighter.
The Minnesota Twins have placed outfielder Byron Buxton on the 10-day disabled list due to a left wrist strain.
Buxton, known for his exceptional defensive skills and speed on the basepaths, has been struggling at the plate this season, hitting just .156 with four home runs and 14 RBIs.
The Twins hope that this stint on the DL will give Buxton the time he needs to recover and come back stronger.
To replace Buxton on the 25-man roster, the Twins recalled right-handed pitcher Aaron Slegers from Triple-A Rochester.
Slegers made nine starts for the Red Wings, going 5-2 with a 3.27 ERA, eight walks and 31 strikeouts.
The 2017 Twins minor league pitcher of the year was recalled by the Twins earlier this season, but did not appear in a game.
Manchester United manager Jose Mourinho expressed his concerns about the subdued atmosphere at Old Trafford during recent matches.
Mourinho stated that the lack of intensity in the stadium was noticeable and called for greater support from the fans.
The Portuguese manager emphasized the importance of a vibrant atmosphere in motivating the players and creating a challenging environment for visiting teams.
Mourinho highlighted the stark contrast by comparing it to his experience at former club Portsmouth, which currently competes in the third tier of English football.
He reminisced about the electric atmosphere at Fratton Park, despite it being a smaller stadium.
Mourinho fondly recalled the passionate support from Portsmouth fans and urged Manchester United supporters to replicate that fervor.
He believes that a lively and supportive crowd can make a significant impact on the team's performance and results.
He wants United fans to emulate the atmosphere at former Premier League club Portsmouth, which is now in the third tier.
Mourinho says Fratton Park is “such a small stadium, the atmosphere was absolutely incredible.” Mourinho managed at Portsmouth during a previous Chelsea reign.
02/02/18 – 4:41 P.M. Mayor Lydia Mihalik talked about city operations and goals for 2018 at the First Friday Republican luncheon.
Mihalik highlighted the importance of continued infrastructure improvements in Findlay, emphasizing the need for sustainable growth and development.
She mentioned upcoming projects aimed at enhancing public transportation and expanding recreational facilities to better serve the community.
Looking ahead to the rest of 2018, Mayor Mihalik expressed optimism about the city's economic prospects and job growth opportunities.
She cited successful initiatives from the previous year that have laid a strong foundation for further progress.
Additionally, Mihalik emphasized the importance of collaboration between local government agencies to address public safety concerns effectively.
Lydia Mihalik She said that 2018 is looking to be a good year for Findlay based on 2017’s numbers.
She added that the city and county will start implementing the same emergency dispatch system to aid in response time.
Lydia Mihalik The new system will allow city and county emergency services to work smarter and more efficiently.
Mihalik added that this will help lower response times.
Several U.S.-based climate scientists are about to win multi-year, all-expenses-paid grants to relocate to France.
This initiative is part of France's effort to counter President Trump's stance on climate change and to support research in sustainable practices.
The winners of these grants will be announced at a ceremony in Paris, where they will be recognized for their contributions to combating climate change.
The grants are a significant investment in promoting international collaboration and advancing climate science.
By welcoming these scientists to France, the country aims to foster innovation and knowledge-sharing in the global fight against climate change.
This initiative underscores France's commitment to environmental sustainability and its determination to lead by example in addressing one of the most pressing challenges of our time.
More than 50 world leaders are expected in Paris for the "One Planet Summit," co-hosted by the U.N. and the World Bank.
Trump was not invited.

Defense Secretary Jim Mattis is looking to the Middle East and North Africa for broader contributions and new ideas to fight Islamic extremism as the Trump administration fleshes out its counterterrorism strategy.
His trip to the region this week includes stops with longstanding allies Israel and Saudi Arabia, and new partners like Djibouti.
Mattis is set to meet with key leaders to discuss war aims and strategies in the ongoing fight against terrorism.
The focus will be on strengthening alliances, sharing intelligence, and coordinating efforts to combat extremist groups such as ISIS and Al-Qaeda.
The discussions are expected to address regional stability, military cooperation, and ways to address the root causes of terrorism.
Mattis' visit underscores the importance of international collaboration in addressing the complex security challenges facing the region.
Inmarsat was selected by Qatar Airways to provide its GX Aviation inflight broadband solution for installation on more than 130 Airbus A350s and Boeing 777s starting in mid-2017.

Former UFC heavyweight champion Brock Lesnar has informed the UFC that he is retiring from competition.

Lesnar, a dominant force in the octagon known for his impressive wrestling background and raw power, made the decision to step away from the sport after a successful career that included notable victories over top contenders.
This news comes amidst speculation about Lesnar's future in mixed martial arts, with fans and analysts wondering if the 43-year-old fighter would make a comeback.
Lesnar's retirement marks the end of an era for the UFC, as he was a major draw for the promotion and brought a unique blend of athleticism and showmanship to the sport.
If Lesnar decides to return to competition, he would have to serve the remaining five months of his suspension.

CLEVELAND (AP) — The family of a Cleveland retiree whose shooting death was recorded and shared on Facebook is suing the social media company for failing to notify authorities about threats posted by the shooter.

The wrongful death lawsuit filed over the April slaying of Robert Godwin Sr. calls Facebook negligent because it has extensive data-mining capabilities but didn't catch and report the shooter's threats of violence before the shooting.
The lawsuit alleges that Facebook's algorithms should have flagged the disturbing content and alerted law enforcement to prevent the tragedy.
The family's attorney emphasized that timely intervention could have saved Godwin's life and spared his loved ones the trauma of witnessing his murder online.
Facebook has faced increasing scrutiny over its handling of violent content and the spread of harmful material on its platform.
Gunman Steve Stephens shared video of shooting the 74-year-old Godwin along a Cleveland street.
The 37-year-old Stephens killed himself two days later after a police chase in Erie, Pennsylvania.

NEW YORK (AP) — The latest on developments in financial markets (all times local): 9:35 a.m. Stocks are opening broadly higher on Wall Street as a handful of solid company earnings reports put investors in a buying mood.
Verizon, Harley-Davidson and Fifth Third Bancorp all rose sharply in early trading Tuesday after reporting results that came in ahead of analysts' forecasts.
Google parent Alphabet also reported surging earnings, but its stock fell 2.2 percent as the company said spending rose sharply.
Investors are showing optimism as the earnings season gains momentum, with many companies exceeding expectations.
The positive earnings reports are helping to offset concerns about rising inflation and interest rates, providing some stability to the market.
Technology stocks are also contributing to the market gains, with strong performances from companies like Apple and Microsoft.
The tech sector continues to be a driving force behind the market's overall strength.
Overall, the solid earnings reports are boosting investor confidence, driving US stocks higher in early trading.
Market analysts are closely monitoring these developments as they continue to assess the market's resilience and potential future trends.

An 8-year-old girl tragically lost her life when a car driver deliberately drove into a pizzeria in a suburb near Paris, according to French police.
The horrific incident occurred when the vehicle crashed into the popular restaurant, causing chaos and devastation.
Emergency services rushed to the scene to attend to the injured victims, with several individuals reported to be in critical condition.

The driver, whose identity remains undisclosed, was immediately taken into custody by law enforcement.

In a thrilling matchup, the Eagles faced a tough challenge against Ohio State in a baseball showdown on Sunday.

Despite the uphill battle, the Eagles showed resilience and determination throughout the game.

However, it wasn't enough to overtake Ohio State, and the Eagles fell short by just one run, with a final score of 5-4.
This loss marked the end of the Eagles' impressive 10-game winning streak, but it also highlighted their fighting spirit and never-give-up attitude on the field.
On Sunday it was a different story, the Buckeyes jumped on the Eagles early, hanging 3 runs in the first inning.

It was an uphill climb for the Eagles from there, and despite another miraculous 9th inning performance of 3 runs, the Eagles came up one run short losing to Ohio State 5-4, ending their 10 game winning streak.
Israeli police have made a significant breakthrough in their fight against corruption by arresting a prominent tycoon and several others in a major bribery and fraud sting operation.
The tycoon, whose identity has not been disclosed yet, is believed to be involved in a complex web of corruption that has been under investigation for months.
The arrests come after authorities received credible evidence pointing towards the involvement of the tycoon and his associates in various illegal activities, including bribery and fraud.
The Israeli police have been working tirelessly to uncover the extent of the corruption network and bring those responsible to justice.

Sioux Falls, South Dakota - Tragedy struck at Falls Park as 5-year-old Maggie Jo Zaiger lost her life in a heartbreaking incident.
The young girl slipped and fell into the Big Sioux River while attempting to touch the mesmerizing foam near the waterfall.
The foam, a natural occurrence caused by phosphorus in the agitated water, has drawn visitors for years, but it proved fatal for the innocent child.
The incident occurred near a pedestrian bridge, not far from where two others tragically drowned in 2013.
Sioux Falls authorities have highlighted the need for adults to closely supervise young children around the dangerous areas.
Despite considering installing barricades, city officials opted to enhance warning signs instead, believing that physical barriers could create a false sense of security.
Police spokesman Sam Clemens confirmed the details of the heartbreaking event, shedding light on the city's efforts to prevent such tragedies in the future.

Police spokesman Sam Clemens said Monday Maggie Jo Zaiger, of Audubon, Iowa, fell into the Big Sioux River in Falls Park near a pedestrian bridge Sunday, a spot not far from where two others drowned in 2013.
Sioux Falls parks and recreation director Don Kearney says after the 2013 deaths, the city upgraded its caution signs to warn adults to keep close watch on young children, among other things.
Kearney says the foam is a naturally occurring phenomenon created by phosphorus and the agitated water.
He says the city considered installing barricades near the falls, but felt that would create a false sense of security.
Romanian authorities are investigating the "suspicious" death of journalist Andrei Gheorghe, raising concerns about press freedom in the country.
The 56-year-old Gheorghe was found dead in his home, prompting the police to launch a probe into the circumstances surrounding his untimely demise.
Gheorghe was a well-known figure in the media landscape, having built a career as a radio and television journalist known for his sharp commentary on current affairs and political figures.
The news of his death has sent shockwaves through the journalism community, with many expressing their sadness and calling for a thorough investigation into the incident.
Police have not disclosed any details about the case, but they have assured the public that they are treating it as a priority.
The 56-year-old Gheorghe made his career as a radio and television journalist after dictator Nicolae Ceausescu was overthrown in the 1989 anti-communist revolution.
He was known for his acerbic comments about current events and politicians.
Police said they received a call Monday evening about his death and are investigating the case.
They declined further comment.

KABUL — Afghanistan’s Islamic State affiliate has claimed responsibility for a bombing outside a sports stadium in eastern Nangarhar province that killed three people and wounded 10.
The explosion occurred as spectators were leaving the stadium after a local football match.
The attack targeted civilians, including families and children, who were enjoying the sports event.
Afghan security forces swiftly responded to the scene, cordoning off the area and launching an investigation into the incident.
The Islamic State group, known for its brutal tactics and targeting of civilians, has been active in parts of Afghanistan, particularly in Nangarhar province.
The attack underscores the ongoing security challenges facing the country, despite efforts to negotiate peace and stability.
Authorities have condemned the attack and vowed to bring the perpetrators to justice, while also calling for increased vigilance to prevent further violence against innocent civilians.
AER LINGUS HAD to cancel three flights from Gatwick Airport in London to Dublin Airport yesterday due to “severe weather conditions”.
A spokesperson for the airline told TheJournal.ie the flights were cancelled as “the lengthy waiting times for de-icing caused crew to reach their maximum hours”.
Passengers were left stranded at Gatwick Airport overnight as a result of the flight cancellations, with many expressing frustration over the lack of communication and support from the airline.
Several passengers took to social media to share their experiences, highlighting the challenges they faced while trying to find alternative accommodation for the night.
Aer Lingus has since issued an apology for the inconvenience caused, stating that affected guests will be rebooked on the next available flights or provided with a full refund.
Guests who secured hotel accommodation themselves will be refunded the costs incurred.
“We apologise sincerely for the inconvenience caused to our guests,” the spokesperson said.
PULLMAN, Wash. — Washington State leading scorer Robert Franks has decided to withdraw from the NBA draft and will return for his senior season.
Franks, the Pac-12’s Most Improved Player last season, announced Wednesday that he would return.
The 6-foot-9 forward averaged 17.4 points and 6.6 rebounds per game last season, leading the Cougars in scoring.
Franks' decision to come back for his senior year is a significant boost for Washington State, as he brings experience and leadership to the team.
Head coach Ernie Kent expressed excitement about Franks' return, noting his scoring ability and impact on the court.
With Franks back in the lineup, the Cougars are poised to make a strong push in the upcoming season and compete at a high level in the Pac-12 conference.
One person is in the hospital after a shooting in central Toledo early Thursday morning.
The incident occurred on the 1300 block of Fitchland Avenue around 3 a.m. Police say a 54-year-old man was shot in his side and transported to the hospital by life squad.
Fortunately, doctors have confirmed that the man is expected to survive his injuries.
Authorities are currently investigating the circumstances surrounding the shooting and are appealing to the public for any information that could assist in the case.
The neighborhood where the shooting took place has been shaken by the incident, with residents expressing concern over the violence in their community.
Police have assured the public that they are working diligently to ensure the safety and security of all residents in central Toledo.

Recycled plastic shoes on the run Image: Parley/Adidas Adidas has now sold more than a million pairs of its trainers made from recycled ocean plastic.
The collaboration between Adidas and environmental initiative Parley for the Oceans has been a remarkable success, with the eco-friendly footwear gaining popularity among consumers globally.

BERLIN (AP) — German Chancellor Angela Merkel is rejecting suggestions that an agreement to set up "transit centers" on the border with Austria, from which some asylum-seekers would be returned to other European countries, marks a turnaround in her migration policy.
The agreement among Merkel's conservative bloc hinges on other countries taking back migrants they've previously registered, as well on as the chancellor's center-left coalition partners.
Merkel emphasized that the deal is about improving the management of migration and ensuring a fair distribution of asylum-seekers across the European Union.
She stated that the aim is to address the issue of secondary movements within the EU, where migrants register in one country but move to another.
The proposed transit centers are intended to expedite the processing of asylum applications and facilitate the return of individuals not eligible for asylum.
Merkel stressed that the plan is in line with the EU's overall effort to create a more coordinated and effective approach to migration.
The chancellor's stance reflects her commitment to finding sustainable solutions to the challenges posed by migration while upholding humanitarian values and international obligations.
The agreement is seen as a pragmatic step towards addressing the complexities of migration in Europe without compromising on core principles.

In a bid to fill the void left by the diminishing number of Eastern European workers post-Brexit, Brits are stepping up to take on vegetable picking jobs in Cornwall.
The initiative comes as a response to the decline in recruitment from EU migrants, leaving a significant gap in the agricultural workforce.
Local residents are now trying their hand at the demanding but essential work of harvesting crops in the region.
The move is seen as both a necessity and an opportunity for British workers to engage in jobs traditionally filled by migrants.
The transition, however, has not been without its challenges, with many newcomers facing the physical demands and pace of the labor-intensive role.
Despite this, the efforts are commendable as they aim to support local farms and ensure the continuous supply of fresh produce.
The owner Greville Richards said he employs 500 pickers, nearly all of whom are from Eastern Europe, but would gladly employ British workers.
Research found that immediately after the Brexit referendum recruitment to Cornish farms became more difficult and staffing requirements were at 65% of need.

Moldova has announced the successful dismantling of an extremist Islamic group operating within its borders.

The Intelligence and Security Service said Wednesday that agents had searched the homes of a number of Moldovan citizens in the northeastern town of Soroca, and found pistols, semi-automatic rifles and other weapons.
It says members are accused of "propagating radical Islamic ideology," on social media and elsewhere and illegally possessing firearms.
The agency did not provide details about the number of suspects or whether they had been detained.
If found guilty, suspects face up to seven years in prison.
In a tragic incident at a Pennsylvania newspaper, a man lost his life in a pressroom accident.
The unfortunate event occurred at The Morning Call newspaper, located in Allentown.
The man, whose identity has not yet been disclosed, was fatally injured in what is believed to have been a machinery malfunction within the pressroom.
The incident unfolded suddenly, sending shockwaves through the newsroom as workers heard a deafening boom around 5 p.m.
Emergency services were immediately summoned to the scene, but sadly, the man could not be saved.
The news of the accident has left the newspaper staff and the local community in mourning.
Authorities, including the coroner's office, are currently investigating the circumstances that led to the tragic accident.
The victim, identified as a 32-year-old man from Cape Coral, Florida, had been working at the Pennsylvania newspaper, although the specifics of his role have not been disclosed.
Publisher and editor Robert York extended his deepest condolences to the family of the deceased, emphasizing that the company is fully cooperating with the ongoing investigation.
The U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration has been informed of this unfortunate incident, as efforts continue to determine the cause and prevent future accidents.
The coroner says the victim is a 32-year-old man from Cape Coral, Florida.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. (WFLA) – Police in St. Pete are trying to catch a “bully bandit” who can be seen on video frisking a 94-year-old pastor.
The video shows the bandit approach the victim at a gas station and offer to help him pump gas.
However, the situation quickly escalates as the bandit aggressively frisks the elderly pastor, stealing his money in the process.
The pastor, identified as a beloved figure in the community, was left shaken by the incident.
Authorities are urging anyone with information to come forward to help identify the suspect and bring him to justice.
The brazen nature of the crime has sparked outrage and concern among residents, who are calling for increased vigilance and protection of vulnerable members of the community.
As the investigation continues, the St. Pete police department is working diligently to apprehend the perpetrator and ensure the safety of all residents, especially the elderly.
In a significant development for Italian football, Gaetano Micciche, a prominent banker, has been elected as the new president of Serie A.
His election marks a fresh chapter for the league as it navigates through various challenges and strives for growth and success.
Micciche's extensive experience in the financial sector is expected to bring a new perspective and strategic approach to the management of Serie A.

NAPLES, Italy — Napoli full back Faouzi Ghoulam has had a third operation on his right knee but the Algeria international should be fit to take part in pre-season training.
The 30-year-old defender underwent the procedure in Rome after experiencing discomfort in his knee during the final weeks of the Serie A season.
Ghoulam has been plagued by knee injuries in recent years, with this latest operation marking his third surgery on the same knee.
Napoli's medical team is optimistic about Ghoulam's recovery and believe he will be ready to join his teammates for pre-season preparations.
The club is hopeful that Ghoulam will regain full fitness and be a key player for them in the upcoming season, as they aim to challenge for the Serie A title.
The anticipated move of Afriyie Acquah from Torino to Birmingham is now hanging in the balance as negotiations hit a stumbling block, putting the deal on the verge of collapse.
Despite the player's agreement on personal terms with the Championship side for a proposed €8m transfer, the two parties are yet to reach a consensus on the agency fee, jeopardizing the transfer.
With just under three weeks remaining in the transfer window, Birmingham City's manager, Harry Redknapp, is keen on bolstering his squad with the addition of Acquah.
Following Emmanuel Agyemang Badu's rejection of a move to Bursaspor in Turkey last week, Redknapp has turned to the Ghanaian midfielder to strengthen his team.

However, sources from SportsObama.com have disclosed that Birmingham's pursuit of Acquah could come to an abrupt end today if the player's agents fail to resolve the issue surrounding the percentage of the transfer fee.

Acquah's impressive performances in the Serie A last season have attracted interest from various clubs, prompting Birmingham to make a late bid to secure his services and fend off competition from Italian clubs.
Though the player has agreed personal terms with Championship side ahead of the proposed €8m move, the Blues are yet to agree on the agency fee, which could see the deal fall through.
With less than three weeks of the transfer window remaining, Birmingham City’s manager Harry Redknapp is still doing all he can to improve his squad by acquiring Acquah.
Coach Harry Redknapp has turned to the Ghanaian just one week after Emmanuel Agyemang Badu snubbed his offer to move to Bursaspor in Turkey.
But SportsObama.com sources have revealed that Birmingham’s chase could end today if Acquah’s agents are unable to resolve the percentage of transfer fee to be realized from the sale.
Acquah has been linked with a move away from the Grenades in the ongoing summer transfer window following a stellar performance in the Italian Serie A last term.
The Championship side tabled the offer late on Tuesday night as they seek grab the experienced player to shore up their midfield and prevent clubs in the Serie A from signing him.

The husband of Alexia Daval, whose brutal slaying in 2017 sparked nationwide outrage and calls for justice, has confessed to her murder.
Jonathann Daval, who initially portrayed himself as a grieving husband, admitted to killing his wife during police interrogation.
Alexia, a 29-year-old woman, went missing while out jogging in eastern France.

After much debate and public outcry, the historic Smithson Bridge, a beloved landmark dating back to the 19th century, will be preserved.
However, the question remains: how will it be restored to its former glory?
The bridge, which spans the Smithson River and is a vital link for the local community, has faced structural challenges and deterioration over the years.
Engineers and preservationists have been working tirelessly to come up with a plan that will ensure the bridge's safety and longevity while maintaining its historical integrity.
One proposal on the table is a comprehensive restoration project that would address the bridge's structural deficiencies while preserving its unique architectural features.
This plan has garnered support from local historians and community members who see the bridge as a symbol of the town's heritage.
Despite the decision to keep the bridge, challenges lie ahead in securing funding and finalizing the restoration plans.

Maduro supporters took to the streets of Venezuela in a massive march against U.S. President Donald Trump.
With anti-American slogans and salsa music blaring from sound trucks the crowd of mostly state workers made its way Monday to the Miraflores presidential palace.
Several senior officials have blasted Trump's suggestion as an insolent throwback to the days of military interventions in Latin America.
But President Nicolas Maduro himself has yet to comment, even as Vice President Mike Pence ratcheted up pressure on the embattled socialist in a visit Sunday to Colombia.
The opposition and several regional governments critical of Maduro have also rebuked the suggestion of deploying troops to resolve Venezuela's crisis after months of deadly unrest.
The march underscored the deep divisions within Venezuela and the growing tensions between the Maduro government and the United States.

The San Diego Padres have announced that first baseman Eric Hosmer has been placed on family medical leave.

MOSCOW (AP) — Russia is hoping to recruit former world champion track cyclist Shane Perkins of Australia in a push for medals at the 2020 Olympics.
Perkins says in a Facebook statement that he "will now be riding for Russia," alongside a picture of himself in Russian team gear.
He adds that the "Russian Cycling Federation has given me another opportunity to chase my dreams of Olympic representation in Tokyo 2020."
However, Russia says the switch isn't yet complete.
Perkins, who won a world title in the keirin event in 2011, has faced challenges in recent years due to changes in Australian cycling programs.
The opportunity to compete for Russia comes after Perkins obtained Russian citizenship through his grandparents, allowing him to potentially represent the country in international competitions.
The Russian Cycling Federation has expressed optimism about Perkins' potential addition to their team, citing his experience and past achievements as valuable assets.
Perkins' decision has sparked discussions about athlete nationality switches and the impact on sporting competitions.
While the process of transitioning to represent Russia is ongoing, both Perkins and Russian officials are hopeful for a successful partnership leading up to the Olympics.
Australia’s prime minister says the country will scrap a temporary visa for skilled foreign workers, arguing that Australians must be given priority for Australian jobs.
The 457 visa allows foreigners to live and work in Australia for up to four years.
The decision to abolish the visa aims to address concerns about the displacement of Australian workers and ensure that job opportunities are first and foremost for locals.

The move has sparked mixed reactions, with some applauding the decision as a step towards protecting Australian jobs, while others express concerns about the potential impact on industries reliant on skilled foreign workers.
The government has announced plans to replace the 457 visa with a new program that will prioritize Australian workers and address genuine skill shortages.
Stay tuned for further developments on this significant policy change.

SAUGATUCK, Mich. (AP) — Michael Ryder had been approved for $360 every week in Michigan unemployment benefits — until the state learned he'd been dogging it at the Detroit-area restaurant chain where he supposedly worked.
The surprising twist unfolded when Michael's owner, attorney Michael Haddock, received a letter addressed to Michael Ryder from Michigan's Unemployment Insurance Agency.
The letter granted the dog unemployment benefits, citing that Michael Ryder had been declared eligible to receive $360 a week.
Amused and bewildered by the mix-up, Haddock shared the letter on social media, sparking a wave of reactions and inquiries.
It turned out that Michael Ryder, the supposed employee, was actually Haddock's dog, a border collie.
The confusion stemmed from a clerical error that linked the dog's name to a former employee's social security number.
Despite the humorous turn of events, the incident highlighted the importance of accurate record-keeping and verification processes within government agencies.
As for Michael Ryder, the border collie will not be cashing in on any unemployment benefits, but he has certainly earned his place in the spotlight with this unexpected tale.

The duo's chemistry was palpable as they effortlessly weaved through the intricate melodies and infectious rhythms of the song.

His heartfelt lyrics and emotive delivery drew the audience in, creating a powerful connection between artist and listener.
The performance culminated in a poignant moment of realization, as .Paak's character came to terms with the consequences of his actions.
The bittersweet ending left a lasting impression on viewers, showcasing the duo's ability to blend personal storytelling with infectious grooves.
The set told the story of a man (.Paak) working to earn back trust from the ladies in his life after an act of infidelity.
By the end of “What More Can I Say,” the two women have moved on with Knxwledge, giving the love parable a bittersweet twist.

and blends whimsical symphonic elements with personal storytelling.

The Northern Ireland Renewables Industry Group (NIRIG) will today publish a strategy to decarbonise the country's energy sector by 2050, while promoting economic development and keeping costs low for consumers.
This ambitious plan aims to transform Northern Ireland's energy landscape by shifting towards renewable sources such as wind, solar, and biomass.
By reducing reliance on fossil fuels, NIRIG envisions a cleaner, more sustainable future that will benefit both the environment and the economy.
The strategy outlines key steps to achieve this goal, including increasing investment in renewable infrastructure, improving energy efficiency, and fostering innovation in clean technologies.
By embracing decarbonisation, Northern Ireland can create new job opportunities, attract investment, and lead the way in the transition to a low-carbon economy.
NIRIG chair Rachel Anderson said: “There’s an urgent need to plan for the post-2020 world in which clean energy will be an engine for economic growth.
“A more diverse, flexible energy mix will increase energy security, as well as generating cheap power for consumers.
This brings enormous economic opportunities to Northern Ireland by attracting regional investment, promoting innovation and developing skills.” Image: Pixabay
In a strategic move to expand its influence in the music industry, Apple Music has recently established its own publishing division, a decision seen as a direct challenge to its rival, Spotify.
By venturing into the realm of music publishing, Apple Music aims to enhance its position in the highly competitive music streaming market.
This bold step signifies Apple's determination to strengthen its foothold in the industry and further differentiate itself from other streaming platforms.
The establishment of a publishing division opens up a plethora of opportunities for Apple Music.
It could enable the company to secure more favorable music licensing agreements, thereby enriching its music library and attracting a larger audience.
Furthermore, it may pave the way for Apple Music to engage in artist signings and development deals independently.
As Rolling Stone notes, a publishing division could help the company make better music licensing deals, or it could just start signing artists -- and offering them development deals -- on its own.
Either way, Apple's new focus on the publishing side of things is a clear sign of how the company wants to continue influencing the music world.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla. — Zach Johnson and Brandon Goodwin combined for 49 points and Florida Golf Coast pulled away from Jacksonville State for an 80-55 win on Saturday night, running the Eagles’ winning streak to 11, their longest at the Division I level.
Johnson had 25 points, Goodwin 24 and Dinero Mercurius 11 as FGCU (18-8, 9-0 Atlantic Sun) picked up its 100th conference win since moving up from D-II in 2008.
Twice the Eagles won 14 in a row, the last time 11 years ago.
The Eagles dominated both ends of the court, shooting 50 percent from the field while holding Jacksonville State to just 35 percent shooting.
FGCU's defense forced 18 turnovers, converting them into 24 points.
Their depth and balanced scoring attack overwhelmed the opposition, with the bench contributing 18 crucial points.
With this victory, FGCU now firmly controls the Atlantic Sun Conference standings.
The Eagles won 68-62 at home a week earlier and are now up three games plus the tiebreaker with five games remaining in the regular season.
Plans for the next phase of the Longbridge regeneration project have been unveiled, showcasing an exciting new development set to transform the area.
The latest application, submitted by developer St Modwen, outlines ambitious proposals for a mixed-use development that promises to breathe new life into Longbridge.
This latest application follows on from news earlier this month that St Modwen had abandoned plans to open a new cinema in Longbridge.
The Birmingham-based developer won planning permission last year to build a new nine-screen cinema for chain The Light, six restaurant units and a fitness centre for budget operator The Gym.
The new proposal envisions a vibrant mix of residential, commercial, and leisure spaces, including modern apartments, retail units, and green public spaces.
The development aims to create a thriving community hub that caters to the needs of residents and visitors alike.
The regeneration project is part of a long-term vision to revitalize Longbridge and create a dynamic urban center that offers a high quality of life for its residents.
By combining modern design with sustainable practices, the development seeks to set a new standard for urban living in Birmingham.
Local residents and businesses have welcomed the plans, expressing excitement about the potential economic and social benefits that the regeneration project will bring to the area.
With construction set to begin in the coming months, Longbridge is on track to undergo a remarkable transformation that will shape its future for years to come.
Fresno State's forward Grimes delivered an outstanding performance, leading his team to a decisive victory over Wyoming.
Grimes showcased his versatility by contributing 20 points and grabbing 12 rebounds, playing a pivotal role in Fresno State's commanding win.
The victory marked a significant turnaround for Fresno State after their previous defeat against Wyoming last season.
The last time these teams met was last season when Wyoming took a 102-100 victory in four overtimes.
Wyoming had won four straight Mountain West games, including a 104-103 double overtime win over then No.

The team's cohesive play and determination were evident throughout the matchup, allowing them to secure a convincing win over Wyoming.

Grimes' impressive performance and the team's overall strong showing highlight Fresno State's potential for success in the competitive Mountain West conference.
As the season progresses, Fresno State will look to build on this victory and continue their winning momentum.
A woman in Florida was left shocked and bewildered after what was supposed to be a simple delivery of a yoga mat turned into a major drug bust.
Instead of receiving her expected fitness accessory, the woman, who remains unnamed, found herself in possession of a package containing a staggering $400,000 worth of illegal drugs.
The incident unfolded when the woman placed an order for a yoga mat online.
However, when the package arrived at her doorstep, she discovered a large quantity of oxycodone-type pills concealed inside.
Concerned and confused, she immediately contacted the authorities to report the unexpected and illegal contents of the delivery.
Law enforcement officials in Florida were quick to respond to the woman's call for help.

Commander Todd Brown of the Jacksonville Sheriff's Office revealed that the drug dealers responsible for the shipment likely intended to intercept the package before it reached its intended destination.
Brown explained that drug dealers often attempt to intercept shipments in various ways to avoid detection.

Brown said that the perfect place for drug pickups are, “vacant apartments [and] homes where people have gone to work for the day.” The drugs were actually sent to the woman’s old house, which is still vacant, but because the address was misspelled the package was re-routed using her name.
“The dealers weren’t as intelligent as they thought they were,” Commander Brown added.
Authorities say each oxycodone-type pill had a street value of about $20, making the total drug bust worth as much as $400,000.
Police are reportedly working to trace the botched delivery back to the person in California who sent it.
Liverpool manager Jurgen Klopp has taken a surprising step back in the ongoing saga surrounding Philippe Coutinho's future at Anfield.
Klopp, who had vehemently maintained Coutinho was not for sale, seems to have shifted his stance following recent developments.
Reports had initially suggested that Klopp's reluctance was the primary obstacle in negotiations with Barcelona, who are keen on acquiring the Brazilian playmaker.
However, revelations from Coutinho's family indicating underlying issues between the player and Klopp, coupled with Coutinho's formal transfer request, have seemingly swayed the manager's position.
In a post-match press conference after the draw with Watford, Klopp announced that the decision regarding Coutinho's future now rests with the club's board.

The Reds boss has been vociferous in his claims that the Brazil international is not for sale, while reports suggested the German was the biggest stumbling block in negotiations between Liverpool and Coutinho’s suitors Barcelona.
But after Coutinho’s family briefed that there are long-standing problems between the attacking midfielder and Klopp, and the player submitted a transfer request, there was a distinct change of tone.
Klopp told his press conference after the draw with Watford that the board will decide on Coutinho’s future.
Las Vegas Metropolitan Police Department has identified the officer involved in the shooting incident that left a woman wounded.
The officer, identified as 23-year-old Ondre Wills, has been with Metro since May 2016.
The incident occurred when officers responded to a call about a woman acting erratically in the northeast valley.
According to the police, the woman was reportedly armed with a knife and refused to comply with the officers' commands.
Despite attempts to de-escalate the situation, the woman continued to advance towards the officers in a threatening manner.
An officer fired his weapon and struck the woman, according to police.
Police named the officer involved as 23-year-old Ondre Wills, employed by Metro since May 2016.
He has been placed on routine paid administrative leave pending the outcome of a review of this incident, according to a release.
She was transported to Sunrise Hospital with at least one gunshot wound.
She was in serious but critical condition.
No one else was injured, Kisfalvi said.
The name of the woman will be released at a future date.

The digs that Hollywood superstar Marilyn Monroe briefly called home during her short-lived marriage to New York Yankees legend Joe DiMaggio in 1954 has been transformed into a $1,200-a-night hotel room at the Lexington Hotel.
It’s now known as the Norma Jeane Suite, after Monroe’s given name.
The suite has been meticulously redesigned to evoke the glamour and elegance of the 1950s, paying homage to the iconic couple's love story.
Guests who stay in the Norma Jeane Suite will be transported back in time to experience a taste of old Hollywood charm and luxury.
The renovation of this historic love nest has garnered significant attention from fans of Marilyn Monroe and Joe DiMaggio, as well as those with a fascination for vintage Hollywood.
The suite features memorabilia and photographs from the couple's time together, adding a personal touch to the space.
Visitors can now immerse themselves in the romance and nostalgia of Marilyn Monroe and Joe DiMaggio's relationship by booking a stay in the Norma Jeane Suite.
It serves as a beautiful tribute to the enduring legacy of these two legendary figures in American pop culture.

MEXICO CITY (AP) — The United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights has called for Mexico to take urgent action in the northern border city of Nuevo Laredo, where at least 23 people have disappeared since the start of February.
The UN expressed deep concern over the escalating cases of disappearances in the city, highlighting the need for immediate investigations and measures to ensure the safety of the residents.
Local authorities have been urged to step up efforts to address the situation and bring those responsible to justice.
The disappearances have sparked fear and outrage among the community, with many demanding answers and concrete actions to prevent further incidents.
Human rights organizations are closely monitoring the developments in Nuevo Laredo and are calling for a comprehensive response to tackle the root causes of these disappearances.
The UN has offered its support to assist in the investigations and protection of the affected individuals and their families.
PARRY SOUND - An e-biker driver faces alcohol-related charges after local police noticed a bike swerve across the road.
On May 27 at approximately 10 p.m., a member of the West Parry Sound Detachment of the Ontario Provincial Police was on patrol on Bowes Street.
The officer observed an e-bike swerving across the centre line and almost hitting the curb.
The officer conducted a traffic stop and spoke with the driver.
Upon further investigation, the driver displayed signs of impairment and failed a roadside breathalyzer test.
The e-biker was subsequently arrested and charged with impaired driving and driving with a blood alcohol concentration above the legal limit.
The driver's e-bike was impounded, and their driver's license was suspended.
The individual is scheduled to appear in court to face the charges.
Authorities remind the public of the dangers of impaired driving, regardless of the vehicle being operated.
In a shocking twist of fate, the alternative ending of the popular soap opera EastEnders has left fans reeling.
In this unexpected turn of events, Ronnie Mitchell manages to survive while her sister Roxy tragically meets her demise.
The emotional rollercoaster of this new ending has left viewers stunned and divided in their reactions.
Ronnie, played by Samantha Womack, has been a central character in EastEnders for years, with her tumultuous relationship with Roxy, portrayed by Rita Simons, captivating audiences.

Better than the swimming pool tragedy?
Or not as dramatic?
