WASHINGTON — A federal judge is warning President Donald Trump’s former campaign chairman that he shouldn’t be trying his case in the press.
That includes drafting opinion essays published in other countries.
Judge Amy Berman Jackson issued the warning to Paul Manafort after he wrote an op-ed in a Ukrainian newspaper defending his work in Ukraine.
Manafort faces charges of money laundering and acting as an unregistered foreign agent.
The judge emphasized that Manafort’s actions could potentially influence jurors or witnesses.
Manafort's attorney argued that the op-ed was a legitimate effort to defend his client and was not meant to sway public opinion.
However, Judge Jackson has made it clear that any further attempts by Manafort to publicly discuss the case could result in a gag order to protect the integrity of the trial.
The Warren County Sheriff's Office is searching for three missing foster children.
Through investigations, police determined that Amber Smith, 17, Jasmine Davis, 15, and Jasmine's baby Mya Davis, 1, ran away from their Bowling Green home at 212 Countrywood Place on foot.
Police believe an unknown subject with a vehicle aided in the trio's escape.
All three juveniles are registered as missing persons.
Authorities are urging anyone with information about the whereabouts of Amber, Jasmine, and baby Mya to come forward.
The foster children were last seen wearing casual clothing and may be in need of medical attention.
The community is asked to remain vigilant and report any sightings or information that could assist in locating the missing juveniles.
The Warren County Sheriff's Office is actively coordinating search efforts with neighboring law enforcement agencies to ensure a swift and safe return of the missing foster children.
Recent studies have shed light on a concerning trend: black boys are experiencing a significant drop in income levels as they transition into adulthood.
This revelation underscores the deep-rooted challenges faced by this demographic group in achieving economic success and upward mobility.
The data paints a stark picture of the obstacles that black boys encounter on their path to financial stability and prosperity.
The disparities in income levels between black boys and their white counterparts are striking, with the former facing greater difficulty in breaking free from low-income brackets.
Factors such as systemic racism, limited access to quality education, and economic opportunities contribute to the persistent income gap observed in these findings.
As a result, the prospects for black boys to improve their economic standing and secure a better future are hindered by structural barriers that continue to perpetuate inequality.
The shift from low income to higher levels also appears to be a greater challenge, which makes closing the gap that much harder.
Emily Badger, Claire Cain Miller, Adam Pearce, and Kevin Quealy for The Upshot cover the data extensively with a series of charts, driven visually with a particle-based Sankey diagram (above).
The individual points provide a vehicle to show variation over aggregates.
Take your time with this one.
You can grab the aggregated data from the Equality of Opportunity Project.
Here’s the research paper in full (pdf) if you’re interested.
And if you’re interested in the Sankey implementation.
In the upcoming second series of the hit show "Flowers," Olivia Colman is back in the spotlight, showcasing her talent once again as she adorns an array of eye-catching and quirky outfits.
The award-winning actress is seen frocked-up in a variety of eccentric costumes, adding to the show's unique and visually captivating aesthetic.

While Olivia Colman's character, Deborah, is known for her distinct sense of style, it's their daughter Amy, played by Sophia Di Martino, who takes center stage in the costumery department this time around.
Amy stumbles upon a mysterious book titled Baumgaertner among her grandfather's belongings, filled with enigmatic Baroque-style paintings that appear to narrate a compelling tale.
As Amy delves deeper into the book's contents, she embarks on a creative journey, attempting to translate the images into music.
This endeavor leads her down a path of self-discovery and surreal experiences, blurring the lines between reality and imagination.
But it’s their daughter Amy (Sophia Di Martino) who’s responsible for the costumery.
She finds a book among her grandad’s belongings called Baumgaertner, which is full of strange Baroque-style paintings that seem to tell a story.

“She tries to set these images to music and her increasingly fizzy state of mind becomes a sort of portal into the world of Baumgaertner,” explains scriptwriter Will Sharpe, who’s also returning to the fray as Shun, the family’s Japanese lodger and illustrator of Maurice’s books.

VENTURA, Calif. — A California police chief says his department will review its procedures after a restaurant patron with his young daughter on his lap was fatally stabbed inside a crowded steakhouse by a homeless man.
Ventura Chief Ken Corney told the Los Angeles Times that officers should have responded in person to initial reports about the suspect rather than simply monitoring his actions via security cameras.
Corney's statement comes in the wake of a tragic incident that shook the community.
Prosecutors say 49-year-old Jamal Jackson walked up to Anthony Mele’s table on April 18 and stabbed him in the neck.
The 35-year-old died at a hospital.
Jackson is charged with murder.
He had been reported earlier for disruptive behaviour, but police had determined he was not a threat.
Jackson has not entered a plea and is due in court this week.

WASHINGTON (AP) — Sales of new U.S. homes jumped 4 percent in March, propelled by a surge of buying in the West.
The Commerce Department says sales last month were at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 694,000.
The two prior months had their sales revised upward with the annual rate being 667,000 in February and 644,000 in January.
The increase in new-home sales in March reflects growing confidence among consumers and a strong job market.
The Western region saw the most significant growth, with buyers taking advantage of favorable market conditions and low mortgage rates.
However, new-home purchases rose slightly in the South, fell in the Midwest, and plunged in the Northeast, indicating regional variations in the housing market.
Despite the surge in sales, the median sales price of a new home rose 4.8 percent from a year ago to $337,200, reflecting the overall strength and stability of the housing market.
New-home purchases rose slightly in the South, fell in the Midwest and plunged in the Northeast.

Gee started working on the LEX over a year ago, using the shutter mechanism from a Sony A7.
Since then, he's done a lot of prototyping, electronics work, design and 3D printing to create the mockup you see above (and prototype below), detailing his development on the LEX website.

"After doing some research it became obvious the 18mm flange focal distance which makes E-Mount amazing for building compact cameras like the Sony A6500 was going to rule out adapting any existing film body I could find," Gee told Sony Alpha Rumors.
"The easiest approach was to start at the beginning and make a whole system from scratch."
He now has a working prototype that looks rougher than the mockup, but it does work, as Gee has used it to take some sample photos, as shown in a gallery here.
The camera is a unique blend of modern digital technology with the classic charm of film photography, offering a hands-on experience that many enthusiasts crave.
Gee's creation marks a significant milestone in the world of photography, as it demonstrates the ingenuity and passion of hobbyists in pushing the boundaries of what is possible.
The Sony E-Mount film camera opens up new creative possibilities for photographers who appreciate the aesthetics and process of shooting film.
Gee's dedication and innovation have truly paid off in bringing this project to life.
Actress Vanessa Kirby will join the cast of the Fast and Furious spinoff along with actor Jason Statham and Dwayne ‘The Rock’ Johnson.
Kirby, known for her roles in "The Crown" and "Mission: Impossible - Fallout," is set to bring her talent to the high-octane world of the Fast and Furious franchise.
Kirby’s addition to the spinoff has generated buzz among fans, who are eager to see how she will fit into the adrenaline-fueled action-packed universe.
The film is expected to feature intense car chases, explosive stunts, and gripping drama, keeping audiences on the edge of their seats.
With Kirby’s versatile acting skills and experience in both drama and action films, her presence in the Fast and Furious spinoff promises to bring a new dynamic to the already popular franchise.
Fans can anticipate an electrifying performance from Kirby as she joins forces with Statham and Johnson in this highly anticipated film.
GOP Representative Trey Gowdy, the former chair of the Benghazi panel, has announced his decision to retire from Congress.
Gowdy, known for his role in investigating the 2012 attack on the U.S. diplomatic compound in Libya, cited his desire to return to the justice system as a prosecutor.
During his time in Congress, Gowdy gained prominence for his tough questioning of witnesses and his commitment to upholding conservative principles.
Gowdy's departure marks the end of an era for the Republican Party, as he was seen as a key figure in the party's efforts to hold the Obama administration accountable.
His leadership of the Benghazi panel was instrumental in uncovering crucial information about the attack and its aftermath.

The Benghazi panel revealed the existence of former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton's private email server and controversies involving it proved to be damaging to her failed 2016 presidential campaign.
Gowdy was elected in the 2010 tea party wave that returned control of the House to Republicans.
More vehicles have been seized and warnings issued to riders as a Nottinghamshire Police operation continues to crack down on the illegal and anti-social use of off-road motorbikes and quad bikes.
Operation Incalculability is part of the force's drive to tackle the inconsiderate and dangerous use of such vehicles.

Nottinghamshire Police’s Off Road Motorcycle Team, supported by uniformed officers, have been carrying out patrols in the Ashfield area, stopping and checking vehicles and identifying any offences requiring action.
On Sunday August 13 the operation targeted locations including the Annesley Woods area where officers issued two Section 59 warnings.
During the operation, police seized bikes and two cars that were believed to be involved in illegal off-roading activities.
The crackdown is a response to numerous reports of disturbances and safety concerns caused by off-road vehicles in the area.
The police are emphasizing the importance of responsible and lawful use of vehicles to ensure the safety of both riders and the community.

Inspector Craig Berry from Nottinghamshire Police’s Off Road Motorcycle Team stated, "We will continue to take action against those individuals who choose to use off-road bikes illegally and anti-socially."
The operation aims to deter illegal off-roading and promote safe and considerate behavior among riders.
Residents are encouraged to report any instances of illegal off-road biking to assist the police in their efforts to maintain law and order in the community.

The Illinois man who shot a Republican congressman and several other people Wednesday while they practiced baseball outside the nation's capital had a number of run-ins with police in recent years, including arrests for battery, resisting arrest and drunken driving.
The suspect, identified as James T. Hodgkinson, was a 66-year-old home inspector from Belleville, Illinois.
Reports indicate that Hodgkinson was a vocal critic of President Trump and Republican policies, with a history of expressing his political views on social media.
Court records show that his legal trouble started in the 1990s.
His most serious problems apparently came in 2006, when he was arrested on the battery charge.
Records indicate he has not been involved in any legal cases since 2011.

Hodgkinson's Facebook page indicates that, until recently, he ran a home-inspection business out of his home in Belleville, in the southwestern corner of the state, across the Mississippi River from St. Louis.
SAN LUIS OBISPO, Calif. — Donovan Fields scored 13 of his 15 points in the second half to help Cal Poly beat Hawaii 78-64 on Saturday night.
Cal Poly (8-15, 3-6 Big West Conference) has won two straight since snapping a six-game skid.
In a thrilling matchup, Cal Poly showcased a remarkable comeback in the second half.
Luke Meikle, Jakub Niziol and Victor Joseph each scored 12 points for the Mustangs.
Sheriff Drammeh scored 17 points to lead Hawaii.
The Rainbow Warriors had a seven-point advantage at the break, but the Mustangs opened the second half with a 16-2 run and led 44-37.
Hawaii had its last lead, 54-53 with 9:12 left.
A 13-0 run gave Cal Poly a 64-54 lead with 5:32 remaining and the Mustangs cruised from there.
Meikle scored four points, Niziol made consecutive 3-pointers and Fields capped the surge with a 3-point play.
Love might trump all, but definitely not cash.
A new survey from Money and SurveyMonkey revealed that more than half of its participants would rather choose a million per year for their rest of their lives over finding true love.
The study delved into the priorities of individuals when it comes to love and money, showing a surprising preference for financial security over romantic relationships.

53% of married participants and 55% of those in domestic partnerships would rather have love however, although nearly every other demographic chose the cash, especially those who were divorced or separated.

Saxophonist and composer Kamasi Washington has released a new single titled "Street Fighter Mas," and it's a musical journey filled with energy and creativity.
Known for his innovative approach to jazz, Washington infuses this track with a blend of traditional jazz elements and modern influences, creating a sound that is uniquely his own.
"Street Fighter Mas" is a dynamic and vibrant composition that showcases Washington's impressive saxophone skills and his ability to craft intricate melodies.
The track is both intricate and accessible, with a driving rhythm and infectious groove that will have listeners tapping their feet in no time.
The title of the song is a nod to Washington's love for video games, particularly the iconic Street Fighter series.
The track exudes a sense of determination and resilience, much like the characters in the game, as it builds to a powerful climax that is both exhilarating and inspiring.
“When I was young, I was obsessed with Street Fighter!” Washington said on Twitter about the song.
“I thought I would be a professional gamer, so I made a theme song.” The new record certainly has that layer of triumph and potency to make for inspirational theme music.
The new single is the latest from Washington’s upcoming two-and-a-half-hour epic double-album, Heaven and Earth, which will be out on June 22nd.
The album also features the previously released “Fists of Fury” and “The Space Traveler’s Lullaby.” Listen to the new track below.

Those of you keen to welcome Britain’s new 65,000-tonne aircraft carrier into Portsmouth Harbour this week can now set your alarm clocks.
HMS Queen Elizabeth was expected to arrive on Friday 18th August, but the Royal Navy have now confirmed she will make her way through the Solent on Wednesday at approximately 0710.
The early arrival of the HMS Queen Elizabeth has sparked excitement among naval enthusiasts and the local community alike.
The aircraft carrier's earlier than expected arrival is seen as a testament to the efficiency and readiness of the Royal Navy.
Crowds are expected to gather along the shores of Portsmouth Harbour to catch a glimpse of this impressive vessel as it navigates its way into port.
The HMS Queen Elizabeth, the largest and most advanced warship ever built in the UK, will be a sight to behold as she sails into her home port.
The ship's arrival marks a significant milestone for the Royal Navy and the UK's defense capabilities.

In a surprising turn of events, the latest employment report has revealed a significant setback in the US job market, with a loss of 33,000 jobs following the devastating impact of hurricanes in Texas and Florida.
The unexpected decline comes as a blow to the economy, reflecting the disruptive aftermath of the natural disasters that wreaked havoc on these states.
One of the hardest-hit sectors was the hospitality industry, with a notable drop in employment numbers.
Last month’s drop was driven by huge losses in a restaurants and bars, which shed 105,000 jobs, a sign of the damage to Florida’s tourism industry.
Authorities say an armed man who ran from security at a hotel in downtown San Antonio and tried to force his way into a room has been shot and killed by officers who confronted him.
The incident unfolded when the man, identified as not being a hotel guest, attempted to enter a room on the upper floors of the hotel.
Police Chief William McManus reported that the man, appearing to be a laborer based on his attire, was confronted by two officers on the seventh floor.
The encounter quickly escalated, leading to the fatal shots being fired by the officers.
The motive behind the shooting remains unclear as investigations are ongoing.
The tense situation prompted a significant police presence downtown, resulting in road closures as authorities worked to secure the area.
McManus says he fled to upper floors, attempted to enter one room and was confronted by two officers on the seventh floor.
The situation escalated and the officers fired, killing the unidentified suspect.
It's not clear what prompted police to shoot.
McManus says the suspect was not a hotel guest and appeared to be a laborer based on the clothes he was wearing.
The incident drew a heavy police presence downtown, with some blocks closed to traffic.

The warm weather has sparked a surge in the number of migrants attempting the perilous journey across the Mediterranean Sea from Libya.
The latest reports indicate that over Easter weekend, rescue ships have been working tirelessly to save lives amidst the exodus.
More than 8,360 individuals have been rescued from 55 different rubber dinghies and wooden boats off the coast of Libya.
Tragically, thirteen bodies were also recovered during these operations.

While the high number of rescues is not uncommon, the timing is significant as Italy prepares to deliver patrol boats to Libya in the coming weeks as part of a new migration deal sanctioned by the European Union.
This agreement aims to enhance border security and stem the flow of migrants attempting the dangerous sea crossing.

According to a spokesman from the International Organization for Migration, smugglers are exploiting the situation, urging migrants to leave immediately to avoid interception by the Libyan coast guard and subsequent deportation back to their country of origin.
This sense of urgency is driving many to take the risk despite the dangers involved in such journeys.
In a separate development, German authorities have reported a concerning trend of violent offenses against homes for asylum-seekers.
The Federal Criminal Police Office disclosed that there were 169 violent incidents targeting asylum shelters in 2016, nearly matching the figures from the previous year.
Most of these acts were found to have far-right motives, reflecting a worrying trend of xenophobia and violence against vulnerable populations.
Over Easter weekend, rescue ships plucked some 8,360 people from 55 different rubber dinghies and wooden boats off Libya's coast.
Thirteen bodies were also recovered.
While such numbers are not unusual, they come as Italy is due to deliver patrol boats to Libya in coming weeks as part of a new EU-blessed migration deal.

An International Organization of Migration spokesman says smugglers are telling customers: "You have to hurry up and leave the country right now because otherwise in a couple of months you will be rescued by the Libyan coast guard and you will be sent back."
——— 12:30 p.m. German authorities say there were 169 violent offenses against homes for asylum-seekers last year, almost as many as in 2015, though the figures sank as the year progressed.
The Federal Criminal Police Office said Tuesday that the number of violent offenses compared with 177 the previous years.
In all, authorities counted 994 offenses against asylum shelters in 2016, a little below the previous year's 1,031.
The police office said that most of them had a far-right motive.
Justice Minister Heiko Maas wrote on Twitter that the figures were "deeply shameful."
Germany saw a huge influx of asylum-seekers and other migrants in late 2015 and early 2016.
That tailed off about a year ago, and the number of crimes targeting asylum homes declined over the course of the year.
LONDON (AP) — A member of Britain's House of Lords has drawn praise and puzzlement for resigning as a government minister because he was late to answer a question.
Lord Bates, the international development minister, shocked his colleagues by taking the unusual step of resigning after arriving late to respond to a question from Labour peer Ruth Lister.
Bates, known for his dedication to public service, expressed deep regret for his tardiness, stating that he was "thoroughly ashamed" and felt compelled to offer his resignation.
The unexpected move left fellow members of the House of Lords in disbelief as Bates announced his decision and promptly left the chamber.
Former Foreign Secretary William Hague, a colleague of Bates in the upper chamber, expressed hope that Bates would reconsider his resignation.
Hague praised Bates for his two decades of strong public service and highlighted his previous charitable endeavors, including a remarkable 2,000-mile trek across South America in 2016.
Bates said Wednesday he was "thoroughly ashamed" and "shall be offering my resignation."
With that, he walked out of the Lords chamber to the astonishment of other members.
Former Foreign Secretary William Hague, who now sits in Parliament's upper chamber, said he hoped "my noble friend, who has given 20 years of strong public service" would reconsider.
Bates quit a previous government position in 2016 to walk 2,000 miles (3,200 kilometers) across South America for charity.
After predicting an early spring on Groundhog Day, chaos ensued when the famous groundhog attempted to make a daring escape.
The furry creature, known as Punxsutawney Phil, startled everyone as he sprinted away from his handlers and into the crowd.
The journalist immediately rushed to catch the critter, when he was bitten by the holiday mascot after grabbing him by the back.
Thankfully both Brett and the groundhog are ok, but it serves as a great reminder to everyone — don’t go grabbing random woodland creatures.
The incident caused a stir among the spectators who were witnessing the annual tradition in Pennsylvania.
Despite the unexpected turn of events, Punxsutawney Phil was eventually safely returned to his enclosure.
The bite serves as a humorous yet cautionary tale of the unpredictability of nature and the importance of respecting wildlife boundaries during such events.
Just a Line, the delightful augmented reality doodling app, is set to receive a groundbreaking update that will transform it into the world's first cross-platform collaborative AR application.

The app, which allows users to draw in the air and view their creations through their devices, is introducing a feature that enables two users to share a doodling space across different devices, regardless of whether they are using an Android phone or an iPhone.
This innovative update was recently teased at Google I/O and is made possible on Android devices by ARCore v1.2 and Google's Cloud Anchors technology.
The synchronized drawings from both devices are stored and accessed from a shared Firebase Realtime Database, ensuring that both users can view and interact with the same AR image simultaneously.
The prospect of sharing AR experiences, particularly more complex ones, opens up a world of possibilities for collaborative creativity and fun.
The updated version of Just a Line is now available for download from APK Mirror and is compatible with any ARCore-enabled device.
The neat (if frivolous) app lets you draw shapes in the air that realistically float in place as you move around them, looking through your phone's display.
Now, two users are able to share one doodling space across separate devices — even if one is an Android phone and the other is an iPhone.
The update was teased at Google I/O this year and made possible on Android by ARCore v1.2, along with what Google calls Cloud Anchors.
The drawings from both devices are continuously synced to and accessed from a shared Firebase Realtime Database, allowing the same interactive image to be viewed across screens.
Apparently, this makes Just a Line the world's first cross-platform collaborative augmented reality app — which, considering what a nascent and specific niche that is, is certainly believable.
Sharing AR experiences, especially more complex ones, seems like it could be a lot of fun.
You can snag the newest version of Just a Line from APK Mirror; it'll work on any ARCore-enabled device.
In an exciting announcement, a Connecticut zoo has shared the joyous news of the birth of rare tiger cubs.
The zoo welcomed the arrival of four Amur tiger cubs, a momentous occasion that has captured the hearts of visitors and staff alike.
The proud mother, a critically endangered Amur tiger, has been caring for her newborns under the watchful eyes of the zoo's dedicated team.
The birth of these tiger cubs is a significant milestone in conservation efforts to protect this magnificent species.
Amur tigers, also known as Siberian tigers, are facing threats in the wild, making the arrival of these cubs even more special.
The zoo is taking every precaution to ensure the health and well-being of the newborns as they continue to grow and thrive.
The 2-week-old cubs are in seclusion in the zoo hospital.
Staff is hand-feeding the cubs five times a day.
The zoo says one of the four kittens had been found unresponsive after birth and a second kitten died later that night.
Director Gregg Dancho says every possible effort was being made to help the kittens survive.
The zoo says Amur tigers, also known as Siberian tigers, are very rare.

NEW YORK (AP) — A retired New York City school librarian has been sentenced to 15 years in prison for scheming to carry out gruesome fantasies of kidnapping, torturing and killing women and girls.
Robert Christopher Asch was sentenced Monday in Manhattan federal court.
The 65-year-old Manhattan resident was convicted in March 2014 along with a New Jersey auto mechanic.
Asch's sentencing comes after a chilling plot was uncovered where he and his accomplice, Richard Meltz, planned to abduct, torture, and murder women and children.
The court heard how Asch engaged in detailed discussions about the abductions and killings, even going as far as scouting potential victims.
The prosecution presented evidence of Asch's active participation in planning these heinous acts, which shocked the community and raised concerns about the safety of women and children in the area.
The judge's decision to hand down a 15-year sentence reflects the severity of Asch's crimes and sends a strong message about the consequences of such sinister intentions.
ALLIANCE, Ohio (AP) — A truck crash in Ohio has left hundreds of chickens dead, and those that did survive huddled together in a nearby ditch.
The accident occurred early this morning when a tractor-trailer carrying the chickens overturned on a sharp curve along Highway 33.
The driver, who sustained minor injuries, reported losing control of the vehicle due to a sudden mechanical failure.
Local authorities and animal rescue teams rushed to the scene to assess the situation and provide aid.
The surviving chickens, visibly distressed and disoriented, were carefully rescued and transported to a nearby shelter for medical treatment and care.
The heartbreaking scene of the overturned trailer and scattered poultry has shocked the community, prompting calls for improved safety measures for transporting livestock on the highways.
Investigations are ongoing to determine the exact cause of the crash and prevent similar incidents in the future.

The community deserves a representative with a genuine commitment to improving infrastructure, not someone looking to clean up their own mess.

Voters must carefully consider whether he is truly the right choice to address the pressing road maintenance challenges facing Gympie.

Soda Butte Creek, a vital waterway in the northeastern corner of Yellowstone National Park, is on track to be removed from the list of impaired rivers.

The Montana Department of Environmental Quality has confirmed that the creek now meets quality standards for heavy metals, marking a significant improvement attributed to abandoned mine cleanups initiated in the 1990s.
Officials from the department have shared that they have received preliminary approval from the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) to delist Soda Butte Creek in 2018.
This achievement underscores the success of ongoing efforts to restore the health of the waterway.
Autumn Coleman, the abandoned mine lands program manager, expressed that this milestone signifies a notable first in the state of Montana as a stream being de-listed due to mine cleanup activities.
The creek, which meanders past the town of Cooke City before joining the Lamar River within Yellowstone National Park, plays a crucial role in the local ecosystem.
This positive development is a testament to the collaborative efforts aimed at safeguarding the environment and ensuring the preservation of natural resources for future generations.
— A creek that flows into the northeastern corner of Yellowstone National Park is set to be removed from a list of impaired waterways next year.

The Bozeman Daily Chronicle reported Sunday that officials with the Montana Department of Environmental Quality say that Soda Butte Creek now meets quality standards for heavy metals thanks to abandoned mine cleanups that started in the 1990s.
The department has received preliminary approval from the EPA to remove the creek from the list in 2018.
The department’s abandoned mine lands program manager, Autumn Coleman, says it will be the first time a stream will be de-listed in the state as the result of a mine cleanup.
The creek flows past the town of Cooke City before entering Yellowstone, where it feeds into the Lamar River.
—— Information from: Bozeman Daily Chronicle, http://www.bozemandailychronicle.com

LOUISVILLE, KY (WAVE) - A Golden Alert has been issued for a missing man in Louisville.
Charles Morris, 68, has dementia.
Authorities are seeking the public's help in locating him.
Morris was last seen on Monday morning in the downtown area.
He is described as being 5 feet 10 inches tall, weighing 160 pounds, with gray hair and brown eyes.
He was last seen wearing a blue jacket, khaki pants, and black shoes.
Family members are concerned for Morris's well-being due to his dementia, which may cause confusion and disorientation.
Anyone with information on his whereabouts is urged to contact the Louisville Metro Police Department immediately.
The community is asked to be on the lookout for Morris and to report any sightings to the authorities promptly.
Time is of the essence in locating him and ensuring his safe return home.
Pixel art RPG 'Songbringer' is set to make its debut on the PlayStation 4 on September 5th, much to the excitement of gaming enthusiasts.
Developed by Wizard Fu Games, this indie title offers a unique blend of retro aesthetics and modern gameplay mechanics.

A mighty Merlin helicopter of the Royal Navy hovered over Sleaford before touching down on Carre’s Grammar School’s sports fields on Monday afternoon.
The impressive aircraft drew gasps of amazement from students and teachers alike as it landed gracefully, its rotor blades still spinning.
The unexpected arrival of the helicopter created a buzz of excitement among the students, who eagerly gathered around to catch a glimpse of the impressive machine up close.
Teacher Ian Scholefield explained the helicopter visited as part of a careers drive to promote Science, Technology, Engineering and Maths subjects among GCSE choices for year nine pupils.
A Royal Navy Merlin helicopter dropped in on Carre's Grammar School to encourage students to take up science, technology, engineering and maths.
Groups of children from year 7 and 9 from all three of the town’s secondary schools were invited to look around the aircraft and talk to the crew during the hour-long visit.

MINNEAPOLIS (WCCO) – Authorities say a 31-year-old Wisconsin man was arrested for driving drunk and fleeing authorities among several charges after leading deputies on a short chase on Sunday in western Wisconsin.
The Barron County Sheriff’s Office says the incident started at about 1 p.m. as a deputy attempted to stop a vehicle on Highway D south of Barron for a traffic violation.
The driver didn’t stop, and a chase ensued that reached speeds of about 100 miles per hour.
The driver, identified as Nicholas Mosay of Balsam Lake, Wis., stopped after about 3.5 miles.
Sheriff Chris Fitzgerald stated that Mosay was found to be under the influence of alcohol and was arrested for operating a vehicle while intoxicated.
In addition to the OWI charge, Mosay faces charges of fleeing police, reckless driving, and speeding.
Fortunately, there were no reported injuries during the pursuit.
Mosay was taken into custody without further incident.
Authorities remind the public of the dangers of driving under the influence and the serious consequences that can result from such reckless behavior.
Mosay is scheduled to appear in court to face the multiple charges filed against him.
NEW CASTLE, Pa. (WYTV) – Police are looking for the public’s help in identifying a woman who was struck by a car and died late Sunday night.
According to a police report, the accident happened about 11:45 p.m. along Route 422, east of Edinburg Road in Mahoning Township.
Police said the woman was walking east on Route 422 when she was struck by a vehicle.
The driver of the vehicle stopped and called 911 immediately after the incident.
Emergency responders arrived at the scene and pronounced the woman dead.
The victim, described as a Caucasian female in her late 40s, did not have any form of identification on her.
Authorities are urging anyone with information about the incident or the woman's identity to come forward.
The investigation is ongoing, and police are working to determine the circumstances that led to this tragic accident.

NEW YORK (AP) — A New York company that sells soup from the recipes of the chef who was the real-life model of the Soup Nazi on “Seinfeld” has filed for bankruptcy.
The company, known for its delicious and unique soup varieties, has faced financial difficulties in recent months, leading to this unfortunate decision.
The Soup Nazi, whose real name is Al Yeganeh, gained fame for his strict ordering rules and high standards for customer behavior at his soup stand in Manhattan.

He and his New York soup stand were the inspiration for the “Seinfeld” character, with the catchphrase “No soup for you!” The company said Tuesday it needs to seek bankruptcy protection in part because of “recent company developments” but store shelves will continue to carry its products including lobster bisque and mulligatawny.

FILE - In this June 26, 2018, file photo, a U.S. Border Patrol truck enters the Port Isabel Detention Center, which holds detainees of the U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement, in Los Fresnos, Texas.
Asylum-seeking parents detained at the Port Isabel Detention Facility are reported to be in a fragile state as they prepare for crucial interviews to determine their fate.
The immense stress and uncertainty surrounding their asylum cases have taken a toll on their mental well-being, according to attorneys closely involved in their cases.
A network of volunteer lawyers has counseled about 210 separated parents at Port Isabel Detention Facility, including about 150 who have already done initial interviews.
David J. Phillip, File AP Photo

LOS ANGELES (AP) — California officials announced Tuesday that they will take a detailed look at the possibility of creating a taxpayer-backed bank to handle what could be billions of dollars in revenue generated by the state's legal marijuana industry.
State Treasurer John Chiang stopped short of endorsing the idea but said his office would work with the state attorney general to examine how a weed bank might function.
Legal pot sales kicked off in California on Jan. 1.
However, many banks don't want anything to do with pot money for fear it could expose them to legal trouble from the federal government, which still lists marijuana as illegal.
That means a lot of pot business is conducted in cash, sometimes tens of thousands of dollars, which is risky for cannabis workers and the public.
Is a public bank a solution?
"Maybe," said Chiang, a Democratic candidate for governor.
The potential creation of a taxpayer-backed bank for marijuana revenue in California presents both opportunities and challenges.
Supporters argue that such a bank could provide a secure and regulated financial system for the booming cannabis industry, offering a safer alternative to handling large sums of cash.
Additionally, a state-run bank could potentially offer financial services to marijuana-related businesses that are currently underserved by traditional banks.

However, the idea comes with formidable risks that were outlined in a state report last year, including unknown startup costs, the probability of losses for several years or more that California taxpayers would have to cover and trouble obtaining federal regulatory approval.
Another problem: The Trump administration has signaled a potentially more aggressive approach to marijuana prosecution by U.S. prosecutors.
That federal action "casts into turmoil a newly established industry that is creating jobs and tax revenues," Chiang said.
BERLIN (AP) — The new leader of one of Germany's governing parties says she plans to join a protest against working conditions at Amazon during a visit by company CEO Jeff Bezos to Berlin.

Saskia Esken, co-leader of the center-left Social Democrats, expressed her intentions to participate in the demonstration aimed at highlighting concerns over labor practices within the tech giant's operations.
Esken's decision to join the protest underscores growing scrutiny and criticism of Amazon's treatment of its workers, particularly regarding issues such as pay, working hours, and job security.
The planned demonstration is expected to draw attention to these grievances and amplify calls for improved working conditions and fair treatment of employees.

As the debate over labor rights and corporate responsibility intensifies, Esken's public stance signals a commitment to advocating for workers' rights and holding companies like Amazon accountable for their practices.

She highlighted Petty's ability to craft melodies that were both intricate and accessible, a quality that she has long admired and strived to incorporate into her own songwriting.

Swift expressed gratitude for the legacy that Petty leaves behind, acknowledging his enduring influence on the music industry and the lasting imprint he has made on generations of musicians, herself included.
Petty's music will continue to be a source of inspiration for Swift and countless others who have been touched by his artistry.

The clashes and violence that unfolded on that fateful day underscored the deep divisions and tensions within the community.

Leeds United's Yosuke Ideguchi has missed out on Japan's 23-man squad for this summer's World Cup in Russia.

The decision to leave out Ideguchi highlights the fierce competition for places in Japan's midfield and the importance of regular game time at the highest level to secure a spot in the prestigious tournament.
Ideguchi will now have to focus on regaining form and fitness to make a strong case for future international call-ups.

The ongoing feud has exposed deep rifts within the company as it navigates through a challenging period of leadership transition.
Meanwhile, speculation is rife that Kalanick is seeking to reclaim his position as CEO, further complicating the situation.

MINNEAPOLIS — The Minnesota Twins have placed outfielder Byron Buxton on the 10-day disabled list with a left big toe fracture.
The injury occurred during a recent game against the Cleveland Indians when Buxton fouled a pitch off his foot.
The talented center fielder has been a key player for the Twins this season, both offensively and defensively, making this loss a significant blow to the team.
In Buxton's absence, the Twins will turn to their depth to fill the void in the outfield.
To replace Buxton on the 25-man roster, the Twins recalled right-handed pitcher Aaron Slegers from Triple-A Rochester.
Slegers made nine starts for the Red Wings, going 5-2 with a 3.27 ERA, eight walks and 31 strikeouts.
The 2017 Twins minor league pitcher of the year was recalled by the Twins earlier this season, but did not appear in a game.

Oklahoma currently boasts the lowest gas prices in the United States, with Arkansas following closely as the 5th lowest.
The average price for a gallon of regular gasoline in Oklahoma stands at $2.33, while Arkansas residents are paying around $2.40 per gallon.
This trend is a welcome relief for motorists in both states, especially as the holiday season approaches.
Factors contributing to the low gas prices include ample supply levels and decreased global demand due to the ongoing pandemic.
Additionally, the recent drop in crude oil prices has also played a role in driving down gas prices across the region.
AAA spokesperson Leslie Gamble says gasoline demand is expected to weaken throughout the winter.
AAA says West Coast gas prices are among the highest in the country, with motorists in California paying $3.13 per gallon.
In a recent report, the ADP revealed that small business hiring experienced a slowdown in May.
The data indicated a decrease in the pace of job creation at small companies compared to the previous months.
ADP's tally of new jobs at companies of all sizes fell to 178,000 from a four-month average of nearly 229,000.
Some companies have said in surveys they want to hire but struggle to find candidates with the right skills.
A survey released Wednesday by the U.S. Chamber of Commerce and MetLife showed that 32 percent of the 1,002 small business owners questioned between late March and late April expect to hire.
The Ukraine energy ministry's website recently fell victim to a ransomware attack, causing concern and disruption.

This incident highlights the growing threat of cyberattacks on critical infrastructure, with ransomware attacks becoming increasingly common worldwide.
The Ukraine energy ministry is working diligently to address the issue and restore normal operations as soon as possible.
Cybersecurity experts are on high alert to prevent any further breaches and ensure the safety of the ministry's systems.
Ukrainian cyber-police spokeswoman Yulia Kvitko told Reuters the attack was an isolated incident with no other government departments affected.
She has been quoted as saying: “This case is not large-scale.
If necessary, we are ready to react and help “Our specialists are working right now… We do not know how long it will take to resolve the issue.”

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J. — A Pennsylvania man who repeatedly stabbed a woman in an Atlantic City casino parking garage last year has pleaded guilty to attempted murder.
David Legette entered his plea Tuesday as part of a deal with Atlantic County prosecutors.
The 54-year-old Bristol Township man faces a 16-year state prison term when he’s sentenced July 20.
Authorities say the victim had an active restraining order against Legette when the attack occurred July 2.
Prosecutors say Legette stabbed her 19 times, then locked the car doors so she couldn’t escape.
The victim managed to free herself from the moving vehicle, sustaining severe injuries in the process.
Legette's guilty plea brings some closure to the harrowing incident that shocked the community.
The prosecution emphasized the severity of the crime and the need for justice to be served.
The sentencing scheduled for July 20 will mark a significant moment in this case, offering a sense of justice for the victim and her loved ones.

LUXEMBOURG (AP) — Greece is hoping to secure more bailout funds to meet a summer debt repayment hump as well as a debt relief deal at a meeting of finance ministers from the 19-country eurozone.
The Greek government is under pressure to secure the necessary funds to repay 7 billion euros ($7.8 billion) in maturing bonds in July.
The country has been relying on bailout funds from international creditors to keep its economy afloat.
The main obstacle to an agreement is a difference of opinion between the eurozone and the International Monetary Fund over Greece's long-term debt outlook.

The expectation is Greece will get the roughly 7 billion euros ($7.8 billion) due, but will struggle to clinch the outlines of a debt relief deal that Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras thinks is crucial for the country's economy in the long-term.

In a recent development, it has been announced that inquests will be conducted into two separate police-involved shootings that occurred in Winnipeg.
The incidents, which resulted in the deaths of two individuals, have raised questions and concerns within the community.
The first shooting took place in the downtown area, where a confrontation between police officers and a suspect escalated, leading to gunfire.
The second incident occurred in a residential neighborhood during a response to a disturbance call.
Both men involved in these tragic events were pronounced dead upon arrival at the Health Sciences Centre.
Both men were pronounced dead at the Health Sciences Centre.

As part of The Fatality Inquiries Act, an inquest must be held if the chief medical examiner has reasonable grounds to believe a person died as a result of the use of force by a peace officer acting in the course of duty.
Dates for the inquests have not been set.

These inquests will play a crucial role in examining the circumstances surrounding the use of force by the police officers and will provide an opportunity to uncover the facts and ensure transparency in the investigations.
The community eagerly awaits further details as the process unfolds.

WASHINGTON — Kyle Hendricks outpitched Stephen Strasburg, and the Chicago Cubs opened defence of their first World Series title in 108 years by beating the Washington Nationals 3-0 on Friday in Game 1 of their NL Division Series.
Kris Bryant and Anthony Rizzo produced RBI singles in the sixth inning for the first two hits off an otherwise-dominant Strasburg.
Hendricks was even better, giving up only two singles in seven strong innings.
The Cubs' victory showcased a masterful performance by Hendricks, who kept the Nationals' batters in check throughout the game.
His precise pitching and strategic play kept the Nationals off the scoreboard, frustrating their attempts to generate any significant offense.
The Cubs' solid defense also played a key role in securing the shutout win.
The win gives the Cubs an early advantage in the series, setting a positive tone as they aim to defend their title.
The Nationals will look to bounce back in Game 2, eager to even the series and turn the tide in their favor.
NEW YORK (AP) — A former New Jersey police officer convicted of causing a wrong-way crash that killed a fellow officer and another friend has been sentenced to up to 25 years in prison.
WABC-TV (http://7ny.tv/2rs3kur ) reports that a judge on Staten Island gave Pedro Abad the maximum sentence on Wednesday — 8 1/3 to 25 years in prison.
The tragic incident occurred in March 2015 when Abad, who was off-duty at the time, drove the wrong way on a highway and crashed head-on into a tractor-trailer.

The collision resulted in the deaths of two passengers in Abad's vehicle, fellow Linden police officer Frank Viggiano and friend Joseph Rodriguez, while Abad and another passenger sustained serious injuries.
During the trial, prosecutors presented evidence that Abad had a blood alcohol level of more than twice the legal limit at the time of the crash.
The judge condemned Abad's reckless actions, stating that he had shown a complete disregard for the safety of others on the road.
The families of the victims expressed relief at the sentencing, hoping it would bring some closure to the devastating loss they have endured.
Abad will now serve his sentence for the tragic consequences of his irresponsible choices behind the wheel.

Tiger Woods has probably holed more shots from off the green than anyone in golf history, but it sure seems like Muirfield Village has been the site for more of his short game magic than anywhere else.
There was the miracle flop in 2012 that Jack Nicklaus called the best he's ever seen , the curling pitch in 2001, and even a walk-off chip-in at the 2009 Memorial Skins Game .
PODCAST: A chat with Aaron Wise & Memorial picks So another improbable make at Muirfield shouldn't be too surprising.
Or exciting when you consider it came during a Wednesday pro-am.
Yet Woods found a way to dazzle us -- and playing partner Peyton Manning -- once again, and he made a young fan's day week year in the process.
During the pro-am event, Woods found himself in the rough, faced with a seemingly impossible flop shot.

With his trademark skill and finesse, Woods executed a perfect shot that defied the odds, sending the ball soaring high into the air before landing softly on the green and rolling straight into the cup.
The crowd erupted in cheers as Woods celebrated yet another remarkable shot.
But the magic didn't end there.
As Woods approached the green to retrieve his ball, he noticed a young fan eagerly waiting nearby.
With a smile, Woods flipped the ball to the young fan, who couldn't contain his excitement at receiving a souvenir from one of the greatest golfers of all time.
It was a touching moment that showcased Woods' generosity and connection with his fans, making the day unforgettable for the lucky young fan and everyone who witnessed the incredible shot.

UK outfit EDS HV has been signed up as high-voltage (HV) consultant for Vattenfall's 406MW Horns Rev 3 wind farm off the coast of Denmark.

Share This Video Facebook Twitter EMAIL It should be obvious by now, but Logic cares very deeply about making music with messages (even if his execution often undershoots his ambition).

The rapper reveals that the song was inspired by his own experiences and the desire to reach out to those who may be struggling silently.

After he responds in the negative, she wonders why he felt it so important to address the subject.

Logic replies that it was prompted by his fans’ messages of support and thanks that propelled him to write “1-800-273-8255.” “They said, ‘you changed my life,'” he shares, “I thought to myself how I wasn’t even trying to do that.

1 debut for his third studio album, Everybody.
In a rare move, the Senate confirmed President Trump's judicial nominee, Justice David Stras, for a seat on the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit.

NEW YORK (AP) — Starting this fall, works in translation will get a spotlight at the National Book Awards.

The National Book Foundation announced Wednesday that it has started a category for best translated literature, awarding a work of fiction or nonfiction translated into English and released in the U.S.
The new prize should provide a boost for authors from overseas who have struggled to catch on in the U.S.
This move represents a significant step towards recognizing the importance of translated works in the literary landscape.
By establishing this category, the National Book Foundation aims to celebrate the art of translation and promote a diverse range of voices and perspectives from around the world.
The inclusion of translated literature not only enriches the literary scene in the U.S. but also fosters greater cultural exchange and understanding among readers.
This exciting development is sure to bring attention to talented translators and authors whose works have previously been underrepresented in American literary awards.

In a controversial move, Mick Mulvaney, the acting director of the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, is pushing for a name change for the agency.
Mulvaney insists that the bureau should be referred to as the Bureau of Consumer Financial Protection.
This change, although seemingly minor on the surface, has significant implications.
It reflects the bureau's official legal name but has sparked criticism from many who see it as emblematic of the agency's shift in ideology under the Trump administration.
Since Mulvaney took over, the bureau has been accused of rolling back regulations and reducing enforcement actions against financial institutions.
Critics argue that the name change is symbolic of the broader changes happening within the agency.
The move has reignited debates about the bureau's priorities and its commitment to protecting consumers against predatory financial practices.

The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau is pushing to be referred to as the Bureau of Consumer Financial Protection, a surface level, but notable change for the agency tasked with protecting consumers against debt collectors and banks.
Officials say the change reflects the bureau's legal name, but critics say it underscores the abrupt ideological turn the bureau has taken since Trump-appointee Mick Mulvaney took over.
The 2010 Dodd-Frank Act did create a "Bureau of Consumer Financial Protection" but that name has rarely been used, except occasionally in court filings.
Under Mulvaney, the bureau has proposed revisiting the regulations and policies the Obama administration put in place, and has also reduced the number of enforcement actions it has taken.
The Canadian Press OTTAWA -- The Ottawa Senators are "hopeful" that Erik Karlsson will be ready for the start of the 2017-18 season following surgery to his left foot on Wednesday.

Karlsson's presence on the ice is crucial for the Senators, as the star defenseman is a key player in their lineup.
His ability to contribute offensively while also playing a solid defensive game has made him a cornerstone of the team.
With a four-month timeline for recovery, the Senators are optimistic that Karlsson will be back in action just in time for the start of the new season.
A four-month timeline would allow for Karlsson to return in mid-October, likely right around the start of the 2017-18 season.
The NHL is expected to announce the schedule next week.
In a shocking development, the Wiltshire poisoning incident has been confirmed to involve the deadly Novichok nerve agent, as announced by the police.
This revelation has reignited fears of a repeat of the nerve agent attack that targeted former Russian spy Sergei Skripal and his daughter Yulia in Salisbury earlier this year.
The latest victims, a couple identified as Charlie Rowley and Dawn Sturgess, were found unconscious at a house in Amesbury, just 12 kilometers (8 miles) from Salisbury.
Following the analysis of samples by experts at Porton Down, it was determined that the same nerve agent, Novichok, was responsible for their critical condition.
Local police have swiftly taken action, setting up two help lines to assist individuals who may have concerns about potential contamination.
The case has now been handed over to counter-terrorism police, underscoring the seriousness of the situation.
Neil Basu, Britain's top counter-terrorism officer, addressed the media, expressing uncertainty about the couple's exposure to the nerve agent and whether they were deliberately targeted.
Downing Street has emphasized the gravity of the incident, with England's Chief Medical Officer reassuring the public that the risk remains low.
Amidst the unfolding investigation, authorities are working tirelessly to unravel the circumstances surrounding this alarming turn of events.
More updates are expected as the situation develops.
Amesbury is 12 kilometers (8 miles) from Salisbury, where the Skripals were poisoned.
Local police have established two help lines to take calls from those who may have concerns about a possible contamination.
Counter-terrorism police are now handling the case.

No danger to public Neil Basu, Britain's most senior counter-terrorism officer, told reporters it was unclear how they came into contact with the nerve agent or whether they had been specifically targetted.
A Downing Street spokesperson said the incident was being treated "with the utmost seriousness."
England's Chief Medical Officer said the risk to the general public remained low.
More to come...

This year, National Ferris Wheel Day is making waves and stealing the spotlight from Valentine's Day.
As people across the country celebrate this unique holiday on February 14th, the iconic Ferris wheel has become a symbol of joy and excitement for many.
With its towering presence and historical significance, the Ferris wheel offers a nostalgic and thrilling experience that captivates people of all ages.
In cities and towns nationwide, Ferris wheel attractions are drawing crowds and creating memorable moments for couples, families, and friends.
From vintage restored wheels to modern marvels, the Ferris wheel continues to enchant and entertain, adding a touch of whimsy to the Valentine's Day festivities.

"We did get it out of Disneyland and it was built, 40 feet tall, and 1938 is when this was built so this is a vintage restored Ferris wheel," said Caryn Olson of Scheels All Sports.

WARREN, Mich. — Police who found a badly decomposed body in bed in a Detroit-area home believe a 62-year-old woman may have shared the home with her dead roommate for months.
Police in Warren found the body of 68-year-old George Curtis on Monday.
The woman, whose identity has not been released, was discovered in the same residence.
Authorities are investigating the circumstances surrounding Curtis's death and the woman's actions during the time she allegedly lived with his decomposing body.
WJBK-TV and The Macomb Daily of Mount Clemens report Tuesday that relatives contacted police after hearing nothing from Curtis for months.
The woman has been hospitalized for a psychiatric evaluation.
Police Commissioner Bill Dwyer tells the newspaper “it’s just bizarre (that) she stayed in the home like that and didn’t report anything.” Police say Curtis may have been dead for months.
Dwyer says the house may have to be condemned and demolished due to the condition inside and the odor.

In a dramatic turn of events, the alleged leader of a major drug ring has been extradited from Colombia to face charges in a U.S. court.

Residents in Reading and Bracknell are being urged to take caution as a weather warning has been issued for freezing fog and icy roads and pavements.
The Met Office has raised concerns about the hazardous conditions that are expected to prevail in the region.
With temperatures set to plummet overnight, untreated surfaces are likely to become extremely slippery, posing a significant risk to commuters and pedestrians.
The warning comes as a result of a sudden drop in temperatures, with some areas expected to experience lows of -3 degrees Celsius.
In addition to icy roads and pavements, there is also a possibility of freezing fog patches in certain areas, further exacerbating the dangerous conditions.
The Met Office has emphasized the need for vigilance and urged individuals to take necessary precautions to ensure their safety.
As the cold spell continues, it is essential for residents to be mindful of the potential risks associated with the icy conditions.
The Met Office has issued a yellow warning of ice for Reading and Bracknell for Monday night until 10am on Tuesday, January 3.
Untreated roads and pavements are likely to be very slippery as temperatures drop sharply overnight, with some rural areas seeing temperatures fall to -3 degrees Celsius.
There is also the risk of freezing fog patches in some areas.

The Met Office's chief forecaster said: "A very cold night is in store, and as moister air comes in contact with cold surfaces later, the potential for a lot of frost to form, rendering some surfaces hazardous."

Rio de Janeiro authorities are urging visitors attending the upcoming Carnival celebrations to stick to urban areas amidst concerns over yellow fever outbreaks in Brazil.
The recommendation comes as a precautionary measure to ensure the safety and well-being of tourists and locals during the festive season.
While the risk of contracting yellow fever in urban regions is relatively low, health officials advise against venturing into forested areas where the disease-carrying mosquitoes are prevalent.
Brazil is vaccinating more than 20 million people against yellow fever to control a budding outbreak, and the secretary says Rio state alone has vaccinated more than 8 million.
Brazil's Health Ministry says 130 cases have been confirmed across the country and 53 people have died in the current outbreak.
A 79-year-old man from Lee’s Summit, suffering from dementia, has been safely reunited with his family after going missing.
The man, identified as Eagles, had left his home without his essential medications, sparking concerns for his well-being.
Fortunately, he was found and returned home unharmed.
The Lee’s Summit Police Department had issued an alert regarding Eagles' disappearance, urging the community to be on the lookout for him.
Thanks to the efforts of law enforcement and concerned citizens, Eagles was located and brought back to the safety of his home.
Eagles' family expressed immense relief upon his return, grateful for the swift action taken to ensure his safety.
The incident serves as a reminder of the challenges faced by individuals living with dementia and the importance of support systems in place to assist them during times of need.
Video footage captured Eagles at his home, reassuring his dog before heading out to grab a bite to eat.
Descriptions provided indicate that Eagles is easily identifiable, and anyone who spots him is urged to contact the authorities promptly.
Video at his home shows Eagles telling his dog that he was going to get something to eat.
Eagles takes medications for dementia but does not have medication on him.
Eagles is approximately 5 feet 10 inches tall and weighs approximately 170 pounds.
He has white hair, blue eyes and was wearing a blue shirt with a red, white and blue eagle on the front.
He also had on blue jeans, white shoes and a red Chiefs hat.
He drives a 2011 silver Ford Taurus with Missouri plate FE7D1W.
If you see Eagles call 911 immediately or call Lee’s Summit police at (816) 969-7390.

LOS ANGELES (AP) — An appeals court says Los Angeles police violated the rights of a man arrested inside Sandra Bullock’s home when they obtained his consent to search his home and recovered illegal automatic firearms.

The 2nd District Court of Appeal ruled Tuesday that police detectives violated Joshua James Corbett’s rights to remain silent during a police interrogation, and his right against an unlawful search of his home.
Corbett was arrested in June 2014 inside Bullock’s home, and he has been charged with felony stalking.
The court's decision came after Corbett’s lawyers argued that the police interrogation conducted after his arrest was unlawful as Corbett was not properly informed of his rights.

Additionally, the court found that the search of Corbett's home, which led to the discovery of illegal automatic firearms, was conducted without a proper warrant and therefore violated his constitutional rights.
Corbett’s defense team hailed the court's ruling as a significant victory for protecting individual rights against unlawful police practices.
The case has sparked discussions about the importance of upholding constitutional protections, particularly in high-profile cases involving celebrities.
The court's decision is expected to have far-reaching implications in how law enforcement conducts interrogations and searches in the future.

DES MOINES, Iowa (AP) — Iowa's governor is keeping campaign donations tied to a firm that profited from a controversial lobbying blitz funded by Saudi Arabia.
Gov.
Kim Reynolds in November returned a $100 contribution from executive branch appointees Kim and Connie Schmett, saying she disagreed with their side work as foreign agents.

LS2Group, the firm in question, received payments from the Saudi government for lobbying services in the U.S., which included efforts to improve the kingdom's image and influence in American politics.
Despite the connection to this controversial work, Reynolds has chosen not to return other donations from LS2Group employees.
Critics argue that by keeping these donations, Reynolds is indirectly benefiting from the firm's pro-Saudi activities.
However, Reynolds' campaign spokesman defends the decision, pointing out that LS2Group is a private business separate from the Schmetts' roles as state officials.
Recently, Connie Schmett was fined $250 by an ethics board for disclosure violations, further raising questions about the connections between the firm and state officials.
Reynolds' campaign spokesman notes LS2Group is a private business while the Schmetts are state officials.
Connie Schmett was fined $250 last week by an ethics board for disclosure violations.

In the dynamic landscape of modern journalism, the traditional newsroom is undergoing a transformation marked by a spirit of playfulness and constant iteration.
This shift is not merely a surface-level trend but rather a fundamental reimagining of the relationship between news producers and consumers.

The newsroom is no longer a static entity churning out information to passive recipients; instead, it has become a vibrant playground where news and its publics engage in a continuous dialogue of iteration and reiteration.

Within this new model, the writer configures the rules and boundaries in which the reader is free to respond and subvert, an interplay that increasingly shapes both current news production and expectations of the public.
This paper then explores play and playful attitudes in newsroom practices and output through semi-structured interviews with journalists, game designers and educators.

The “Game Team” at the news and entertainment Web site BuzzFeed acts as a primary case study of a group of journalists who make a variety of playful products — from full-fledged games to interactives — which they iterate and improve over time, in response to readers’ feedback.

-- Ready to get into the Christmas spirit?
It may seem early, but Hallmark is putting on display - for the first time ever - all of Norman Rockwell's iconic Christmas card art.
The exhibit opens Saturday, Oct. 7 at the Hallmark Visitor's Center at 25th and Grand in Kansas City.
It showcases the 32 original pieces of art Rockwell created for Hallmark Christmas cards over a ten-year period - from 1947 until 1956.
A lot of people remember these paintings from their childhood.
Besides iconic images of Santa, he also painted Christmas portraits from Charles Dickens novels and humorous scenes of everyday families celebrating the holidays.
"Millions of Americans grew up with these images as being a part of their ideal of what Christmas is about," Hallmark Curator Joe Houston said.
"He was such an amazing storyteller.
He loved Charles Dickens, he loved the idea of Christmas and this was always a favorite holiday of his."
The collection offers a nostalgic journey through Rockwell's timeless artistry, capturing the essence of the holiday season with warmth and charm.
Visitors can immerse themselves in the intricate details of each painting, from the twinkle in Santa's eye to the joy on children's faces, evoking a sense of nostalgia and wonder.

The Hallmark Visitor's Center invites guests to experience the magic of Rockwell's Christmas art collection, a tribute to the artist's enduring legacy and his ability to capture the spirit of the season in every brushstroke.
Don't miss this opportunity to witness a piece of American art history come to life this holiday season.

The Independent Electricity System Operator (IESO) has been under scrutiny after uncovering a significant amount of ineligible expenses by power generators.
The IESO found that these generators had billed for expenses that did not qualify under the rules governing the electricity market.
This discovery has raised concerns about potential financial mismanagement within the sector.
In response to these findings, the IESO has taken action to address the issue.
They have conducted a thorough review of the billings and have identified a total of $168 million in expenses that were deemed inappropriate.
This significant sum highlights the extent of the problem and the need for further investigation.
Progressive Conservative Todd Smith, the Minister of Energy, has taken a proactive step by writing to the Ontario Provincial Police (OPP) to request an investigation into the matter.
Smith emphasized the severity of the situation, stating that the abuses were so egregious that a closer examination by law enforcement is necessary.
The OPP has not yet responded to inquiries about whether they will pursue an investigation.
The IESO has recovered $168 million of those billings that were deemed inappropriate.
Progressive Conservative Todd Smith has now written to the OPP to ask them to investigate, saying the abuses were so egregious that a second look by law enforcement is prudent.
The OPP did not immediately respond to a question about whether or not they will look into it.
RCMP are continuing their search for a missing Enoch Cree Nation man who has been missing since 2003, and they’ve released an age-progression photo.

HELSINKI — A fawn that became stranded on a patch of ice in Finland’s Inkoo archipelago has gotten a hand from members of the Finnish coast guard.
The distressed young deer was spotted by a passing vessel crew, who quickly alerted the coast guard.
Responding promptly, the coast guard team navigated through the icy waters to reach the fawn, carefully lifting it to safety.
Lieutenant Jukka Von Brunn, who led the rescue operation, stated that the fawn had likely wandered onto the ice and couldn't find its way back to shore.
With the help of the coast guard, the fawn was reunited with its anxious mother waiting on the nearby shore.

Von Brunn said: “The mother deer was very happy and grateful to get her baby back.” The Coast Guard said while animal rescue missions are not part of its personnel’s normal duties, they do occur from time to time.
The Finnish Border Guard, of which the coast guard is past, posted the rescue video on social media.

Two men are in a critical condition following an explosion inside a North Lanarkshire building.

PORTLAND, Ore. (AP) – Two 19-year-old women are dead after a fall from the Pacific Crest Trail about six miles northwest of Oregon’s Timberline Lodge.
The Clackamas County Sheriff’s Office said Monday that other hikers saw the women’s bodies and called 9-1-1 after they fell about 150 feet on Saturday evening.
Emma C. Place and Emily D. Lang, both 19, were pronounced dead at the scene by rescue teams.
They were both from Portland.
Authorities have been unable to locate any witnesses who saw the women falling.
The Pacific Crest Trail, a popular hiking destination, offers breathtaking views but also poses risks due to its rugged terrain.
The tragic incident has left the local community shocked and saddened.
The sheriff's office is investigating the circumstances surrounding the fall to determine what led to this heartbreaking outcome.
Our thoughts are with the families and loved ones of Emma and Emily during this difficult time.

SAN DIEGO (AP) — Federal immigration authorities have formalized the practice of sending deportation agents to federal, state and local courthouses to make arrests, dismissing complaints from judges and advocacy that it instills fear among crime victims, witnesses and family members.
The Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) agency defended the policy, stating that courthouses are a safer option for making arrests compared to other locations.
ICE argues that courthouses provide a controlled environment where agents can safely apprehend individuals who are in violation of immigration laws.
However, critics of the practice argue that it undermines the justice system by deterring individuals from participating in court proceedings, whether as victims, witnesses, or defendants.
They emphasize that the fear of encountering immigration authorities at courthouses can have a chilling effect on the willingness of individuals to seek justice or fulfill their legal obligations.
The formalization of these plans by ICE has sparked renewed debate and concerns about the impact on the administration of justice and the rights of individuals involved in legal proceedings.

FLINT, Mich. — A state official is contradicting Michigan Gov.
Rick Snyder about when the governor learned about a Flint area Legionnaires’ disease outbreak.
Harvey Hollins, who was co-ordinating the state’s response to the Flint water crisis, says he told Snyder by phone in December 2015.
This statement directly contradicts Snyder's previous claims that he only became aware of the outbreak in January 2016.
The discrepancy in timelines raises questions about the transparency and handling of the crisis by state officials.
The issue emerged as Hollins testified at a court hearing involving Nick Lyon, head of the Department of Health and Human Services.
Lyon is charged with involuntary manslaughter and misconduct.
Prosecutors say he failed to alert the public quickly about Legionnaires’.
A judge must decide whether to send Lyon to trial.
Some experts have linked Legionnaires’ to Flint’s poor water quality in 2014-15.

BOSTON — On commencement day at Northern Michigan University, some students protested the speaker, Gov.
Rick Snyder, and his handling of the water crisis in Flint.
While some students outside the event carried signs against him, students inside the hall simply — and silently — turned their backs on him as he spoke.
Protests at college commencements are almost a rite of spring, and this graduation season is no different.
Some of the demonstrations this year have shapeshifted into actions more subdued than those of just a few years ago.
Some are small events within larger ceremonies.
And silence as a protest tactic is being used to make a point without ruffling too many feathers.
At Northern Michigan, the university’s president, Fritz Erickson, appeared pleased with the outcome.
In a statement, he said he appreciated that the governor, a Republican, still came, despite advance word that he would be met by protests.
The shift towards more subdued protests at commencements reflects a growing trend of expressing dissent in a quieter, yet impactful manner.
Instead of loud disruptions or confrontations, students are opting for gestures like turning their backs or remaining silent to convey their message.
This approach allows for a peaceful demonstration while still drawing attention to important issues.
President Erickson's positive response to the silent protest indicates a level of respect for differing viewpoints and the importance of open dialogue even in moments of disagreement.
As graduation season continues, it will be interesting to see how these quieter forms of protest evolve and influence the discourse surrounding key societal issues.
A San Jose man died Sunday after he fell off his motorcycle on a Central Valley rural road.
The tragic incident occurred on a remote stretch of Highway 25 near Hollister.
The victim, identified as 32-year-old Mark Rodriguez, was riding his motorcycle alone when the accident took place.
According to the California Highway Patrol (CHP), Rodriguez lost control of his motorcycle while navigating a sharp curve on the winding road.
He was unable to regain control and was thrown from his bike, sustaining fatal injuries upon impact with the pavement.
Despite the efforts of emergency responders at the scene, Rodriguez was pronounced dead shortly after their arrival.
The cause of the crash is still under investigation, but initial reports suggest that speed may have been a contributing factor.

A federal judge ruled that the denial of a proposed mosque's application for additional parking in a New Jersey township was unconstitutional.
He said the township's planning board had "unbridled and unconstitutional discretion" due to its vague parking requirements.
The Islamic Society's application to build the mosque was denied after more than three years and 39 public hearings.
The group sued the township in March.
The mosque's attorney, Adeel Mangi, called the decision a "landmark ruling."
NJ.com reports township officials say they "vehemently" disagree with the decision and will decide how to proceed after the township's attorneys study it.
The judge's ruling brings attention to the issue of religious freedom and municipal regulations.
The case highlights the complexities and legal challenges that arise when balancing zoning regulations with the rights of religious organizations to establish places of worship.
It remains to be seen how the township will respond to the court's decision and what implications this ruling may have for similar cases in the future.

The Latest on U.S. Vice President Mike Pence's trip to Asia (all times local): 12:15 p.m. U.S. Vice President Mike Pence has arrived in Japan for the second stop of a 10-day Asia tour.
His plane touched down Tuesday at the U.S. military's Atsugi base outside Tokyo.
The focus of his trip is expected to shift in Japan to trade.
North Korea's nuclear and missile development dominated the agenda on his first stop in South Korea.
During his visit to Japan, Pence is set to meet with Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe to discuss trade relations and economic cooperation between the two nations.
The United States and Japan have a longstanding economic partnership, and both countries are keen on strengthening their trade ties further.
Pence's discussions in Japan are also expected to touch upon regional security issues, including the ongoing tensions with North Korea.
The visit is seen as an opportunity to reaffirm the strong alliance between the United States and Japan in the face of regional challenges.

A pink Camaro rolled into the dealership on Friday, ahead of the Making Strides Against Breast Cancer Walk on Saturday.
