SHAFTSBURY, Vt. (AP) — The Robert Frost Stone House Museum is ready to reopen under new ownership.
The Friends of Robert Frost announced last September that it was donating the house, seven acres of property, and two barns to Bennington college.
It's due to open for the season on May 3.
The museum, once the residence of the renowned poet Robert Frost, has undergone renovations and updates in preparation for the reopening.
Visitors can explore the historic house where Frost lived and wrote for nearly a decade, gaining insight into the poet's life and work.
The museum will feature exhibitions showcasing Frost's personal belongings, manuscripts, and memorabilia.
Bennington College plans to offer educational programs, workshops, and events at the museum, aiming to promote Frost's legacy and inspire future generations of writers and poetry enthusiasts.
The reopening of the Robert Frost Stone House Museum marks a significant milestone in preserving and celebrating the poet's contributions to literature.
In a recent Quality of Living Survey conducted by a renowned global consulting firm, Ottawa has been ranked 19th out of a list of cities worldwide.
The survey assessed various factors such as healthcare, education, infrastructure, safety, and overall quality of life to determine the rankings.
Ottawa, the capital city of Canada, scored well in categories like education and healthcare, reflecting the city's commitment to providing excellent public services to its residents.
The city's vibrant cultural scene, diverse population, and low crime rates were also highlighted as contributing factors to its favorable ranking.
However, challenges remain, particularly in the area of sanitation.
Conditions used in the sanitation ranking include air pollution, infectious diseases, sewage, water availability and waste removal.

- Two orphaned grizzly bear cubs that were found wandering near a highway in Montana have been safely captured and relocated to a zoo in Quebec, Canada.
The cubs, a male and a female believed to be about six months old, were spotted by a passing motorist who immediately alerted wildlife authorities.
After a successful rescue operation, the cubs were deemed healthy and were transported to their new home at the Quebec zoo, where they will receive the care and attention they need to thrive.
Officials at the zoo expressed their commitment to providing a safe and nurturing environment for the young bears, who will be closely monitored as they adjust to their new surroundings.

The relocation of these orphaned grizzly cubs highlights the importance of wildlife conservation efforts and the collaborative work of agencies across borders to ensure the well-being of vulnerable species.
ROME (AP) — Police in northern Italy found a small arsenal of Kalashnikovs, pistols and ammunition hidden in the trunk of a rental car and arrested the Bosnian man who was driving it.

The ANSA news agency says police believe the car, which had Swiss license plates, was headed to Barcelona when they stopped it on a routine check April 19 in Gorizia, near Italy's northeast border with Croatia and Austria.
The discovery raised concerns as it comes amid heightened security alerts across Europe following recent terror attacks.
Italian authorities are working closely with their Spanish counterparts to investigate any potential links to criminal or terrorist activities.
They then proceeded to search the rest of the car and found several guns in the spare wheel well of the trunk and another stash under the back seat.
The 52-year-old Bosnian was being held on suspicion of possession and transport of weapons of war.

Lens Description: High-performance wide-angle zoom features Nano Crystal Coat and VR image stabilization for dramatically sharper still images and video capture.
Photography Life Review Summary: After weeks of testing the Nikon 16-35mm VR, I am very impressed with its performance and contrast.
I do not see a reason to buy the more expensive Nikon 17-35mm f/2.8D anymore.
This lens is a versatile option for photographers seeking a wide-angle zoom with excellent image quality.
The 16-35mm focal length range allows for capturing sweeping landscapes, architecture, and interiors with ease.
The Nano Crystal Coat reduces flare and ghosting, resulting in clear and vibrant images even in challenging lighting conditions.
The VR image stabilization system is a standout feature of this lens, providing up to 4 stops of compensation for camera shake.
This technology enables photographers to shoot handheld at slower shutter speeds without compromising image sharpness, making it ideal for low-light situations or when capturing moving subjects.

I took this lens for a real challenge and shot in very dark corners of Denver and VR worked beautifully, allowing me to shoot at extremely slow shutter speeds of 1/10th of a second and slower – something I have never been able to do with the 17-35mm or the 24-70mm lenses.

The release of this new video has further elevated the popularity of "Versace on the Floor" and has left fans eagerly anticipating more collaborations between Mars and Zendaya in the future.
The strip mall in National City impacted by Friday's gas leak.
Approximately 20 stores at a National City strip mall were evacuated Friday after a construction crew accidentally pierced a gas line, causing a leak.
The National City Fire Department (NCFD) said a 2-inch gas line was ruptured at around 12:20 p.m. at a shopping center located at 2220 E. Plaza Boulevard.
Emergency responders swiftly evacuated the area, ensuring the safety of patrons and employees.
Nearby roads were temporarily closed off as a precautionary measure.
As a result of the leak, businesses in the strip mall were temporarily disrupted, with employees and customers being asked to vacate the premises.
No one was hurt.
San Diego Gas & Electric (SDG&E) crews were called to the scene to investigate the leak and shut off service.
WWE's Elias, known for his musical talents as well as his in-ring skills, is gearing up for an exciting venture outside the squared circle.
The talented wrestler-turned-musician has announced that he will be releasing a new album, much to the delight of his fans.
But that's not all – Elias has also promised a special concert at WrestleMania 34, adding another dimension to his already impressive resume.
It makes sense that his musical career would take the next step, and it’s only right that Elias gets an opportunity for a WrestleMania moment.
Elias spoke with Guitar World about all of that and more.
Fans can expect a unique blend of rock and wrestling as Elias prepares to showcase his musical prowess on the grand stage of WrestleMania.
With his larger-than-life personality and undeniable talent, Elias is sure to leave a lasting impression both in the music industry and the world of professional wrestling.
SYDNEY (AP) — Paul Gray, lead singer of the 1980s Australian pop band Wa Wa Nee, has died of cancer.
He was 54 years old.
Gray's distinctive vocals and energetic performances helped Wa Wa Nee rise to fame in the mid-1980s with hits like "Stimulation" and "Can't Control Myself."
The band's infectious blend of pop, funk, and dance music garnered a dedicated following both in Australia and internationally.
Gray's passing has left fans and the music community mourning the loss of a talented artist whose music continues to resonate with audiences decades later.
In addition to his contributions as a singer, Gray was also a skilled songwriter and musician, playing a key role in shaping Wa Wa Nee's sound.
The band later charted in the United States with the song "Sugar Free."
The band's broke up in 1989, but reformed recently in recent years to perform at 1980s revival concerts and to support British group The Human League on their Australian tour last year.
Real Salt Lake secured a hard-fought 2-1 victory over Houston Dynamo, with Beckerman making a significant impact off the bench.
Salt Lake (6-6-1) has won 10 of its last 11 home games, conceding just 12 goals.
Houston (5-4-3) lost for the first time in five games.
Luis Silva put RSL in front in the 34th minute by heading in Sebastian Saucedo's cross.
Beckerman, who entered having played every minute of every RSL game this season, came in as a substitute in the 64th.
Beckerman wasted no time leaving his mark on the game, scoring a crucial goal in the 75th minute to extend Real Salt Lake's lead.
Despite a late goal from Houston's Mauro Manotas in the 88th minute, Salt Lake held on for the win, further solidifying their strong home record and moving up the standings.
NEW YORK — A New York City bartender’s on-screen antics and big bets while competing on “Jeopardy!” are winning him cash to go along with a cult following.
By the end of Thursday’s show, Austin Rogers had won eight days in a row and more than $300,000.
“Jeopardy!” says that total put him at fifth on the show’s list of all-time regular season money winners.
Rogers has done it while sporting wild hair and a bushy beard and making animated gestures after correct answers.
Viewers have been captivated by Rogers’ unorthodox approach to the game, which includes bold wagers and a quick wit that keeps the audience entertained.
His quirky personality and strategic gameplay have endeared him to fans, who eagerly tune in to see what antics he will bring to the show next.
Rogers won a whopping $34,000 bet on the show’s “Final Jeopardy” segment Tuesday.
Fans are singing his praises on Twitter by using the hashtag #AustinOnJeopardy.
Rogers tells “Good Morning America” that the secret to his success is uncovering patterns in clues by watching hundreds of “Jeopardy!” episodes.
In a shocking development, a rural Oregon Fire District employee has been charged with theft.
The employee in question, identified as John Young, served as the secretary and treasurer of the district.
Authorities allege that Young was involved in embezzling funds from the fire district, a betrayal that has left the community reeling.
The investigation into Young's activities began after discrepancies were discovered in the district's financial records.
It is believed that Young misappropriated a significant amount of money over a period of several years.
The exact amount of funds that were allegedly stolen has not been disclosed at this time.

The district has expressed deep concern and disappointment over the situation, emphasizing that the alleged actions of one individual do not reflect the values and integrity of the entire organization.
The district assures the public that steps are being taken to address the issue and prevent such incidents from occurring in the future.
The district says it found more than $76,000 of questionable checking transactions since Young began work as its secretary and treasurer in 2013.
— Information from: Herald and News, http://www.heraldandnews.com
This undated photo released by the Nevada Department of Corrections shows inmate Raymond Wallace Shuman.

The 83-year-old Nevada prison inmate who was serving two life terms has died three decades after his case resulted in a U.S. Supreme Court decision that overturned state laws requiring the death penalty for prison lifers who commit murder.
Shuman had been incarcerated since 1974 for a double murder conviction.
His death comes as a reminder of the legal complexities surrounding capital punishment and the rights of inmates serving life sentences.
Despite his advanced age, Shuman's case had continued to draw attention due to the precedent-setting nature of the Supreme Court ruling that stemmed from his original trial.
The circumstances surrounding his passing are currently under investigation by prison authorities.
Camp Day 2018 was a huge success as the community came together to support a great cause.
100% of coffee sales and proceeds from bracelet purchases will help brighten a kid’s future.
Every coffee you order helps send kids from low-income families to a Tim Horton Camp, so they can see a world of possibility.
There are 3 ways to help: Buy a Coffee, Donate online or buy a bracelet.
The generosity and support shown by everyone involved truly made a difference and will have a lasting impact on the lives of these children.
Thank you to all who participated and contributed to making Camp Day 2018 a memorable and successful event.
Sarah Huckabee Sanders, the White House press secretary, audibly choked up during Wednesday’s press briefing as she answered a student’s question about school shootings.

The student, who several White House reporters identified as Benje Choucroun, 13, was at the White House covering a children’s fitness event, but was called on as he sat among the White House press corps.
He said his school recently had a lockdown drill.
Sanders, visibly moved by the young boy's question, expressed empathy for the fear and anxiety students face in today's world.
She acknowledged the seriousness of the issue and emphasized the administration's commitment to ensuring the safety of students in schools across the country.

Sanders highlighted ongoing efforts to address mental health issues and improve school safety measures, but also stressed the need for a comprehensive approach to tackle the root causes of such tragic incidents.
The emotional moment underscored the gravity of the issue and the urgent need for collective action to prevent further tragedies.
BOYNTON BEACH, Fla. (AP) – Authorities say two Florida women overdosed on heroin in a sports utility vehicle with two infants in the back seat.

Boynton Beach police spokeswoman Stephanie Slater said in a news release that 28-year-old Kristen Leigh O’Connor and 29-year-old June Schweinhart were taken to a hospital Thursday after officers found them inside the SUV.
The infants, ages 1 and 2 months, were properly strapped into their car seats.
O’Conner told investigators she picked up Schweinhart – who she met in a drug treatment program – and they bought $60 worth of heroin from her old drug dealer.
Following the incident, both women were charged with child neglect.
Authorities expressed deep concern over the welfare of the infants and the reckless behavior displayed by the mothers.
The consequences of their actions could have been tragic had law enforcement not intervened promptly.
The incident serves as a stark reminder of the devastating impact drug addiction can have, not only on the individuals involved but also on innocent children who are put in harm's way.
The infants were turned over family members.
Jail records don’t list attorneys for either woman.

New Surveillance Video Shows Man Wanted In Slashing Of Boy In Bronx Mosque  Newly released surveillance footage reveals a man wanted in connection with the slashing of a young boy inside a mosque in the Bronx.
The disturbing incident occurred during evening prayers at the mosque located on East 198th Street.
The video captures the suspect entering the mosque premises just before the attack took place.
In the footage, the man is seen approaching the 9-year-old boy from behind and swiftly slashing his face with a sharp object.
The boy, who was taken by surprise, can be seen recoiling in pain as the perpetrator makes a hasty exit from the scene.
Witnesses rushed to the boy's aid, providing immediate assistance before emergency services arrived.
“Were you scared?” CBS2’s Scott Rapoport asked the boy, who replied “Yes.” The incident left the child with seven stitches.
Surveillance video shows the man fleeing the mosque shortly after.

VALENCIA, Spain — The Egyptian Football Federation says Mohamed Salah's shoulder injury will not keep him out for longer than three weeks, meaning he should be fit to play at least some part in the country's World Cup campaign.
Salah sustained the injury during Liverpool's Champions League final defeat to Real Madrid on Saturday, sparking fears that the prolific forward could miss the tournament in Russia.
The Egyptian national team doctor, Mohamed Abou El-Ela, expressed optimism about Salah's recovery, stating that the Liverpool star's absence is not expected to extend beyond a three-week period.
This news comes as a relief to Egyptian fans and the team's coaching staff, who were concerned about the impact of losing their talismanic player for the World Cup.
However, despite the positive prognosis, Salah's return timeline remains tight.
That could still rule him out of Egypt's opening World Cup match on June 15 against Uruguay, with their second against hosts Russia coming four days later.
CLEVELAND (AP) — Authorities say two children and two adults are unaccounted for after an overnight house fire in Cleveland.
Firefighters say a woman believed to be the children's mother escaped the fire early Tuesday morning by jumping from the home on the city's east side.
She was taken to a hospital, and information about her condition wasn't immediately released.
The blaze broke out around 2 a.m., quickly engulfing the residence in flames.
Fire crews arrived at the scene to find the structure fully involved, making it difficult to conduct an immediate search for the missing individuals.
Efforts to contain the fire were hampered by strong winds in the area.
Investigators are working to determine the cause of the fire, while family members and neighbors anxiously await any updates on the fate of the missing family members.
The community has come together to support each other during this difficult time as hopes remain for a positive outcome.
In a tragic incident, a man in his 70s has lost his life in a car crash in County Monaghan.
The collision occurred on the N2 road near Castleblayney yesterday evening.
Emergency services rushed to the scene, but despite their efforts, the driver was pronounced dead at the scene.
The identity of the victim has not been released pending notification of family members.
The circumstances surrounding the crash are still under investigation, and it is unclear at this time what may have led to the collision.
Garda forensic collision investigators are examining the crash site and local diversions are in place.
The local coroner has been notified.
Anyone with information has been asked to contact Castleblayney Garda Station on 042 974 7902, the Garda Confidential Line on 1800 666 111 or any garda station.
In a stunning turn of events, a UK lord has left Parliament in disbelief by resigning due to being late for a session.
Lord Michael Bates, a Conservative member of the House of Lords, shocked his colleagues by apologizing for his tardiness and promptly announcing his resignation on Wednesday.

The unexpected incident unfolded during the session when Lord Bates stood up to address the chamber, expressing his deep regret for not being present to respond to a fellow member's question on an important issue.
His apology took a surprising turn as he declared, "I am thoroughly ashamed" and stated his intention to offer his resignation on the spot.
As Lord Bates made his decision known, the atmosphere in the Lords chamber turned to one of astonishment.
Former Foreign Secretary William Hague, who now serves in the upper chamber, voiced hope that Lord Bates, known for his two decades of dedicated public service, would reconsider his resignation.

This move marks a remarkable exit for Lord Bates, who had previously made headlines in 2016 by resigning from a government position to embark on a charitable mission of walking 2,000 miles (3,200 kilometers) across South America.
International Development Minister Michael Bates apologized to another member "for my discourtesy for not being in my place to answer her question on a very important matter."
Bates said Wednesday he was "thoroughly ashamed" and "shall be offering my resignation."
With that, he walked out of the Lords chamber to the astonishment of other members.
Former Foreign Secretary William Hague, who now sits in Parliament's upper chamber, said he hoped "my noble friend, who has given 20 years of strong public service" would reconsider.
Bates quit a previous government position in 2016 to walk 2,000 miles (3,200 kilometers) across South America for charity.
There's no question that the Snapchat redesign prompted harsh criticism -- when your stock price drops because Kylie Jenner said she'd stopped using your app, you sit up and take notice.
Snap may be trying to appease critics by reverting to the old ways.
It's not certain that Stories use has dropped as a result of the split, but it wouldn't be surprising.
And as Recode observed, there's a chance that Snap would use its unified Stories as a way to pitch professional content.
If you have to glance at the latest big-name shows in order to catch your friend's concert snap, you might be more inclined to watch those shows.
Snapchat has announced that it will be backtracking on its redesign to highlight friends' Stories, a move that aims to address user feedback and improve the overall user experience.
The company faced backlash from users following the initial redesign, with many expressing frustration over the changes that made it difficult to navigate the app and view content from friends.
By reverting to the previous format that prioritizes friends' Stories, Snapchat hopes to regain user trust and engagement.
The decision to reverse the redesign underscores Snapchat's commitment to listening to its user base and making changes based on their feedback.
This move also reflects the competitive nature of the social media landscape, where platforms constantly evolve to meet user expectations and preferences.
As Snapchat continues to refine its user interface and features, it remains to be seen how these changes will impact user engagement and the platform's overall growth.
The family of a U.S. man jailed in Venezuela is pleading for his release amidst growing health concerns.
Matthew Johnson, a teacher from Idaho, was detained on charges of espionage, which his family vehemently denies.
Johnson's health has deteriorated in prison, with reports of inadequate medical care and poor living conditions.
His loved ones fear for his well-being and are urging the U.S. government to intervene.
Johnson's case has garnered international attention, with human rights organizations calling for his release.
The U.S. State Department has expressed concern over his treatment and is working towards a resolution.
Johnson's family remains hopeful that he will be reunited with them soon and receive the medical attention he urgently needs.

In October, flight engineer Joe Acaba made an historic contact with the Maria Montessori Institute Educational Unit in San Cristobal, Venezuela: the first-ever educational ham radio contact in that country’s history, courtesy of the Amateur Radio on International Space Station program.
Here’s a look at the excitement on the ground as more than a dozen elementary and middle school students got their chance to talk to a man in space.
Tragedy struck a family in Texas as gas poisoning claimed the lives of four children, with others left fighting for survival.
The incident, which occurred in a home in an undisclosed location, has left the community in shock and mourning.
Emergency services were called to the scene in the early hours of the morning, responding swiftly to the medical emergency.

Larry Davis, a spokesperson for the local authorities, confirmed the devastating news, revealing that one child was pronounced dead at the scene while three others succumbed to the effects of the gas at the hospital.
The identities and ages of the victims have not been disclosed, leaving many unanswered questions swirling in the air.
In the aftermath of this heartbreaking event, family members and first responders are also receiving medical attention as they grapple with the aftermath of this tragic loss.
Larry Davis said in a statement Monday that crews responded to a medical call at the home about 5 a.m. One child died at the scene and three others died at a hospital.
Officials didn’t release any identifying information, including the children’s ages.
Other family members and first responders are being treated.
VALDOSTA, Ga. (AP) — Authorities say a silo used to store pecan shells has exploded in south Georgia, shattering windows at businesses blocks away.
No injuries have been reported.

Workers said nearby buildings shook just before 1 p.m. Wednesday when the silo exploded outside the offices of South Georgia Pecan in Valdosta, a city of 56,000 people near the Georgia-Florida state line.
The explosion sent a plume of smoke and debris into the air, causing concern among residents and business owners in the area.
Emergency responders quickly arrived at the scene to assess the situation and ensure the safety of everyone in the vicinity.
Twisted metal littered a parking lot.
The cause of the blast wasn't immediately determined.
The U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration has reported more than 500 silo explosions in the U.S. since 1976.
Dust collecting in agricultural silos can be highly combustible and may ignite like gunpowder if triggered by a spark.
___ Information from: The Valdosta Daily Times, http://valdostadailytimes.com/
The Golden State Warriors faced yet another setback in their season as Draymond Green became the latest player to suffer an injury.
The team had been hoping to turn their fortunes around after a series of injuries had already plagued their roster.
Well, that was the case right up until Green suffered an injury that ended up causing him to leave the game early.
Green tried to contest a Danny Green layup in the second quarter of the game and took a shot to the midsection.
The impact of Green's absence was immediately felt on the court, as his defensive presence and playmaking abilities were sorely missed.
Green had been a key component of the Warriors' lineup, providing leadership and versatility on both ends of the floor.
His injury further complicates an already challenging season for the team, as they struggle to find consistency amidst a string of setbacks.
As Green receives treatment and the extent of his injury is assessed, the Warriors will have to regroup and find ways to fill the void left by his absence.

With the team already dealing with multiple injuries, they will need to rely on their depth and resilience to navigate through this latest setback and stay competitive in the tough Western Conference.

FOX Sports Sun’s Rich Hollenberg and Orestes Destrade talk about Brad Miller’s second inning error that eventually led to three unearned for the Boston Red Sox.
The pivotal mistake occurred during the Rays' game against the Red Sox, altering the course of the match.
Despite Tampa Bay's strong efforts, the error opened the door for the Red Sox to capitalize and secure a significant advantage in the game.
The Red Sox wasted no time in seizing the opportunity presented by Miller's error, swiftly turning the game in their favor.

A federal lawsuit accuses the ex-wife of Oklahoma energy tycoon T. Boone Pickens of racial discrimination at her rural Nevada dude ranch.

The lawsuit claims that the owner of Mustang Monument, Madeleine Pickens, asked the ranch's chef to prepare "black people food" for an event, leading to allegations of racial insensitivity and discrimination.
The chef, Armand Appling, alleges that he was subjected to a hostile work environment at the ranch, where he was the only African American employee.
According to the lawsuit, Appling was asked by Pickens to cook food that was stereotypically associated with black people, which made him uncomfortable and offended.
He alleges he was fired 2014 in retaliation for complaining about a hostile work environment.
Pickens’ lawyers say the comments were not racially motivated.
At worst, they say, the remarks were rude and insensitive.
Several arrests were made after a large 'Abolish ICE' sign was unfurled from the Statue of Liberty in New York City.
The sign, which called for the abolishment of Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE), caused a stir among visitors and officials alike.
ICE is a division of the Department of Homeland Security whose officers arrest and deport unauthorized immigrants inside the U.S., among other duties.
Activists with the group Rise and Resist say they hung the banner to protest U.S. immigration policy.
They oppose President Donald Trump's administration and advocate ending deportations and family separations at the U.S.-Mexico border.
Law enforcement swiftly responded to the incident, leading to the arrests of several individuals involved in the protest.
The incident highlights the ongoing debate and activism surrounding immigration policies in the United States.
Gabrielle Union and Will Packer stop by the V studios to talk about their new movie Breaking In.
The dynamic duo shared insights about the making of the intense thriller, which showcases Union in a powerful lead role.
Directed by James McTeigue, Breaking In follows a mother's fight to protect her family when they become the target of a group of criminals during a home invasion.

Union's portrayal of a determined and resilient mother resonates with audiences seeking empowering narratives.
Packer, known for producing hit films like Girls Trip and Ride Along, praised Union's performance and highlighted the film's gripping storyline that keeps viewers on the edge of their seats.
Breaking In promises to deliver heart-pounding action and suspense while also showcasing themes of family and strength.
Fans of Union and Packer can look forward to experiencing their collaboration in Breaking In, set to captivate audiences with its thrilling storyline and standout performances.

Nigerian Army of ‘Operation Lafiya Dole’ in the north east on Friday night made a heavy breakthrough when it arrested a Caretaker Chairman of Mafa Local Government Area of Borno state, Alhaji Shettima Lawan Maina for hiding a top Boko Haram Commander (name withheld) in his house at 1000 housing estate along Maiduguri- Damaturu- Kano road.

Already the source said, both the top Boko Haram Commander and the Chairman have been detained in a military facility to enable thorough investigation as to how a wanted terrorist will sneak into the house of the Chairman, knowing fully well, that politicians of such caliber do not usually allow access to their house of abode.

NEW YORK (AP) — Millions of workers at small businesses will be distracted in the coming months by a series of big sporting events: the Super Bowl, Olympics, NCAA basketball and World Cup soccer.
Some company owners realize that trying to eliminate sports talk or forbidding staffers to watch games is demoralizing and also difficult to achieve.
So as long as there isn't too much Monday morning quarterbacking or time spent in front of the office TV, bosses will go easy on fans.
Small businesses understand the importance of keeping their employees engaged and motivated.
Allowing sports fans to enjoy these major events can boost morale and create a positive work environment.
By embracing the sports fever, companies can foster a sense of camaraderie among employees and even organize fun activities around the games.
Ultimately, striking a balance between work and play can lead to increased productivity and a happier workforce.
Small businesses are demonstrating that a little sports distraction can go a long way in keeping employees motivated and engaged.

HAMILTON, Bermuda (AP) — The Latest on the American student reported missing in Bermuda (all times local): 5:30 p.m. A police spokesman in Bermuda says authorities have found a body amid a search for a U.S. student who disappeared after a rugby tournament on the British island territory.
Spokesman Dwayne Caines did not disclose any details about the discovery and did not confirm that the body was that of 19-year-old Mark Dombroski.
The Bermuda Police Service said a news conference would be held later Monday.
Authorities and members of Dombroski's family had been searching Bermuda for the young man in a wooded area known as The Arboretum.
The discovery of the body has heightened concerns and brought a sense of tragedy to the ongoing search efforts.
Mark Dombroski, a student from the United States, was last seen after leaving a local establishment popular with rugby players.
His disappearance sparked a widespread search involving local authorities and volunteers combing through various parts of the island.
The community has rallied together to support the efforts to locate Dombroski, with many expressing hope for his safe return.
The news of the body found has cast a somber mood over the search operation, as authorities work to confirm the identity of the deceased individual and provide updates to the public.
Stay tuned for further developments as the investigation unfolds.
MEXICO CITY (AP) — Mexico's national security commissioner says respected journalist Javier Valdez was killed last year because of his work.
Valdez, known for his fearless reporting on drug trafficking and organized crime, was gunned down in the state of Sinaloa, where he co-founded the newspaper Riodoce.
Valdez's murder sent shockwaves through Mexico's journalism community, highlighting the dangers faced by reporters covering sensitive topics.
The official statement confirms what many suspected: Valdez was targeted for his investigative journalism that exposed the influence of drug cartels in the region.
The authorities have pledged to continue investigating the case and bringing those responsible to justice.
Valdez's tragic death serves as a stark reminder of the risks journalists face while pursuing the truth in a country plagued by violence and corruption.

Sports News of Monday, 14 August 2017 Source: GHANAsoccernet.com 2017-08-14 Sam Mensah Ghanaian defender Samuel ‘Mensiro’ Mensah has bemoaned Ostersunds FK profligacy in 2-2 stalemate against IF Hammarby in the Swedish Allsvenskan League on Sunday.
Despite an impressive performance on the field, Ostersunds FK was unable to secure a victory against IF Hammarby, leaving Samuel Mensah frustrated with the missed opportunity.
The match was filled with action and excitement as both teams fought hard to secure the three points.
Mensah, known for his defensive prowess, expressed his disappointment with Ostersunds FK's inability to capitalize on their chances and convert them into goals.
The team's profligacy in front of goal ultimately cost them a much-needed win.
The Ghanaian defender highlighted the importance of converting scoring opportunities in such competitive matches, emphasizing the need for better efficiency in the final third.
Mensah acknowledged the efforts of his teammates but stressed the need for improvement in finishing to secure positive results in future games.
Despite the draw, Mensah remains optimistic about Ostersunds FK's performance in the league and is determined to work harder to ensure better outcomes in the upcoming matches.
The team will look to learn from this experience and make necessary adjustments to achieve success in their future fixtures.

SE Lithuanian Airports announced (05-Oct-2017) the Lithuanian Government created a new strategic committee, tasked with running the proposed concession of Kaunas International Airport, Palanga International Airport and Vilnius International Airport.
As previously reported by CAPA, the Government approved draft guidelines for the concessions in 2016.
The strategic committee aims to oversee the concession process, ensuring transparency and efficiency in the selection of suitable concessionaires.

This move is part of the government's broader strategy to enhance the competitiveness and operational efficiency of the airports while attracting private sector investments to support their development.
The concession of these key airports is expected to bring in new opportunities for growth, modernization, and improved services, benefiting both the airports and the traveling public.
The strategic committee's establishment underscores the government's commitment to driving the aviation sector's growth and ensuring sustainable development in Lithuania.
SEATTLE (AP) – Boeing plans to shift another work group away from the Puget Sound region.
The Seattle Times reports (https://goo.gl/awwrNu ) the company confirmed Wednesday the work shifting to Mesa, Arizona, could involve hundreds of jobs.
The changes will affect Boeing’s Shared Services Group, which employs about 3,000 people and provides support services to Boeing’s corporate and production units.
This move is part of Boeing’s broader strategy to streamline operations and cut costs.
The aerospace giant has been facing increasing pressure to improve efficiency amid fierce competition and a challenging market landscape.
By consolidating certain functions in Mesa, Boeing aims to optimize its resources and enhance operational effectiveness.
Boeing’s decision to relocate a significant portion of its Shared Services Group underscores the company’s commitment to adapting to market demands and positioning itself for long-term success.
While the move may lead to job displacement in the Puget Sound region, Boeing is working closely with employees to facilitate a smooth transition and provide support during this period of change.
Boeing aims to complete the reorganization by 2020.
Group president Beverly Wyse says it’s too early to know how many jobs will be moved.
Indian tycoon Vijay Mallya has been arrested in the UK on fraud charges.

Mallya, known for his role in the liquor industry and former owner of the now-defunct Kingfisher Airlines, has been under scrutiny for financial irregularities totaling a staggering 94 billion rupees ($1.45 billion).
The arrest comes after a prolonged legal battle, with India's Enforcement Directorate seeking Mallya's extradition to face charges in his home country.
Mallya's arrest in London marks a significant development in the case, as Indian authorities have been pushing for his return to face justice.
The tycoon has been accused of financial misconduct and defaulting on loans, leading to the collapse of his business empire.
The legal proceedings following his arrest are expected to shed light on the alleged fraud and mismanagement that have surrounded Mallya's business dealings.
A statement from the Metropolitan Police in London says Mallya was arrested after appearing in a police station, and will appear in court later Tuesday.

India’s Enforcement Directorate, now investigating the liquor baron’s debts totaling 94 billion rupees ($1.45 billion), asked a New Delhi court last year to demand Mallya’s presence during legal proceedings.
At the time, it said Mallya was not cooperating with investigators, and three times ignored their summons to give evidence.
In a recent development, a judge is currently deliberating on whether a Baton Rouge Police Department officer can proceed with a lawsuit against Black Lives Matter protesters.
The officer alleges damages and injuries sustained during a protest event organized by the activist group.
The case has sparked debate over the rights of law enforcement officers to seek legal recourse in such situations and the boundaries of peaceful protest.
Legal experts are closely monitoring the proceedings, as the outcome could set a precedent for future lawsuits involving similar circumstances.
The judge's decision will likely have far-reaching implications for both law enforcement officers and protesters exercising their First Amendment rights.
Stay tuned for updates on this developing story as the court's ruling could have significant implications for police-protester interactions in Baton Rouge and beyond.

Former UFC heavyweight champion Brock Lesnar has officially informed the UFC of his retirement from competition.
Lesnar, who last fought in the UFC in July 2016, submitted his retirement paperwork to the promotion, signaling the end of his MMA career.
The 43-year-old Lesnar had a successful run in the UFC, capturing the heavyweight title in just his fourth professional fight.
Known for his immense strength and wrestling background, Lesnar became a major draw for the organization and headlined several high-profile events during his tenure.
However, Lesnar's MMA career was not without controversy.
He faced a suspension for testing positive for a banned substance following his UFC 200 bout against Mark Hunt in 2016.
The suspension was later frozen when Lesnar announced his retirement, but it would have required him to serve the remaining five months had he decided to return to competition.
Lesnar’s decision to retire means he has been removed from USADA’s drug-testing pool, which monitors the fighters year-round.
If Lesnar decides to return to competition, he would have to serve the remaining five months of his suspension.
MADRID — Real Madrid has denied reaching an agreement to sign France forward Kylian Mbappe from Paris Saint-Germain.

The Spanish club released a statement Wednesday calling reports of an agreement between Madrid and PSG “completely false.” Madrid says it “has not made any offer to PSG or the player and condemns the spreading of this type of information that has not been proven by the parties concerned.” The denial comes two days after Madrid dismissed a report that it had offered to buy Neymar from PSG for a world record transfer of 310 million euros ($360 million).
The statement from Real Madrid is a clear response to recent speculation surrounding their potential transfer dealings with Paris Saint-Germain.
The rumors had suggested that a deal was in place for Mbappe to make a sensational move to the Spanish capital.
However, Madrid has moved swiftly to quash these reports and reaffirm that no such agreement exists.

This development will come as a disappointment to many Real Madrid fans who had been eagerly anticipating the arrival of Mbappe, widely regarded as one of the most talented young players in world football.
The club's statement serves as a reminder of the importance of accurate reporting in the world of sports transfer news, urging caution against the dissemination of unverified information.
As the summer transfer window continues, it remains to be seen how the situation will unfold and whether Real Madrid will pursue other targets to strengthen their squad ahead of the new season.

Justice, the male, has the crucial job of catching fish and bringing them for his mate and hatchlings," said Earth Conservation Corps in a statement on its website.A naming contest is forthcoming, but details about it have not been announced at this time.
Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin has taken a second emergency step to avoid hitting the federal borrowing limit, as he waits for Congress to address the debt ceiling issue.
Mnuchin announced that he would suspend investments in certain government retirement funds in order to free up cash to keep the government running.
This move follows an earlier decision by Mnuchin to halt sales of state and local government securities.
The U.S. government is fast approaching its debt ceiling, and without congressional action, it risks defaulting on its obligations.
Mnuchin has emphasized the urgency of raising the debt limit to prevent severe economic consequences.
Mnuchin has said he will employ various "extraordinary measures" to buy time until Congress raises the limit.

The Syrian government has attributed recent power cuts in the capital city of Damascus to the actions of militants.
The state-run news agency reported that the electricity network had been targeted by "terrorist groups" operating in the area.
These power outages have caused significant disruptions to daily life, with residents left without electricity for extended periods.
The government's statement comes amid ongoing conflict in various parts of the country, including the Barada Valley northwest of Damascus.
The area has been a focal point of fighting between government forces and rebel groups.
The government has accused these militants of deliberately targeting critical infrastructure, including the power supply, in an attempt to destabilize the region.
Fighting has raged in the water-rich Barada Valley northwest of Damascus over the past two weeks.
The Fatah al-Sham Front and the Islamic State group are not included in the truce.
It cost taxpayers $14.5 million to defend Mayor de Blasio and his aides in federal and state investigations of his shady fundraising practices, it was revealed on Monday.

Corporation Counsel Zachary Carter revealed the figure during a City Council budget hearing, where he also said that de Blasio’s personal law firm, Kramer Levin Naftalis and Frankel LLP, billed $2.2 million alone.
Carter said he did not expect any additional bills.
The mayor initially pledged to pay for his own defense, at one point saying he would raise the money through a legal defense fund.

But when the city’s Conflicts of Interest Board determined he would have to follow strict limits — which include a prohibition on donations larger than $400 from people who have business before the city — the mayor suddenly reversed course and announced he’d put his mound of legal bills on the taxpayers’ tab.
The revelation sparked outrage among taxpayers who questioned the ethics of using public funds to defend the mayor in a case involving alleged misconduct.
Critics argue that de Blasio should be held personally accountable for the costs incurred due to his actions.
The substantial amount spent on legal fees has raised concerns about transparency and accountability in government spending, especially when it involves high-profile officials.
As the investigation continues, the public will be closely monitoring how taxpayer money is being utilized in this ongoing legal battle.

Football fans in the Lehigh Valley may need to prepare for a snowy Super Bowl Sunday, as weather forecasts suggest the possibility of winter weather hitting the region.
Higher amounts, about 4 inches, are forecast for the Pocono Mountains, according to the National Weather Service.

The timing for precipitation's arrival looks good for Sunday night plans, as the system moves off to the east "rather quickly" during the early evening, says Bobby Martrich, with the Eastern PA Weather Authority in Allentown.
While the exact amounts and timing may vary as the weekend approaches, residents are advised to stay updated on the latest weather forecasts and be prepared for potential snowfall.
Road conditions could be impacted, so drivers are urged to use caution if traveling before, during, or after the game.

As preparations for the big game are underway, it seems that Mother Nature may have a surprise in store for the Lehigh Valley this Super Bowl Sunday.

WORTHINGTON, Ohio (AP) — Police say an Ohio high school student faces criminal charges after officers found a handgun in a backpack on the school campus.
The unidentified student was arrested Thursday morning at Thomas Worthington High School outside of Columbus.
Worthington police say the student will be charged with felony possession of a deadly weapon in a school safety zone and misdemeanor charges of carrying a concealed weapon and inducing panic.
Police are investigating whether a second student had the gun earlier in the day.
The incident has raised concerns about school safety and the presence of firearms on campus.
Worthington school officials have reassured parents and students that they are cooperating fully with the police investigation and are committed to maintaining a secure learning environment.
The school district is also reviewing its safety protocols to prevent similar incidents in the future.
The community is urged to remain vigilant and report any suspicious activity to authorities promptly.

India’s finance ministry has called for a meeting of primary dealers in New Delhi on Wednesday to discuss its near record bond-sale program for the new fiscal year, according to people with knowledge of the matter.
The meeting comes as the government aims to raise funds in the face of increasing borrowing costs and a challenging economic environment.
The primary dealers, a crucial link between the government and bond investors, will play a key role in facilitating the bond sales and ensuring smooth market operations.
The recent turmoil in the bond market has raised concerns about the government's ability to meet its borrowing targets.
The meeting is expected to address strategies to manage the upcoming bond sales effectively and attract investor interest.
With bond yields on the rise and market sentiment fragile, the government is looking to reassure investors and maintain stability in the bond market.
All the people asked not to be named as they aren’t authorized to speak publicly.
Finance Ministry spokesman D.S.
Malik didn’t immediately respond to a request for comments.
The central government cut back on the size of several bond sales and canceled others in December and January as a rout in debt markets deepened.
State-run banks, the biggest holders of the securities, have stayed away after incurring losses amid the selloff.
India’s bonds have slumped for seven straight months, the longest stretch in two decades.
A rising debt supply, climbing global yields, faster inflation and the prospect of higher interest rates have all helped sour sentiment.

TEHRAN, Iran — A top adviser to Iran’s Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, is proposing Iran resume its uranium enrichment in the wake of the U.S. withdrawal from the nuclear deal between world powers and Tehran.
The adviser, Ali Akbar Velayati, emphasized that Iran should be prepared to quickly ramp up its enrichment capacity if necessary.
This move comes amid escalating tensions between the U.S. and Iran, with the Trump administration imposing stringent sanctions on Tehran.
Velayati's statement underscores Iran's defiance against the U.S. pressure and its commitment to advancing its nuclear capabilities.
The proposal to push for uranium enrichment signals a shift in Iran's nuclear policy and a willingness to challenge the restrictions imposed by the international community.
The situation remains fluid as Iran navigates the complexities of its nuclear program amidst heightened geopolitical tensions.
ABU DHABI, United Arab Emirates (AP) — Jordanian-Palestinian writer Ibrahim Nasrallah has won the International Prize for Arabic Fiction with a novel about humanity's capacity for savagery.
"The Second War of the Dog" was named winner at a ceremony Tuesday in the Emirates capital, Abu Dhabi.
Set in a dystopian future society, the book centers on an opponent of the regime who descends into brutal nihilism.
Nasrallah's novel delves into the dark realms of human nature, exploring themes of power, corruption, and the consequences of unchecked authority.

The story follows the protagonist's transformation from a principled dissenter to a figure consumed by violence and despair, reflecting the fragility of societal structures and the potential for individuals to be shaped by their environments.
The International Prize for Arabic Fiction recognizes outstanding literary works that captivate audiences with their depth and relevance.
Nasrallah's win highlights the enduring impact of dystopian narratives in shedding light on contemporary issues and provoking reflection on the complexities of human behavior.
Congratulations to Ibrahim Nasrallah on this well-deserved recognition for his thought-provoking and impactful contribution to Arabic literature.

INGLEWOOD, Calif. — Queens of the Stone Age frontman Joshua Homme has apologized after a photographer claimed the singer kicked her camera while she photographed the band’s concert in Southern California.
The incident occurred during the band’s performance at the Forum in Inglewood on Saturday night.
Photographer Lauren was reportedly taking photos in the pit when Homme kicked her camera, which hit her in the face and left her bruised.
Homme said on Twitter Sunday that he was “in a state of being lost in performance” and thought he was kicking lighting equipment on state.
He says it was unintentional and he hopes Lauren accepts his apology.
Emails seeking further comment from Homme’s representatives were not immediately returned.
In a bizarre yet fascinating turn of events, an Oklahoma veterinarian successfully removed a staggering 21 pacifiers from the belly of a dog named Dovey.
The incident unfolded when Dovey's owners noticed that their fur baby was showing signs of discomfort and unusual behavior, prompting them to seek medical attention.
Dr. Chris Rispoli, the veterinarian at Gentle Care Animal Hospital, performed an X-ray on Dovey, revealing a shocking discovery - a belly full of pacifiers.
The pacifiers, belonging to the couple's newborn baby, had gone missing over the past few months, leaving the family puzzled until this unexpected revelation.
With swift and delicate precision, Dr. Rispoli conducted a surgical procedure to extract the 21 pacifiers from Dovey's stomach, ensuring the dog's safety and well-being.
Despite the unusual nature of the case, Dovey is now recovering under the loving care of her relieved owners.
Dovey is on the mend and has already gone home.
The veterinarian cautioned pet owners in a recent Facebook post that “dogs will eat anything, anytime and at any age.” —— Information from: KFOR-TV, http://www.kfor.com

MINNEAPOLIS — The Minnesota Twins have placed outfielder Byron Buxton on the 10-day disabled list with a left big toe fracture.
This comes as a blow to the Twins as Buxton has been an integral part of their outfield defense and has shown signs of improvement at the plate recently.
Buxton, known for his speed and defensive prowess, was batting .156 with four home runs and 14 RBIs in 28 games this season.
To replace Buxton on the 25-man roster, the Twins recalled right-handed pitcher Aaron Slegers from Triple-A Rochester.
Slegers made nine starts for the Red Wings, going 5-2 with a 3.27 ERA, eight walks and 31 strikeouts.
The 2017 Twins minor league pitcher of the year was recalled by the Twins earlier this season, but did not appear in a game.
We just want our friend to come visit us while we’re in the hospital sometimes.
Sometimes our friends are our pets, and they’re not always allowed in the hospital.
Until today, 21-year-old Shelby Hennick from California, thought her grandma would appreciate seeing her best friend Patsy.
In a heartwarming display of love and determination, Shelby decided to sneak her grandmother's beloved dog, Patsy, into the hospital for a surprise visit.
Patsy is a 13-year-old Chihuahua who means the world to Shelby's grandmother, who was hospitalized and missing her furry companion dearly.
Despite the hospital's strict no-pet policy, Shelby ingeniously disguised Patsy as a baby by wrapping her in a blanket and carrying her like an infant.
With nerves of steel and a heart full of love, Shelby managed to sneak Patsy past hospital staff and into her grandmother's room.
The moment her grandmother laid eyes on Patsy, her face lit up with joy and gratitude.
Tears of happiness flowed freely as Patsy showered her with kisses and snuggles, providing a much-needed dose of comfort and companionship.
Shelby's act of kindness and creativity touched the hearts of many, reminding us of the powerful bond between humans and their pets, and the lengths we are willing to go for the ones we love.
Guatemala was shaken to its core as the nation mourned the tragic deaths of two young boys whose bodies were discovered in sacks.
The heartbreaking discovery of the murdered children sent shockwaves through the community, leaving many questioning how such a heinous act could occur.
The boys, identified as 11-year-old Juan Daniel Cux and 12-year-old Toc Cotzajay, were found with their throats slashed, hands and feet bound, in a disturbing display of violence.
Reports surfaced that strangers had offered the boys a ride before their disappearance, and neighbors revealed a ransom demand had been made.
The chilling details surrounding the boys' deaths heightened the sense of fear and outrage among residents.
The brutal nature of the crime left many demanding justice for the innocent victims.
As the community gathered to bid farewell to the young boys, a somber procession made its way to the cemetery.
White balloons floated in the air as a banner bearing the words "Enough Violence, We Want Justice" led the way.
The boys' caskets were escorted by a parade of grieving residents, united in their call for an end to the senseless violence that claimed the lives of Juan Daniel and Toc Cotzajay.
The boys' throats had been slashed and their hands and feet bound.
There were reports that strangers had offered them a ride, and neighbors reported a ransom demand was made.
The boys' caskets were accompanied to a cemetery by a parade of residents bearing white balloons and a banner reading "Enough Violence, We Want Justice."
"These children were without sin," said Toc Cotzajay's mother, Maria Eurelia Toc.
ATLANTA (AP) — Two Atlanta men have been sentenced for illegally buying and trafficking at least three dozen guns from Georgia to Trinidad and Tobago.
The U.S. attorney's office in Atlanta says Errol Alfred, known as "Major," was sentenced Thursday to five years in prison.
Kerry Fernandez, known as "Trini," was sentenced April 19 to two years and three months.
Both had previously pleaded guilty to charges including conspiring to smuggle firearms out of the U.S.

The men were involved in a scheme where they purchased firearms from licensed dealers using fake identification and then shipped the weapons to Trinidad and Tobago without the required export licenses.
Alfred then hid the guns in shipping barrels to smuggle them to Trinidad, where they were sold.
A third man, Jordan Dunham, in April got six months in prison for illegally purchasing some of the guns the two men shipped.
CHICAGO — The mayors of Chicago and Washington are making a friendly wager on the outcome of the National League Division Series between the Cubs and the Nationals.

Mayor Lori Lightfoot of Chicago and Mayor Muriel Bowser of Washington have agreed that the losing city's mayor will wear the winning team's jersey for a day and treat the winning mayor to a local delicacy.
With the Cubs and the Nationals set to face off in a highly anticipated series, both mayors are showing their support for their respective teams.
The friendly bet adds an extra element of excitement to the series, with fans eagerly awaiting the outcome to see which mayor will come out on top.
The wager highlights the friendly rivalry between the two cities and adds a fun twist to the playoff matchup.
Fans on both sides are sure to be watching closely to see if their team can come out victorious and claim bragging rights for their city.
A recent study has found that individuals who consume alcohol have a higher level of harmful bacteria in their mouths compared to non-drinkers.
The study, conducted by researchers at NYU School of Medicine and published in the journal Microbiome, sheds light on the impact of alcohol consumption on oral health.

"Our study offers clear evidence that drinking is bad for maintaining a healthy balance of microbes in the mouth and could help explain why drinking, like smoking, leads to bacterial changes already tied to cancer and chronic disease," says study senior investigator and epidemiologist Jiyoung Ahn, PhD.Possible explanations for drinking-related microbiome imbalances, Ahn says, could be that acids in alcoholic beverages make the oral environment hostile for certain bacteria to grow.

Another reason, she says, could be the buildup of harmful byproducts from alcohol's breakdown, including chemicals called acetaldehydes, which along with the harmful toxins in the mouth from tobacco smoke, are produced by certain bacteria, such as Neisseria.The study was published in the journal Microbiome online April 23 and led by NYU School of Medicine researchers.
The findings highlight the importance of maintaining good oral hygiene practices, especially for individuals who consume alcohol regularly.
By understanding the impact of alcohol on oral bacteria, researchers hope to develop strategies to mitigate the negative effects and promote better oral health in the population.

TAMPA, Fla. (WFLA) – Monday morning is the coldest start the Tampa Bay area has had so far this season.
Temperatures in the area will fall between 27 to 32 degrees.
The chilly weather is being attributed to a strong cold front that moved through the region over the weekend, bringing gusty winds and significantly cooler temperatures.
Residents are advised to bundle up and take precautions against the cold weather.
Frost advisories and freeze warnings have been issued for many parts of the Tampa Bay area, prompting residents to protect sensitive plants and bring pets indoors.
The National Weather Service warns of the potential for icy conditions on roadways, especially on bridges and overpasses, so drivers are urged to use caution during their morning commute.
As the day progresses, temperatures are expected to remain cool, with highs reaching only into the mid-50s.
The cold weather will be a shock for some as you head off to work and to send the kids off to school.
Keep in mind, freezing temperatures can harm vulnerable plants, animals and those sensitive to cold.
Longtime leader Milo Djukanovic has announced his candidacy for the upcoming presidential election in Montenegro scheduled for April.
Djukanovic has previously served as Montenegro's prime minister and president in several mandates since the early 1990s.
Djukanovic was premier during a tense October 2016 parliamentary election when authorities said they thwarted an attempted pro-Russian coup to prevent the Adriatic country from joining NATO.

Shire, the Irish drugmaker, announced today that it is inclined to recommend the revised bid of $64 billion from Takeda Pharmaceutical Co.
This move comes after Takeda's latest effort to acquire Shire, marking a significant development in the ongoing acquisition saga.
Takeda last week raised its offer to 47 pounds a share and lifted the cash portion of the bid after three prior proposals were rejected.
Takeda has been ramping up its takeover ambitions as Chief Executive Officer Christophe Weber faces challenges in ensuring the future of Japan’s biggest drugmaker.
With few late-stage experimental drugs in its own pipeline and a shrinking home market, Takeda needs lucrative new therapies.

A Shire takeover would bring it medicines for rare diseases such as hemophilia -- a field that’s luring a growing number of drugmakers who can charge more for unique life-saving drugs than for routine treatment.

WARREN, Ohio (WYTV) – Fire investigators are still trying to figure out who set the Powerhouse Bar and Grill on fire, but WKBN learned Friday that there could have been a break-in prior to it lighting up.
According to Chief Fire Investigator John Nussle, evidence of forced entry was discovered at the scene, suggesting that someone may have broken into the establishment before the fire was started.
Nussle stated that the investigation is ongoing, and they are working to piece together the sequence of events leading up to the blaze.
The fire, which broke out in the early hours of Thursday morning, caused significant damage to the popular bar and restaurant, leaving many in the community shocked and saddened.
Authorities are urging anyone with information to come forward to help shed light on what happened.
Anyone with information on the crime is asked to call the State Fire Marshal’s Fire and Explosion Investigation Bureau Tipline at 1-800-589-2728.
Chief Nussle said investigators have received some information, but they’re still looking for more.

Anger is mounting in Puerto Rico as residents in the town of Las Piedras are left without basic services following recent earthquakes.

The recent horror story in The Express-Times about a sociopath who took an infant and slammed its head on the floor seven times because he wouldn't stop crying, raises this question: In these "United" States, why the disparity among the states for certain types of crimes?
The sociopath got 25 to 40 years.
But in another "united" state, the driver of a get-away car, parked a quarter or a half mile from where a bank heist took place (and turned bad with several dead) was sentenced to 75 years.
The driver had no weapon on him.
What sort of "law" can be legitimate with such disparity in penalty?
It brought to mind a scene from the movie "A Man for All Seasons," wherein Thomas More, a lawyer, berates his son-in-law over unequal enforcement of the law: "What would you do?
Cut a great road through the law to get after the Devil?"
This stark contrast in sentencing between states not only highlights the inconsistency in the justice system but also questions the fundamental principles of fairness and equality under the law.
The disparity in penalties for similar crimes undermines the credibility of the legal system and erodes public trust in the judiciary.
In a country that prides itself on the rule of law, such discrepancies raise serious concerns about the integrity and impartiality of the justice system.
As citizens, we must demand a more equitable and just legal framework that ensures equal treatment for all individuals, regardless of where they reside.
Only then can we truly claim to be united under the law.

MINNEAPOLIS (AP) — Roger Goodell wants to see the mystery of the NFL's catch rule solved, and he's ensured that the process has begun.
The commissioner said at his annual Super Bowl news conference Wednesday that he personally sees that rule as the most obvious to address.
Asked about the scrutiny that NFL officiating came under this season, Goodell said "on the catch/no catch rule, we need to find a rule we think will address that.
We certainly need to get this rule right so everyone can appreciate."
He added that there were more video replay interruptions in 2017 "and I think we can look at that.
How do we make the game more attractive with less stoppages is one of the things we focus on."
Goodell's comments come amid ongoing debates and controversies regarding what defines a catch in the NFL.
The catch rule has been a point of contention for players, coaches, and fans alike, with numerous instances where seemingly clear catches were overturned upon review.
The confusion surrounding the rule has led to frustration and calls for a more definitive and consistent standard.
With Goodell's push for a thorough examination of the catch rule, there is hope that the league will work towards clarifying and simplifying the criteria for what constitutes a catch in the NFL.
This initiative reflects the league's commitment to enhancing the fan experience and ensuring that the game is officiated fairly and transparently.
As the NFL continues to evolve and adapt, addressing the catch rule is seen as a crucial step in maintaining the integrity and excitement of the sport.

Former world number one Caroline Wozniacki showcased her dominance on the tennis court as she waltzed into the third round of the tournament.
Wozniacki took control early on and did not relent as she put her 26-year-old opponent, who was spirited but well short of the world number two's quality, to the sword.

The Lakers Haven’t Shown Urgency In Trying To Trade For Kawhi Leonard  Despite the persistent rumors surrounding a potential trade for Kawhi Leonard, the Los Angeles Lakers have not displayed the level of urgency one might expect in pursuing the star player.
Speculation has been rife about Leonard's future and the possibility of him joining forces with LeBron James, yet concrete progress seems to be lacking.
Reports suggest that negotiations between the Lakers and the San Antonio Spurs have been slow-moving, with neither side showing a strong commitment to striking a deal.

Archaeologists have made a stunning discovery in London, unearthing a secret tomb containing the remains of several archbishops.
The tomb, found beneath a church, is believed to date back centuries, shedding light on the city's rich history.
Among the identified remains is that of Richard Bancroft, who served as Archbishop of Canterbury from 1604 until his death in 1610.
Bancroft became archbishop in 1604 and played a major role in production of the King James Bible.
The remains of the others have not been identified.
TORONTO, ON – The Ontario Ministry of Transportation is implementing electronic single trip permits for oversize/overweight vehicles beginning Monday, August 14.
If permit holders choose to carry an electronic version of the permit, it has to be downloaded to a handheld device or tablet before departure – or printed as a hard copy, the ministry notes.
This new system aims to streamline the permit process, reduce paperwork, and increase efficiency for carriers and enforcement agencies.
The electronic permits will be easily accessible and can be quickly verified by authorities.
Permit holders will also have the option to email the permit to enforcement officers upon request, further simplifying the inspection process.
This move towards electronic permits aligns with modern technological advancements and is expected to enhance compliance and safety on Ontario's roadways.

Those who choose to carry and surrender an electronic permit must also agree to hand over the hand-held device or tablet when requested by police or other ministry-appointed personnel carrying out provisions under the Ontario Highway Traffic Act.
They must also, on request, email the permit to the officer.
The Martin City Board has approved borrowing $11.3 million in bonds to pay for a future police headquarters, fire station and library.

During Monday night’s regular monthly meeting, Board members voted unanimously to enter into three separate loan agreements that will provide $4.5 million for the construction of a new police station, $5.5 million to fund the construction of a new library, and $1.3 million for a fire station to serve the west side of town.
These projects will be funded by USDA Rural Development Community Facilities Direct Loan and Grants.
The decision to secure the $11.3 million loan underscores the city's commitment to enhancing public safety and community resources.
The new facilities are expected to improve emergency response times and provide residents with modern, efficient library services.
Construction is set to begin in the coming months, with completion anticipated within the next two years.
The Board expressed confidence in the positive impact these developments will have on the city's infrastructure and overall quality of life for its residents.
DAYTON, Ohio (WDTN) – Dayton police are investigating after a gunshot victim shows up at Miami Valley Hospital.
According to regional dispatch, initial reports came in of a black sedan shooting at a white vehicle on West Third Street and Infirmary Road around 4-30 this afternoon.
15 minutes later, dispatch got a call from Miami Valley Hospital saying a female shooting victim showed up in their emergency room.
The victim, identified as a young woman in her early twenties, was rushed into surgery upon arrival.
Her condition remains critical.
Police are working to gather more information on the incident and are asking for any witnesses to come forward.
The motive behind the shooting is currently unknown, and investigators are actively pursuing leads to identify the suspect or suspects involved.
Right now, police are blocking off West Third Street from Elmhurst Road and Almond looking for clues.
No suspect information has been given.

KfW Ipex-Bank has structured debt finance for the 24MW Kosten wind farm in Argentina under development by Spanish outfit Grenergy Renovables.
This move marks the German bank's entry into the Argentine renewable energy market, reflecting its commitment to supporting sustainable projects globally.
The Kosten wind farm is a significant step towards Argentina's renewable energy goals, with its 20-year power purchase agreement secured through the Renovar programme.
This agreement not only ensures a stable revenue stream for the project but also contributes to Argentina's target of achieving 20% clean power by 2025.

Located in the province of Chubut, the Kosten wind farm is anticipated to be operational by the end of the second quarter of 2019, further solidifying Argentina's position in the renewable energy sector.
Kosten, which is located in the province of Chubut, is expected to be commissioned by the end of the second quarter of 2019.
It secured a 20-year power purchase agreement through the Argentinian government's Renovar programme.
Renovar awards long-term contracts for renewable generation to meet a 20% by 2025 clean power target.

- The annual polar plunge event in Fort Wayne saw a record turnout this year, with hundreds of participants braving the icy waters for a good cause.
The event, which took place at Lake James, raised funds for a local charity that supports families in need during the winter months.
Despite the frigid temperatures, the atmosphere was filled with excitement and camaraderie as participants cheered each other on before taking the plunge.
Spectators lined the shores, bundled up in blankets and sipping hot drinks as they watched the daring plungers dive into the icy waters.
Organizers were thrilled with the success of this year's event and expressed gratitude to all who participated and supported the cause.
The annual polar plunge has become a beloved tradition in Fort Wayne, bringing the community together for a fun and meaningful experience.
Boonville police are actively searching for a woman accused of child abduction.
Jerran Wilson, the mother of the child, allegedly took custody of her son in December of 2013 and failed to return him to his father.
Despite the father being granted full legal custody of the child months prior, Wilson has reportedly maintained physical control over the boy, only permitting telephone contact with the father.
Authorities have been unable to locate Wilson, with court documents indicating that her current address is unknown.
The last known residence for Wilson was in Las Vegas.
The situation has left the father distressed and seeking the safe return of his child.
According to the probable cause statement, Jerran Wilson took custody of her child in December of 2013 and never returned him to his father.
Months before, the father was granted full legal custody over the child and Wilson was granted visitation rights.
Since the abduction, Wilson has had full physical control over the child and has only allowed the father to have telephone contact with the boy.
Court documents show that Wilson's current address is unknown but she was last known to live in Las Vegas.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark.
(AP) — A 22-year-old man has been sentenced to 30 years in prison after pleading guilty to the drive-by shooting death of a 2-year-old girl in Little Rock.
The tragic incident occurred when the man, identified as John Rushing, opened fire on a residential street, resulting in the death of Ramiya Reed, an innocent toddler caught in the crossfire.
The senseless act of violence sent shockwaves through the community, prompting calls for justice and stricter gun control measures.
Rushing expressed remorse during the sentencing, acknowledging the irreparable harm caused by his actions.
The judge condemned the act as a heinous crime that robbed a family of their beloved child and emphasized the need for accountability in such cases.
Rushing will be eligible for parole after 21 years.
According to the Arkansas Democrat-Gazette , Rushing will be eligible for parole after 21 years.
A month after Ramiya's killing, 3-year-old Acen King was killed in an apparent road-rage case in Little Rock.
The alleged shooter in that case awaits trial.

The Opposition is calling for urgent action to address the issue of illegal migrants entering the country.
Members argue that the current government's approach is inadequate in dealing with the escalating numbers of asylum seekers.
Michelle Rempel, the Conservative immigration critic, emphasized the need for a more robust strategy to secure the borders and prevent unauthorized entries.
Concerns have been raised about the strain this influx is placing on resources and services.
The Opposition is urging the government to take concrete steps to address the situation promptly.
Rempel stressed the importance of protecting the integrity of Canada's immigration system and ensuring fair treatment for those who enter the country through legal channels.
Concerns were raised last week by the Quebec government over the mounting pressures caused by the tens of thousands of asylum seekers pouring into that province over the last year.

Some officials are projecting a further 400 people a day could cross into Quebec through forest paths this summer to claim asylum in Canada — a situation Rempel says will only exacerbate ongoing backlogs in the processing of refugee claims.

YAOUNDE, Cameroon (AP) — Cameroon's minister of communications says 47 suspected separatists and leaders of a group that declared the independence of English-speaking regions have been extradited from Nigeria.
Issa Tchiroma Bakary said those extradited arrived in Cameroon on Monday.
He said among them were Julius Ayuk Tabe, who in October proclaimed himself the president of Ambazonia.
The move comes as Cameroon continues to grapple with a separatist crisis in its Anglophone regions.
The separatists have been demanding independence, citing marginalization and discrimination by the Francophone-majority government.
The extradition of these individuals is seen as a significant step by the Cameroonian authorities in their efforts to quell the unrest and restore stability in the affected regions.
The extradition has sparked mixed reactions, with supporters of the separatist movement condemning the action and calling for the release of those detained.
The Nigerian government's decision to hand over the individuals has also raised questions about the diplomatic relations between the two neighboring countries.
Tempers flared during the Cubs-Pirates game on Tuesday night, as a hard slide by Joe Musgrove led to both benches emptying onto the field.
The incident occurred in the third inning when Musgrove, the Pirates' pitcher, slid aggressively into second base in an attempt to break up a double play.
The slide caused Cubs' shortstop Javier Baez to be knocked off balance, although he managed to stay on his feet and avoid falling to the ground.
Baez was knocked off balance but did not hit the ground.
No punches were thrown as both teams milled around the infield and there were no ejections.
Crew chief Gerry Davis instituted a video replay review to see if Musgrove interfered with Baez.
However, replay officials at Major League Baseball’s central office in New York informed Davis that it was not a reviewable play.
The Pirates were angered Monday when Anthony Rizzo’s slide upended catcher Elias Diaz at home plate, successfully breaking up a potential double play in the eighth inning of Chicago’s 7-0 win.
The umpiring crew and replay officials ruled Rizzo did not interfere with Diaz.
The tension between the two teams was palpable throughout the game, with emotions running high as both sides looked to gain an edge in a tightly contested matchup.
Despite the heated exchanges, the game ultimately continued without any further incidents on the field.
