In a touching statement released today, Billie Lourd, daughter of the late Carrie Fisher and Debbie Reynolds, has broken her silence following the heartbreaking deaths of her mother and grandmother.
The 24-year-old actress expressed her gratitude for the outpouring of support she has received from fans and well-wishers during this difficult time.
“Receiving all of your prayers and kind words over the past week has given me strength during a time I thought strength could not exist,” Lourd, 24, wrote today.
“There are no words to express how much I will miss my Abadaba and my one and only Momby.

Carrie Fisher, best known for her iconic role as Princess Leia in the "Star Wars" franchise, passed away on December 27, 2016, followed by her mother, legendary actress Debbie Reynolds, the very next day.
The sudden loss of both beloved Hollywood stars has left fans and the entertainment industry in mourning.
Lourd's poignant words reflect the deep bond she shared with her mother and grandmother, highlighting the profound impact they had on her life and the immense void their passing has left behind.
The young actress's strength and resilience in the face of such profound loss serve as a testament to the love and support she has received from around the world.
Former Prime Minister of Macedonia, Nikola Gruevski, has announced his resignation as the leader of the opposition party.
Gruevski, who served as the country's prime minister from 2006 to 2016, cited personal reasons for stepping down from his position.
His resignation comes at a crucial time for the opposition party as they prepare for an upcoming party congress.
Gruevski's departure marks a significant shift in Macedonia's political landscape, as he has been a prominent figure in the country's politics for many years.
His decision to resign has sparked speculation about the future direction of the opposition party and its leadership.
Meanwhile, Prime Minister Zoran Zaev's government has been actively working towards strengthening Macedonia's international ties.
Zaev's government has renewed the country's drive to join NATO and improve troubled relations with neighbor Greece.
Gruevski submitted his resignation late Sunday and the decision was formally announced Monday, two weeks ahead of a party congress.

Arconic Inc. Chief Executive Officer Klaus Kleinfeld stepped down after showing what the board of directors called “poor judgment” in sending a letter to Elliott Management Corp. amid a proxy fight.
The abrupt resignation of Kleinfeld, who has been at the helm of the manufacturing company since 2008, comes as a surprise to many in the industry.
The letter in question, sent by Kleinfeld to Elliott Management, a major shareholder of Arconic, raised concerns about the hedge fund's tactics in the proxy battle.
This move was seen as a misstep by the board of directors, leading to Kleinfeld's resignation.
In a statement, Arconic highlighted that Kleinfeld's departure was in the best interest of the company and its shareholders.
The board expressed gratitude for Kleinfeld's leadership over the years but emphasized the importance of upholding the highest standards of conduct.
The news of Kleinfeld's resignation has sparked speculation about the future direction of Arconic and who will step in to fill the vacant CEO position.
Investors and stakeholders are closely monitoring developments as the company navigates this unexpected leadership transition.
Thieves broke into the Beverly Hills Hotel room of Caitlin McHugh, actress and fiancee of actor John Stamos, stealing an estimated $165,000 worth of jewelry.
The burglary occurred on Friday when McHugh was out of the room.
Among the stolen items was the engagement ring Stamos had given her, which was reportedly valued at $75,000.
The Beverly Hills Police Department confirmed the incident and stated that they are actively investigating the theft.
McHugh, who is pregnant with the couple's first child, was understandably shaken by the violation of their privacy and loss of sentimental items.
A message seeking comment from Stamos' publicist wasn't immediately returned Saturday.
Stamos stars in Netflix's "Fuller House" and spent part of last year with The Beach Boys as a drummer.
McHugh has had guest spots on "The Vampire Diaries" and "NCIS: Los Angeles."
In a troubling development, a second Wichita Falls Independent School District (WFISD) employee is facing charges, as reported by Newschannel 6 Now in Wichita Falls, TX.
The employee, identified as Haynes Elementary Principal Cindy Underwood, has been charged with Failure to Report.

This charge stems from a Texas state law that mandates individuals in official capacities to promptly notify law enforcement and Child Protective Services upon learning about or suspecting child abuse, with a strict 48-hour window for reporting.
Wichita Falls Police Department's Crimes Against Juvenile detectives have taken action in this case, reaching out to the WFISD Police Chief to alert them before warrants were issued.
As a result, Cindy Underwood has been placed on administrative leave by WFISD.
Notably, this incident marks the second such offense involving a WFISD Principal this year, raising concerns within the community.
As investigations continue, Newschannel 6 will provide updates on this developing situation.
The authorities have not disclosed the name on the arrest warrant, underscoring the ongoing nature of this case.
Stay tuned for more information as it unfolds.
(Source: KAUZ) Wichita Falls Police have confirmed to Newschannel 6 a WFISD employee is facing a charge of Failure to Report.
Texas state law requires a person in an official capacity to notify police and Child Protective Services within 48 hours of learning about or suspecting an incident involving any abuse of a child.
WFPD says its Crimes Against Juvenile detectives did reach out to the WFISD Police Chief and made them aware of the situation before these warrants were issued.
The WFISD has confirmed Haynes Elementary Principal Cindy Underwood has been placed on administrative leave but police have not released the name on the arrest warrant.
This is the second such offense involving a WFISD Principal this year.
Stay with Newschannel 6 as we continue to learn more.

BEREA, Ohio (AP) — Browns rookie defensive end Myles Garrett, the No.
1 overall pick in this year’s draft, injured his left foot late in practice on Wednesday.
Garrett was rushing quarterback Brock Osweiler during a two-minute drill when he went down in the backfield.
He stayed on the ground for nearly a minute and was checked by a trainer and coach Hue Jackson before being helped up and hobbling to the sideline.
He did not return to practice and limped into the field house when the Browns were forced to go indoors because of inclement weather.
Garrett continued to favor his foot when he walked into the locker room.
Jackson said he would not know the extent of Garrett’s injury until he is examined by doctors.
The injury comes as a blow to the Browns, who were hopeful that Garrett would be a key player in their defense this season.
Garrett, known for his speed and agility on the field, was expected to make an immediate impact for the team.
Fans and teammates alike are anxiously awaiting further updates on Garrett's condition and hoping for a swift recovery.
Stay tuned for more information as the situation develops.
In a tense matchup between the Chicago Cubs and the Pittsburgh Pirates, tensions flared as Musgrove's hard slide into second base caused both benches to empty.
The incident occurred in the eighth inning when Musgrove slid aggressively into second, colliding with Cubs' shortstop Javier Baez in an attempt to break up a double play.
Baez took exception to the slide, leading to a heated exchange between the two teams.
Players and coaches from both sides quickly rushed onto the field, resulting in a brief but intense confrontation.
Umpires worked swiftly to restore order and prevent the situation from escalating further.
Crew chief Gerry Davis instituted a video replay review to see if Musgrove interfered with Baez.
However, replay officials at Major League Baseball's central office in New York informed Davis that it was not a reviewable play.
HandBrake 1.0.1: Enhanced Features and Fixes  HandBrake, the popular open-source video transcoder, has recently released version 1.0.1, bringing a host of new features and improvements to its users.

The update completely overhauls the official presets with new general use presets for broad compatibility and Matroska (MKV) presets (including VP9 video with Opus audio), plus new device and web presets.
(Official presets from HandBrake 0.10.x are still available under "Legacy;" any custom presets you may have previously created may not be compatible with newer versions.)

It also improves the audio/video sync engine to better handle difficult sources, adds VP9 video encoding via libvpx and Opus audio encoding/decoding via libopus, improves subtitle rendering for some languages, adds new Decomb/Deinterlace filter settings and improved defaults, improves support for importing/exporting comma-separated (.csv) chapter markers, adds support for multiple source URLs for third-party downloads, and improves drag and drop support.

Shortly after this release, Handbrake 1.0.1 was issued to fix a potential crash when using the subtitles burn feature on OS X systems prior to macOS 10.12 Sierra, resolve an issue with certain controls not updating when saving or loading a preset, and fix additional crashes.
Stay tuned for more updates and enhancements from the HandBrake team as they continue to provide the community with a powerful and reliable video transcoding tool.
There's no question that the Snapchat redesign prompted harsh criticism -- when your stock price drops because Kylie Jenner said she'd stopped using your app, you sit up and take notice.
Snap may be trying to appease critics by reverting to the old ways.
It's not certain that Stories use has dropped as a result of the split, but it wouldn't be surprising.
In a move to address user feedback and possibly regain lost ground, Snapchat has announced a backtrack on its redesign to once again highlight friends' Stories.
The redesign, which initially separated friends' Stories from content by publishers and celebrities, faced widespread backlash from users who found the new layout confusing and cumbersome.
By returning to the previous format where friends' Stories are given more prominence, Snapchat aims to improve user experience and engagement.
The decision to revert the design change reflects the company's responsiveness to user preferences and demonstrates a willingness to listen to feedback.
This strategic move could help Snapchat win back users who were dissatisfied with the redesign and attract new users who may have been deterred by the initial changes.
Time will tell whether this backtrack will be successful in restoring Snapchat's popularity and growth in the highly competitive social media landscape.

CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla. (AP) — Want the world’s best, up-close view of a rocket launch without being right there at the pad?
For the first time, cameras will provide live 360-degree video of a rocket heading toward space.
NASA will provide the 360 stream Tuesday as an unmanned Atlas rocket blasts off from Cape Canaveral, Florida, with a capsule full of space station supplies.
The stream will begin 10 minutes before the scheduled 11:11 a.m. liftoff and continue until the rocket is out of sight.
This groundbreaking initiative by NASA aims to offer viewers an immersive experience, allowing them to witness the rocket launch from every angle.
The live 360-degree video feed will be accessible on NASA's official website, enabling space enthusiasts worldwide to feel as though they are part of the action.
The use of 360-degree cameras will provide a unique perspective, capturing the intensity and beauty of the launch in unprecedented detail.
Viewers will have the opportunity to pan, tilt, and zoom the camera to explore different aspects of the launch site, enhancing their viewing experience.
Don't miss this historic event as NASA revolutionizes the way we observe rocket launches, bringing space exploration closer to audiences around the globe.
Member of Knesset Oren Hazan has issued a public plea to fellow Likud party members Sharren Haskel and Yehuda Glick, urging them to vote in favor of the Supermarket Law.
The proposed law aims to regulate the operation of supermarkets on Shabbat, a topic that has sparked heated debate within the coalition.
Hazan emphasized the importance of unity within the party and the coalition, highlighting the need to consider the interests of traditional and religious constituents.
While acknowledging that adjustments could be made to the legislation, he stressed the need to prioritize coalition stability over individual disagreements.
"Yehuda and Sharren, we in the Likud represent a great deal of traditional and religious people.
If we need to – we can improve the Supermarket Law, but you do not bring down a coalition over such a law.
In any event, I do not feel so good, so do us a favor: Finish the talks with Bibi and let's vote and get it over with," Hazan wrote on Twitter.

Los Angeles will pay tribute to the late Adam West, best known for his iconic portrayal of Batman, by lighting up the Bat-Signal.
The signal will shine over the city in honor of the beloved actor's contributions to the Batman legacy.
West's portrayal of the Caped Crusader in the 1960s television series left an indelible mark on popular culture, and fans around the world continue to celebrate his legacy.
Mayor Eric Garcetti announced that the Bat-Signal will illuminate the night sky at L.A.'s City Hall at 9 p.m. on Thursday.
The Bat-Signal, a symbol synonymous with Batman, serves as a beacon of hope and justice in Gotham City.
West's passing at the age of 88 has sparked an outpouring of tributes and memories from fans and colleagues alike.
Mayor Eric Garcetti says the Bat-Signal will be lit at L.A.'s City Hall at 9 p.m. Thursday.
In Batman comics, movies and TV shows, the Bat-Signal is a spotlight with the shadow of Batman's winged emblem that is shown on the night sky to call for Batman's help.
West died Friday at age 88.
Garcetti announced the event on Twitter and added the hashtag, #BrightKnight.
Batman is often referred to as the Dark Knight, but West's children said in a statement that he aspired to positivity and always saw himself as "The Bright Knight."

WASHINGTON (AP) — A nuclear reactor investment firm that once hired Michael Flynn as a security adviser is denying a report from a congressional whistleblower that Flynn sent text messages during President Donald Trump's inauguration saying the company's Mideast reactor project was "good to go" and that U.S. sanctions hobbling the project would be "ripped up."
ACME Reactor Investments released a statement refuting the allegations, claiming that there is no truth to the reported texts.
The company emphasized its commitment to compliance with all regulations and reiterated that Flynn's role was strictly advisory.
The alleged texts have sparked controversy and calls for further investigation into the interactions between Flynn, the company, and the Trump administration.
Flynn, a key figure in the Russia investigation, has not publicly commented on the matter.
David Banks/Getty Images(CHICAGO) — Chicago White Sox Pitcher Danny Farquhar is improving after undergoing surgery on Saturday following a brain aneurysm.
Farquhar sustained the aneurysm during the team’s game against the Houston Astros on Friday.
The White Sox provided an update on Farquhar's condition, stating that he is progressing well and showing signs of improvement.
The 31-year-old pitcher is currently in stable but critical condition at Rush University Medical Center in Chicago.
The team expressed gratitude for the outpouring of support and well-wishes from fans, teammates, and the baseball community.
Farquhar's teammates and coaches have been deeply affected by the incident, with many expressing their concern and support for him and his family.
The White Sox organization has rallied around Farquhar, offering their full support and assistance during this challenging time.
The road to recovery for Farquhar is expected to be long, but the positive developments in his condition are a source of hope and encouragement for all involved.
The White Sox community continues to send thoughts and prayers for Farquhar's swift and full recovery.
MADRID — Spain’s maritime rescue service says it has saved 104 migrants trying to make the perilous crossing of the Mediterranean Sea to Europe from North Africa.
The service says its rescue craft Guardamar Concepcion Arenal intercepted two boats carrying 53 and 22 migrants each overnight and early Sunday in the Strait of Gibraltar.
The migrants, including women and children, were in distress as they attempted the dangerous journey, seeking a better life in Europe.
The rescue operation was carried out swiftly, with the migrants brought safely onboard the rescue vessels and provided with necessary medical assistance.
Another rescue craft, the Salvamar Denebola, later spotted a tiny rubber boat carrying four more migrants that it took to shore.
Tens of thousands of migrants try to reach Europe each year in small smugglers’ boats unfit for the open sea, with thousands dying in the attempt.

The fight is on between two titans of combat sports as Floyd Mayweather and Conor McGregor are set to face off in what is being billed as a historic showdown.
The American boxer, Mayweather, retired in 2015 after clashing with Philippine’s Manny Pacquiao in what was termed as the ‘Fight of the Century’.
He won a staggering 49 matches and never lost a single one in his entire career that spanned almost 20 years.
40-year-old Mayweather took a u-turn on his retirement which he announced in 2008 and went on to win another 10 matches before finally hanging his gloves in 2015.
On the other hand, mixed martial artist Conor McGregor who is known for his ruthless attacking style, became UFC’s first dual-division champion last year.
The Irish fighter got his boxing license in December, 2016 which enabled him to practice his profession in the United States.

Residents of Durham gathered for a crucial meeting to address growing concerns over the proposed placement of a new Publix store in their community.

People planning to show up at the meeting are specifically upset about Publix.
A spokeswoman for Publix says the 45,000 square feet store will hire some 140 employees.
Publix recently opened new locations in Apex, Fayetteville and Wake Forest.

Two of the biggest crime gangs of Brazil began fighting last year over control of several prisons.
It's not immediately clear what sparked the latest unrest.

A New Jersey police sergeant on vacation in Florida turned into a hero when he saved a drowning toddler off a beach.
Sgt.
Sean O'Hare, from Morris Township Police Department, was enjoying his time in Florida when he noticed a commotion near the water.
Without hesitation, he sprang into action upon realizing that a young child was struggling in the water.
O'Hare quickly swam out to the toddler, who was unconscious, and brought the child back to shore.
The cop initiated CPR and was able to resuscitate the child.
An update on the child's condition was not immediately available Monday.
In a Facebook post, the Morris Township Police Department praised O'Hare's actions and called him a "true hero."
WARREN, Ohio (WYTV) – A 15-month-old stopped breathing and went into cardiac arrest after swimming in Warren Wednesday evening, according to dispatch reports.
Now police are asking why.
Officers arrived at the home in the 200 block of Homewood Avenue SE about 6:30 p.m.
Authorities are investigating the circumstances surrounding the incident, focusing on the pool where the child was swimming.
Police are working to determine if there were any safety hazards or negligence that may have contributed to the child's distress.
Neighbors expressed shock and concern over the incident, highlighting the need for increased vigilance when it comes to child safety around water.
The community is rallying together in support of the family during this difficult time, hoping for the toddler's full recovery.
Police were asked to get a sample of the pool water and treat it as a crime scene, according to dispatch.
The report said a woman at the scene was taken in for questioning.
PODGORICA, Montenegro (AP) — Police in Montenegro say they have picked up 17 migrants, including 11 Syrians, from an Italian fishing boat that sent a distress signal off the Montenegrin coast.
The migrants were rescued near the coastal town of Ulcinj after the boat encountered difficulties at sea.
Authorities provided medical assistance to the migrants, who were reported to be in good health despite their ordeal.
Police say two Moroccans, two people from Yemen, one from Afghanistan and one from Pakistan were also on the boat.
The group included four children.
It was not immediately clear where the migrants started their journey.

Montenegro has been largely spared from the migrant flow across the Balkans that peaked in 2016, with people fleeing wars and poverty in the Middle East, Africa and Asia trying to reach the Western Europe.
WASHINGTON (AP) — Congressional Democrats stand divided over whether to fight now or later about the fate of some 800,000 immigrants who came to the U.S. illegally as children.
The Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program is set to expire in March, leaving these young immigrants, known as "Dreamers," in limbo.
Some Democrats are pushing to include protections for Dreamers in the year-end budget bill, while others are concerned about the potential political fallout.
The fate of these "Dreamers" is among the trickiest issues to resolve as Washington seeks to avert a Christmas government shutdown.
For Illinois Rep. Luis Gutierrez, there is no more important issue in the year-end budget showdown.
But at the top of Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer's list of political concerns are the re-election bids of 10 Senate Democrats in states Trump won.
They want nothing to do with shutting down the government over immigration.
KENAI, Alaska (AP) – The Upper Cook Inlet had a scarce sockeye salmon harvest this year, but commercial fishers caught more coho, chum and pink salmon than expected.
The Alaska Department of Fish and Game reported that the sockeye harvest in the region was the smallest in the past decade, raising concerns among fishermen and stakeholders.
The low sockeye numbers are attributed to various factors, including warmer water temperatures affecting migration patterns and changing ocean conditions impacting the fishery.
Despite the decline in sockeye numbers, the commercial fishing industry in Upper Cook Inlet saw higher-than-anticipated catches of coho, chum, and pink salmon.
This unexpected increase in other salmon species helped offset some of the losses from the poor sockeye season.
Fishermen are hopeful that the positive trend with coho, chum, and pink salmon will continue in the upcoming seasons to support the local fishing economy.
WASHINGTON (AP) — U.S. businesses stockpiled more goods in December and posted the biggest sales increase in nearly six years.
The Commerce Department says business inventories rose a seasonally adjusted 0.4 percent in December, led by an increase in stockpiles at stores that sell food and beverages.
Auto and auto parts dealers reduced inventories 0.6 percent.
Furniture and appliance stores also cut back.
The jump in sales, up 2 percent in December, was the largest gain since March 2014.
This surge in sales suggests strong consumer demand, which is encouraging for the overall economic outlook.
The increase in inventories indicates that businesses are optimistic about future sales and are preparing to meet the expected demand.
The data reflects a positive trend in the U.S. economy as businesses appear to be gearing up for growth and expansion in the coming months.

Benefits of CHP Financial Benefits of CHP CHP represents a highly efficient use of fuel, which means lower energy costs for the user.
In the UK, taxation benefits can be obtained through avoidance of Climate Change Levy (Good Quality CHP) and the possibility of Enhanced Capital Allowances for eligible organisations.
Combined Heat and Power (CHP) systems offer numerous advantages that go beyond just cost savings.

By simultaneously generating electricity and useful heat from the same energy source, CHP technology provides increased energy efficiency compared to conventional methods of separate power and heat generation.
One of the key benefits of CHP is its environmental impact.
The technology significantly reduces greenhouse gas emissions and helps in achieving sustainability goals.
By utilizing waste heat that would otherwise be wasted in conventional power generation, CHP systems contribute to a more resource-efficient and environmentally friendly energy production process.
Moreover, CHP systems enhance energy security by providing a reliable source of power and heat.
This is especially beneficial in critical facilities such as hospitals, data centers, and industrial plants where uninterrupted energy supply is essential.
By decentralizing energy production and reducing reliance on the national grid, CHP systems improve overall energy resilience and reduce the risk of disruptions due to external factors.
In addition to the financial and environmental benefits, CHP systems also offer operational advantages such as increased energy independence and flexibility in energy management.
By producing electricity on-site, users have greater control over their energy supply and can respond more effectively to fluctuating energy prices and demand patterns.
In conclusion, the benefits of CHP extend far beyond just cost savings, encompassing environmental sustainability, energy security, and operational efficiency.

As the demand for cleaner and more resilient energy solutions continues to grow, CHP technology presents a compelling option for organizations looking to optimize their energy usage and reduce their carbon footprint.

DUBAI, United Arab Emirates (AP) — Leading Emirati rights activist Ahmed Mansoor has been sentenced to 10 years in prison and fined 1 million dirhams, or about $272,000, by an appeals court in Abu Dhabi.
The Dubai-based Gulf News reported on Wednesday that the defendant, identified as "AMS" by his initials, will also be under probation for three years after prison.

Mansoor, a prominent human rights campaigner known for his online activism, was charged with using social media to "publish false information and rumors" that "harm national unity and social harmony" according to the court's ruling.
The 52-year-old activist has been a vocal critic of the UAE government's human rights record and has advocated for political reform in the country.
Human rights organizations and activists around the world have condemned Mansoor's sentencing, calling it a blatant violation of freedom of expression.
Amnesty International has labeled Mansoor as a "prisoner of conscience" and urged the UAE authorities to release him immediately.
The sentencing of Ahmed Mansoor highlights the ongoing crackdown on dissent and freedom of speech in the United Arab Emirates.

The incident occurred outside a home, where a gathering was taking place to celebrate the start of the new year.

Health care companies led a decline in stocks on Tuesday, with prescription drug makers, drug distributors, and health insurers experiencing significant losses.
The drop was fueled by concerns over potential competition from a new venture announced by JPMorgan Chase, Amazon, and Berkshire Hathaway.
Express Scripts saw a sharp decline of 9 percent, while UnitedHealth Group sank by 4.4 percent.
This news sent ripples through the market, causing the Standard & Poor's 500 index to fall by 0.7 percent to 2,853.
The Dow Jones industrial average also slid by 0.7 percent, dropping 226 points to 26,214.
Additionally, the Nasdaq composite lost 0.8 percent, shedding 58 points to 7,407.
Bond prices fell in response to the market activity, with the yield on the 10-year Treasury note rising to 2.71 percent.

Prescription drug makers, drug distributors and health insurers posted big losses early Tuesday on fears of stiff competition from a new venture announced by JPMorgan Chase, Amazon and Berkshire Hathaway.
Express Scripts plunged 9 percent and UnitedHealth Group sank 4.4 percent.
The Standard & Poor's 500 index fell 19 points, or 0.7 percent, to 2,853.
The Dow Jones industrial average slid 226 points, or 0.7 percent, to 26,214.
The Nasdaq composite lost 58 points, or 0.8 percent, to 7,407.
Bond prices fell.

The worsening situation in southern Syria’s de-escalation zone could be among the talking points when Russian President Vladimir Putin meets with U.S. counterpart Donald Trump on July 16.

But he also said they would oppose any attempt, by the Syrian opposition, backed by the US, to create an autonomous region in southern Syria.
He said: "Favourable conditions for the refugees to return to their homes will be created only after the terrorist groups are elimated from the area."
Lavrov also said Russia was hopeful that the Putin-Trump summit could provide an opportunity for a frank conversation about issues which divide Russia and the US.
The meeting comes at a crucial time as tensions in the region continue to escalate.
The Syrian government, backed by Russia, has been making significant gains in southern Syria, causing concern among the US and its allies.
The potential discussions between Putin and Trump on the situation in southern Syria will be closely watched by international observers.
Both leaders have the power to influence the outcome in the region, and their meeting could have far-reaching implications for the future of Syria and the broader Middle East.
Stay tuned for updates on this developing story.

Video Thousands of neo-Nazi music tracks calling for genocide and the violent murder of Muslims, Jews and other groups can be easily found on the world's most popular video-sharing site, YouTube.
Despite YouTube's policies against hate speech and violent content, a recent investigation has revealed a disturbingly large collection of such music on the platform.
The tracks, often accompanied by hateful imagery and lyrics, have raised concerns about YouTube's ability to effectively moderate its content and prevent the spread of extremist ideologies.
Critics argue that YouTube needs to take more proactive measures to combat the proliferation of neo-Nazi content on its platform and protect vulnerable users from exposure to dangerous ideologies.
The revelation has sparked a debate about the responsibilities of tech companies in policing harmful content and the potential consequences of allowing such material to flourish online.
Video journalist: Natalia Zuo Reporter: Mike Wendling More details about our investigation on the BBC Trending blog.

FORT WORTH, Texas (AP) — A capital murder charge has been dismissed against a North Texas man in the death of his 2-year-old daughter after prosecutors learned her then-5-year-old brother said he caused her death.
Anthony Michael Sanders was accused of smothering his daughter, Ellie Mae, at their home in the Fort Worth suburb of Watauga in 2015.
Investigators believed Sanders held his hand over her mouth out of anger for her interrupting his computer games.
Jailed since April 2016, Sanders denied responsibility.
The case took a dramatic turn when Sanders' now 7-year-old son confessed to causing his sister's death.
The boy, whose identity remains protected due to his age, revealed that he accidentally suffocated Ellie Mae while playing with her.
This revelation led to the dismissal of the charges against Sanders, bringing a sense of relief and vindication to the family.
Sanders, who had maintained his innocence throughout the ordeal, expressed gratitude for the truth coming to light and the support he received from his loved ones.
The heartbreaking tragedy that had torn the family apart now takes on a new perspective with the exoneration of Sanders and the acknowledgment of his son's confession.
The highly-anticipated film 'Shamshera', starring Sanjay Dutt and Ranbir Kapoor, finally has a release date.
The action-packed movie is set to hit the theaters on 31st July 2020.
Fans have been eagerly waiting for this collaboration between the two talented actors, especially with Sanjay Dutt portraying Ranbir Kapoor's nemesis in the film.

The announcement was made by renowned film critic Taran Adarsh on Twitter, revealing that the movie is produced by Aditya Chopra and directed by Karan Malhotra.
The filming for 'Shamshera' is scheduled to begin by the end of 2018 and is expected to wrap up by mid-2019.
Movie enthusiasts can expect a gripping storyline and stellar performances from the cast in this much-anticipated project.
In the project, Sanjay Dutt plays Ranbir Kapoor’s nemesis and the film also stars ‘Befikre’ actor Vaani Kapoor.
Film critic Taran Adarsh took to Twitter to make the announcement.

“Ranbir Kapoor and Sanjay Dutt… #Shamshera release date finalised: 31 July 2020… Costars Vaani Kapoor… Produced by Aditya Chopra… Directed by Karan Malhotra… Starts 2018-end… Shooting will wrap by mid-2019,” he tweeted.
The Karan Malhotra-directorial is set to go on floors by the end of this year and the shooting is expected to wrap by mid-2019.
Getty Image The Golden State Warriors might have made the move of the offseason when they secured the services of DeMarcus Cousins on a one-year deal worth a hair above $5 million.

Cousins is working his way back from a ruptured achilles, but even if he takes his time and gets as close to 100 percent possible, that’s fine, because the Warriors can afford for him to take as much time as he needs.

It’s a major blow to the other 29 NBA teams, but it’s an especially tough break for the New Orleans Pelicans, which traded for Cousins prior to the 2017 NBA trade deadline and were unable to keep him on board.
As it turns out, they tried to secure his services ones more, but surprisingly enough, Cousins turned them down.
According to Marc Stein of the New York Times‘ newsletter, the Pelicans offered Cousins a two-year deal prior to their season ending.
This deal was reportedly worth $40 million, a significant offer.
However, Cousins made the decision to decline this offer, opting instead to explore other opportunities.
This decision comes as a surprise to many, as the Pelicans were eager to retain Cousins' services and had put forth a lucrative offer.
The rejection of the deal leaves the Pelicans in a challenging position as they look to fill the void left by Cousins' departure.
It remains to be seen what the future holds for both Cousins and the Pelicans following this unexpected turn of events.>
MIAMI (AP) - Police say seven people, including three teenagers, were injured in a New Year's Day shooting in Miami-Dade's West Little River neighborhood.
The incident occurred outside a home where a large gathering was taking place to celebrate the start of 2022.
Authorities responded to reports of multiple gunshots around midnight, finding a chaotic scene with victims scattered across the front yard and street.
Emergency medical services quickly arrived at the scene, transporting the injured to nearby hospitals for treatment.
Among the victims were the three teenagers, aged 15, 16, and 17, who sustained gunshot wounds of varying severity.
The motive behind the shooting remains unclear, and investigators are working to determine the circumstances that led to the violence.
A 17-year-old is in critical condition.
Police say there may be more than one suspect.
A description of the suspect's vehicle was not given.
Pakistan authorities are currently questioning a senior militant who they claim surrendered recently.
The militant in question is identified as Ahsan, a former member of the main Pakistani Taliban who allegedly split from the group four years ago to join a breakaway faction.

According to officials speaking on condition of anonymity, Ahsan is believed to have been involved in a deadly car bomb attack near a Shiite mosque on March 31, resulting in the tragic deaths of at least 24 individuals.
The interrogation of Ahsan has reportedly yielded vital information that has led to further arrests and the discovery of a weapons cache.
The officials emphasized that these developments were crucial in advancing their efforts to combat terrorism in the region.
They say he split with the main Pakistani Taliban four years ago and joined the breakaway faction, which claimed a March 31 car bomb near a Shiite mosque that killed at least 24 people.
The officials, who spoke on condition of anonymity because they were not authorized to brief the media, said information gleaned from Ahsan led to other arrests and the location of a weapons cache.

WARSAW, Poland — German Chancellor Angela Merkel is in Poland for top-level talks that will focus on the European Union’s future and security, and on bilateral issues between the neighbouring countries.

Merkel was greeted Monday by Polish Prime Minister Mateusz Morawiecki before going into talks on the EU’s post-Brexit future, the bloc’s budget, ways of solving the migration crisis and Poland’s refusal to accept migrants under an EU plan.

The discussions between Merkel and Morawiecki are crucial as the EU seeks to navigate through various challenges, including the repercussions of Brexit, financial planning for the EU without the UK's contributions, and finding common ground on migration policies that satisfy all member states.
Merkel's visit highlights the importance of cooperation and coordination between Germany and Poland, two influential countries in the EU.
Merkel will also meet with President Andrzej Duda.
She is making her second foreign trip, after visiting Paris, since she was sworn in for a fourth term last week.
Germany’s new foreign minister visited Warsaw on Friday.

The victim, believed to be in his 40s, was found with multiple knife wounds by emergency crews just after 22:20 BST on Wednesday.
The incident took place on a residential street in Kensington, with shocked residents reporting hearing commotion and then seeing the victim lying on the ground.
Despite the efforts of paramedics, the man succumbed to his injuries at the scene.
The police have cordoned off the area as they conduct their investigation, gathering evidence and speaking to witnesses to piece together the events leading to the fatal stabbing.
The motive behind the attack remains unclear, and no arrests have been made as of yet.
The community is on edge following this violent incident, with many expressing concern over the safety of the neighborhood.
Detectives are working tirelessly to identify the perpetrator and bring them to justice.
"Detectives from the Homicide and Major Crime Command are investigating," the Met said in a statement.
"A crime scene remains in place."
Witnesses or anyone with information about the murder have been urged to contact police.
Utah Jazz center Rudy Gobert will not be suiting up for Game 2 against the Los Angeles Clippers after suffering a knee injury in Game 1.
Gobert's absence will be a significant blow to the Jazz, as he is a key defensive anchor and a crucial part of their playoff success.
An MRI on Saturday night showed no ligament damage, meaning the Defensive Player of the Year candidate avoided serious injury.
"Trying to get better every day," Gobert told ESPN via text message Sunday.
Despite the positive news regarding the injury, the Jazz are taking a cautious approach with Gobert's recovery to ensure he is fully healthy before returning to the court.
In Gobert's absence, the Jazz will need other players to step up and fill the void left by their star center.
Derrick Favors is expected to see increased minutes and responsibilities in Game 2 as he looks to provide a strong defensive presence in the paint.
The Jazz will have to adjust their game plan without Gobert, but they remain confident in their ability to compete and secure a victory in Game 2 against the Clippers.
Stay tuned for updates on Gobert's status as he continues his recovery process.
A man has died after being shot in the chest by a suspect outside an east Las Vegas grocery store, Metro police confirmed.
The incident took place in the parking lot of an East Valley grocery store, sending shockwaves through the community.
The victim, identified as a local resident in his mid-30s, was pronounced dead at the scene.
Witnesses reported hearing a loud argument followed by gunshots erupting in the parking lot.
The suspect fled the scene before law enforcement arrived, sparking a manhunt in the area.
Authorities have launched an investigation into the motive behind the shooting and are appealing to the public for any information that could lead to the apprehension of the perpetrator.
Local residents expressed their shock and concern over the incident, with many calling for increased security measures in the area.

The grocery store management issued a statement expressing condolences to the victim's family and reassurance to the community that they are cooperating fully with the authorities in their investigation.
The tragic event serves as a stark reminder of the ongoing issue of gun violence in the community and the need for greater efforts to ensure public safety.
A recent report by UNICEF has highlighted a concerning trend of increased illiteracy among young people in regions facing instability.
The data reveals a troubling reality where conflict, displacement, and other crises are significantly hindering access to education for children and adolescents.
The lack of educational opportunities in these volatile areas is not only depriving young individuals of essential skills but also jeopardizing their future prospects.
The statistics underscore the urgent need for targeted interventions and support to ensure that all children, regardless of their circumstances, have access to quality education.
Without adequate educational resources and stability, young people are at a higher risk of being trapped in a cycle of poverty and insecurity.

New UNICEF Executive Director Henrietta Fore says: "These numbers are a stark reminder of the tragic impact that crises have on children's education, their futures, and the stability and growth of their economies and societies."
In a dominant display of skill and teamwork, Grand Canyon's Braun led the charge in a resounding 89-55 victory over Chicago State.
Braun's stellar performance ignited the Antelopes, as he showcased his scoring prowess and court vision throughout the game.
From the opening tip-off, Grand Canyon asserted its dominance on both ends of the court, building an insurmountable lead early on.
Braun's scoring outburst, combined with his defensive tenacity, set the tone for the Antelopes' commanding performance.
His seamless execution and leadership on the court propelled Grand Canyon to a decisive win.
By halftime, the Antelopes led 36-27.
Benson hit a layup and followed it with a 3 to push the lead to 46-27 barely two minutes into the second half.
Grand Canyon finished with 11 3-pointers on 27 attempts (40.7 per cent).

TOLEDO, Ohio (AP) — Another Ohio city has lifted its moratorium on cultivating medical marijuana as the state accepts applications from potential growers in that newly legalized sector.
The Blade reports the Sandusky City Commission this week rolled back its ban on medical marijuana cultivation.
The city manager says it wasn’t a response made for any particular grower, but people have reached out with interest about potential grow sites in Sandusky.

The decision to lift the ban comes as Ohio's medical marijuana program continues to gain momentum, with more cities and towns opening up to the idea of allowing cultivation and dispensing facilities within their limits.
Sandusky's move is seen as a positive step towards embracing the economic opportunities that the medical marijuana industry can bring to the area.
Officials in Stryker also are considering a measure to support a tentative agreement with a potential grower.
Ohio legalized medical marijuana last year, but some communities have chosen to ban medical marijuana businesses.
In the fast-paced world of software development, effective documentation plays a crucial role in the success of DevOps practices.
Microsoft, a leading technology company, recognizes the significance of documentation in a DevOps world and has been actively working to enhance this aspect of software development.

In an industry where speed and quality are paramount, effective documentation is a key ingredient for success.

BARCELONA, Spain (AP) — A rescue ship carrying 60 migrants has arrived in a Spanish port after being refused entry by Italy and Malta, the second time in a month that a humanitarian group has been forced to travel for days to unload people rescued in the central Mediterranean.
The migrants, including five women and four children, were rescued off the coast of Libya by the Open Arms ship.
Italy and Malta closed their ports to the vessel, prompting a journey of over 1,500 kilometers to reach Barcelona.
The Spanish aid group Proactiva Open Arms said the migrants come from 14 countries and are in good health.
Doctors Without Borders says more than 500 people have died in the Mediterranean since the Aquarius, another rescue ship, was blocked from ports in Italy and Malta in June.
The North Island Medical Health Officer says a lot of lessons have been learned in the year since a public health emergency was declared in BC.
This weekend marked the one year anniversary since the emergency was declared, following a spike in overdose deaths.
Doctor Charmaine Enns says one thing the crisis has done is shed light on the issue of hidden drug use in our communities.
Enns highlighted the importance of increased access to harm reduction services and the need for more comprehensive addiction treatment programs.
She also emphasized the significance of community engagement and education in addressing substance abuse issues.
Despite the challenges faced over the past year, Enns expressed optimism about the progress made in raising awareness and implementing strategies to combat the opioid crisis.
Moving forward, she stressed the importance of continued collaboration and proactive measures to prevent further tragedies.
CHRISTCHURCH, New Zealand (AP) — India will meet Australia in the final of the Under-19 cricket World Cup after overpowering Pakistan by 203 runs in a one-sided semifinal on Tuesday.
Shubman Gill made an unbeaten 102, his sixth score of 50 or more in youth ODIs, as India made 272-9.
Pakistan struggled to chase the target and were bowled out for just 69 runs in 29.3 overs.
India's bowlers were relentless, with Kamlesh Nagarkoti and Shivam Mavi taking three wickets each to dismantle Pakistan's batting lineup.
India's dominant performance showcased their depth in both batting and bowling, setting the stage for an exciting final against Australia.
The young Indian team will be looking to carry forward their winning momentum and claim the Under-19 World Cup title.
Australia, on the other hand, will be a tough opponent, having also displayed impressive performances throughout the tournament.
Cricket fans can expect a thrilling clash between two talented teams vying for the championship.

Sports News of Monday, 14 August 2017 Source: Goal.com 2017-08-14 Emmanuel Agyemang Badu Ghana midfielder Emmanuel Agyemang-Badu says the Turkish Super Lig is very competitive, two weeks after joining Bursaspor.
The 26-year-old signed a season-long loan deal from Udinese, ending a seven-year stay at the Serie A outfit following his move from Ghanaian club Berekum Arsenal in 2010.
Badu made his debut on Friday when Bursaspor lost 1-0 to Istanbul Basaksehir, who featured former Ghana U20 star Joseph Attamah Laweh and Togo captain Emmanuel Adebayor.
The former Asante Kotoko box-to-box midfielder lasted the entire duration.
“Life is all about challenges and as a man you need to challenge yourself in life.
That is why when the Bursaspor offer came, I didn’t hesitate to go for it,” Badu told Happy FM.
Badu expressed his admiration for the level of competition in the Turkish Super Lig, emphasizing the quality of teams and players in the league.
He believes that the league is one of the best in the world, with its intense matches and talented footballers providing an exciting environment for players to test themselves.
Having embraced the challenge of playing in Turkey, Badu is determined to make a significant impact at Bursaspor and help the team achieve success in the upcoming season.
His positive outlook and eagerness to excel in the Turkish Super Lig reflect his ambition and commitment to his career as a professional footballer.
San Francisco Fleet Week, an annual event that celebrates the rich maritime history of the city, kicks off today with a spectacular lineup of activities and events.

This week-long celebration not only honors the men and women of the United States Navy, Coast Guard, and Marine Corps but also serves as an opportunity for the public to engage with the military and learn about their vital roles in national security.
The highlight of Fleet Week is the awe-inspiring air shows that feature acrobatic maneuvers by various aircraft, including the renowned Blue Angels.
Spectators can expect to witness thrilling aerial displays, precision flying, and breathtaking stunts that showcase the skill and expertise of the pilots.
In addition to the air shows, there will be ship tours, military demonstrations, and interactive exhibits that offer a glimpse into the daily operations of the armed forces.
Fleet Week is not only a chance to marvel at the impressive military capabilities but also a time to express gratitude to the servicemen and women who dedicate their lives to protecting our country.
It provides an opportunity for the community to come together, show support for the military, and foster a sense of unity and patriotism.
Whether you're a military enthusiast, a history buff, or simply looking for a fun and exciting event to attend, San Francisco Fleet Week has something for everyone.
So mark your calendars, gather your friends and family, and join us in celebrating this beloved tradition that honors our nation's armed forces.
We'll be live streaming the show from noon until four on our website and app.

BRUSSELS (AP) — European Union foreign policy chief Federica Mogherini is meeting with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu to address the issues of Jerusalem as Israel's capital and the chances of reinvigorating negotiations on the peace process.
Mogherini has joined many EU leaders in expressing disapproval of the U.S. decision to recognize Jerusalem as Israel's capital.
The meeting comes at a crucial time as tensions in the region remain high following the U.S. move.
Both parties are expected to discuss potential ways to move forward in the peace process and find common ground on the status of Jerusalem.
Netanyahu emphasized the importance of acknowledging the reality on the ground and how it can pave the way for meaningful peace negotiations.
Netanyahu insisted that what U.S. President Donald Trump did was "put facts squarely on the table.
Peace is based on reality."
He said the reality of seeing Jerusalem as Israel's capital "doesn't obviate peace, it makes peace possible."

SHAFTSBURY, Vt. — The Robert Frost Stone House Museum is ready to reopen under new ownership.
After months of anticipation, the beloved museum, dedicated to the renowned poet Robert Frost, is set to welcome visitors once again.
The new owners have been working tirelessly to restore and enhance the museum's exhibits, ensuring a fresh and engaging experience for all who visit.
The reopening of the Robert Frost Stone House Museum is a significant moment for literature enthusiasts and fans of the poet's work.

With new ownership at the helm, visitors can expect a renewed focus on preserving and celebrating Frost's contributions to American literature.
Excitement is building as the museum prepares to open its doors, offering visitors a chance to immerse themselves in the world of Robert Frost like never before.
Getting high is down in Breckenridge for the first time in more than two years — or at least that’s what the town’s sales tax receipts from its marijuana dispensaries seem to indicate.
The 25-month streak of increasing cannabis sales in the Colorado town has come to an end, with September showing a decline compared to the same month in the previous year.
Despite the overall trend of growth in marijuana sales, September saw a dip in Breckenridge's cannabis sales figures.
This unexpected downturn has raised eyebrows among town officials and industry observers, prompting questions about potential factors contributing to this shift in consumer behavior.

However, September’s decline marked the first time since July 2015 that the town’s “weedtail” category — as officials have creatively coined it — hasn’t produced better numbers than it did the same month in the previous year.

Breckenridge finance director Brian Waldes said he’s discovered tracking marijuana sales reports in Breckenridge can be “wacky,” with the sector known for wild, high-percentage spikes within a relatively short sample period.

Whoever stole a flag from Stowmarket’s Market Place must be a fan of the town.
For the £200, 6ft by 4ft white flag bears only the town council’s crest a on a white background, and it is a bit tatty round the edges having been in pole position for three years.
The theft was discovered by a local council worker during their routine morning checks in the Market Place.
The flag, which had been proudly flying in the heart of Stowmarket, was reported missing on Monday morning.
Local authorities are baffled by the theft as the flag holds sentimental value to the town and its residents.
The flag has been a symbol of pride and unity for the community, representing the town's heritage and values.
The town council has expressed their disappointment over the incident and is urging anyone with information to come forward.
Residents of Stowmarket have also expressed their shock and dismay over the theft, with many taking to social media to voice their concerns.
The town is now left without its iconic flag, and efforts are underway to replace it as soon as possible.
Authorities are investigating the theft and are hopeful that the flag will be returned to its rightful place in the Market Place.

ST. PAUL, Minn. (WCCO) — A bill to legalize online fantasy sports betting in Minnesota unexpectedly failed in the Minnesota House on Tuesday.
After the vote, critics said the rush to legalize the popular past time is coming from major corporations.
Many lawmakers expressed concerns about the potential social impacts of expanding gambling in the state, citing worries about addiction and the influence of big money in politics.
Supporters of the bill argued that legalizing online fantasy sports betting could generate significant revenue for the state and provide consumer protections for players.
However, opponents raised questions about the lack of safeguards to prevent underage gambling and the potential for exploitation of vulnerable individuals.
The bill would have set up regulations for online fantasy sports betting.
It is not officially legal in Minnesota, but there’s no law against it either.
Former FBI Director James Comey's highly anticipated memoir, "A Higher Loyalty," has taken the literary world by storm, selling over 600,000 copies in its first week of release.
The book, published on April 17, has quickly become one of the most sought-after political reads of the year.
Comey’s memoir delves into his experiences investigating Hillary Clinton’s emails and his contentious interactions with President Donald Trump.
In the book, Comey paints a vivid picture of Trump as a mafia-like figure who prioritizes personal allegiance over national duty.
The success of "A Higher Loyalty" follows the trend set by Michael Wolff’s explosive bestseller, "Fire and Fury," which was also published by a Macmillan imprint in January.
Comey’s candid and revealing account has captivated readers and reignited public interest in the inner workings of the government.
The former FBI director’s memoir has been one of the year’s most anticipated releases.
It includes his accounts of investigating Hillary Clinton’s emails and of his awkward encounters with President Donald Trump.
Comey, fired by Trump a year ago, has likened the president to a crime boss who values personal loyalty over service to the country.
Published April 17, “A Higher Loyalty” is the hottest political book since Michael Wolff’s million-selling “Fire and Fury,” which came out in January.
Both books were published by imprints of Macmillan.
LONDON (AP) — Formula One says it is ending the practice of using "grid girls" and "podium girls" at races.
F1 managing director of commercial operations Sean Bratches says the use of the women on the grid is clearly "at odds with modern day societal norms."
The decision comes after years of debate over the role of grid girls in the sport, with critics arguing that it perpetuates outdated stereotypes and objectifies women.
The move is part of Formula One's efforts to modernize and appeal to a wider audience.
Bratches emphasized that the focus should be on the drivers and the racing itself, rather than on the presence of women as decorative elements.

The decision has been met with mixed reactions from fans and stakeholders, with some applauding the move towards greater inclusivity and others expressing disappointment at the end of a long-standing tradition in the sport.
RENO COUNTY – The suspect in a February 4, stabbing in a vehicle in Hutchinson’s Carey Park was in court Tuesday to hear the formal reading of charges.
The incident, which left the victim with severe injuries to the face, has shocked the local community and raised concerns about public safety.
Authorities have identified the suspect as John Norris, a 32-year-old Kansas man with a history of violent offenses.
According to the criminal complaint, Norris allegedly stabbed the victim multiple times during a confrontation inside the vehicle.
The motive behind the attack remains unclear, but investigators are looking into possible connections between the suspect and the victim.
Norris now faces multiple charges, including attempted murder, aggravated assault, and possession of a controlled substance.
In addition to the violent charges, authorities also found illegal drugs in Norris' possession at the time of his arrest.
The total weight being over 25 grams according to the complaint.
Norris has served time in prison for aggravated battery, possession of drugs and burglary and his case now moves to a future waiver-status docket.
He remains jailed on a $50,000 Bond.
The Pavlof Volcano in Alaska experienced another brief eruption yesterday, sending ash and steam up to 20,000 feet into the air.
The Alaska Volcano Observatory reported increased seismic activity in the area, leading to the eruption.
While the eruption was short-lived, it prompted the issuance of an aviation warning due to the potential ash cloud.
Pavlof Volcano, one of the most active in Alaska, last erupted in 2016.
The current eruption is being closely monitored for any further activity.
Local residents have been advised to stay indoors and keep windows closed to avoid exposure to ash particles.
Higher level winds could push ash southeast into the Gulf of Alaska.
The volcano is 850 miles southwest of Anchorage.
HAVANA (AP) — Cuba has opened up its first wholesale market in an economy dominated by government-run enterprises.
State-run newspaper Granma says the market is part of an ongoing effort to "reorganize" commerce on the communist island.
The market will sell beans, beer, sugar, cigars and other basic staples for 20 to 30 percent less than the products are sold throughout the country.
This move is seen as a significant step towards providing more affordable access to essential goods for the Cuban population.
The wholesale market aims to improve the distribution and availability of key items, addressing the challenges of supply chain disruptions and high prices that have been prevalent in Cuba.
With this new initiative, the Cuban government hopes to alleviate some of the economic pressures faced by its citizens and create a more efficient system for the distribution of basic necessities.
The introduction of the wholesale market is expected to have a positive impact on the local economy and consumer welfare.
OPP are urging the public to be careful while boating this summer after a 17-year-old was thrown from a jet ski and flown to hospital with serious injuries.
Norfolk OPP and paramedics arrived at Turkey Point at about 3:30 p.m. Tuesday after reports a teen had hurt himself while on a jet ski on Lake Erie.
Off-duty police officers and bystanders saw the incident, rescued the teen and held him above the water until emergency crews arrived, OPP said.
According to witnesses, the teen was thrown from the jet ski after losing control and hitting a wave at high speed.
The impact ejected him into the water, where he was found struggling to stay afloat.
Quick action from the off-duty officers and bystanders prevented a potential tragedy, as they managed to keep the teen above water until professional help arrived.
The victim was airlifted to a nearby hospital with serious injuries, including fractures and lacerations.
Authorities are reminding boaters, especially young and inexperienced riders, to always wear personal flotation devices and operate watercraft with caution.
As summer activities on the water increase, safety measures must be a top priority to prevent accidents and injuries.
Up-close footage of a powerful tornado in Nebraska has captured the awe-inspiring force of nature as it tore through the open plains.
The dramatic video shows the swirling vortex of wind and debris, reaching down from the darkened sky to the ground below.
The tornado, a rare sight in this region, displayed its full fury as it moved across the landscape, leaving a trail of destruction in its wake.
The tornado touched down near the towns of Syracuse and Nebraska City.
National Weather Service meteorologist Van DeWald confirmed the tornado happened at around 4:58 p.m. local time, the Omaha World-Herald reported.
Wind gusted up to 70 mph.
There have been no reports of injuries or property damage in the remote area of Nebraska where the cyclone touched down.
Hail, some pieces measuring 1.75 inches, also fell about 20 miles east of Otoe County as the storm moved into Iowa.

MARION, Ind.
(WISH) — A Grant County judge on Wednesday dismissed a child seduction charge against a teacher at Oak Hill High School, according to court records.
Mitchel Hueston, who was 33 when charged in January, was alleged to have inappropriately touched a 16-year-old girl during the summer of 2016.
The decision to drop the charges came after new evidence was presented in court that raised doubts about the validity of the allegations against Hueston.
The defense argued that there was no concrete proof linking him to the alleged incident, and the judge ultimately ruled in favor of dismissing the charge.
His current status was not immediately available.
Oak Hill High School is in Converse, about 35 miles north of Indianapolis.

SKOPJE, Macedonia (AP) — Paleontologists from Bulgaria and Macedonia are excavating the fossilized remains of a prehistoric elephant believed to pre-date the mammoth, after its bones were discovered accidentally by a man working in a field.
The remarkably well-preserved remains include a nearly complete skull, tusks, and several leg bones, providing valuable insights into the ancient creature's anatomy and behavior.
Experts believe the elephant-like creature, known as Gomphotherium, roamed the area that is now Macedonia millions of years ago.
These findings shed light on the biodiversity and climate of the region during the prehistoric era, offering a glimpse into the distant past of the Balkans.
They estimated the animal would have weighed about 10 tons and have been about 50 years old at the time of its death, roughly 8 million years ago during the Miocene epoch.
Biljana Garevska of the Natural Science Museum in Skopje said the fossil was of one of the elephant's ancestors which roamed the region at a time when it was covered by African-like savannah.

Daseke, a leading provider of transportation and logistics solutions, has announced its move to the NASDAQ stock exchange.
The company will now trade under a new ticker symbol, reflecting its continued growth and expansion in the industry.
This strategic move to the NASDAQ platform is expected to enhance Daseke's visibility and market presence, attracting more investors and stakeholders.
With a focus on innovation and customer service, Daseke has established itself as a reliable partner for a wide range of transportation needs.
The company's commitment to safety, efficiency, and sustainability has earned it a strong reputation in the market.

Somali extremists launched a brutal siege on a popular restaurant in the capital city of Mogadishu, unleashing a night of terror and bloodshed.
The attack began on Wednesday evening and continued through the night, with heavy gunfire and explosions rocking the area.
The militants reportedly stormed the Pizza House restaurant, a bustling establishment frequented by locals and foreigners alike.
Security forces swiftly responded to the scene, engaging in a fierce gun battle with the attackers.
The intense fighting led to the roofs of the restaurant and surrounding buildings being blasted off by powerful explosions.
The situation remained dire as the standoff extended into the early hours of Thursday morning.
Senior Somali police office Capt.
Mohamed Hussein said at dawn Thursday that at least one attacker was firing on troops from inside the restaurant.
The roofs were blown off the Pizza House restaurant and nearby buildings from the powerful blasts.
High casualties are feared in the attack on the busy restaurant.
Police said the bodies of five girls thought to have been killed by militants were found in the restaurant.

Quebec's transport minister, Robert Poeti, has announced that he will not be seeking re-election in this year's upcoming election.
Poeti, who previously served as a provincial police officer, has been a prominent figure in Quebec's political landscape.
His decision not to run again comes as a surprise to many, as he has been a dedicated and hardworking member of the cabinet.
During his tenure as transport minister from 2014 to 2016, Poeti made significant contributions to the province's transportation infrastructure and policies.
However, his time in the cabinet came to an end when former Premier Philippe Couillard removed him from his position.
Poeti's decision to step down adds to a growing list of Quebec cabinet ministers and backbenchers who have chosen not to seek re-election.
This trend reflects a changing political landscape in Quebec as the province prepares for the upcoming election on October 1.
The former Quebec provincial police officer served as transport minister between 2014 and 2016 before Couillard kicked him out of cabinet.
Poeti joins fellow ministers Julie Boulet, Martin Coiteux, Stephanie Vallee, Jean-Marc Fournier and David Heurtel in deciding to pack it in.
Nine Liberal backbenchers have also said they won’t run again in the campaign leading to the Oct. 1 election.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y. (AP) -- Takal Molson and Jermaine Crumpton posted double-doubles and Canisius used a late surge to take a 73-67 victory over Marist on Friday night.

Molson had 21 points and 10 rebounds and Crumpton 18 points and a career-high 16 boards for the Golden Griffins (14-9, 8-2 Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference), who bounced back from a loss to Niagara to win for the fifth time in six starts.
Isaiah Reese added 21 points.
Crumpton's double-double is a career first; Molson's is his second.
The Red Foxes (5-18, 3-8) had led the entire second half, by as many as 11, when Canisius took the lead on Jibreel Faulkner's dunk with 5:35 to go.
Canisius then held off Marist down the stretch, with Molson and Crumpton making key plays on both ends of the court.
Marist struggled to regain momentum as the Golden Griffins tightened their defense and executed on offense.
The win solidifies Canisius' position near the top of the Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference standings, showcasing their resilience and ability to come back from deficits.
The team's strong performance was a testament to their determination and skill, setting a positive tone for the remainder of the season.
The Dutch police have officially retired their unique and innovative program that involved using a convocation of drone-catching eagles.
The program, which garnered worldwide attention for its unconventional approach to dealing with rogue drones, has now come to an end.
The decision to retire the eagle program was made after it became apparent that the birds could not be effectively trained to become "operational" in the way that was initially envisioned.
The rodents couldn't be made "operational," police said.
It wasn't hard to predict that the eagle program would shut down.
Even if you discount the utility of the birds, anti-drone technology is advancing quickly enough that technology can likely do the job as well or better.
If you can disable drones at will with a portable gun, why spend years grooming eagles that aren't even guaranteed to do what you want?
As it stands, we're sure the eagles would rather catch the sort of prey they can eat.
While the use of eagles to intercept drones was a novel concept, it ultimately proved to be impractical in the face of evolving technology.
With advancements in anti-drone technology, such as portable guns that can disable drones efficiently, the need for avian assistance became less pressing.
The eagles, known for their hunting prowess in the wild, may now return to catching prey more suited to their natural instincts.

Regis Center in Salem.

Regis Center is a vital community resource that provides addiction treatment and recovery services to those in need.

Cobb, a long-time advocate for mental health and addiction awareness, has called on fellow Roanokers to donate essential items such as clothing, toiletries, and non-perishable food items to help those undergoing treatment at the center.

A recent report has shed light on the impact of Airbnb on the housing market in New York City.
The analysis published Monday comes from a researcher at McGill University in Montreal and was commissioned by the Hotel Trades Council, a union of hotel workers.
Several local neighborhood organizations were co-sponsors.
The report finds that Airbnb listings have removed 7,000 housing units from circulation in the past three years and increased median rent in the city by $380 a year.
Officials have tried to combat illegal listings with fines for property owners.
Airbnb says many everyday New Yorkers use its site to temporarily rent space to make extra money.
The company questioned the findings of Tuesday's report and said the study's methodology is flawed
This revelation raises concerns about the impact of short-term rental platforms on affordable housing in the city.
SAN DIEGO (Daily Aztec) - San Diego State men’s basketball may be in a hole in the Mountain West Conference, but the team continues to find itself on the winning end at Viejas Arena.
The home court success kept on rolling Saturday night, with the Aztecs defeating Air Force Academy by a final score of 81-50.
SDSU jumped out to a big lead thanks to eight of 16 shooting from behind-the-arc in the first half, and used runs of 13-2, 15-2 and 9-0 to put away the Falcons (8-13, 2-7 MW).
“We made some early threes to start this game so that always opens the game up,” head coach Brian Dutcher said.
“We’ve been pretty dominant at home in the conference.” The Aztecs, who remain in eighth place in the conference with a record of 5-5, improved to 9-2 at home this season and 13-8 overall.
Following a tough conference road loss to University of Nevada, Las Vegas last Saturday, SDSU needed a big win in front of their home crowd.
San Diego State's defense was stifling, holding Air Force to just 28.6% shooting from the field and 17.9% from three-point range.
The Aztecs capitalized on their defensive stops, converting them into fast-break opportunities and easy baskets.
The victory showcased the depth of the Aztecs as multiple players contributed to the scoring effort.
Senior guard Jordan Schakel led the team with 17 points, while junior forward Matt Bradley added 14 points off the bench.
The Aztecs will look to carry this momentum into their upcoming road games as they aim to climb the standings in the Mountain West Conference.
Barrie Police are on the lookout for a stolen mobility toy that belongs to a 10-year-old girl with cerebral palsy.
The toy, a miniature black Escalade, is an essential means of transportation for the young girl when she is outside with friends or family.
The incident occurred on Bourbon Street Sunday night when a witness reported seeing an adult man utilizing a young boy to steal the precious toy car from outside the girl's residence.
Authorities describe the suspect as a white male with a medium build, approximately 5’8 in height.
He was last seen wearing a blue t-shirt and was accompanied by a young boy estimated to be around 4-5 years old.
The police are urging anyone with information regarding the theft or the whereabouts of the stolen mobility toy to contact Barrie Police at 705-725-7025.

Renowned philanthropist and deep-sea explorer, Victor Allen, has made a groundbreaking announcement regarding the discovery of the long-lost USS Juneau.
The USS Juneau, a World War II cruiser, sank during the Battle of Guadalcanal in November 1942, with the loss of nearly 700 sailors, including the five Sullivan brothers.
Allen's expedition team made the historic find in the depths of the Pacific Ocean, marking a significant breakthrough in maritime archaeology.
The discovery of the USS Juneau holds immense historical and emotional significance for the families of those who served aboard the ship.
Allen's dedication to exploring the world's oceans and uncovering hidden treasures has once again captured global attention.
The expedition team says in a statement it first identified the USS Juneau on Saturday using sonar technology and used a remotely operated underwater vehicle to verify the wreckage on Sunday.

Lloyd Hammond was convicted of wanton murder in the death of William Sawyers, and facilitation to commit murder in the death of Tarrell Cherry.
>> MUGSHOTS: February 2018 Roundup Both men were shot and killed in 2006.
This is Hammond's third trial in this case.
A trial in 2009 ended before it began.
Sawyers' girlfriend, Troya Sheckles, was set to testify as a witness but she was gunned down by Dejuan Hammond -- Lloyd's brother.
The recent verdict brings closure to a long-standing case that has gripped the Louisville community for years.
Hammond, known for his involvement in gang-related activities, has a history of violence and criminal behavior.
The conviction serves as a reminder of the impact of gang violence on communities and the importance of seeking justice for victims and their families.
As the legal proceedings come to a close, the community reflects on the lives lost and the impact of such crimes on the city.
Hammond's conviction sends a strong message that criminal behavior will not be tolerated, and justice will be served for those affected by such violence.

It was a rough start to the week in Toronto and New York as the markets took some steep losses today.
Materials and energy weighed Bay Street down as oil prices fell and investors played it safe ahead of an expected U.S. interest rate increase this week.

× KCMO considers ordinance that would require Airbnb hosts to register with city, pay yearly fees KANSAS CITY, Mo.
— Kansas City, Mo., is considering an ordinance that would affect Airbnb hosts.
The ordinance would require hosts to register with the city and pay fees up to about $300 a year for a house that you own but don’t live in.
Right now, short-term rentals of houses through services such as Airbnb is illegal.
Read the full short-term stay ordinance proposal There’s going to be a meeting to talk about the purposed ordinance Wednesday at 4 p.m. at the Gregg Klice Community Center in Kansas City.
The proposed ordinance aims to regulate the growing short-term rental industry within the city limits.
It seeks to address concerns related to safety, tax compliance, and neighborhood disturbances.
By requiring hosts to register and pay yearly fees, city officials hope to create a more structured framework for short-term rentals while also generating revenue for municipal services.
Hosts and residents are encouraged to attend the meeting to provide feedback and learn more about the potential impacts of this ordinance on the local community.

Talented youngster Matthew Woodhall, of Sutton Swimming Club, clocked a personal-best (PB) time and finished a respectable fifth when competing at the Swim England National Open Water Festival.

Matthew, who qualified by winning the Midland Open Water Championships, competed aginst 37 other boys from all four corners of the UK in the 1500m race for his age group at Rother Valley Country Park, near Sheffield.

His dedication to training and passion for open water swimming have been evident in his consistent success in the sport.
Matthew has won the Nottinghamshire county age group title for the past four years, but open water swimming is a discipline that requires different skills to succeed.
TAIPEI (Taiwan News) — The Central Weather Bureau (CWB) reported on Saturday morning that it snowed on Yushan at dawn from 4:30 to 5:50.
With the accumulation from previous days, the snow depth was measured at 8.6 centimeters as of now, said the CWB.
The rare sight of a snow-covered Yushan, Taiwan's highest peak at 3,952 meters, attracted many visitors and photographers to capture the breathtaking scenery.
The snowfall created a winter wonderland, transforming the usual lush green landscape into a picturesque white paradise.
Visitors were seen enjoying the serene beauty of the snow-covered mountain, creating memories that will last a lifetime.
The bureau reminded people planning a snow-gazing trip to keep themselves warm and have their vehicle tires wrapped with snow chains.
People should also be vigilant about the changing weather and traffic conditions in case of being trapped in the mountains.
(Photos courtesy of the Central Weather Bureau)

This incident serves as a cautionary tale, highlighting the importance of allowing trained professionals to handle delicate situations.
