In a recent development in the ongoing case involving British IT expert Marcus Hutchins, a judge has set bail at $30,000.
Hutchins, who gained fame for his role in slowing down the WannaCry global cyber attack, faced accusations related to a malware case.
The decision on the bail amount was made by Judge Nancy Koppe, who dismissed claims by the federal prosecutor that Hutchins posed a flight risk.
Despite being granted bail, Hutchins will not be released immediately as his defense team was unable to post the bail before the court clerk's office closed.
His attorney, Adrian Lobo, informed reporters about the situation, emphasizing that Hutchins was in good spirits considering the circumstances.
Lobo also mentioned that it was unexpected for Hutchins to find himself in this legal predicament.
The news of Hutchins' arrest has shocked the cybersecurity community, with many researchers coming to his defense and expressing disbelief that he could be involved in cybercrime.
If and when Hutchins is released, he will be prohibited from using computers or accessing the internet as part of the bail conditions.
His attorney, Adrian Lobo, told reporters he would not be released on Friday because the clerk's office for the court closed before his defense team could post the bail.

British IT expert Marcus Hutchins who has been branded a hero for slowing down the WannaCry global cyber attack, sits in front of his workstation during an interview on May 15, 2017 in Ilfracombe, England.
file Frank Augstein / AP file Judge Nancy Koppe dismissed a federal prosecutor's claim that Hutchins was a flight risk.
If released, Hutchins will be barred from computer use or internet access.
Hutchins was "doing well, considering what's gone on," his defense attorney, Adrian Lobo, told reporters.
She said it was "unexpected in (Hutchins') mind to ever be in this situation."
News of Hutchins' arrest on Wednesday shocked other researchers, many of whom rallied to his defense and said they did not believe he had ever engaged in cyber crime.

Natalie Portman’s brave response to being invited to accept Genius Prize in Israel “Portman will not accept Israeli prize” (Page A2, April 21): Kudos to Natalie Portman for opting not to travel to Israel to accept the Genesis Prize.

Regardless of differing opinions, Natalie Portman’s choice to forego the Genesis Prize ceremony demonstrates her commitment to her beliefs and values.
It serves as a reminder of the complexities surrounding international events and the impact of individual actions in the public sphere.
The New York Jets have made significant moves to bolster their defense, signing linebacker Brandon Copeland and re-signing defensive lineman Xavier Cooper.
Copeland, a versatile player known for his athleticism and pass-rushing ability, brings valuable experience to the Jets' defense.
He signed with Baltimore as an undrafted free agent out of Penn in 2013 and spent time later that season on Tennessee's practice squad.
After signing with Orlando of the Arena Football League in 2015, Copeland impressed Detroit after participating in the NFL Veterans Combine.
Meanwhile, the Jets have also secured the return of defensive lineman Xavier Cooper, adding depth to their defensive line.
Cooper, a former third-round pick by the Cleveland Browns in 2015, has shown promise with his disruptive play along the defensive front.
His presence will provide stability and playmaking ability to the Jets' defense.
These signings demonstrate the Jets' commitment to strengthening their defense and building a competitive roster for the upcoming season.
With Copeland and Cooper on board, the Jets look poised to make an impact on the field and improve their performance on defense.
SEAFORD, N.Y. (CBSNewYork) — The worst litterbugs in New York state appear to be on Long Island.
How bad is the situation?
As CBS2’s Jennifer McLogan found out on Tuesday, state Department of Transportation crews picked up 18,000 tons of garbage in honor of Earth Day.
From the scenic shores of Jones Beach to the bustling streets of Hempstead, Long Island is grappling with a serious litter problem.
Residents and officials are expressing deep concern over the sheer volume of trash blighting the region's beauty.
Local authorities are urging the community to take action, promoting initiatives for proper waste disposal and recycling.
The environmental impact of this widespread littering is alarming, threatening wildlife and marine ecosystems.
Efforts to combat the issue are underway, with cleanup campaigns and educational programs aimed at raising awareness about the importance of preserving Long Island's natural environment.
The battle against litterbugs continues as Long Island strives to reclaim its pristine landscapes.
Cardiff Devils are in pre-season training camp, preparing for the Elite League season and the Champions Hockey League.
BBC Sport Wales caught up with them to see who their new signings are and how they are fitting in.
The Elite League champions face HC Davos from Switzerland, Bili Tygri Liberec of the Czech Republic and Sweden's Vaxjo Lakers in Group E of the Champions League.

With the season fast approaching, fans are eager to see how the Devils will perform in both domestic and international competitions.
BERLIN — Germany’s foreign minister says a “United States of Europe” proposed by his party’s leader wouldn’t spell the end of nation-states on the continent.

Foreign Minister Heiko Maas, a member of the Social Democratic Party, emphasized that the concept of a United States of Europe is about deepening cooperation and unity among European nations rather than erasing their individual identities.

In a recent interview, Maas expressed that the vision of a United States of Europe is not about creating a single, centralized European state but rather about strengthening the European Union as a whole.
He highlighted the importance of maintaining the diverse cultures and traditions of each nation while working together towards common goals and addressing shared challenges.
Maas's comments come at a time when discussions about the future of the European Union and its member states are ongoing.

The idea of a United States of Europe has been a topic of debate among politicians and scholars, with varying perspectives on how such a concept would impact the sovereignty and autonomy of individual nations.

Maas's clarification aims to reassure that the vision of a United States of Europe is not intended to override the identities and sovereignty of European nations but to foster greater cooperation and unity for the collective benefit of all.

SEOUL, South Korea (AP) — The Latest on reactions to President Donald Trump's State of the Union address (all times local): 6:50 p.m. South Korean analysts say President Donald Trump's fiery comments on North Korea reflected confidence that his campaign of pressure and sanctions on the country is working.

Trump's strong stance towards North Korea during his address has been interpreted by experts in South Korea as a sign of his belief in the effectiveness of the pressure tactics employed against the regime.
The comments made by Trump suggest a level of assurance in the impact of the sanctions imposed on North Korea, pushing the country towards negotiations and denuclearization.

Du Hyeogn Cha, a visiting scholar at Seoul's Asan Institute for Policy Studies, says for North Korea, it has to hurt that Trump declared the country as a regime that cannot co-exist with the founding values of the United States.

Koh Yu-hwan, a North Korea expert at Seoul's Dongguk University and a security adviser to South Korea's presidential office, says Trump likely saw North Korea's outreach over the Pyeongchang Winter Olympics as a clear sign that pressure and sanctions are working.
CHARLOTTE, N.C. — Body-camera footage released by a North Carolina police department shows a man had his arms raised to his side just before officers fatally shot him last month.
The video was among five released Friday by Charlotte-Mecklenburg police.
Officers can be heard on the video yelling at Rueben Galindo to drop a gun they said he was holding in his left hand before shots were fired Sept. 6.
The footage has sparked outrage and calls for justice from the community, with many questioning the use of lethal force in this situation.
Galindo's family has expressed their grief and disbelief, stating that he was not a threat and was trying to comply with the officers' commands.
The incident has reignited conversations about police training, de-escalation tactics, and the need for better communication between law enforcement and the communities they serve.
Authorities have promised a thorough investigation into the shooting.
Oregon's legal marijuana industry is facing a significant challenge as an oversupply of cannabis products floods the market.
The ease of entry into Oregon's pot industry has led to a massive surplus, driving prices down and creating concerns among growers and retailers.
The state's regulatory framework, which allows for relatively simple licensing and low barriers to entry, has contributed to the rapid expansion of cultivation operations.
As a result, many businesses are struggling to sell their products, leading to financial strain and uncertainty within the industry.
The oversupply has forced some growers to sell their cannabis at a fraction of the expected price, impacting their profitability and sustainability in the long run.
Looking ahead, experts warn that other states considering legalization should learn from Oregon's experience.
A similar regulatory structure there could mean an oversupply on a much larger scale as that state's market emerges.

The front-runner to succeed Michael Flynn as White House national security adviser is a former Navy SEAL and retired three-star admiral who became one of Defense Secretary Jim Mattis’s most-trusted colleagues while leading troops in Afghanistan and Iraq.

Retired Vice Admiral Bob Harward, who served as Mattis’s deputy at U.S. Central Command during the secretary’s career as a Marine Corps general, is at the top of the list for the influential White House post, according to a U.S. official and another person familiar with the matter.
Opinion Journal: The Next National Security Adviser (4:19) Hoover Institution Research Fellow Kori Schake on the resignation of Lt. Gen. Michael Flynn.
Photo credit: Reuters.
Harward retired from the Navy in 2013 and is currently chief executive of Lockheed Martin Corp.’s LMT, +0.08% operation in the United Arab Emirates.

He is being considered alongside Keith Kellogg, the retired three-star Army general who took over as acting national security adviser late Monday, and former Central Intelligence Agency Director David Petraeus, a retired four-star Army general, according to administration officials.
An expanded version of this report appears on WSJ.com.
Bob Harward's extensive military background and close working relationship with Mattis make him a strong candidate for the role.
His experience in key leadership positions and strategic planning in high-stakes environments like Afghanistan and Iraq have earned him respect within defense and intelligence circles.
If appointed, Harward would bring a wealth of knowledge and expertise to the position, which is crucial for shaping and implementing the nation's security policies.
The decision on Flynn's replacement is eagerly anticipated as the administration seeks to maintain stability and effectiveness in its national security apparatus.
Four Baltimore teenagers have been indicted in connection with the killing of a police officer.

The Turpin siblings, who captured the world's attention with their harrowing escape from captivity in the Perris torture case, are now reveling in their newfound freedom.
After enduring years of abuse and isolation at the hands of their parents, David and Louise Turpin, the siblings are finally experiencing a life they never thought possible.
Since their rescue, the siblings have been embracing their independence and savoring the simple joys of everyday life.
From relishing home-cooked meals to exploring the outdoors and forming new friendships, they are making up for lost time and creating precious memories along the way.
With the unwavering support of their caretakers and the community, the siblings are gradually adjusting to their new reality and building a brighter future for themselves.
According to their attorney, Jack Osborn, the siblings are not only resilient but also incredibly compassionate towards each other.
"They are joyful, they are warm, they are considerate...I give them a lot of credit for helping each other, relying on each other.

I think they've learned how to bring out the best in each other over the years," Osborn said.Their parents, David and Louise Turpin, remain behind bars on dozens of charges including torture and child endangerment.The attorney for the adult siblings says they've communicated with their younger brothers and sisters through Skype, and they all hope to have a reunion soon.
RICHMOND, Ind.
(AP) — Indiana University will offer six weeks of paid parental leave for certain employees, both male and female, beginning July 1.
This new policy is a significant step forward in supporting the work-life balance of staff members and recognizing the importance of family responsibilities.
The parental leave will be available to staff members who have completed at least one year of continuous service at the university.
The leave can be taken within 12 months of the birth or adoption of a child and can be used intermittently if needed.
This progressive move by Indiana University reflects a growing trend among employers to provide better support for working parents.
In addition to the six weeks of paid parental leave, eligible employees will have the option to use any accrued vacation or sick time to extend their leave if desired.
This comprehensive approach aims to provide flexibility and financial stability to staff members during a significant life event.
The new parental leave policy at Indiana University demonstrates a commitment to fostering a supportive and inclusive work environment that values the well-being of its employees and their families.

In a surprising turn of events following the recent election, Professor Matthew Goodwin made headlines by fulfilling a bold promise he had made months ago.
Goodwin, a prominent academic known for his pro-Brexit stance, had vowed to eat his own book if Labour under Jeremy Corbyn managed to poll at 38%.
“I’m saying this out loud,” Matthew Goodwin tweeted on May 27.
“I do not believe that Labour under Jeremy Corbyn will poll 38%.
However, the election results proved to be a shock to many, as Labour indeed reached the 38% mark.
True to his word, Professor Goodwin found himself in a rather unusual situation as he prepared to dine on his own words, quite literally.
The momentous occasion took place in front of a small audience, with cameras capturing the unique event.
Goodwin, with a mix of humor and humility, proceeded to tear pages out of his book, dip them in a glass of water, and consume them one by one.
The act of eating his pro-Brexit book served as a symbolic gesture, marking the unforeseen outcome of the election and Goodwin's commitment to his words.
As the last shreds of paper disappeared into his mouth, Goodwin reflected on the significance of the moment.
"While this may be a humorous spectacle, it also serves as a reminder of the unpredictability of politics and the importance of staying true to one's word," he remarked.
The incident left many observers amused and impressed by Goodwin's willingness to follow through on his promise, even if it meant literally eating his own book.
The event stands as a memorable footnote in the aftermath of the election stunner, underscoring the twists and turns that can occur in the world of politics.

PRINCETON, N.J. — Jerome Desrosiers’ 3-pointer with 36 seconds left in overtime provided the winning points in Princeton’s 76-73 victory over Yale on Friday.
Desrosiers finished with a team-high 19 points, showcasing his clutch performance when it mattered most.
The Tigers fought hard throughout the game, and Desrosiers' shot in the overtime period proved to be the decisive moment in securing the win for Princeton.
The game was intense from start to finish, with both teams displaying strong offensive and defensive efforts.
Yale put up a tough fight, led by standout performances from Alex Copeland and Trey Phills.
However, it was Princeton's resilience and determination that ultimately led them to victory in this hard-fought contest.
Yale took possession after a tie-up in regulation but Trey Phills was unable to connect on a 3-pointer as the game went to overtime.

Myles Stephens scored 18 points and Devin Cannady and Bell 16 apiece for the Tigers (11-8, 3-1 Ivy), who have won three straight, with Bell collecting a career-high 11 rebounds for his first career double-double.
Alex Copeland scored 18 points, Phills had 17 points and a career-high 14 rebounds for his first career double-double while Blake Reynolds added 15 points for the Bulldogs (9-12, 2-3).
BEIRUT (AP) — Kazakhstan says it has postponed talks aimed at firming up a Syrian cease-fire by one day.
The talks were scheduled to take place in the Kazakh capital, Nur-Sultan, but have now been pushed back due to logistical reasons.
The delay comes as international efforts continue to seek a lasting solution to the conflict in Syria, which has been ongoing for over a decade.
The talks, organized by Russia, Turkey, and Iran, are part of the Astana peace process, which aims to bring together the Syrian government and opposition groups to negotiate a lasting cease-fire.
The postponement underscores the complexities and challenges of reaching a consensus among the various parties involved in the conflict.
Despite the setback, all parties remain committed to finding a peaceful resolution to the Syrian crisis.

MADRID (AP) — Six of nine prominent Catalan separatist politicians jailed for promoting the region's drive to secede from Spain have been moved to prisons closer to their homes.
The transfer was seen by some as a conciliatory gesture, but Catalan leader Quim Torra emphasized that it should not be misconstrued as a peace offering.
Torra stated that the prison transfer was a legal requirement and not a sign of any negotiations between the Catalan separatists and Madrid.
He reiterated that the conflict between Catalonia and the Spanish government is fundamentally political rather than legal in nature.
Torra said in a statement outside the Catalan regional parliament in Barcelona that the transfer is stipulated by law and "is not part of any negotiation."
He says the Catalan conflict with Madrid is political, not legal.
Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu participated in the foundation-laying ceremony of a Holocaust museum in Thessaloniki, Greece.
The museum is dedicated to the memory of the thousands of Jews who were deported from the city during World War II.
Netanyahu emphasized the importance of remembering the atrocities committed during the Holocaust and the need to educate future generations about the horrors of the past.
Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras also attended the ceremony, expressing his commitment to preserving the memory of the Holocaust and combating anti-Semitism.
About 50,000 died there.
Tsipras said Tuesday the museum will fulfill an old debt for the city, some 40 percent of whose pre-war population was Jewish.
Overall, some 90 percent of Greece's Jewish population was murdered by Nazi forces during the war.

TORONTO — Firefighters say a large blaze that led to the evacuation of six buildings and shut down parts of midtown Toronto is now under control.
Toronto Fire Chief Matthew Pegg says the fire was extinguished at 5:45 a.m. Wednesday, nearly a day after it began burning at The Badminton and Racquet Club.
He says no one was seriously injured as more than 100 firefighters at any given time battled the blaze.

Pegg says residents and office workers won't be allowed back into the evacuated buildings until Wednesday afternoon at the earliest as they deal with expected hot spots and flare-ups throughout the day.
The fire, which sent plumes of dark smoke into the sky and caused significant traffic disruptions in the area, prompted a swift and coordinated response from emergency services.
Pegg commended the efforts of the firefighters in containing the blaze and preventing it from spreading further.
The cause of the fire is still under investigation, and authorities are working to assess the extent of the damage to the affected buildings.
Local residents and business owners expressed relief that the fire was brought under control without major injuries or loss of life.
As cleanup and recovery efforts get underway, the community is coming together to support those impacted by the incident.

The local police department is inviting residents to join in for a unique opportunity to engage with law enforcement officers over a cup of coffee this Friday.
The popular "Coffee with a Cop" event will take place at the Community Center from 9 am to 11 am.
This initiative aims to foster positive interactions between the police and the community, breaking down barriers and building trust.
Residents are encouraged to drop by, grab a cup of coffee, and have a chat with the officers who serve their neighborhoods.
Whether it's sharing a concern, asking a question, or simply getting to know the faces behind the badges, this event provides a casual and welcoming environment for open dialogue.
The Coffee with a Cop program is a nontraditional way to generate conversation between the police department and the community it serves.
The event allows the public to interact with officers, including top department leadership, in an informal setting to ask questions or address concerns.
Cycling enthusiasts are invited to share their unique bike ride experiences as entries are being sought for a one-of-a-kind guide to quirky bike rides.
The guide aims to showcase hidden gems and lesser-known cycling routes in England and Scotland that may not be found on traditional cycle maps.
Whether it's a picturesque coastal path, a charming village trail, or a scenic countryside loop, cyclists are encouraged to reveal their favorite off-the-beaten-track places to explore on two wheels.
The guide will serve as a celebration of unconventional cycling destinations, highlighting local attractions, charming coffee shops, and breathtaking viewpoints that make each ride memorable.

The #MyFavBikeRide Guide will celebrate the best ‘off the beaten track’ places to cycle in England and Scotland with the aim of trying to encourage those who rarely use a bike to get back on two wheels this summer.
Cyclists are being called on to reveal their own favourite routes that people wouldn’t necessarily find on cycle maps such as coffee shops or best views.
The guide will be produced to mark bike hire company Bike & Go’s fourth birthday.

Las Vegas Strip headliner David Copperfield is due to return to the witness stand in a lawsuit by a British tourist who claims he was seriously hurt in a fall while taking part in one of Copperfield’s signature illusions in 2013.

The magician resumes testimony Tuesday after last week revealing secrets behind a trick that appears to make volunteer audience members vanish onstage and appear a few moments later in the back of the theatre.

The British man, Gavin Cox, alleges that he slipped and fell while participating in Copperfield's "Lucky #13" illusion, which involved disappearing from the stage and reappearing in the back of the theatre.
Cox claims he suffered brain and bodily injuries due to the fall, leading to a lengthy legal battle.
Copperfield's testimony is anticipated to shed light on the events surrounding the illusion and the circumstances of Cox's alleged injuries.
The trial continues to attract attention as both sides present their arguments in this high-profile case.
MOUNT PLEASANT, S.C. — It wasn’t the Easter bunny that startled a South Carolina homeowner and his family.
It wasn’t even a burglar.
Instead, it was a massive 9-foot alligator that made itself right at home on their porch.
The homeowner, Mr. Johnson, discovered the unexpected visitor early Monday morning when he went outside to grab the newspaper.
To his surprise, he found the massive reptile lounging casually on his porch, seemingly unperturbed by the commotion it had caused.
Local wildlife officials were quickly called to the scene to safely remove the alligator, which was eventually relocated to a more suitable habitat away from residential areas.
Mr. Johnson and his family were relieved that no one was hurt during the encounter, but they were certainly left with a story to tell for years to come.

NEW YORK (AP) — Regulators want to make emergency alerts on cellphones more useful by requiring wireless carriers to distribute them less widely.
The Federal Communications Commission says carriers must transmit the alerts to more specific locations, rather than broadly.
The move comes in response to concerns that the current system floods entire regions with alerts, leading to desensitization and confusion among the public.
By targeting alerts to affected areas more precisely, emergency messages are expected to reach those directly impacted while reducing unnecessary disruptions to others.
The new rules aim to improve the effectiveness of emergency alerts, ensuring that individuals receive timely and relevant information during crises.
Wireless carriers will need to implement these changes to enhance the overall utility of the alert system and better serve the public in times of need.
Nigeria’s government has proposed closing the airport in its capital, Abuja, for six weeks to repair runways that some airlines have described as dangerous.
Continue Reading Below The government wants to close Nnamdi Azikiwe International Airport, the country’s second busiest, for most of February and March.
This decision has raised concerns among airlines and travelers about the impact on air travel and the inconvenience it will cause.
Flights would be diverted for six weeks to Kaduna city, which is 250 kilometers (155 miles) from Abuja on a road frequented by bandits.

A government statement Monday says officials will meet stakeholders on Thursday, realizing the “high level of discomfort and inconvenience” the closure of one of West Africa’s busiest airports will cause.
When Oregon lawmakers created the state's legal marijuana program, they made low barriers to entry to convince pot growers to leave the black market.
This strategy worked perhaps too well, as the state now faces a massive surplus of cannabis.
The flood of product into the market has caused prices to plummet, leading to financial struggles for many growers.
Now marijuana prices in Oregon are in freefall and the farmers who put Oregon on the map decades before legalization are losing their now-legal businesses.
Oregon regulators have announced they will stop processing new applications for marijuana licenses in two weeks and want state lawmakers to take up the issue next year.
As the market stumbles, experts say the dizzying evolution of Oregon's marijuana industry may well be a cautionary tale for California.
A similar regulatory structure there could mean an oversupply on a much larger scale as that state's market emerges.
TOKYO — Japan coach Akira Nishino is relying heavily on veteran players with previous World Cup experience in his 23-man squad for the tournament.
The squad includes familiar faces such as Shinji Kagawa, Keisuke Honda, and Maya Yoshida, who have proven their worth on the international stage in past World Cup campaigns.
Nishino's decision to opt for experience suggests a cautious approach, prioritizing the stability and composure that seasoned players bring to high-pressure situations.
However, the squad also features some younger talents like Takuma Asano and Yuya Osako, injecting a blend of youth and experience into the team.
"These players have experience but more than that they were picked based on their performance and the balance they offer."
Nishino made his debut as Japan coach on Wednesday when his team lost to Ghana 2-0 in a friendly.
By MARTHA McCLAIN Special to the PRESS Laguna Vista officials were unanimous in their opposition to Senate Bill 2113 during their meeting Tuesday.
The bill, introduced into the State Legislature by Sen. Eddie Lucio Jr., could have initiated a plan to study the consolidation of public schools in Cameron County into one county-wide district.
Mayor Susie Houston expressed concerns about the potential impact on local control and educational quality.
Councilman John Smith highlighted the importance of maintaining the individuality and unique characteristics of each school.
The officials emphasized the need for community input and involvement in decisions that directly affect the education system.
Superintendent Maria Garcia echoed these sentiments, stating that a one-size-fits-all approach may not be suitable for the diverse needs of the county.
The opposition to the legislation reflects a shared commitment to preserving the autonomy and identity of local schools.
Crawley residents are bracing themselves for heavy snowfall later today as the Met Office issues a weather warning for the area.
The heavy snow is now expected to arrive between 11am and 2pm, when temperatures are likely to drop to just 1C.
No further snow is forecast for later in the day, though temperatures will consistently drop until they hit -1C at about 11pm.
But if you think that’s cold enough - be warned - taking wind chill into account, it will feel more like -4C, -5C or even -6C throughout the day.
The Met Office has advised people in Crawley to prepare for potential travel disruptions and to take precautions to stay warm and safe.
With the possibility of heavy snowfall and plummeting temperatures, residents are urged to avoid unnecessary journeys and to wrap up warm if they need to go out.
Local authorities are also on high alert, ready to deploy gritters and snowplows to keep key routes clear and ensure essential services can continue to operate smoothly.
Schools and businesses are advised to monitor the situation closely and make any necessary arrangements in case of closures or disruptions.
As Crawley braces for the winter blast, residents are reminded to check on vulnerable neighbors and loved ones to ensure they are also prepared for the inclement weather.
Stay tuned to local weather updates for the latest information on the developing situation.
As freezing temperatures descend upon Lancashire, drivers are being urged to exercise caution due to icy road conditions.
With the sudden drop in temperature, road surfaces have become treacherous, posing a risk to motorists across the region.
The Lancashire County Council has issued a warning to drivers, highlighting the potential hazards of icy roads and advising individuals to adjust their driving behavior accordingly.
The plummeting temperatures have led to the formation of black ice, a particularly dangerous phenomenon that can catch drivers off guard.
Local authorities are urging motorists to drive at reduced speeds, increase their following distance, and avoid sudden maneuvers that could result in loss of control.

Additionally, drivers are encouraged to ensure their vehicles are equipped with appropriate tires for icy conditions and to drive with extra vigilance on bridges and overpasses, which tend to freeze first.
Anyone taking to the roads this morning is advised to take particular care on rural roads and asked to leave extra time for their journeys.
Drivers are also being asked by police to thoroughly defrost their cars before they set off.
Lancashire Road Police shared a picture on social media of the Bay Gateway in Lancaster covered in ice.
Officers jokingly offered residents "free ice skating lessons".
A spokesman for British Transport Police said: "It's pretty icy in places around stations, especially car parks and walk ways.
Please, be careful and take your time."
ALBANY, N.Y. (AP) -- Joe Cremo scored a career-high 31 points and Albany pulled away late in the second half to beat New Hampshire 83-74 on Saturday night.
Albany (18-7, 6-4 America East Conference) dropped a three-point decision to New Hampshire (9-15, 5-5) on Jan. 6, and now has won 10 of the last 14 games against the Wildcats.
Cremo, a senior guard, was unstoppable throughout the game, shooting 11-of-17 from the field, including 5-of-9 from beyond the arc.
His offensive prowess kept Albany in control despite a resilient effort from New Hampshire.
The Great Danes led by just two points with under five minutes remaining before Cremo took over, scoring eight consecutive points to extend the lead and secure the victory.
Albany's defense also played a crucial role in the win, forcing key turnovers and limiting New Hampshire's scoring opportunities down the stretch.
Ahmad Clark contributed 18 points and Devonte Campbell added 12 points for the Great Danes.
New Hampshire was led by Tanner Leissner with 19 points and Jordan Reed with 17 points, but they couldn't overcome Albany's offensive firepower led by Cremo.
The win solidifies Albany's position in the conference standings as they continue their push towards the postseason.
Hartford's Tracy Carter scored 10 of his 14 points in the final five minutes to help the Hawks secure a 73-64 victory over Stony Brook.
Carter's late-game heroics, combined with strong performances from John Dunne and Malik Lynch, propelled Hartford to a hard-fought win on the road.
John Dunne led the Hawks with 18 points, showcasing his scoring ability and leadership on the court.
Malik Lynch provided a spark off the bench, contributing 15 points and making crucial plays down the stretch to help Hartford maintain its lead.
Stony Brook put up a tough fight, with Akwasi Yeboah leading the Seawolves with 23 points.
UC Iroegbu added 12 points to the scoreboard, while Elijah Olaniyi recorded a double-double with 10 points and 10 rebounds.
Despite their efforts, Stony Brook couldn't overcome Hartford's resilience, dropping their fifth straight game by a margin of 9 points.
The Seawolves have endured a challenging stretch of close losses, falling short in tight contests against their opponents.
Akwasi Yeboah led the Seawolves (8-16, 3-7) with 23 points, UC Iroegbu added 12 and Elijah Olaniyi 10 points and 10 rebounds for his first double-double.
Stony Brook has dropped five straight, losing by 2, 3, 4, 7 and 9 points.
Google has recently introduced voice recognition capabilities for Indian and African languages on its popular Gboard platform.
This update allows users to communicate more naturally in their native languages, enhancing the overall user experience.
With this addition, Google now supports a wide range of languages, catering to a diverse global audience.
In total, this brings the grand total of Gboard's voice recognition to 119 languages.
Google has also added the ability for US English users to add emoji with simple voice dictation.
If you say, "winky face emoji," the proper emoji will appear.
Google's working on expanding this feature to more languages in the near future.
You can access these languages today in Cloud Speech API, which means that they will soon be available across Google services and products, including in apps such as Google Translate.
You can download Gboard for Android from the Google Play store.
DETROIT — The PGA Tour is returning to the Detroit area after a 10-year absence.
Detroit-based Quicken Loans has signed an agreement to host a new PGA Tour event in the Motor City starting next year.

POTOMAC, Md.
- A dramatic rescue unfolded on the Potomac River near Washington, DC, when a teenager was plucked from the water after a near-drowning incident.
The incident occurred on a busy Sunday afternoon when onlookers noticed the teen struggling in the water and quickly called for help.
Emergency responders rushed to the scene and a daring rescue operation ensued, with a team of firefighters and divers working tirelessly to reach the struggling teen.
After several tense moments, the rescuers were able to pull the teenager to safety, providing immediate medical attention on the riverbank.
The teen was then transported to a nearby hospital for further evaluation and treatment.

The quick response and heroic efforts of the rescue team undoubtedly saved the teenager's life, highlighting the importance of water safety and the swift actions of trained professionals in emergency situations.
TORONTO (WCMH) — A Canadian brewery has announced a new craft beer called Fake News Ale.
The restaurant and brewery, Northern Maverick Brewing, announced the beer on twitter April 10.
The brewery describes the Fake News Ale as a beer that will “make beer great again,” poking fun at the popular political slogan.
This unique brew is said to be a smooth, easy-drinking ale with a crisp finish, perfect for those who enjoy a lighter beer.

The brewery's decision to name the beer Fake News Ale has sparked mixed reactions online, with some finding it humorous and others expressing concern about the implications of using the term in a commercial product.

WASHINGTON (AP) — President Donald Trump says OPEC is "doing little to help" rising gas prices and claims "if anything, they are driving prices higher."
Trump tweeted Wednesday: "The OPEC Monopoly must remember that gas prices are up & they are doing little to help.
If anything, they are driving prices higher as the United States defends many of their members for very little $'s.
This must be a two way street.
REDUCE PRICING NOW!"
Trump's comments come as gas prices in the United States have been steadily increasing in recent months, reaching levels not seen in years.

The president's criticism of OPEC, the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries, is not new, as he has previously accused the group of manipulating oil prices to benefit its member countries.
The United States has been pushing for lower oil prices, as higher gas prices can have a negative impact on the economy and consumers.
Trump's call for OPEC to reduce pricing reflects his administration's efforts to address the issue and ensure that Americans are not burdened by high gas costs.
It remains to be seen how OPEC will respond to Trump's latest remarks and whether any changes in pricing will occur in the near future.

— Jeremy Rainville scored twice and set up three more as the Cantonniers de Magog toppled the Toronto Young Nationals 7-4 on Tuesday for their second straight win to open the 2018 Telus Cup.
Rainville leads all scorers through two games at the national midget championship with seven points.
The game started with high intensity as both teams traded goals in the first period.
Magog's offense exploded in the second period, with Rainville leading the charge with a goal and two assists to give his team a commanding lead.
Toronto fought back in the third period, but Magog's defense held strong to secure the victory.
The Cantonniers showcased their depth with contributions from multiple players, including Gabriel Montreuil and Olivier Nadeau, who each scored a goal and added an assist.
The win solidifies Magog's position as a top contender in the tournament, with Rainville emerging as a standout player to watch.
Caroline Wozniacki eased into the third round of the French Open with a 6-1 6-0 demolition of Georgina Garcia Perez on Wednesday.

RALEIGH, N.C. — Federal wildlife officials say the only wild population of endangered red wolves is unsustainable and could be wiped out within years.
The prediction comes in a five-year review of the status of the species released Tuesday by the U.S.
Fish and Wildlife Service.
The report highlights the critical situation faced by the red wolves, with only around 20 to 25 remaining in the wild in eastern North Carolina.
Factors such as habitat loss, illegal killings, and hybridization with coyotes have contributed to the decline of the population.

Conservationists are calling for urgent measures to protect the remaining red wolves, including increased habitat protection, stricter law enforcement against illegal killings, and efforts to address hybridization issues.
Without immediate action, the iconic red wolf species, once prevalent throughout the southeastern United States, faces the real threat of extinction in the wild.

Officials tweaking new licenses plates to make them more legible hello Illinois' new license plates are about to get a touch-up after complaints that the new ones aren't as easy to read as the old ones.
The current design, which features a blue and white color scheme with a mix of letters and numbers, has faced criticism for its lack of clarity, especially at a distance.
In response, officials have announced plans to adjust the font size, spacing, and color contrast to enhance readability.
The Illinois Secretary of State's office assured that the updated design will maintain the aesthetic appeal of the plates while prioritizing legibility for law enforcement and the general public.
The tweaks aim to ensure that license plates remain easily identifiable for automated license plate readers and surveillance cameras.
Motorists can expect to see the revised plates rolling out in the coming months, with a focus on improving visibility and compliance with state regulations.
Cleveland Browns' Myles Garrett runs though drills during the team's organized team activity at its NFL football training facility Tuesday, June 6, 2017, in Berea, Ohio.
(AP Photo/Ron Schwane) BEREA, Ohio (AP) -- Browns rookie defensive end Myles Garrett, the No.
1 overall pick in this year's draft, limped off the field with an apparent foot injury late in practice on Wednesday.
The team is awaiting further evaluation to determine the severity of the injury.
Garrett, who has been impressing coaches and teammates with his performance during OTAs, was participating in a team drill when he appeared to injure his foot.
Head coach Hue Jackson expressed concern over Garrett's injury, emphasizing the need to prioritize the player's health above all else.
The Browns are hopeful that the injury is not serious and that Garrett will be back on the field soon.
He did not return to practice and limped into the field house when the Browns were forced to go indoors because of inclement weather.
Garrett continued to favor his foot when he walked into the locker room.
Jackson said he would not know the extent of Garrett's injury until he is examined by doctors.
Garrett missed time earlier this spring with an unspecified injury.
The Browns signed Garrett to a four-year, $30.4 million contract.

The NYPD is facing a lawsuit demanding access to records concerning the treatment of disabled prisoners.
Amy Jane Agnew, an attorney representing Wayne Stewart, 38, filed the lawsuit last week in an effort to obtain all complaints made by wheelchair-bound suspects against the police.
Agnew alleges that there is a pattern of police officers violating the civil rights of disabled prisoners.

Stewart, who is currently serving a 33-year to life sentence for murder, claims that he suffered from sepsis after being placed face-down on the floor of a cell at the 25th Precinct station house back in July 2014.
The city Law Department was in the process of settling the lawsuit, but it was later withdrawn as Stewart refused to drop a separate personal-injury suit related to the same incident.
Amy Jane Agnew, attorney for Wayne Stewart, 38, sued the NYPD last week, seeking all complaints made by wheelchair-bound suspects against the police.
Agnew says she believes cops routinely violate disabled prisoners’ civil rights.

Stewart, who is now serving 33 years to life for murder, claimed in his Manhattan federal suit that he got sepsis after cops laid him face-down on the floor of a cell at the 25th Precinct station house in July 2014.
A city Law Department spokesman said the settlement was withdrawn because Stewart refused to drop a second personal-injury suit over the same incident.

CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla. (AP) — Want the world’s best, up-close view of a rocket launch without being right there at the pad?
For the first time, cameras will provide live 360-degree video of a rocket heading toward space.
NASA will provide the 360 stream Tuesday as an unmanned Atlas rocket blasts off from Cape Canaveral, Florida, with a capsule full of space station supplies.
The stream will begin 10 minutes before the scheduled 11:11 a.m. liftoff and continue until the rocket is out of sight.
This groundbreaking initiative by NASA will allow viewers from around the globe to immerse themselves in the excitement of a rocket launch like never before.

Through the live 360-degree video feed, spectators will have the opportunity to witness the intricate details of the launch pad, the roaring engines igniting, and the rocket ascending majestically into the sky.
The innovative technology will enable viewers to pan and tilt the camera, giving them a complete perspective of the launch from every angle.
This immersive experience promises to bring the thrill of space exploration closer to audiences worldwide, providing a unique and unforgettable glimpse into the wonders of space travel.
Don't miss this historic event as NASA takes us on a virtual journey to the stars.
The latest update for Destiny 2, titled Warmind, is set to bring a chilling new horde event to the game's arctic Mars location.
The add-on introduces a wave-based activity that will test the skills and coordination of players as they face off against a formidable enemy horde in the icy terrain of Mars.
Players will have to strategize and work together to fend off the relentless onslaught of enemies while uncovering new challenges and rewards along the way.
The elite foe at the heart of the event promises to be a formidable adversary, dropping custom gear that will entice players to return again and again.
One noteworthy aspect of the horde event is that players have control over when it is activated, ensuring that the challenge won't be random and allowing for more strategic gameplay.
Additionally, the Warmind update brings significant changes to the PvP experience in Destiny 2.
Two new ranked modes, Valor and Glory, will provide players with different avenues to test their skills in competitive play.
The Glory mode will feature a rank ladder that moves players up and down based on their performance in matches, adding a new layer of competitiveness to the PvP experience.
Fans can also look forward to new exclusive PvP weapons each season, as well as tweaks to existing exotic guns like Sturm/Drang, Graviton Lance, and more.
The update will introduce two new strikes, Strange Terrain and Will of the Thousands, along with a PS4 exclusive strike, The Insight Terminus.
Furthermore, the Leviathan raid will receive a second lair called Spire of the Stars, and the Eater of Worlds raid will get a prestige version when the game's third season begins.
With a host of new content and updates on the horizon, Destiny 2 players have plenty to look forward to in the Warmind expansion.
The elite foe drops custom gear so folks will have to wait over a month to collect them all; Since players activate the event, at least it won't be random.
PvP is getting two ranked modes, one for casual (Valor) and competitive (Glory), though the latter will move players up and down the rank ladder as they win and lose games.
Every season will introduce a new gun exclusive to PvP for players to earn.

Fans already knew that tweaks were coming for their favorite exotic guns, including Sturm/Drang, Graviton Lance, Skyburner's Oath and Rat King, but the stream also showed off changes to Fighting Lion, Riskrunner, Crimson and the infamous Hard Light.
There will be two new strikes, Strange Terrain and Will of the Thousands, and one coming exclusively for PS4 players: The Insight Terminus.
The Leviathan raid will get a second lair called Spire of the Stars, which will arrive after Warmind launches.
Finally, the prestige version of Curse of Osiris' raid, Eater of Worlds, will arrive when the game's third season starts.
Ahead of next weekend's rescheduled Champions Cup game against Racing 92, Munster have confirmed that Darren Sweetnam will be sidelined for six weeks.
Sweetnam sustained a knee injury in an off-the-ball tackl just before half-time in Munster's Pro12 win over Leinster on St Stephen's Day.
The 23-year-old winger has been a key player for Munster this season, showcasing his pace and agility on the field.
His absence will undoubtedly be felt by the team as they prepare for a crucial period of fixtures in both domestic and European competitions.
In the wake of Sweetnam's injury, Munster will be looking to other players to step up and fill the void.
With a busy schedule ahead, including the rescheduled Champions Cup clash and crucial Pro12 matches, the depth of the squad will be tested.
Head coach Rassie Erasmus will be assessing his options to ensure that the team remains competitive in Sweetnam's absence.
In other injury news for the province, Tommy O'Donnell will undergo further investigation for an ankle injury he sustained late on in the Pro12 win over Connacht on New Year's Eve.
Alex Wootton (shoulder), Sean McCarthy (knee), Mark Chisholm (concussion), Duncan Casey (knee), Mike Sherry (back), Cathal Sheridan (ankle) are all currently available.
On a player news front, it has been confirmed that Angus Lloyd and Jaco Taute will remain with the province until June 2017.
In joining the province at the start of November on a short-term loan from Ulster, scrumhalf Lloyd has extended his stay until the summer.
The 24-year-old Dublin native made his debut against Treviso at the end of November.
Springbok Taute, who plays centre/fullback has made 11 appearances for Munster so far, scoring five tries.
Town progressed to the semi-finals of the Buckingham Charity Cup with a very laboured performance on Tuesday night against a very hard working Unite MK 2-1 in Bletchley.
The match started off with both teams testing each other's defenses, but it was Leighton Town who managed to break the deadlock first.
Tom Silford found the back of the net from close range, giving his team the lead.
However, their joy was short-lived as Unite MK fought back and equalized with a scrappy goal.
As the game progressed, both teams pushed for the crucial winning goal.
It was substitute James Hatch who proved to be the hero for Leighton Town, scoring the decisive goal near the end of the match.
Despite having the greater share of possession, Leighton Town struggled to create clear-cut chances and failed to trouble the home keeper consistently.
Although Leighton had the greater share of possession they failed to really trouble the home keeper.
Town went ahead when Tom Silford beat the 'keeper from close range and this should have set them on the way to victory but a scrambled effort drew their hosts level.
Substitute James Hatch got the winner near the end and Town played out the final minutes without any scares.

Although Town started this game without seven regular first team players, manager Reynolds needs to work hard to have the entire squad up for games of this nature if they are to continue to challenge for honours this season.
In a surprising turn of events, a renowned weather reporter was caught fabricating data to sensationalize their forecasts.
The incident has shocked the journalism community as the reporter was known for their accurate predictions and engaging reporting style.
The falsified information came to light during an internal audit of the station's weather department, revealing discrepancies in the recorded weather patterns and actual meteorological data.
This scandal has raised concerns about the reliability of weather reporting and the pressure faced by forecasters to deliver captivating content.
As viewers rely on accurate weather forecasts for planning their daily activities, such deceit erodes trust in the profession.
The incident serves as a reminder of the importance of integrity in journalism and the need for transparency in reporting.

As part of the ongoing cuts at Condé Nast, eight people were chopped at Vogue, the flagship title headed by Anna Wintour.
Among those who The Post has confirmed were laid off were Director of Communications Zara Rahim and Senior Market Editor Kirby Marzec.
News of the cuts was first reported by Business of Fashion.
The moves are part of the rolling cuts that are re-shaping Condé Nast, which was said to have lost more than $100 million last year.
As part of that, earlier this year, Vanity Fair cut about 20 editorial staff, and Glamour cut around 10 in a single day of bloodletting.
Radhika Jones, who replaced Graydon Carter at the helm of VF earlier this year, has slowly been filling about half the spots.
The layoffs at Vogue are indicative of the broader challenges faced by the publishing industry, as print publications struggle to adapt to the digital age.
The fashion world is not immune to these shifts, with traditional publications facing increased competition from online platforms and social media influencers.
The restructuring at Condé Nast reflects a larger trend in the media landscape, as companies seek to streamline operations and cut costs in response to changing consumer habits and market dynamics.
Vogue, known for its iconic fashion coverage and celebrity features, will undoubtedly feel the impact of these layoffs as it navigates a rapidly evolving industry.
Former San Antonio Spurs legend David Robinson has weighed in on the ongoing Kyrie Irving trade saga, expressing his belief that the Spurs would be foolish not to pursue the talented guard.
With Irving recently requesting a trade from the Cleveland Cavaliers, speculation has been rife about potential landing spots for the All-Star.
Robinson's endorsement of the Spurs as a desirable destination for Irving adds further fuel to the fire.
Irving has reportedly listed several preferred destinations for a trade, with the Spurs being one of the teams he would welcome a move to.
That list included the Spurs, the Heat, the Timberwolves, and the Knicks.
But seeing as how he doesn’t have a no-trade clause, virtually every team in the league has come calling in hopes that they can finagle a deal to land the Cavs’ superstar guard.

If Irving truly wants to jump from one contender to another, his best bet is absolutely the Spurs, although there are plenty who think his isolation-heavy style of play is a poor fit in San Antonio’s share-the-wealth system.
Just don’t count David Robinson among those skeptics, as he told SiriusXM NBA radio recently:

WATCH THIS: “The New Celebrity Apprentice” (8 p.m., NBC): With Donald Trump headed for the White House, action movie star and former California governor Arnold Schwarzenegger takes over the boardroom as this reality series takes on a new look.
But some things never change: The cast still features a bunch of folks you’ll have to Google.

The 36-year-old software sales executive is no stranger to the spotlight, having previously appeared on “The Bachelorette” and “Bachelor in Paradise.” Will Nick finally find the one among the 30 women vying for his heart?
Tune in to find out as the drama unfolds in the iconic Bachelor mansion.

Now Holden must try and figure out what happened to him during those 12 years; how to survive a world that changed while he was gone; and answer the question, why did this happen to him?

The Cyprus Co-Operative Bank has announced its decision to put itself up for sale in a bid to address its financial challenges.
The bank, which is currently 77-percent state-owned, is seeking investors to inject capital and help alleviate its burden of bad loans, which account for over 58 percent of its total loan portfolio.
This move comes as part of the bank's strategic plan to strengthen its position in the market.
In a statement released today, the bank revealed that it has appointed Citigroup Global Markets to oversee the sale process.
Interested investors have until March 29 to submit their expressions of interest.
Despite its struggles with non-performing loans, the Cyprus Co-Operative Bank remains a key player in the local banking sector, holding the highest amount of deposits by Cypriots.
The bank said Monday it has appointed Citigroup Global Markets to look for investors as part of its strategic plan.
The deadline for expressions of interest is March 29.
The bank is 77-percent state-owned and is the leader in the amount of deposits held by Cypriots.
But it's weighed down by bad loans — more than 58 percent of the total.
That was a consequence of a 2013 banking crisis that forced Cyprus to accept a rescue deal that included a seizure of unsecured deposits in the country's two largest lenders.
Finance Minister Harris Georgiades said the move would help rebuild confidence and credibility in the bank.
Four men have been arrested in Toronto following a dramatic pursuit that unfolded in the city streets.
The incident began when an officer spotted four individuals in a vehicle, dressed in what seemed to be clothing meant to conceal their identities.
One of the occupants reportedly exited the vehicle brandishing a handgun and fired shots towards passing traffic and pedestrians, fortunately without causing any injuries.
The ensuing chase came to a halt after the vehicle collided with a police car, having previously crashed into two taxis and driven erratically along a sidewalk, narrowly avoiding pedestrians.
The authorities have apprehended the suspects, shedding light on the alarming events that transpired on Monday.
They say the men were arrested on Monday after an officer saw four people, who appeared to be wearing clothing designed to disguise their identities, in a vehicle.
It's alleged one of the occupants got out of the vehicle carrying a handgun and fired in the direction of traffic and pedestrians, but it's not believed anyone was struck.
Investigators say a pursuit of the vehicle ended when it struck a police car, but not before it had collided with two taxis and driven down a sidewalk, narrowly missing pedestrians.
Facebook and Newell Brands took a hit in the market today, while Orbotech saw a significant climb in its stock value.
Facebook shares dropped by 2.7% following reports of a data breach scandal, leading to concerns about user privacy and regulatory scrutiny.
Newell Brands also experienced a decline of 6.5% after announcing a deal with activist investor Carl Icahn, who will nominate four directors to its board.
On the flip side, Orbotech's stock surged by 10.3% after the company reported better-than-expected earnings and revenue for the quarter.
Investors responded positively to the strong performance, driving up the stock price.
Overall, technology companies faced a tough day in the market, with Alphabet Inc. also seeing a notable decline of 3% in its stock value.
The broader market sentiment was mixed, with investors closely monitoring various developments and news impacting different sectors.
In other market news, Stewart Information Services Corp. saw a significant increase in its stock value after announcing its acquisition by Fidelity National Financial.
GGP Inc. faced a slight decline following reports of a new offer from Brookfield Property Partners.
Universal Display Corp. also experienced a drop in its stock price after news that Apple may start designing and manufacturing its display screens internally.
Stewart Information Services Corp., up $1.89 to $42.61 The title insurance and real estate services company said it will be bought by Fidelity National Financial for about $1.2 billion.
GGP Inc., down 20 cents to $21.52 Reuters reported that Brookfield Property Partners made a new offer for the shopping mall operator.
Universal Display Corp., down $15 to $109 Bloomberg News reported that Apple is designing and making display screens and may stop buying them from other companies.
Newell Brands Inc., down $1.87 to $26.79 The consumer products company announced a deal with activist investor Carl Icahn, who will nominate four directors to its board.
Alphabet Inc., down $34.35 to $1,100.07 Technology companies fared worse than the rest of the market Monday.
The fire duo, known as Half-A-Mil, which consists of Dom Kennedy and Hit-Boy, have made their return with their third installment of their joint EP series.
The highly anticipated EP, titled "Half-A-Mil 3," showcases the seamless collaboration and undeniable chemistry between the two artists.
Fans can expect a blend of smooth West Coast vibes and dynamic production that have become signature elements of their music.
"Half-A-Mil 3" features a mix of introspective lyrics, infectious hooks, and innovative beats that highlight Dom Kennedy's laid-back flow and Hit-Boy's exceptional production skills.
The EP is a testament to the duo's creativity and musical prowess, solidifying their status as a powerhouse team in the hip-hop industry.
With this latest release, Dom Kennedy and Hit-Boy continue to push boundaries and deliver top-notch music that resonates with fans worldwide.
"Half-A-Mil 3" is sure to be a hit among both longtime supporters and new listeners alike.

The 200,000 people forced to evacuate their homes in Oroville have been told they can go back home.They were instructed to flee Sunday because a damaged spillway threatened to collapse and send water flowing into the valley north of Sacramento.
Now, water levels at Lake Orville are dropping and it is expected to be low enough to handle an incoming storm.Work continues nonstop at the dam itself Tuesday night.
The reprieve from mother nature has reduced the danger to surrounding communities, enough so that officials felt comfortable letting people return to their homes.
As the residents returned to Oroville, a mix of emotions filled the air.
Relief washed over many as they unlocked their doors and stepped back into their homes, grateful to find their belongings intact.
However, the fear of what could have been lingers in the minds of Oroville's residents.
The experience of being evacuated on such short notice has left a lasting impact, prompting many to reconsider their emergency preparedness plans.

"This situation is a textbook example of why we need to pursue a major infrastructure package in Congress," said White House Press Secretary Sean Spicer.By nightfall, the thousands of people who had left in such a hurry Sunday night were flowing back into downtown Oroville.

Many businesses did not immediately open but prepared to Wednesday.Though clearly grateful to be back home and eager to return to some sense of normalcy, some here told ABC7 News they're already thinking about how to be better prepared if there is a next time.
"We're not sure if we're to keep our vehicles," said resident Chuck S. "Not quite sure about that one yet.
""I'm still a little weary," said another resident Gail McElroy.
"Still got everything packed up."
Speculation is mounting over Dundee manager Paul Hartley’s future.
The Tele understands the Dark Blues board is meeting today to discuss the alarming slump that has seen their team drop to the relegation play-off place on the back of seven consecutive defeats.
And that could mean a change of gaffer by the time the team see action in their first post-split fixture, at Motherwell on Saturday week.
The club have refused to comment on the speculation and first thing this morning the manager and his players reported for training as normal.
The run of poor results has put Hartley under increasing pressure, with fans expressing their frustration at the team's performances.
The board is likely to assess the situation carefully before making any decisions regarding the manager's future.
With crucial matches ahead, including the play-off battle to avoid relegation, Dundee will be looking to turn their form around quickly.
Stay tuned for updates as the situation develops.
BAKU, Azerbaijan (AP) — The mayor of Azerbaijan's second-largest city has been shot and wounded in an attack that also wounded his bodyguard.
The Interior Ministry said Elmar Veliyev, the mayor of Ganja, was attacked outside his office late Tuesday.
It said in Wednesday's statement that the gunman was arrested by police.
His motives weren't immediately clear.
The shooting of Mayor Veliyev has sparked concerns and raised questions about the safety of public officials in Azerbaijan.
Authorities have launched an investigation into the incident to determine the reasons behind the attack.
Veliyev and his bodyguard are currently receiving medical treatment for their injuries, and their condition is reported to be stable.
The news of the shooting has sent shockwaves through the city of Ganja, with residents expressing their support and well-wishes for the mayor's swift recovery.
Further updates on the situation are expected as the investigation progresses.
Nanaimo marijuana dispensary closed down by police  In a recent operation, the Nanaimo Royal Canadian Mounted Police (RCMP) shut down an illegal marijuana dispensary in the downtown area.
Acting on a tip from concerned citizens, officers conducted a raid on the establishment, which had been operating without the necessary licenses and permits.
The police arrested the owner, a 35-year-old man, on charges of drug trafficking and operating an unlicensed cannabis store.
The business was then closed and secured.
Officers later seized approximately 1.5 pounds of marijuana during a search of the premises.
“The RCMP is guided by the existing laws and legislation.

We recognize the current complexities surrounding the potential for future legislative changes, however, the RCMP is mandated with enforcing the laws of Canada as they exist today,” says Superintendent Cameron Miller, Officer in Charge of the Nanaimo RCMP.
The man arrested was released with a promise to appear in court in July.
Jaelene Hinkle revealed she decided not to play for the U.S. women's national team last year because her Christian faith prevented her from wearing a jersey that commemorated LGBTQ Pride Month.
Hinkle revealed the reason for her decision last June in an interview posted Wednesday on The 700 Club website.
No formal reason for her absence was given by the national team at the time.
"I just felt so convicted in my spirit that it wasn't my job to wear this jersey," she said.
Hinkle has not been called up to the national team since.
A defender, Hinkle plays for the North Carolina Courage of the National Women's Soccer League.
The Courage visited the Portland Thorns on Thursday night, and there were boos heard when she was announced in the starting lineup.
Hinkle's decision has sparked debate and controversy within the soccer community and beyond.
Supporters of LGBTQ rights have criticized her stance, while others have applauded her for standing by her beliefs.
Hinkle's case raises questions about the intersection of sports, personal beliefs, and societal issues.
The incident highlights the ongoing challenges of balancing personal convictions with professional responsibilities in the realm of sports.
Sheriff's deputies are searching by land and air for a missing at-risk person in Lakeside.
The missing individual is identified as 68-year-old John Strausbaugh, who was last seen in the area of Willow Road and Winter Gardens Boulevard.
Strausbaugh, who suffers from a medical condition that requires daily medication, was reported missing by his family earlier today.
Authorities are concerned for Strausbaugh's well-being due to his medical needs and the time he has been missing.
The search efforts involve K-9 units, drones, and patrol units scouring the Lakeside area in hopes of locating him swiftly.
The Department's Lakeside substation is asking anyone who sees or thinks they have seen Strausbaugh to call the SDSO dispatch at (858) 565-5200.
LOS ANGELES (AP) — The winds aren't changing for Southern California's wildfires yet.
As the wildfires continue to ravage parts of California, dangerous winds persist, fueling the flames and hampering firefighting efforts.
Authorities are on high alert as the strong gusts have been spreading the fires rapidly, threatening homes and communities in their path.
Evacuation orders remain in place for several areas as firefighters battle to contain the blazes amidst challenging conditions.
The unrelenting winds have made it difficult for fire crews to gain the upper hand, with the fires showing no signs of slowing down.
Residents are urged to stay vigilant and prepared for any sudden changes in the fire's behavior.
With the relentless winds showing no signs of abating, the situation remains precarious as firefighters work tirelessly to protect lives and properties from the devastating wildfires.
RVH, Royal Victoria Regional Health Centre, is setting its sights on establishing a new campus in the south end of Barrie.
The proposed ‘South’ Campus aims to cater to the growing population in the area and alleviate the strain on RVH’s current facilities.
With patient volumes on the rise and the existing medical/surgical occupancy rates consistently exceeding capacity, the need for expansion has become imperative.
The envisioned ‘South’ Campus is expected to provide a range of healthcare services to residents in the southern region of Barrie and beyond.
By strategically locating this new facility, RVH aims to ensure better access to healthcare services for a larger portion of the community.
The potential benefits of this expansion include reduced wait times, improved patient care, and more efficient service delivery.
To spearhead this ambitious project, a Capital Planning Committee has been established to explore all possibilities for enhancing service provision to the south end of Barrie.
Two comprehensive planning studies will be conducted to determine the services RVH should offer in the future, identify the optimal location for the new campus, and plan the necessary infrastructure.
Since the opening of its expansion in 2012, RVH has been grappling with escalating patient volumes, leading to surge conditions and consistently high occupancy rates.
The pressing need for additional space has forced RVH to care for patients in unconventional areas, such as hallways.
The introduction of the ‘South’ Campus is envisioned as a crucial step in addressing these challenges and ensuring the continued delivery of quality healthcare services to the community.
A Capital Planning Committee has been struck to look at all the possibilities for boosting service to south end Barrie and beyond.
Two planning studies will explore, in great detail, the services RVH should provide in the future, the preferred location and infrastructure planning.
Since opening the expansion in 2012, RVH has grappled with surging patient volumes.
The health centre has experienced surge conditions for the past year and on most days every bed is full.
In fact, the medical/surgical occupancy rate at RVH is consistently over 115 percent and recently hit 135 percent.
Those surging volumes mean RVH must care for patients in unconventional spaces, including hallways.
Authorities have taken a significant step in the long-standing investigation into the deaths of two young women from the Kansas City area.

Kylr Yust was charged Thursday with two counts of first-degree murder and two counts of abandoning a corpse in the deaths of 17-year-old Kara Kopetsky of Belton and 21-year-old Jessica Runions of Raymore.
He is being held on $1 million bond.
Yust had long been a suspect in the two deaths.
Runions was seen leaving a gathering with Yust before she disappeared in September 2016.
Kopetsky had filed a protection order against Yust in April 2007, a month before she went missing after walking out of Belton High School.
The charges bring a sense of closure to the families of the victims, while also shedding light on the tragic events that have haunted the community for years.
In a dominant display of home court advantage, UC Santa Barbara Men's Basketball team continued their undefeated streak at the Thunderdome by defeating CSU Northridge with a commanding 75-51 victory.
The Gauchos showcased their prowess right from the tip-off, setting the tone for the game early on.
UCSB's offensive strategy was firing on all cylinders, with Ar'Mond Davis leading the charge with an impressive 20 points.
Davis' stellar performance was complemented by his teammates' solid contributions, as the Gauchos maintained a tight grip on the game throughout.
The first half saw both teams trading baskets, but UCSB managed to pull away with an 8-2 run, finishing the half with a 32-25 lead.
The Gauchos continued their momentum in the second half, where they unleashed a dominant 19-1 run, leaving CSU Northridge struggling to keep up.
Max Heidegger's sharpshooting from beyond the arc, including four crucial 3-pointers, added 14 points to UCSB's tally.
Marcus Jackson and Ami Lakoju also made significant contributions with 12 and 10 points respectively.
UCSB first pulled away with an 8-2 run to end the first half with a 32-25 lead.
The Gauchos then kept CSU Northridge (5-18, 2-7) at bay until going on a 19-1 run to lead 68-44.
Max Heidegger added four 3-pointers and 14 points, Marcus Jackson scored 12 and Ami Lakoju 10 for UC Santa Barbara.
Tavrion Dawson had 16 points and 10 rebounds and Lyrik Shreiner scored 10 for the Matadors.
Sweet news for chocoholics, Nutella have announced the launch of a new chocolate, biscuit snack bar set to launch in stores this September.
The beloved brand, known for its delectable hazelnut spread, is expanding its product line to offer consumers a convenient and indulgent treat on the go.
The new Nutella chocolate snack bar combines the rich flavors of Nutella with a crunchy biscuit texture, creating a satisfying snack that is sure to delight fans of the brand.
Each bar is individually wrapped, making it perfect for enjoying as a quick pick-me-up during a busy day or as a sweet treat to satisfy cravings.
Nutella has long been a favorite among chocolate lovers for its creamy texture and irresistible taste.
With the introduction of the new snack bar, fans can now enjoy the iconic Nutella flavor in a convenient and portable format.
Whether you're looking for a tasty snack to enjoy during your commute or a delicious treat to share with friends, the Nutella chocolate snack bar is sure to become a go-to option.
In addition to its delicious flavor, the Nutella chocolate snack bar is also a convenient option for those looking for a satisfying snack that can be enjoyed anytime, anywhere.
With its combination of chocolate and biscuit, this new offering from Nutella is set to become a staple in the snack aisles of stores across the country.
Make sure to keep an eye out for the new Nutella chocolate snack bar when it hits shelves this September.
Indulge in the rich and creamy taste of Nutella in a convenient and delicious new way with this exciting product launch.
TEMPE, Ariz. (AP) In what coach Bruce Arians called ”great news,” Arizona Cardinals running back David Johnson’s knee injury is not serious and will not require surgery.
An MRI showed Johnson has a left MCL sprain that would require six to eight weeks of rest and rehabilitation.
Johnson, speaking to reporters on Monday, said he knew a few moments after the injury that it wasn’t serious because of the amount of weight he could put on the leg and his ability to move around.
The injury ended his NFL record string of at least 100 yards from scrimmage in each of the first 15 games of a season.
He also fell short in his bid to be the third player to have 1,000 yards rushing and 1,000 yards receiving in the same season.
Despite the setback, Johnson remains optimistic about his recovery and is focused on getting back to full strength for the next season.
The Cardinals organization is also relieved that their star running back will not be sidelined for an extended period.
Johnson's absence will undoubtedly be felt on the field, but the team is confident in their depth at the running back position to fill the void in his absence.
Fans and teammates alike are sending their well wishes to Johnson for a speedy recovery, knowing that his presence on the field is crucial for the team's success.
With determination and hard work, Johnson is expected to make a full recovery and return stronger than ever for the upcoming season.
Manchester City manager Pep Guardiola has unequivocally shut down rumors linking Isco to the club, firmly stating that there are no plans to bring the Real Madrid midfielder to the Etihad Stadium.
Guardiola's dismissal comes amidst speculation surrounding Isco's future, with reports suggesting a potential move away from the Spanish capital.
Guardiola's focus remains on City's current squad and their objectives for the upcoming season.
The manager is content with the players at his disposal and is not looking to make any significant additions at this time.
With the transfer window in full swing, Guardiola's comments provide clarity on City's transfer stance regarding Isco.
While Guardiola is ruling out Isco's arrival, he is fully concentrated on City's pursuit of success, particularly in the Champions League.
Real Madrid, under the guidance of Zinedine Zidane, has been a dominant force in the competition in recent years, clinching three consecutive titles.
Guardiola acknowledges the challenge posed by the Spanish giants but remains determined to thwart their quest for a fourth consecutive triumph.
Guardiola's respect for Zidane's managerial prowess is evident as he expresses his admiration for Real Madrid's achievements and his ambition to disrupt their reign in Europe.
However, he has promised City will do its utmost to end the Spanish club's recent dominance.
"It's spectacular, you have to take your hat off to them," Guardiola said.
"It doesn't matter if they deserve it or not, because it's very difficult to do what they've done.
"They've demonstrated their quality, and we hope to prevent them from taking the fourth consecutive one.
"Zidane has done a spectacular job."
WASHINGTON (AP) — The Republican-led Senate has voted to block an Obama-era regulation that would prevent an estimated 75,000 people with mental disorders from being able to purchase a firearm.
The rule, put forth in the final days of the Obama administration, aimed to strengthen gun control measures by ensuring that individuals deemed mentally impaired would not have access to firearms.

The Obama administration rule strengthened the federal background check system by requiring the Social Security Administration to include the names of beneficiaries with mental impairments who also have a third party to manage their benefits.
But critics say the rule was too broad and unfairly stigmatized the disabled.
With a Republican ally in the White House, the GOP has moved aggressively to rescind several late Obama administration regulations.
