The White House says it disagrees "strenuously" with a budget analysis of the Republican health care plan.
Health Secretary Tom Price says it will cover more individuals and lower costs.
Congress' nonpartisan budget analysts projected Monday that 14 million Americans would lose coverage next year under House Republican legislation remaking the nation's health care system.
In response, Secretary Price emphasized that the administration's plan is focused on expanding access to healthcare and reducing costs for all Americans.
He highlighted the importance of providing more choices and flexibility in healthcare coverage.

The disagreement between the Health Secretary and the Congressional Budget Office report underscores the ongoing debate and differing perspectives on the best approach to reforming the healthcare system in the United States.
Stay tuned for further developments and reactions to this unfolding story.
The UK Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) has put forth a set of proposals aimed at curbing high-cost lending practices within the country.
The suggested crackdown targets overdraft fees, rent-to-own agreements, doorstep lending, and catalog credit and store cards.
According to the FCA, more than 3 million consumers in the UK rely on high-cost credit, leading to financial instability for many individuals.
The proposed reforms seek to protect vulnerable borrowers from excessive charges and predatory lending practices.
The FCA's chief executive, Andrew Bailey, emphasized that the new measures aim to shift the balance in favor of customers who are often burdened by high-cost debts.

The regulatory body plans to conduct further research and analysis before finalizing any decisions to ensure that the reforms are effective in safeguarding consumers from exploitative lending practices.
The authority's chief executive Andrew Bailey said that "the proposals will benefit overdraft and high-cost credit users, rebalancing in the favor of the customer."
The body is also proposing reforms on rent-to-own operators, door-step lending and catalog credit and store cards, saying that high-cost credit is used by more than 3 million consumers in the U.K.
The FCA says it will gather more evidence and analysis before any formal decisions are made.
A teenage boy is expected to survive after being life-flighted to the hospital following a crash in Kansas City.
The incident occurred earlier today when a car collided with a truck in the heart of the city.
Emergency responders quickly arrived at the scene to provide assistance and transport the injured teen to the hospital for further treatment.

The crash forced accident investigators to close roads in the area, but the scene is expected to clear at about 7 p.m. KCPD Sergeant Bill Mahoney says the driver of a car was attempting to turn and may have misjudged how much time they had, colliding with a truck.
FOX 4 is told everyone involved in the crash will be okay, but that the teen will likely be kept at a hospital overnight for observation.
Netflix is shaking things up yet again with the testing of a new 'Ultra' subscription tier that comes with a hefty price tag.
This premium tier aims to offer subscribers an even more enhanced viewing experience, but at a cost.
The new plan, spotted by users in Europe, is priced at €16.99 per month, significantly higher than the current Premium plan.
The 'Ultra' tier is said to include HDR support, which promises richer colors and better contrast for those with compatible devices.
However, the steep price increase has raised eyebrows among Netflix users.
Many are questioning whether the additional feature justifies the extra cost, especially when the number of screens or other perks remain the same as the existing Premium plan.
In Europe, that top tier costs €13.99 (£9.99 in the UK).
Thankfully, it doesn't look like Netflix is planning to hike its current subscription prices any further, but a new even higher tier could be on the way.
According to TuttoAndroid, users in Italy have noticed a new 'Ultra' plan costing an additional €3.
The only discernible difference is the inclusion of HDR support.
That seems like a lot of money for no extra screens or other perks, but for the moment this is just a test to see what people make of the new model.
In a statement given to CNET, a Netflix spokesperson said that they "continuously test new things at Netflix and these tests typically vary in length of time.
In this case, we are testing slightly different price points and features to better understand how consumers value Netflix."
The test shows different things to different people.

LEWISTON, Maine (AP) — U.S. family-owned promotional products company Geiger is buying the largest family-owned promotional products distributor in the United Kingdom.
CEO Gene Geiger said Monday the merger with BTC Group expands the company's footprint in Europe.
The acquisition of BTC Group marks a significant milestone for Geiger as it strengthens its presence in the European market.
With this strategic move, Geiger aims to enhance its product offerings and services to a broader customer base.
The combined expertise and resources of both companies are expected to create synergies that will drive growth and innovation in the promotional products industry.
Geiger's commitment to quality and customer satisfaction aligns well with BTC Group's values, making this partnership a promising endeavor.
The expansion into the UK market presents new opportunities for Geiger to establish a stronger global presence and deliver value to clients on an international scale.
A tragic incident unfolded in Riverview, near Tampa, as a man stands accused of the brutal killing of two family members and injuring another.
The Hillsborough County Sheriff’s Office announced that Ronnie Oneal III, 29, was arrested and charged with two counts of murder along with other offenses.
Authorities were alerted to the scene following a distressing 911 call reporting gunshots.
Upon arrival, deputies discovered a woman outside the residence who had succumbed to her injuries.
The situation intensified as Oneal confronted the deputies, resulting in his apprehension using stun guns.
Inside the burning home, firefighters made a harrowing discovery of an 8-year-old boy with stab wounds and his deceased sister.
The young boy was rushed to a nearby hospital for urgent medical care.
This heartbreaking event has left a community reeling from the senseless violence and loss.
A Hillsborough County Sheriff’s Office news release says 29-year-old Ronnie Oneal III was charged Monday with two counts of murder and other charges.
Deputies say they responded to the Riverview home, near Tampa, late Sunday after a 911 call from a woman who claimed she had been shot.
The deputies found the woman in the lawn, and she was later pronounced dead.
Deputies say they were confronted by Oneal and subdued him with stun guns.
Firefighters found the couple’s 8-year-old son stumbling out of the house with multiple stab wounds, and then his sister was found dead inside the burning home.
The boy was taken to a Tampa hospital for surgery.

Archaeologists have made a remarkable discovery in Egypt as they uncovered a 4,000-year-old tomb from the ancient civilization.
The tomb, believed to date back to the Fifth Dynasty of the Old Kingdom, provides valuable insights into the rich history and culture of ancient Egypt.
The tomb's architecture and intricate decorative style showcase the advanced craftsmanship of the time, highlighting the significance of this find.
The archaeological mission, led by Egypt's secretary general of antiquities, Dr. Mostafa Wazir, has been diligently working to unearth and preserve this historical site.

The discovery of this tomb adds another piece to the puzzle of Egypt's ancient past, offering researchers and historians a rare opportunity to study and learn from this well-preserved archaeological find.

TEMPE, Ariz. — The death of a woman who was struck by a self-driving Uber SUV as she crossed a street in suburban Phoenix is the event that many in the auto and technology industries had been dreading.
The crash marks the first fatality involving a fully autonomous vehicle, raising significant concerns about the safety of self-driving technology.
The victim, Elaine Herzberg, was walking outside of the crosswalk when the incident occurred, highlighting the complexities of integrating autonomous vehicles into urban environments.
Authorities are investigating the circumstances of the accident, with both Uber and local police cooperating to determine the cause.

Clifton Edward Avent Jr., 48, was charged with robbery and theft of property more than $1,000 in value after police received tips that identified him via Facebook.
The incident took place at the Sav-A-Lot store on Maple Street last Thursday, where Avent allegedly entered the store, brandished a weapon, and demanded money from the employees.
He then fled the scene with an undisclosed amount of cash, leaving the store staff shaken but unharmed.
Authorities were able to track down Avent thanks to the information provided by concerned citizens who recognized him from surveillance footage shared on social media.
Avent was apprehended at his residence on Saturday evening without incident and taken into custody for questioning.
During the interrogation, Avent reportedly confessed to the robbery, claiming financial hardship as the motive behind his actions.
He was arraigned in court on Sunday and is currently being held without bail pending further legal proceedings.
He remained in jail Sunday.
Avent was released from jail three days prior for violation of conditional release, according to jail booking records.
In a thrilling encounter at the DW Stadium, Wigan Athletic secured a crucial 2-0 victory over Gillingham, maintaining their position at the top of League One.
The match showcased Wigan's attacking prowess and defensive solidity, as they dominated proceedings from the first whistle.
The home side wasted no time asserting their dominance, with Will Grigg opening the scoring in the 10th minute with a clinical finish from close range.
Reece James orchestrated the goal with an excellent run down the left flank, setting up Grigg perfectly for the opener.
Wigan continued to press forward and were rewarded in the 34th minute when Nick Powell headed home a pinpoint corner from Max Power to double their lead.
As the second half kicked off, Wigan remained relentless in their pursuit of goals.
Michael Jacobs came agonizingly close to extending their lead, hitting the post early in the half.
Gillingham tried to mount a comeback, but their efforts were thwarted by Wigan's resolute defense.
In a tense moment towards the end of the match, Elliott List thought he had pulled one back for Gillingham in stoppage time, only for his celebrations to be cut short by the offside flag.
The final whistle blew, confirming Wigan's victory and maintaining their two-point lead at the top of the League One table.
Grigg opened the scoring on 10 minutes with a deadly finish from close range after Reece James had done well down the left-hand side.
And Powell scored the goal his overall display warranted with a bullet header from Max Power’s pinpoint corner on 34 minutes.
Michael Jacobs hit a post at the beginning of the second period, which wouldn’t have flattered the home side.
There was a scare right at the end, when Elliott List thought he’d pulled one back for Gillingham in stoppage-time, but the celebrations were halted by an offside flag.
Latics remain two points clear at the top of League One over Shrewsbury, who have played a game more, but are now four points ahead of third-placed Blackburn, who have played two games more.
Trial set for ex-cop accused of supporting Islamic State  Former police officer Nicholas Young is facing trial for allegedly supporting the Islamic State group.
Jury selection is scheduled to begin Monday afternoon in federal court in Alexandria, Virginia.
Young, who worked as a police officer in the Metro system, was arrested last year in a government sting operation.
Prosecutors claim that Young purchased nearly $250 in gift cards with the intention of supporting the Islamic State, and then gave the cards to an individual who turned out to be an FBI informant.
Young's defense team argues that their client was a victim of entrapment, pointing out that he had been under surveillance for six years prior to his arrest.
Surveillance documents indicate that Young had been monitored since 2010.
The trial, which was initially set to commence last week, was postponed due to the emergence of new evidence.

Jury selection begins Monday afternoon in federal court in Alexandria, Virginia, in the case against Nicholas Young, who was a police officer in the region’s Metro system when he was arrested last year in a government sting.
Prosecutors say Young bought nearly $250 in gift cards he intended for the Islamic State group, giving the cards to an individual who turned out to be an FBI source.
Young’s lawyers say the sting amounts to entrapment after their client was under surveillance for six years.
Documents show Young had been under surveillance since 2010.
The trial had been expected to begin last week but was delayed when new evidence emerged.
Bonnie Tyler is having a total turnaround.

Sales for the songstress’ 1983 hit “Total Eclipse of the Heart” skyrocketed ahead of Monday’s “Great American Eclipse.” Last week, the ballad saw a 503 percent increase in digital download sales, with 12,000 downloads recorded compared to just 2,000 in the week ending Aug. 13, according to Billboard.
On Sunday, the day before the historic solar eclipse was set to streak the United States from coast to coast, the song garnered 4,000 downloads.
It also came in at No.
23 in iTunes’ top 100 songs Monday.
“Eclipse” reached No.
2 on the iTunes chart in 2017 after Tyler performed the song on a cruise ship during the solar eclipse.
The song’s resurgence in popularity could be attributed to its fitting title and theme, resonating with the celestial event capturing the nation’s attention.
Fans and new listeners alike are rediscovering the power ballad, propelling it back into the limelight decades after its initial release.
Tyler’s timeless vocals continue to strike a chord, bridging the gap between nostalgia and contemporary fascination with cosmic phenomena.

Palestinians are expressing confusion and concern following the United States' recent view on the possibility of a two-state solution.
The U.S. has indicated that the two-state solution is optional, sparking skepticism and uncertainty among Palestinians.
Many have long viewed the two-state solution as the most viable path towards a lasting peace agreement with Israel.
Dr. Husam Zomlot, head of the Palestinian mission in the UK, has highlighted that the U.S. stance has left Palestinians puzzled and questioning the future of peace negotiations.
A White House official has said that it’s up to Israelis and Palestinians to decide what peace will entail, and that peace, not a two-state solution, is the goal.

In March, housing starts in the US experienced a decline, although they remained notably higher compared to the figures from 2016.
The dip in housing starts is a cause for concern, as it may indicate a slowdown in the housing market despite the overall strength in the economy.
However, the fact that the numbers are still stronger than in 2016 provides some reassurance to analysts and investors.
The housing market is closely tied to economic conditions, and the recent drop in housing starts could be a reflection of various factors such as rising material costs and labor shortages.
More Americans are seeking new homes as job security has improved with low unemployment.
Rising housing starts suggest higher sales, but the construction has not overcome a dwindling supply of new and existing homes.
Building permits — an indicator of future home construction — rose 3.6 percent in March to an annual rate of 1.26 million.

Drop an F-bomb, drop some weight.
That’s per a recent presentation to a conference organized by the British Psychological Society.
Keele University psychologist Richard Stephens organized two groups of participants, who were told to pedal vigorously on an exercise bike for 30 seconds and perform a hand-grip test respectively.
The surprising twist?
One group was allowed to swear repeatedly during the activities, while the other had to remain silent.
The findings were intriguing – those who swore showed significant increases in both their physical performance and strength compared to the non-swearing group.
This led to the conclusion that swearing might actually have a positive impact on physical performance.
While the idea of loud, swearing gym bros might seem off-putting to some, there could be a scientific basis behind their behavior.
The act of swearing has long been associated with releasing pent-up emotions and stress, which could help individuals push through physical barriers during exercise.
Furthermore, the use of strong language has been linked to increased pain tolerance and a surge in adrenaline levels, both of which can be beneficial during intense workouts.
It appears that the raw, unfiltered expression of swearing might be a powerful tool in unlocking hidden reserves of strength and endurance.
So, the next time you hear someone dropping colorful language at the gym, they might actually be onto something.
While it's important to be mindful of the environment and respectful of others, a well-placed expletive could be the secret ingredient to taking your workout to the next level.

Many small business owners are open to hiring or want to recruit employees who have disabilities.

Business owners do need to make reasonable accommodations if employees need help balancing their work and their personal or medical needs.

Kansas lawmakers are currently evaluating the possibility of implementing tax hikes to address the state's budget deficit.
The proposed measures aim to tackle the significant financial challenges Kansas is currently facing.
With a budget shortfall projected to reach nearly $1.1 billion by June 2019, finding sustainable solutions has become a pressing concern for legislators.
The proposed bill has garnered bipartisan support, highlighting the recognition of the urgency to stabilize the state's finances.
However, within the GOP-controlled House, Republicans are divided on the issue, indicating potential challenges in passing the legislation.
Kansas has been grappling with ongoing financial difficulties following substantial tax cuts initiated in 2012 and 2013 at the urging of former Governor Brownback.
The bill under consideration includes ending tax exemptions for over 330,000 farmers and business owners, as well as raising income tax rates.
These measures are crucial steps in addressing the state's budget woes and setting it on a path towards financial recovery.
The measure has bipartisan support but Republicans in the GOP-controlled House are split.
Kansas faces budget shortfalls totaling nearly $1.1 billion through June 2019.
The state has experienced persistent financial problems since Republican lawmakers slashed personal income taxes in 2012 and 2013 at Brownback’s urging.
The bill would end an exemption for more than 330,000 farmers and business owners and boost income tax rates.

MILWAUKEE (AP) — Prosecutors allege a Milwaukee woman killed her 4-year-old son by setting him on fire in a bathtub in their apartment.
Twenty-three-year-old Amelia DiStasio faces a charge of first-degree intentional homicide.
She remains jailed with bail set at $400,000.
According to the complaint, authorities were called about smoke at DiStasio’s south side apartment Thursday morning and found her son Antonio’s burned and lifeless body in the bathtub.
His hands had been bound behind his back with several belts, and a plastic garbage bag was over his head.
An open bottle of cooking oil was in the bathroom.
The mother was not home.
A witness says she saw DiStasio climb out of the apartment window and run away.
The tragic incident has shocked the community, with neighbors expressing disbelief and horror at the gruesome details of the crime.

Authorities are still investigating the motive behind this heinous act, and the case has left many wondering about the circumstances that could drive a mother to commit such a horrific crime against her own child.
The Milwaukee Police Department has assured the public that they are diligently working on the case to ensure that justice is served for young Antonio.
As the community mourns the loss of the innocent child, there is a collective call for support and awareness to prevent such tragedies from occurring in the future.

A deadly incident in Nantes has sparked clashes between police and protestors, escalating tensions in the city.
The situation unfolded when police officers attempted to apprehend a man suspected of being involved in organised robbery.
The man, whose identity remains undisclosed, reportedly resisted arrest and allegedly assaulted one of the officers.
In response, another officer fired a fatal shot at the man, who was rushed to the hospital but succumbed to his injuries shortly after.
The shooting has ignited anger among residents, leading to confrontations with law enforcement in the streets of Nantes.
Protestors have voiced their outrage over the use of lethal force and are demanding justice for the deceased individual.
The incident has reignited debates over police conduct and the handling of potentially volatile situations.
Police have defended their actions, stating that the officer resorted to using his weapon after the man refused to comply with orders and assaulted a fellow officer.
An arrest warrant had been issued for the man prior to the incident, further complicating the circumstances surrounding the shooting.
In response to the escalating tensions, additional police reinforcements are expected to be deployed in Nantes to prevent further violence.
Police say an officer shot the man after he had refused to comply with orders and had hit another officer.
The man - who has not been identified - was taken to hospital but died soon afterwards.
An arrest warrant had earlier been issued for the man on suspicion that he was involved in organised robbery, France's BFMTV reports.
Police reinforcements are now expected in Nantes to prevent any further violence.
German police have made significant strides in combating migrant-smuggling activities by arresting three individuals in coordinated raids.
The arrests come as part of a crackdown on a smuggling ring that has been operating in the country.
The suspects, believed to be part of an organized group involved in smuggling migrants from neighboring countries, were apprehended in Berlin and Bad Muskau.
Federal police spokesperson Christian Meinhold disclosed that the raids were conducted across four German states, resulting in the seizure of seven properties.
The group is suspected of transporting migrants from the Czech Republic and Poland, predominantly utilizing trucks for their illicit activities.
The investigation into the smuggling operation began last fall following reports of increased trafficking.
Germany has been grappling with the issue of illegal migration, with approximately 186,000 asylum-seekers entering the country last year.
Authorities attribute the persisting high numbers in part to the activities of human smugglers, underscoring the need for continued vigilance and enforcement efforts.
Federal police spokesman Christian Meinhold said raids were staged in four German states Wednesday.
Two suspects were arrested in Berlin and a third in Bad Muskau, on the Polish border, and seven properties searched.
The suspects are believed to belong to a group that smuggled migrants from the Czech Republic and Poland, largely using trucks.
The alleged smuggling took place since August and an investigation was launched in the fall.
Germany saw around 186,000 asylum-seekers arrive last year.
That's much lower than the previous two years, but officials say it's still too high and that's due in part to smugglers' activities.
In a tense World Cup qualifying match, Wales secured a crucial 1-0 victory against Georgia, keeping their hopes alive for a spot in the upcoming finals in Russia.
The only goal of the game came in the 58th minute when Tom Lawrence found the back of the net with a powerful strike, much to the delight of the Welsh supporters.
Despite missing their star player Gareth Bale due to a calf muscle strain, Wales displayed determination and resilience throughout the match.
Georgia put up a strong fight, but Wales' solid defense and strategic attacks ultimately paid off, earning them three vital points in the qualifying campaign.
With this victory, Wales now sits in second place in Group D, just a point behind leaders Serbia.
The race for qualification is heating up, with every point crucial in determining which teams will secure their spots in the World Cup finals.
Third-placed Ireland faces a must-win situation against Moldova to stay within touching distance of Wales before the highly anticipated clash between the two Celtic rivals in Cardiff on Monday.
Meanwhile, Serbia has the opportunity to clinch qualification with a win against Georgia in their final qualifier.
Bale's absence was felt by the Welsh team, but they showed their depth and resilience in securing the important win.
The upcoming matches promise to be intense as the teams battle for qualification spots in the finals.
Third-placed Ireland must beat Moldova at home to stay within a point of Wales, ahead of a meeting between the two Celtic rivals in Cardiff on Monday in the final round of qualifiers.
If the Serbs fail to beat Austria, they can clinch qualification with a win at home to Georgia on Monday.
Bale was missing for the Welsh at Boris Paichadze Dinamo Arena in Tbilisi because of a calf muscle strain, sustained while playing for Real Madrid.
He will also miss the match against Ireland.
The group winner qualifies automatically for the finals in Russia.
The best eight second-place finishers from the nine groups in the European zone advance to the playoffs.
In a significant move aimed at providing relief to the underprivileged, India's recent budget announcement includes plans to offer free cooking gas and a health insurance scheme for the poor.

The new government will determine the full-year budget for 2019-20.

CHAMPAIGN COUNTY, Ohio (WDTN) – The Champaign County Sheriff’s Office issued a missing juvenile alert October 5.
Alexis Johnson, a 16-year-old female, was last seen leaving Graham High School in St. Paris around 3:30 p.m. on October 4.
She was reported missing by her family after failing to return home that evening.
Alexis is described as 5 feet 5 inches tall, with brown hair and hazel eyes.
She was last seen wearing a gray hoodie and black leggings.
Authorities are concerned for Alexis's well-being and are actively searching for her.
According to the Champaign County Sheriff’s Office report, Alexis had a ride from the high school to Urbana and Alexis’s friends said she could be heading towards Columbus.
Anyone with information regarding the missing juvenile is encouraged to contact Detective Ryan Black, or Detective Josh Welty with the Champaign County Sheriff’s Office at (937) 653-3409.

During a white supremacist rally in Charlottesville, Virginia over the weekend, far-right demonstrators including neo-Nazis and Ku Klux Klan members were involved in violent clashes with counter-protesters.
A woman was killed and 19 other people were injured on Saturday when a car ran into a crowd protesting against the rally.
This incident sheds light on the alarming rise of hate groups in America.
According to a recent report by the Southern Poverty Law Center, there has been a significant increase in the number of hate groups operating in the United States in recent years.
These groups promote ideologies based on racism, white supremacy, anti-Semitism, and other forms of hatred and bigotry.
The proliferation of hate groups poses a serious threat to the social fabric of American society.
Not only do they propagate dangerous ideologies that can incite violence and discrimination, but they also contribute to the spread of fear and division within communities.
The events in Charlottesville serve as a stark reminder of the destructive impact that these groups can have on individuals and society as a whole.
In response to the growing threat of hate groups, law enforcement agencies and community organizations are working to combat their influence and prevent further acts of violence.
It is essential for individuals and communities to stand together against hate and intolerance, promoting unity and understanding as the antidote to the toxic ideologies espoused by these groups.

Survival Story: Pilot who crashed blimp speaks out  In a harrowing tale of survival, pilot Jack Thompson recounted the terrifying moments when his blimp crashed during a routine flight.
"It all happened so fast.
One minute we were cruising along, and the next, we were plummeting towards the ground," Thompson said.
Miraculously, Thompson managed to steer the blimp away from populated areas before crash landing in an open field.
Despite sustaining minor injuries, Thompson's quick thinking and experience as a pilot undoubtedly saved lives that day.
The cause of the crash is still under investigation, but Thompson remains grateful to be alive and is determined to return to the skies once he fully recovers.

Quicken Loans, a prominent Detroit-based mortgage lender, has announced its sponsorship of a new PGA Tour event set to take place in Detroit.

The sound of gunfire echoed through the streets as police engaged in a tense battle with armed suspects.
The incident unfolded after law enforcement officers were targeted with gunfire from a residence on Monday, sparking a violent confrontation.
Authorities swiftly responded to the scene, leading to the arrest of five individuals and the seizure of 10 guns.
The intensity of the gunfight left residents on edge, highlighting the escalating security concerns in the region.
Fortunately, the prosecutor's office in the state of Baja California Sur confirmed that no fatalities were reported.
The aftermath of the incident revealed a troubling cache of weapons, including eight rifles and numerous ammunition magazines at the site.
The arrests shed light on the criminal activities of the suspects, who were wanted for various serious offenses.

Baja California Sur, once known for its peaceful ambiance and popular resorts, now grapples with a rising murder rate, underscoring the challenges faced by local authorities in maintaining public safety.
The prosecutor's office in the state of Baja California Sur reports there were no deaths, but says five people were arrested and 10 guns were confiscated.
The office said Tuesday that the gunfight occurred after police came under fire from a house on Monday.
Some of the suspects were wanted on murder, drug, weapons and other charges.
Police found eight rifles and 65 ammunition magazines at the house.
Baja California Sur was once a peaceful state home to the twin resorts of Los Cabos, but now has Mexico's second-highest murder rate, at 69 per 100,000 inhabitants.

BELLEVUE, Wash. — A Seattle-area company has removed a school shooting video game off of its online platform following widespread backlash.
The “Active Shooter” video game was pulled days before it was to be released on the video-game marketplace Steam.
The controversial game sparked outrage due to its premise, allowing players to simulate a school shooting scenario.
Critics argued that such a game glorified violence and was highly insensitive, especially in light of the increasing number of school shootings in the United States.
In response to the public outcry, the game's developer announced the decision to remove "Active Shooter" from its platform.
This move was welcomed by many who saw the game as crossing a line in terms of what is acceptable in video game content.

The incident has reignited debates about the ethical responsibilities of video game developers and the potential impact of such games on society, particularly in relation to sensitive and traumatic real-world events.

× Azubuike withdraws from draft, set for junior year at Kansas LAWRENCE, Kan. — Kansas forward Udoka Azubuike withdrew his name from the NBA draft on Wednesday, choosing to return for his junior season after participating in the combine.
The 7-footer from Nigeria started 34 games last season, averaging 13 points and seven rebounds.
He shot 77 percent from the field, a Big 12 record and the best mark in the nation.
Azubuike's decision to return to Kansas for his junior year comes as a pleasant surprise to Jayhawks fans, who were eagerly awaiting news on his NBA aspirations.
The talented big man's dominance in the paint and efficiency on offense make him a crucial asset for the team as they look to make a deep run in the upcoming season.
The league’s up-tempo pace and the value placed on big men who can shoot from outside go against his strengths, and developing an outside shot will likely be an emphasis at Kansas.
Azubuike said in a statement that he received “good feedback from many sources around the NBA over the last month.” He did not hire an agent and had until Wednesday’s deadline to withdraw.
U.S. Investors Just Gave Up on the Bull Market  After a long period of optimism, U.S. investors seem to have lost faith in the bull market.
The sentiment shift is evident in recent data showing a significant decrease in the number of Americans expecting U.S. stocks to rise in the coming year.
This shift marks a notable departure from the positive outlook that has characterized market sentiment in recent years.

The net share of Americans who expect U.S. stocks to rise over the next year fell below zero for the first time since November 2016 -- the month of Donald Trump’s shock election -- according to the Conference Board’s April survey.
That means that more people think the market will go down than up over a 12-month horizon.
It’s also the largest negative three-month swing since August 2011, which followed the debt-ceiling drama that sparked a downgrade of the U.S. credit rating.
Neil Dutta, head of U.S. economics at Renaissance Macro Research, flagged the retreat as a contrarian indicator for investors.
“No bulls here,” he said.
“It’s OK to buy stocks.”
Nestled in the heart of California, Sacramento offers a vibrant blend of history, culture, and culinary delights that captivate visitors in just 36 hours.
As you explore the city, you'll find yourself immersed in a tapestry of experiences that showcase the best of what Sacramento has to offer.

Down the street, the Warehouse Artist Lofts Public Market has a small but enticing food court with excellent poke — the Hawaiian-style raw fish salad that’s sweeping California — at Fish Face Poke Bar and an exciting collection of shops: midcentury wares and records at Kicksville Vinyl & Vintage, where you can find everything from 45s to atomic age lamps; and fabulously retro vintage clothing at Old Gold.
For admirers of bespoke clothing, Benjamins crafts shoes — like a $375 boot made of leather from the Chicago tannery Horween, which takes 16 to 20 weeks to deliver — on site.

In Sacramento, history comes alive at the California State Railroad Museum, where you can marvel at beautifully preserved locomotives and learn about the pivotal role of the railroad in shaping the state's development.

For a taste of the region's agricultural heritage, a visit to the bustling farmers' markets is a must, where you can sample fresh produce and artisanal goods while mingling with local farmers and producers.
As the sun sets, the city's culinary scene comes alive with a diverse array of dining options.
From farm-to-fork eateries showcasing the best of California's bounty to trendy gastropubs serving up innovative dishes, Sacramento's food scene is a delightful fusion of flavors and influences.
Be sure to indulge in the local craft beer and wine offerings to round out your culinary journey.
With its rich history, vibrant culture, and delectable cuisine, Sacramento offers a memorable getaway that will leave you longing to return for more.
So pack your bags and immerse yourself in the charm of the California capital for an unforgettable 36 hours.

Several homes were evacuated in the city today as a man was detained under the Explosives Act.
Authorities responded to reports of suspicious activity in the area, leading to the evacuation of nearby residents for safety reasons.
The man in question was taken into custody as a precautionary measure while investigations continue.
The situation escalated quickly, prompting a swift response from law enforcement and bomb disposal units.
Residents were urged to stay clear of the area as a precautionary measure.
Concerns for public safety were paramount as authorities worked to assess the potential threat posed by the individual and any possible explosives involved.
Controlled explosion The BBC understands a controlled explosion took place on an area of scrap land nearby.
Image caption A controlled explosion took place Police said they were keeping an "open mind" in relation to the incident, which started during the morning.

Footage shows a vehicle appear to drive into a group of counter-protesters in Charlottesville, Virginia.
Clashes between white nationalists and counter protesters had been ongoing on Aug. 12.
President Donald Trump’s national security adviser, in an interview Sunday, clearly labeled Saturday's deadly car attack in Charlottesville, Virginia, as terrorism, NBC News reported.
National Security Adviser H.R.
McMaster condemned the violent incident, stating, "Of course it was terrorism."
The car ramming incident resulted in the death of a 32-year-old woman and left several others injured.
The attack occurred during a white nationalist rally in Charlottesville, where tensions escalated between the rally participants and counter-protesters.
McMaster emphasized the need to address such acts of violence swiftly and decisively, reaffirming the administration's commitment to combating domestic terrorism.
The incident has sparked widespread condemnation from political leaders and communities across the country, with many calling for unity and peaceful resolution of conflicts.
As investigations into the Charlottesville car attack continue, authorities are working to determine the motives behind the tragic event and bring those responsible to justice.
The incident serves as a stark reminder of the ongoing challenges of extremism and hate in society, underscoring the importance of promoting tolerance and understanding among all communities.
EBS Labour MEP Jude Kirton-Darling says that despite low unemployment levels, one in ten workers in the North-East of England is in precarious work.
The region is the UK's "capital of zero-hours contracts", she adds.
The issue of zero-hour contracts was at the center of a heated debate among Members of the European Parliament (MEPs) this week.
Supporters argue that such contracts offer flexibility for both employers and employees, while critics claim they exploit workers and leave them without job security or stable income.
MEPs discussed potential regulations to address the concerns surrounding zero-hour contracts, with some advocating for stricter laws to protect workers' rights.
The debate highlighted the ongoing tension between labor flexibility and job security, sparking calls for further action to ensure fair working conditions for all employees in the EU.>
Arsenal's midfield maestro Mesut Ozil has made a significant change ahead of the upcoming season by switching to the iconic number 10 jersey, previously worn by club legend Dennis Bergkamp.
The German playmaker, known for his creativity and vision on the field, decided to take on the revered number, signaling a new chapter in his Arsenal career.
But it is a French football icon that Ozil had in mind when opting for a new number.
"It has never been a secret how special this number is to me," Ozil told Arsenal's website.
"My childhood idol Zinedine Zidane wore this number and it is still the most characteristic one for the playmaker position.
"I'm looking forward to putting it on for the first time at Arsenal after the summer break!"
The number 10 jersey holds a special significance in football, often associated with creative midfielders who orchestrate play and provide key assists.
With Ozil taking on this number, Arsenal fans can expect him to continue pulling the strings in midfield and creating opportunities for his teammates with his exceptional vision and passing ability.
As Ozil prepares to don the number 10 shirt for the Gunners, fans will be eager to see him continue his legacy of dazzling performances and playmaking prowess on the pitch.

As we wait for kickoff, WFLA’s Daisy Ruth connected with Instagram fans from across the country to see just which team has the cutest four-legged friends.

SpaceX launching research to space station _ plus ice cream hello CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla. -- SpaceX is about to launch a few tons of research to the International Space Station - plus ice cream.
An unmanned Falcon 9 rocket is scheduled to blast off at 12:31 p.m. Monday from Florida's Kennedy Space Center.
Experiments make up most of the 6,400 pounds of cargo.
That includes 20 mice.
The Dragon capsule is also doubling as an ice cream truck this time.
There was extra freezer space, so NASA packed little cups of vanilla, chocolate and birthday cake ice cream for the station's crew of six, as well as ice cream candy bars.
The research being sent to the space station covers a wide range of scientific areas, from biology to technology.
These experiments will help scientists better understand how different organisms and materials behave in the unique environment of space.
Additionally, the ice cream treats will provide a special and enjoyable respite for the astronauts living and working on the station, offering a taste of home even in the depths of space.
This launch highlights the continued collaboration between SpaceX and NASA in advancing space exploration and research efforts.
Stay tuned for updates on the mission as the Falcon 9 rocket prepares to deliver its payload to the International Space Station.

In a surprising turn of events at the local zoo, visitors were left in awe as they witnessed a gorilla named Louis strolling around his enclosure on two legs, just like a human.
The unusual sight sparked curiosity among onlookers, with many wondering what could possibly prompt a gorilla to walk in such an unconventional manner.
Well you might be surprised to learn that this ape wasn’t on their way to start the revolution.
They just didn’t want to get their food dirty.
According to the zoo’s Director of Communications, Dana Lombardo, Louis walks on his two legs all the time.
She told People, “Louis just hates when his food gets muddy,” so to keep his snacks from getting dirty, he carries them while walking on his hind legs.
Okay… so, Louis is a germaphobe.
Gotcha.

WINNIPEG (AP) — The Winnipeg Hawks appointed controversial Australian opening batsman David Warner as captain of their Global T20 Canada team on Wednesday.
The 31-year-old cricketer replaces the injured West Indian Dwayne Bravo as skipper.
Hawks coach Waqar Younis told the BBC: "He's going to be a good leader.
He's a team man.
He's up front and he likes to give whatever his knowledge is."
Warner's appointment comes with both excitement and some skepticism due to his aggressive playing style and past controversies.
Known for his explosive batting and competitive spirit, Warner brings a wealth of experience to the team.
His leadership skills will be put to the test as he guides the Hawks through the upcoming matches.
Fans are eager to see how Warner's captaincy will impact the team's performance and dynamics on the field.
The Winnipeg Hawks are hopeful that Warner's leadership will lead them to success in the T20 tournament.

From The Trussville Tribune staff reports TRUSSVILLE –Motorists should expect delays on North Chalkville Road this week as Jefferson County road crews work to improve drainage in the area near Snake Hill Road.
The project, aimed at enhancing the safety and functionality of the roadway, involves the installation of a new drainage pipe and the filling of a ditch to prevent flooding during heavy rainfall.
According to Jefferson County Commissioner Joe Knight, the upgrades are crucial for preventing potential road hazards and ensuring smoother traffic flow in the future.

“We’ll cover the pipe and fill the ditch, which will make the road much safer.” Knight said workers may find it necessary to close one lane for extended periods of time over the next several days while they complete the project.
Any closures would begin after morning rush hour and school traffic with plans to open both lanes before the afternoon rush hour.
Drivers going south on Chalkville Road can take Valley Road until it turns into Linden Street and take a right onto Highland Avenue to reach U.S. Highway 11 south of downtown.
Drivers can also detour around the work by taking Green Drive to Trussville-Clay Road and turning right to get back to North Chalkville Road south of the construction area.

A previous evacuation order has been reduced to an evacuation warning, Butte County Sheriff Kory Honea told a news conference, after water management officials drained enough water from the Oroville Dam.
The warning means that people can return but should be prepared to evacuate again if necessary, Honea said.

Both the primary and backup drainage channels of the dam, known as spillways, were damaged after a buildup of water that resulted from an extraordinarily wet winter in Northern California that followed years of severe drought.
Residents who were forced to flee their homes due to the potential threat of flooding can now breathe a sigh of relief as they are allowed to return home.
The progress made in managing the water levels at the Oroville Dam has enabled authorities to lift the mandatory evacuation order.
However, the situation remains fluid, and residents are advised to stay vigilant and ready to evacuate if the need arises again.
The community's safety remains a top priority as officials continue to monitor the dam's condition closely.
MADRID (AP) — Girona avoided conceding late this time, holding on to beat Catalan rival Espanyol 1-0 in the Spanish league on Monday.
The match was tightly contested, with both teams creating chances throughout the game.
However, it was Girona who found the breakthrough just before halftime.
David Timor scored in the first top-flight meeting between the Catalan clubs just before halftime at RCDE Stadium in Barcelona, moving Girona to ninth place.
It was the fourth loss in five league matches for Espanyol, which dropped to 16th in the 20-team standings, near the relegation zone.
"We started well but in the end it was another loss," Espanyol goalkeeper Pau Lopez said.
"It has been a very bad season so far."
Girona conceded injury-time goals in a draw at Real Betis two weeks ago, and in a loss against Alaves last week.

BAKU, Azerbaijan — The mayor of Azerbaijan’s second-largest city has been shot and wounded in an attack that also wounded his bodyguard.
The Interior Ministry said Elmar Veliyev, the mayor of Ganja, was attacked outside his office late Tuesday.
It said in Wednesday’s statement that the gunman was arrested by police.
The motive behind the attack remains unclear, and authorities are investigating the incident.
Veliyev and his bodyguard were immediately rushed to the hospital for medical treatment.
The shooting has sent shockwaves through Ganja, a key city in Azerbaijan known for its historical significance and vibrant culture.
Residents are expressing concern over the safety of their city officials and are calling for increased security measures in the area.
As the investigation unfolds, the community is hopeful for the swift recovery of Mayor Veliyev and his bodyguard, while also seeking answers regarding the troubling incident.
SQUAMISH, B.C.
- Search crews are intensifying their efforts in the search for three hikers who went missing near Shannon Falls in British Columbia.
The trio, identified as experienced hikers, were last seen near the pool system close to the falls.
Concerns grew when they failed to return from their hike as scheduled.
Rescue teams, including members from Squamish Search and Rescue, RCMP, and other agencies, have been scouring the area in hopes of locating the missing hikers.
Despite their collective efforts, the challenging terrain and swift water currents have posed significant obstacles to the search operation.
Corp. Sascha Banks says in a statement that teams from several agencies have been searching for the trio but have not yet spotted the hikers in the pool system.
Banks says the "terrain is difficult, very dangerous, and the water flow is heavy which is complicating the search."

One Dead, One in Police Custody Following Early-Morning Montgomery Stabbing by Rashad Snell The Montgomery Police Department is conducting a homicide investigation following the early-morning stabbing death of Ladarius Snow, 22.
Authorities responded to a call reporting a disturbance on the 300 block of Oak Street around 3 a.m.
Upon arrival, they discovered Snow with multiple stab wounds.
Despite efforts to save him, Snow succumbed to his injuries at the scene.
Witnesses provided crucial information that led to the swift apprehension of a suspect in the vicinity.
The individual, whose identity has not been disclosed, is currently in police custody as the investigation unfolds.
A suspect has been taken into custody and charges are pending.
No additional information is available for release at this time in connection with this continuing investigation.
A recent petition in Hawkins County aimed at forcing a special election on the controversial wheel tax fell short by 127 signatures.
County Clerk Nancy Sharp and her team diligently counted signatures since July 27th, working late into the night on Saturday to finalize the count.
The wheel tax, a measure passed by county leaders to address a $2 million deficit, has stirred debate among residents.
Despite efforts to gather enough support for a special election, the petition fell short of the required number of valid signatures.
The outcome leaves the wheel tax in place for the time being, much to the disappointment of those who had hoped for a different result.
It’s a wheel tax county leaders say they voted on in order to offset a 2 million dollar deficit.
Sharp and her staff began counting signatures on July 27th, and she said they just wrapped up around midnight Saturday.
Ultimately the petition fell short by 127 valid signatures.

Former NBA star David Robinson has weighed in on the potential trade interest in Kyrie Irving, stating that the San Antonio Spurs would be wise to pursue the talented guard.
But seeing as how he doesn’t have a no-trade clause, virtually every team in the league has come calling in hopes that they can finagle a deal to land the Cavs’ superstar guard.

If Irving truly wants to jump from one contender to another, his best bet is absolutely the Spurs, although there are plenty who think his isolation-heavy style of play is a poor fit in San Antonio’s share-the-wealth system.

Robinson's endorsement of Irving highlights the interest and speculation surrounding the All-Star guard's future, with the Spurs emerging as a potential landing spot amidst a flurry of trade talks across the league.
As the trade rumors swirl, it remains to be seen where Irving will ultimately end up and how his playing style will mesh with his potential new team.
Ex-soldiers convicted of killing Chilean singer Victor Jara have been sentenced to prison.
The court found eight former military officers guilty of involvement in the murder of the iconic folk singer during the country's military dictatorship in the 1970s.
Victor Jara, known for his socially conscious music, was a prominent figure in Chilean culture and a vocal supporter of socialist causes.
The investigation into Jara's death revealed that he was tortured and killed in a stadium shortly after the military coup that brought General Augusto Pinochet to power in September 1973.
The court's ruling marks a significant step towards justice for the victims of Pinochet's regime, which was responsible for the deaths of thousands of people.
The office of the court system says a ninth veteran was sentenced to five years for cover-up.
The Marxist folk singer was seized in the hours after Gen. Augusto Pinochet overthrew socialist President Salvador Allende on Sept. 11, 1973.
He was taken the country's main soccer stadium where he was tortured and killed.
Allende's prisons chief Littre Quiroga also was killed.
The ruling announced Tuesday can be appealed.
More than 3,000 people were slain during the 1973-90 dictatorship of Gen. Augusto Pinochet, and most of those crimes remain unsolved.

WASHINGTON (AP) — A U.S. Navy commander says an Iranian naval patrol boat shined a laser at a U.S. Marine Corps helicopter flying over the Strait of Hormuz in what officials say was an unsafe encounter.
U.S. Navy Cmdr.
Bill Urban says the Iranian vessel also turned its spotlight on two Navy ships that were moving through the strait on Tuesday.
This incident has raised concerns about escalating tensions in the region, as the strait is a critical waterway for global oil shipments.
The Strait of Hormuz has been a flashpoint for confrontations between Iran and the United States in the past.

The U.S. military has labeled the Iranian actions as unsafe and unprofessional, emphasizing the need for adherence to international maritime norms to prevent further incidents that could potentially lead to dangerous situations.
Diplomatic channels are being utilized to address the issue and prevent further escalation in the region.
Russia's ROSATOM, a prominent player in the nuclear energy sector, has asserted that nuclear power is a crucial component of a low-carbon energy mix.
The head of ROSATOM, Alexey Likhachev, emphasized the significance of nuclear power in reducing carbon emissions and combating climate change.
Likhachev highlighted the role of nuclear energy in achieving decarbonization goals, citing its importance in meeting international commitments like the Paris Agreement.
Likhachev defended nuclear power as an essential source of clean energy, advocating for its integration alongside renewable sources such as wind and solar power.
He emphasized the unique contribution of nuclear power in providing baseload capacity and ensuring energy security.
ROSATOM is actively involved in diversifying its energy portfolio by developing wind power capacity in Russia, reflecting a multi-faceted approach to energy generation.
Furthermore, Likhachev underscored the broader benefits of nuclear technology beyond energy production.

He noted that technologies derived from the nuclear sector, such as radioactive isotopes, have significant applications in fields like medicine, contributing to advancements in healthcare and saving lives.
He said the controversial source of electricity is “essential” in working towards decarbonisation goals and international obligations such as the Paris Agreement on climate change.

The boss of the state-owned corporation suggested nuclear power must be employed with other forms of energy such as wind and solar and would provide a form of energy storage through baseload capacity.
He added ROSATOM itself is working to develop wind capacity in Russia.

Mr Rozhdestvin also said various technologies from the nuclear sector can spin off and have positive effects in other industries, such as radioactive isotopes being used in the medical field to save human lives.

General News of Friday, 6 October 2017 Source: ghanacrusader.com 2017-10-06 President Nana Akufo-Addo President Akufo-Addo has called on Ghanaians to help him and his New Patriotic Party (NPP) government to end fertiliser smuggling in the country.
According to Nana Addo, whenever something good is happening to all of us, there will always be a few greedy evil people who would wish to pervert the good things for their selfish gains.

The President emphasized the importance of collective effort in combating the issue of fertiliser smuggling, which has been a significant challenge undermining the progress of agricultural initiatives in the country.
He urged citizens to be vigilant and report any suspicious activities related to smuggling to the relevant authorities.
Nana Addo highlighted the detrimental effects of smuggling on the economy and stressed the need for unity in addressing this issue.
He noted that, “I need your help.

I need the help of you and your community to keep an eye out and cooperate with the law enforcement agencies to stop the smuggling.” According to him, he will put laws in place to deal accordingly with persons who smuggles fertiliser to neighbouring countries adding that it is essential he don’t allow a few people to destroy the good thing we have.
Nana Addo stressed on the Planting for Jobs and Programme initiative he introduced stating that is one of the best way of transforming Agriculture in the country.
In Egypt's upcoming election, President Abdel-Fattah el-Sissi is prioritizing stability over democracy, a move that has stirred mixed reactions among the Egyptian populace.

El-Sissi, a former military general who came to power in 2014 after ousting the country's first freely elected president, has been criticized for cracking down on dissent and stifling political opposition.
Despite facing some backlash, el-Sissi's supporters argue that his firm hand is necessary to combat terrorism and maintain order in a region plagued by turmoil.
They point to the relative stability Egypt has experienced under his rule, contrasting it with the chaos that followed the Arab Spring uprisings.
However, critics view el-Sissi's consolidation of power as a dangerous erosion of democratic principles, with many opposition figures either jailed, exiled, or intimidated into silence.
The upcoming election, set for March 26-28, is widely seen as a foregone conclusion, with el-Sissi expected to secure a second term in office.
As the election draws near, Egyptians are expressing their views through protests and demonstrations.
They held banners and chanted slogans, though the chants weren't exactly resounding victory cries for their candidate, an almost unknown politician named Moussa Mustafa Moussa.
They shouted: "Whether Moussa wins or el-Sissi wins, either is our president!"
There's no question the general-turned-president el-Sissi will win a second four-year term.

But the March 26-28 election will likely be remembered as the event that signaled Egypt's break with what pretense it had left of democratic rule, seven years after a popular uprising toppled autocrat Hosni Mubarak in the name of democracy.
A woman in Wigan found herself in need of rescue after she went into a stream to help a duck in distress.
The incident unfolded near a park where the woman spotted the struggling duck and decided to wade into the stream to assist the animal.
However, she soon found herself in difficulty and unable to get back to the bank on her own.
Concerned onlookers quickly called emergency services, and soon after, five fire engines arrived at the scene.
Firefighters acted swiftly, placing a ladder on the bank to reach the woman and bring her to safety.
Despite the chilly water and her wet clothes, the woman was thankfully unharmed.
Gareth Gray, watch manager at Wigan fire station, commented on the incident, stating, "She was a bit cold and a bit wet, but she was checked over by the ambulance service and she was okay."
He emphasized the importance of avoiding open water due to the potential dangers it can present.
This incident serves as a reminder of the risks associated with attempting to rescue animals in distress and the importance of prioritizing personal safety in such situations.
Five fire engines attended and firefighters placed a ladder on the bank to help her out.
Gareth Gray, watch manager at Wigan fire station, said: "She was a bit cold and a bit wet, but she was checked over by the ambulance service and she was okay."
He urged people to stay away from open water due to the dangers it can pose.
Norway's Ingvild Flugstad Oestberg and Sweden's Stina Nilsson claimed victories in the women's cross-country skiing World Cup sprint event in Davos, Switzerland.
Oestberg showcased her prowess on the challenging course, clinching her fourth World Cup win in Davos.
She outpaced the competition, including second-placed Nilsson, to secure a well-deserved victory.
On the men's side, Norway's Emil Iversen and Johannes Hoesflot Klaebo celebrated a one-two finish, with Iversen crossing the finish line first.
The Norwegian duo demonstrated exceptional skill and determination throughout the race, solidifying their dominance in the sport.
Third-placed Krista Parmakoski of Finland was 7.9 back.
“Davos is my favourite place, it’s almost the only venue I can win a World Cup,” said Oestberg, who has three wins at the Swiss resort.
World Cup leader Charlotte Kalla of Sweden was eighth, 26 seconds back.

WASHINGTON (AP) — Former Cambridge Analytica employee Christopher Wylie has arrived on Capitol Hill, where he is talking to House Democrats about his time with the data mining firm affiliated with President Donald Trump's campaign.
Wylie's testimony is expected to shed light on the controversial practices of Cambridge Analytica and its involvement in the 2016 election.
The whistleblower's revelations have already sparked widespread concerns about data privacy and manipulation in political campaigns.
Members of Congress are eager to hear Wylie's firsthand account of the firm's operations and any potential ties to foreign entities.

The testimony is likely to fuel further debates on the regulation of data collection and usage in the digital age, as lawmakers grapple with how to protect citizens from exploitation while preserving the integrity of democratic processes.

Through hands-on experience, they are not only building a robot but also building their confidence and capabilities.

ISIS claimed responsibility for the deadly attack on a popular night club in Istanbul, Turkey, during New Year's celebrations.
The brutal assault left 39 people dead and dozens injured in what has been described as a horrific act of terrorism.
The assailant, armed with a high-powered rifle, stormed into the Reina nightclub and opened fire on innocent revelers, creating a scene of chaos and devastation.
Eyewitnesses recounted the terrifying moments as the gunman sprayed bullets indiscriminately, causing panic and confusion among the partygoers.
The attack, which took place shortly after midnight, sent shockwaves across the city and the entire nation, as Turkey grappled with yet another senseless act of violence.
Authorities have identified the suspect as a lone gunman who managed to flee the scene following the massacre.
He may have escaped by abandoning his gun at the scene and slipping off in the ensuing chaos.
Advertisement Police have supposedly seen some similarities between this attack and the suicide bomber who killed more than 40 people at Istanbul’s Atatürk airport in June.

The Guardian says that aside from arrests, the response to ISIS and this recent attack has been swift: The Turkish military said it had carried out raids against Isis in Syria in response to the attack.
Turkish jets struck eight targets, and tanks and artillery fired on 103 targets near al-Bab, killing 22 fighters, the Turkish chief of general staff’s office told Anadolu.
ISIS claims to have multiple cells in Turkey, which it called in its statement a “protector of the cross.”
Over the past few years Game of Thrones has gone from cult-hit to one of the biggest shows on television, watched by millions across the globe.
Based on the books of George RR Martin, HBO's smash-hit fantasy TV series tells the story of warring factions in Westeros fighting for control of the coveted Iron Throne in King's Landing.
But all the while "winter is coming" and north of the wall a ferocious frozen army is about to attack everything that the people of Westeros hold true.
Who will win this epic battle and what will be left remains to be seen.

Starring a huge ensemble cast including Emilia Clarke, Kit Harrington, Peter Dinklage, Sophie Turner, Iain Glen, Natalie Dormer, Alfie Allen, Maisie Williams and Jerome Flynn to name but a few, the series explores politics, power and family feuds in one of the most expensive and beautifully shot series ever to arrive on TV screens.
In the UK Game of Thrones is broadcast on Sky Atlantic, and is available to download via the Sky Go service for Sky subscribers.
As one of the most popular TV shows of recent times, many fans wonder if Game of Thrones is available on Netflix.
Currently, Game of Thrones is not available on Netflix.
The show's streaming rights are held by HBO, which has its own streaming service called HBO Max.

Therefore, fans looking to watch the epic battles, intricate political maneuverings, and shocking plot twists of Game of Thrones will need to turn to HBO Max or other platforms where the show is available.
Northeast Ohio is experiencing a delightful phenomenon as an increasing number of Snowy Owls make their presence known in the region.

These majestic birds, known for their striking white plumage and piercing yellow eyes, have been spotted in various locations across Northeast Ohio, much to the delight of bird enthusiasts and nature lovers.
The sudden influx of Snowy Owls is believed to be a result of a successful breeding season up north.
Marty Calabrese, a naturalist at Cleveland Metroparks, says the reason is owls had more to eat this summer, which led to more offspring.
Snowy Owls There’s more snowy owls so their distribution is reaching further south.
And we call that irruption with an I. Calabrese says the owls are not invasive, and are commonly seen along Lake Erie shore.
They are expected to stay until March.
In an exciting theatrical event, Charles Dickens' classic novel, "Barnaby Rudge," has been brought to life on stage in a stunning adaptation that promises to captivate audiences.
The play, directed by acclaimed theater director, Sarah Stewart, delves into the intricate tale of Barnaby Rudge, a young man caught in the midst of the Gordon Riots in 18th-century London.
Stewart's adaptation stays true to the essence of Dickens' work, focusing on the gripping narrative of Barnaby's journey through tumultuous times.
The production showcases the rich tapestry of characters and the vivid historical backdrop that sets the stage for Barnaby's struggles and triumphs.
Audiences can expect a riveting performance filled with high drama, mystery, and a touch of the supernatural.
The cast brings to life the colorful characters that populate Dickens' world, from the enigmatic Barnaby himself to the sinister figures that shape his fate.

A spokesman from Lincolnshire Rural Touring said: “With its high drama, strange secrets and ghostly doublings, Barnaby Rudge is a powerful blend of historical realism and ‘grotesque’ melodrama.” Stewart said: “We are going to play down or even completely ignore many of the other wonderful characters and subplots and follow Barnaby’s exciting story and await his fate with bated breath.” The show starts at 7.30pm.
Tickets, priced at £12 for adults, £10 for concessions, and £7.50 for those under the age of 16, are available from 01522 883311.
Harrington Police Department has made progress in the case of a shooting incident that occurred recently, resulting in one arrest and another suspect being sought.

Tragically, a 17-year-old was struck in both legs during the chaos.
Authorities have identified and apprehended 20-year-old David Brown of Dover, who was found to have disposed of the weapon used in the shooting.
However, the search continues for 19-year-old Trequon Seth, also from Dover, believed to be the individual who fired the gun.
The Harrington PD is urging anyone with information on the whereabouts of Trequon Seth to come forward and assist in resolving this case swiftly and safely.
A fight began but as it broke up one suspect fired a handgun multiple times – striking a 17 year old in both legs.
Police have arrested 20 year old David Brown of Dover who disposed of the gun, but are still looking for 19 year old Trequon Seth of Dover who fired the gun.
In a recent development, the United Arab Emirates (UAE) has sentenced prominent activist Ahmed Mansoor to 10 years in prison for his social media posts.
Mansoor, a well-known human rights defender, was convicted of spreading false information and stirring up sectarian hatred through his online activities.
The court's decision to imprison Mansoor has sparked outrage among human rights organizations and activists worldwide.
Many have condemned the UAE's crackdown on freedom of expression and called for Mansoor's immediate release.
Mansoor has a history of advocating for human rights, democracy, and government accountability in the UAE.
Mansoor's imprisonment is seen as part of a broader trend of silencing dissent and restricting freedom of speech in the region.
The UAE has faced criticism in the past for its treatment of activists and journalists who speak out against the government.
Rights groups have called for Mansoor's release, calling his detention a violation of freedom of expression and opinion.

North Carolina based producer Hanz (aka Brandon Juhans) has shared “King Speed.” You can hear the song above.
The song, influenced by William S. Burroughs’ cut-up technique, is a slow burning set of shifting textures, like a low hanging cloud of samples.
"King Speed" is a miasmic hip-hop collage that showcases Hanz’s experimental approach to music production.
The track weaves together a myriad of sounds and influences, creating a mesmerizing sonic landscape that is both chaotic and cohesive.
With its distorted beats, warped vocals, and glitchy effects, "King Speed" is a testament to Hanz’s skill as a sonic alchemist, transforming disparate elements into a unified whole.
This latest release is part of Hanz’s upcoming EP, Plasty I.
The EP marks the first installment of a two-part release, with a full album’s worth of material spread across two 12-inch records.
Fans can expect the second part of the EP to drop in Spring 2018, with more details to be announced.
Plasty I follows Hanz’s 2014 debut on Tri Angle Records, Reducer.
Hanz has previously self-released singles and albums on Bandcamp, showcasing his versatility and innovation as a producer.
Plasty I is set to be released via Tri Angle Records on 01/19, promising a bold and boundary-pushing addition to Hanz’s discography.

PITTSBURGH (AP) — Attorney General Jeff Sessions says the federal government is stepping up its fight against opioid-related crimes online.
Sessions announced the establishment of a new team to disrupt online opioid sales on Monday in Pittsburgh.
The new team will focus on identifying and targeting illegal online sales of opioids, which have contributed to the devastating opioid crisis gripping the nation.
Sessions emphasized the importance of cracking down on these illicit online activities to stem the flow of opioids into communities and prevent further harm.
The team will more than double the FBI's investment in fighting online opioid trafficking.
Sessions says the FBI is dedicating dozens more staffers to the team so they can focus on the one issue.

In a recent development in the case of the Stoneman Douglas school shooting suspect, Nikolas Cruz has been found to be indigent, meaning he is unable to afford his legal fees.
As a result, Cruz will continue to be represented by a public defender for his defense.
This decision comes after Cruz's legal team argued that he did not have the financial means to hire a private attorney for his defense.
The revelation of Cruz's indigent status sheds light on the complexities of the legal proceedings surrounding this high-profile case.
With the public defender continuing to represent Cruz, the focus remains on ensuring a fair trial while addressing the gravity of the charges he faces.
Add Interest Cruz is accused of fatally shooting 17 students and staff of Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School in Parkland, Florida, on Feb. 14.
