A recent court filing alleges that the Department of Education unlawfully obtained Social Security number data to calculate federal loan forgiveness for students of a closed for-profit school.

The motion, filed by attorneys from the Project on Predatory Student Lending at Harvard University, asserts that the Education Department covertly accessed Social Security data without proper notification to students.
The filing claims that this action was illegal and done without the students' consent.
The Education Department disclosed its intention to utilize earnings data to determine loan forgiveness amounts for students of the defunct for-profit institution in December.
However, the motion argues that the agency's use of Social Security data was unauthorized and unethical.
The Education Department has refrained from commenting on the ongoing legal proceedings.
The Education Department announced in December that it will use earnings data in order to determine how much of federal loans to forgive for students of the now defunct for-profit school.
The motion claims that the agency "secretly and illegally co-opted Social Security data."
Attorneys with the Project on Predatory Student Lending at Harvard University say the agency should have notified students that it would use their data.
The Education Department declined to comment on pending litigation.
WASHINGTON — The Justice Department is asking a judge to dismiss a lawsuit by Donald Trump’s former presidential campaign chairman.
Paul Manafort was indicted in October in special counsel Robert Mueller’s (MUHL’-urs) Russia investigation.
A suit Manafort filed last month challenges the scope of Mueller’s appointment and authority.
Manafort's lawsuit claims that Mueller exceeded his authority by investigating matters that are not related to Russian interference in the 2016 election.
The Justice Department argues that Mueller has the necessary authority to investigate Manafort’s business dealings and other activities that may be linked to the broader Russia probe.

The government’s motion to dismiss Manafort’s lawsuit emphasizes that the special counsel regulations provide Mueller with the authority to investigate and prosecute any matters that arise from his investigation into Russian interference.
The Justice Department asserts that Manafort’s claims are without merit and that the court should reject his attempt to challenge Mueller’s authority.
Manafort, who faces multiple charges including money laundering and conspiracy against the United States, continues to deny any wrongdoing.
The court will now consider the government’s request to toss out Manafort’s lawsuit.
"4th of July public service announcement: You're not a firework.
Don't drive lit."
"You're not a firework.
Don't drive lit," read an electronic sign spotted by local resident Michael Meitz above Interstate 95 in Stafford County, Virginia.Though the message may seem fun and clever, it's an important one.
Though the message may seem fun and clever, it's an important one.
As Independence Day approaches and celebrations gear up, it's crucial to remember the significance of staying safe on the roads.
Driving under the influence not only endangers your life but also puts others at risk.
The combination of alcohol and driving is a deadly one that can lead to devastating consequences.
Law enforcement agencies across the country will be on high alert during the holiday weekend, cracking down on impaired driving.
Remember that buzzed driving is drunk driving, and the consequences can be severe.
Plan ahead for a designated driver, use ride-sharing services, or stay put if you've been drinking.
Let's celebrate the 4th of July responsibly by enjoying the festivities without putting lives in danger.
Remember, you're not a firework – don't drive lit.
Stay safe, stay smart, and have a happy Independence Day!
Munster’s back-row player, Jack O'Donoghue, is facing a ‘long-term’ rehabilitation process due to an unspecified injury.
The club has confirmed that O'Donoghue will require an extended period to recover fully, emphasizing the need for patience and careful management during his rehabilitation.
This setback comes as a blow to both the player and the team, as O'Donoghue has been a key contributor to Munster's success on the field.
Despite the challenges ahead, Munster remains committed to supporting O'Donoghue through his recovery journey.

Munster have indicated that O’Donoghue is expected to follow a ‘long-term rehabilitation programme.’ On the contract front, prop Jeremy Loughman will remain with the province for next season after signing a one-year contract extension.
The Munster players continuing to rehab following injury are Tyler Bleyendaal (neck), Chris Farrell (knee), Tommy O’Donnell (shoulder) and Stephen Archer (pec).
ISLAMABAD (AP) — A Pakistani rights group has appealed on Indonesia to free on humanitarian grounds a terminally ill Pakistani convict on death row.
The group, advocating for human rights, has urged Indonesia to consider the deteriorating health of the prisoner and grant clemency.
The convict, who has been identified as a Pakistani national, is suffering from a severe illness that has reached a critical stage.
The group emphasized the importance of compassion and mercy in such cases, citing the prisoner's deteriorating health and the need for urgent medical treatment.
The Pakistani group's plea comes amidst growing concerns over the well-being of prisoners on death row, especially those facing serious health issues.
The appeal aims to draw attention to the humanitarian aspect of the case and to urge authorities to prioritize the prisoner's health and well-being.

GANGNEUNG, South Korea (AP) — The North Korean flag is flying in South Korea for the first time in years as the South prepares for the Winter Olympics that has brought a temporary lull to tensions surrounding the North's nuclear program.

The Olympic village in Gangneung turned into a selfie site on Thursday as volunteers posed under a North Korean flag that has been raised in the country for the first time since the 2014 Asian Games in Incheon.
The display of the North Korean flag in the South is a symbolic gesture of unity and peace during the Olympic Games.
This rare occurrence signifies a moment of thaw in the strained relations between the two Koreas.

The presence of the flag has sparked mixed reactions among spectators and athletes, with some viewing it as a positive step towards reconciliation, while others remain cautious about the underlying political implications.
As the world watches the opening ceremony of the Winter Olympics, all eyes are on how this symbolic gesture will impact the broader geopolitical landscape in the region.
NBC NEWS – Messages, posts and likes, kids have a lot of ways to stay connected.
One of the newest social media apps is called Sarahhah and it targets adults but is gaining popularity with teens.
Made as a way to “get honest feedback from your coworkers and friends”.
The app allows users to send anonymous messages but cyberbullying can occur on any social media site.
Seventy percent of kids ages 12 to 17 say they have seen it happen, according to a study.
Sue Scheff, author of Shame Nation, says bystanders can make a big difference.
Instead of ignoring cyberbullying, major social media sites have options for reporting online abuse and even muting or blocking users.
Some students are even countering with a trend of cyber-encouragement.
Students creating pages to spread positive comments about their peers.
However, the rise in cyberbullying through apps like Sarahah is a growing concern among parents and educators.
With the cloak of anonymity, individuals feel emboldened to send hurtful messages without consequences.
This has led to cases of severe emotional distress and, in some tragic instances, self-harm among young victims.
As technology continues to evolve, it is crucial for both online platforms and users to prioritize safety and respect in their interactions.
Encouraging a culture of kindness and support can help combat the negative effects of cyberbullying and foster a more positive online environment for everyone.

"It's a feeling like no other to be able to bring Alex's story to life on stage," she shared after the performance.

"I hope to inspire others to pursue their passions with the same dedication and commitment."
Looking ahead to future performances, Joanne expressed her enthusiasm for the upcoming shows in Aylesbury.
“It’s another amazing opportunity in my musical theatre career and I can once again sing and act alongside dancing.

I just hope the water is not too cold when it falls on me!’ Flashdance tells the inspiring and unforgettable story of 18-year-old Alex, a welder by day and ‘flashdancer’ by night, who dreams of going to the prestigious Shipley Dance Academy and becoming a professional dancer.
When a romance complicates her ambitions, she harnesses it to drive her dream.

Cal Poly staged a remarkable comeback in the second half to secure a convincing 78-64 victory over Hawaii in a thrilling college basketball showdown.
The game began with the Rainbow Warriors taking control early, establishing a seven-point lead by halftime.
However, the Mustangs came out firing after the break, igniting a spectacular 16-2 run that completely shifted the momentum in their favor.
The second half belonged to Cal Poly as they surged ahead to lead 44-37, capitalizing on their newfound energy and determination.
Although Hawaii briefly regained the lead at 54-53 with just over nine minutes remaining, it was short-lived as the Mustangs launched a decisive 13-0 run that left their opponents trailing.

Key contributions from Meikle, Niziol, and Fields propelled Cal Poly's surge, with Meikle scoring crucial points, Niziol sinking consecutive 3-pointers, and Fields sealing the deal with a 3-point play.
The Mustangs' dominant performance in the second half allowed them to maintain their lead and ultimately secure a well-deserved victory.
The Rainbow Warriors had a seven-point advantage at the break, but the Mustangs opened the second half with a 16-2 run and led 44-37.
Hawaii had its last lead, 54-53 with 9:12 left.
A 13-0 run gave Cal Poly a 64-54 lead with 5:32 remaining and the Mustangs cruised from there.
Meikle scored four points, Niziol made consecutive 3-pointers and Fields capped the surge with a 3-point play.

In a display of personal diplomacy that seemed straight out of a buddy cop movie, President Donald Trump and French President Emmanuel Macron showcased their growing camaraderie during Macron's visit to the White House on Tuesday.
The two leaders, who previously shared a tense meeting, appeared to have developed a warm rapport that was on full public view.
The affectionate exchanges between Trump and Macron included a double cheek kiss, a European custom rarely seen in American politics.
The pair also engaged in a lingering handshake and a playful moment where Trump brushed what he claimed was dandruff off Macron's shoulder during a press appearance.
These gestures of friendship and camaraderie underscored the evolving relationship between the two leaders and their countries.
Despite their policy differences, the personal bond between Trump and Macron was unmistakable, showing a softer and more intimate side to their political engagement.

President Donald Trump and his French counterpart Emmanuel Macron put their warm bromance on full public display Tuesday, engaging in frequent PDAs at the White House that revealed how friendly they have grown since a tense meeting last spring.
Trump's tenderness Tuesday first revealed itself during an arrival ceremony for Macron, when the powerful pair performed a double cheek kiss — a typical European greeting custom.
Moments later, during the ceremony, the two smooched again and carried on a long handshake that clocked in around five seconds.
Later Tuesday, during a brief appearance by the two leaders in front of reporters, the American president gently wiped something — Trump said it was dandruff — off Macron's shoulder.
AUSTIN, Texas — The family of Texas basketball star Andrew Jones says he is making “positive strides” in his leukemia treatment.
The sophomore guard was diagnosed in January and is at the University of Texas MD Anderson Cancer Center in Houston.
The family says in a statement Saturday that Jones recently was able to get out of bed, a “huge difference” from when he was first diagnosed.
Jones' battle with leukemia has been closely followed by fans and the basketball community, with an outpouring of support and well wishes being sent his way.
He was the team’s leading scorer when sidelined for several games with a wrist fracture.
He was diagnosed with leukemia after complaining of always feeling tired.
His last game was Jan. 1 against Iowa State.
A fundraising website set up by the school to support Jones’ family has raised more than $150,000.
A dramatic police chase came to a dramatic end when the suspect jumped into the Missouri River.
Police Department officers were involved in a pursuit of a suspect Wednesday afternoon.
The pursuit began when a driver reportedly struck a police vehicle at Independence and Kensington around 1:45 p.m. and attempted to flee.
The chase reportedly made its way through downtown KCK in the area of the rail yards at Quindaro Boulevard and Fairfax Trafficway.
The man jumped into the Missouri River but was eventually captured by KCK firefighters in a boat.
The suspect’s identity has not been released.
Idaho police are on a frantic search for a missing teen who vanished after his prom in Orofino.
Kristian Perez, a high school student, disappeared after attending the prom on Saturday night.
The community is rallying together to help find the missing teenager, with law enforcement officials leading the search efforts.
Perez was last seen at the prom venue at around 9:30 p.m.
According to reports, he left the prom and has not been in contact with his family since.
Authorities have revealed that Perez signed out of the prom at 9:32 p.m. and was last seen near a parking lot along U.S. Highway 12.
His tuxedo jacket, one shoe, and a broken cell phone were found near the vehicle he arrived in.
In a bid to gather more information, police have obtained a search warrant to access Perez's call records and text messages.
They are hoping that this will provide crucial leads in their search for the missing teen.
Despite following up on a possible sighting in Lewiston, which is about 40 miles away from Orofino, authorities have not been able to locate Perez.
Orofino police were still searching for Kristian Perez on Monday.
Perez apparently left the prom at about 9:30 p.m. and his family has not seen or heard from him since, KREM-TV reported.
Police confirmed that the teen had signed out of the prom at 9:32 p.m.
He had gone to the event with a relative and his tuxedo jacket, one shoe and a broken cell phone were recovered near the vehicle.
Police said in a statement they obtained a search warrant to scour through Perez’s call records and text messages to try and find out any information that could be useful in their search.
Police, using a K-9 officer, indicated he may have walked from where the prom was being held to a nearby parking lot along U.S. Highway 12 and got into a car.
Lewiston police confirmed they followed up on a possible sighting of Perez in the city, about 40 miles west of Orofino, but surveillance video showed it was not him, Orofino police said.
Arsene Wenger has made a bold decision by handing Colombia international David Ospina the start in goal for Arsenal's crucial Champions League clash against Bayern Munich.
Ospina, who has been Arsenal's cup goalkeeper of choice over the past two seasons, will be looking to make amends for his past Champions League mishaps.

Colombia international Ospina has been Arsenal's cup goalkeeper of choice over the past two seasons but his Champions League campaign last term was marred by him dropping a corner over his own goalline in the group-stage defeat to Olympiacos.

That saw regular number one Petr Cech restored for the first leg of the tie against Barcelona in the knockout stages, with the 28-year-old coming back for the return at Camp Nou where a 5-1 aggregate loss was completed.

This time around, Ospina helped Arsenal through an unbeaten group stage with relatively few alarms and Wenger told a pre-match news conference at the Allianz Arena that he would not revert to Cech again.
The decision to start Ospina comes as a surprise to many, especially given his past errors on the big stage.
However, Wenger's faith in the goalkeeper is unwavering as Arsenal aim to secure a positive result against a formidable Bayern Munich side.
Ospina will have the opportunity to prove his worth and show that he is capable of delivering a solid performance when it matters most.
Arsenal fans will be hoping that Ospina can rise to the occasion and help his team secure a crucial victory in this pivotal Champions League encounter.
MELVILLE, N.Y. (CBSNewYork) – A small plane has crashed in Melville, N.Y.
The vintage aircraft came down in a wooded area, narrowly missing nearby homes.
Emergency services rushed to the scene, where they found the plane engulfed in flames.
Eyewitnesses reported hearing a loud bang before seeing the plane spiraling towards the ground.
The pilot, who was the sole occupant of the aircraft, was pulled from the wreckage and taken to a nearby hospital with serious injuries.
Authorities are investigating the cause of the crash, but initial reports suggest engine failure may have been a contributing factor.
Local residents expressed their shock and concern following the incident, highlighting the dangers of vintage aircraft and the importance of strict maintenance and safety protocols.
The community is coming together to support the pilot and their family during this difficult time.
In a thrilling basketball matchup, Mercer pulled off an impressive victory by defeating Wofford with a final score of 73-65.
The game showcased Mercer's resilience and determination on the court, led by standout performances from Ross Cummings and Desmond Ringer.
Cummings was a force to be reckoned with, showcasing his sharpshooting skills by sinking a total of six 3-pointers during the game.
His exceptional form continued from the previous games as he has now combined for 14 3-pointers in the last three matchups.
Ringer also made a significant impact on the game, contributing 16 points to Mercer's winning effort, while Demetre Rivers added 10 points to the scoreboard.
Despite trailing by double digits in the first half, Mercer staged a remarkable comeback with an 11-0 run just before halftime.
The team's tenacity and strategic plays paid off as they managed to edge past Wofford in the second half.
Cummings' clutch 3-pointer with 4:11 remaining proved to be a game-changer, propelling Mercer to a lead they would not relinquish.
Rivers' timely 3-pointer further extended the team's advantage, securing a well-deserved victory.
Cameron Jackson's efforts for Wofford were not enough to overcome Mercer's strong performance, as Cummings sealed the deal with another crucial 3-pointer to maintain Mercer's lead.
With this victory, Mercer snapped a four-game losing streak and improved their record to 11-13 overall and 4-7 in the Southern Conference.
The game was a testament to Mercer's resilience, teamwork, and ability to rise to the occasion when it mattered most.
Fans can look forward to more thrilling matchups as Mercer continues to showcase their competitive spirit on the basketball court.
He has combined for 14 3-pointers in the last three games.
Desmond Ringer added 16 points and Demetre Rivers had 10 for Mercer, which snapped a four-game skid.
Mercer (11-13, 4-7 Southern Conference) trailed by double figures midway through the first half but tightened it up with an 11-0 run just before the break.
Cummings drained a 3-pointer with 4:11 remaining to put Mercer on top for good, 61-59, and Demetre Rivers hit a 3 to stretch the lead to five.
Cameron Jackson cut the deficit to 64-61 on a dunk but Cummings responded with his sixth 3.
The victory against Wofford marks a significant turning point for Mercer, showcasing their potential and determination to compete at a high level in the Southern Conference.
Fans can expect to see more exciting performances from Mercer as they continue to strive for success on the basketball court.

Motorists in Lancashire are being urged to exercise caution as freezing temperatures grip the region, leading to icy road conditions.
The Lancashire Police have issued a warning to drivers, emphasizing the need for heightened awareness on the roads.
With temperatures plummeting, the risk of icy patches forming on the road surfaces has significantly increased, posing a potential hazard to drivers.
Anyone taking to the roads this morning is advised to take particular care on rural roads and asked to leave extra time for their journeys.
Drivers are also being asked by police to thoroughly defrost their cars before they set off.
These precautionary measures are crucial in ensuring the safety of both drivers and other road users during this period of inclement weather.
It is recommended that motorists reduce their speed and increase following distances to allow for extended braking distances on icy roads.
Additionally, drivers are advised to check their vehicles' tires and ensure they are adequately inflated to maintain traction on slippery surfaces.
By heeding these warnings and taking necessary precautions, drivers can help mitigate the risks associated with icy road conditions and ensure a safer journey for all.

TRUMBULL CO., Ohio (WYTV) – The Trumbull County Board of Elections voted to allow former County Republican Party Chairman Randy Law to run on the May primary ballot, despite objections from members of his own party.
Law, who previously served as the party chairman, faced opposition from some party members who argued that he did not meet residency requirements to run for the Ohio House.
However, after a thorough review, the Board of Elections determined that Law did, in fact, meet all necessary qualifications to be a candidate in the upcoming election.
Law expressed gratitude for the decision and emphasized his commitment to serving the people of Trumbull County.
He highlighted his experience and dedication to the community as reasons why he believes he is the right candidate for the position.
The upcoming primary will be closely watched as Law seeks to secure the Republican nomination for the Ohio House seat.

In a dominating performance, UC Santa Barbara (UCSB) continued their unbeaten streak at home by defeating CSU Northridge with a final score of 75-51.
The victory marked UCSB's 18th win of the season, solidifying their position as one of the top teams in the conference.
The Gauchos showcased their strength early in the game, taking control and maintaining a steady lead throughout.
By the end of the first half, UCSB had established a 32-25 advantage over CSU Northridge, setting the tone for the rest of the match.
As the game progressed, UCSB extended their lead with an impressive 19-1 run, leaving CSU Northridge struggling to keep up.
Max Heidegger led the scoring for the Gauchos with four 3-pointers and a total of 14 points, supported by Marcus Jackson with 12 points and Ami Lakoju contributing 10 points.
Despite a strong effort from CSU Northridge, led by Tavrion Dawson with 16 points and 10 rebounds, the Matadors were unable to overcome UCSB's relentless offense and solid defense.
Their overall record of 18-5 is their best overall start since the 1988-89 team did the same.
In conference they are tied with UC Davis at 7-2.
UCSB first pulled away with an 8-2 run to end the first half with a 32-25 lead.
The Gauchos then kept CSU Northridge (5-18, 2-7) at bay until going on a 19-1 run to lead 68-44.
Max Heidegger added four 3-pointers and 14 points, Marcus Jackson scored 12 and Ami Lakoju 10 for UC Santa Barbara.
Tavrion Dawson had 16 points and 10 rebounds and Lyrik Shreiner scored 10 for the Matadors.
Police are appealing for witnesses to a crash between a lorry and a car on the M1.
The incident happened between 3.15pm and 3.30pm on Monday, April 30 near junction 28 on the northbound carriageway.
Police said they understand the lorry struck the back of a black Audi TT, which was being driven by a 25-year-old woman.
The collision led to a temporary closure of the M1 as emergency services rushed to the scene.
The driver of the Audi TT sustained minor injuries and was taken to a nearby hospital for treatment.
Fortunately, no other vehicles were involved in the crash.
Authorities are urging anyone who witnessed the incident or has dashcam footage of the collision to come forward and assist with the investigation.
Eyewitness accounts and additional evidence could help shed light on the circumstances leading to the crash and determine liability.
The aftermath of the accident caused significant traffic delays, highlighting the importance of road safety and vigilance while driving on busy highways like the M1.
Anyone with information is asked to contact the police to aid in their inquiries.
TRENTON, N.J. (AP) — The final two defendants convicted in one of the largest credit card fraud schemes ever charged by the U.S. Department of Justice have been sentenced to prison terms.
Federal prosecutors in New Jersey say 65-year-old Iselin resident Sat Verma was sentenced Tuesday to a year in prison.
He had pleaded guilty to access device fraud.
Verma was part of a sophisticated operation that involved the theft and unauthorized use of credit card information from thousands of victims across the country.
Additionally, 42-year-old Priya Patel, also of Iselin, was sentenced to 18 months in prison for her role in the scheme.
The defendants were ordered to pay restitution to the victims.
The successful prosecution and sentencing of these individuals mark a significant milestone in the fight against financial crimes and serve as a warning to those who engage in fraudulent activities.

The German government says the leaders of Germany, Russia, Ukraine and France have renewed their commitment to implementing a faltering peace deal for eastern Ukraine.

Chancellor Angela Merkel’s office said the German leader spoke by phone Monday night with Russian President Vladimir Putin, Ukrainian President Petro Poroshenko and French President Francois Hollande.

The four leaders discussed the importance of upholding the Minsk agreements, which were designed to end the conflict in eastern Ukraine but have faced numerous challenges since they were signed in 2015.
The discussions come amid heightened tensions in the region, with recent clashes between Ukrainian forces and Russia-backed separatists.
The leaders emphasized the need for all parties to fully adhere to the ceasefire and work towards a lasting political solution.
The international community is closely watching these developments as efforts continue to bring peace to Ukraine.
Teen who used 'affluenza' defense set for release April 2  Ethan Couch, the teenager whose infamous "affluenza" defense made headlines, is scheduled to be released from jail on April 2.
Couch, now 20 years old, has been serving a 720-day sentence in the Tarrant County Jail in Fort Worth, Texas, following the revocation of his probation in 2016.
The case dates back to June 2013 when Couch, then 16, was involved in a fatal accident that resulted in the deaths of pedestrians.
During his manslaughter trial, a psychologist testified that Couch's actions were influenced by "affluenza," a term suggesting that his wealthy upbringing led to a lack of responsibility.
In addition to his own legal troubles, Couch's mother, Tonya Couch, is also facing legal challenges.
She is awaiting trial on charges of hindering apprehension of a felon and money laundering after fleeing to Mexico with Ethan in 2015.
Tonya Couch is currently out on bond as the legal proceedings continue.
Ethan Couch has served almost two years in jail for a revoked probation and is to be freed from the Tarrant County Jail in Fort Worth, Texas.
He's been serving a 720-day sentence after his 2016 probation revocation for attending a party where alcohol was served.
Couch was 16 when the truck he was driving killed pedestrians in June 2013.
A psychologist at his manslaughter trial blamed his actions on "affluenza," or irresponsibility due to family wealth.
His mother, Tonya Couch, awaits trial on charges of hindering apprehension of a felon and money laundering after she fled to Mexico with Ethan in 2015.
She's free on bond.

Residents in Llanelli, Carmarthenshire, are facing a sudden influx of flies, prompting the local council to launch an investigation into the matter.
Concerns have been raised as the flies have been causing significant nuisance and disruption to daily life in the area.
The Carmarthenshire council is actively involved in determining the source of the issue, with environmental officers dedicated to resolving the fly infestation.
Efforts are being made "around the clock" to address the problem and provide relief to the affected residents.
Llanelli town councillor Sean Rees, representing Glanymor ward, acknowledged the severity of the situation, emphasizing the urgent need for action.
Numerous residents have expressed frustration over the persistent presence of the flies, urging authorities to take swift measures in resolving the issue.
One resident said on Twitter: "Okay... seriously... these flies need to do one now!!!
Doing my head right in!!!"
Carmarthenshire council said it was working "around the clock" to try and establish the source of the flies and environmental officers are on the case.
Llanelli town councillor Sean Rees, of Glanymor ward, said he had received a number of messages from residents and "something needs to be done" about the problem.

Former NFL running back and ex-Pro Bowler DeAngelo Williams is making a return to the world of professional wrestling.

Egyptian police have arrested 12 people at a protest against the transfer of two Red Sea islands to Saudi Arabia.
The arrests took place as demonstrators gathered in Cairo's Tahrir Square, demanding the cancellation of the controversial agreement that cedes control of Tiran and Sanafir islands to Saudi Arabia.
The protesters argue that the islands are historically Egyptian territory and should not be handed over to another country.
The transfer of the islands has sparked widespread public outrage and led to mass protests across Egypt.
Critics of the deal accuse the government of President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi of selling off national assets in exchange for financial aid from Saudi Arabia.
The arrests of the protesters are seen as a further crackdown on dissent in Egypt, where freedom of expression is increasingly restricted.
Former Leonard Kirtz teacher’s aide, Sarah Johnson, has been sentenced to probation for abusing students under her care.
Johnson, who pleaded guilty to the charges of mistreating students, was handed a sentence of two years of probation by the judge.
The incidents of abuse, which took place over several months, came to light when concerned parents reported suspicious behavior by Johnson to the school authorities.
During the court proceedings, it was revealed that Johnson had used her position of authority to mistreat and emotionally harm the students in her care.
The judge emphasized the seriousness of the offenses and stated that such behavior would not be tolerated in any educational setting.
She already voluntarily surrendered her teaching license for one year, but as part of her sentence, she can’t teach during probation.
North Carolina Governor Roy Cooper recently engaged in discussions with a top Trump administration official regarding the controversial topic of offshore drilling.

Cooper expressed his apprehensions about the potential risks associated with expanding offshore drilling, particularly highlighting concerns about the possible detrimental impact on North Carolina's thriving tourism and fishing industries, valued at $3 billion.
The Democratic governor emphasized the importance of residents in the state voicing their opposition to the federal government regarding this matter.

Cooper disclosed that his conversation with Interior Secretary Ryan Zinke was productive, with both parties engaging in a dialogue about the potential consequences of offshore drilling in North Carolina.
Notably, Cooper's stance against offshore drilling finds common ground with Republican South Carolina Governor Henry McMaster, who also expressed similar reservations during his meeting with Zinke.
The bipartisan opposition to the proposed offshore drilling expansion underscores the significant concerns shared by leaders across party lines.
Roy Cooper says he had a good conversation with a top Trump administration official over plans to expand offshore drilling.
Cooper said he talked to Interior Secretary Ryan Zinke about concerns that drilling could cause catastrophic damage to the state’s $3 billion tourism and fishing industries.
The Democratic governor says residents of North Carolina need to make their opposition clear to the federal government.
The plan has bipartisan opposition: Republican South Carolina Gov.
Henry McMaster met with Zinke on Friday and shared similar concerns.
In January, Zinke announced plans to vastly expand offshore oil drilling from the Atlantic to the Arctic and Pacific oceans.
The plan would open 90 percent of the nation’s offshore reserves to development by private companies.
MONCTON, N.B.
- Authorities are investigating after a body was discovered following a fire at a residence in Moncton, New Brunswick.
Firefighters were called to the scene on Maple Street early this morning, where they found the home engulfed in flames.
The fire was quickly extinguished, but sadly, a body was recovered from the building.
The deceased individual has been identified as a male resident of the home, but his identity has not been released pending notification of next of kin.
The circumstances surrounding the fire and the man's death remain unclear, prompting an investigation by the coroner's office and the fire department.
Chief Fire Inspector, Kevin Brine, stated that the cause of the fire is still under investigation, and it's too early to determine whether foul play was involved.
Brine says it's yet to be determined whether the man's death was related to the fire — that will be determined by the coroner and a fire department investigation.

In a recent development, the Progressive Conservative (PC) Government has announced a comprehensive review of public service compensation.
This move signals a significant shift in the province's approach to managing public finances.
The decision comes amidst efforts to streamline government spending and ensure fiscal responsibility.
The review will focus on evaluating the salaries and benefits of managers, executives, and staff not covered by collective bargaining agreements.
The aim is to align compensation with the government's budgetary priorities and fiscal objectives.
This decision reflects the government's commitment to prudent financial management and accountability to taxpayers.

A memo posted on the government website says pending pay adjustments for managers, executives and staff not covered by collective bargaining will be on hold “until the new government can put in place an expenditure management strategy.” Ford previously put the public service under a hiring freeze, except for essential front line staff such as police and corrections officers, and halted discretionary spending such as newspaper subscriptions.

After the meeting, the NAACP’s Chattanooga President, Dr. Elenora Woods, said that things will have to change and that voting out the commissioners who opposed the removal of the bust is a key order of business.
Last week, Commissioner Greg Beck introduced legislation to seek the state’s permission to remove the bust, which was erected in 1919 by the United Daughters of the Confederacy.
The debate surrounding Confederate symbols and monuments continues to be a divisive issue in Tennessee, with advocates on both sides passionately voicing their opinions.
Have your say Police are appealing for witnesses following a burglary in Mundford on Saturday.

"[Bento] is my best friend.
This cat makes me make art.
He's always motivating me to take pictures of him, draw him.
He's just motivating artistically," Schmidt said in an ad the pair did for animal shelters.

Macedonian authorities have made a significant drug bust, seizing a large load of cannabis amidst a spike in trafficking activities.
The customs office intercepted the illicit cargo, which was destined for Western Europe, with an estimated street value of 800,000 euros ($990,000).
The operation led to the arrest of a 36-year-old Greek truck driver on trafficking charges.
The individual's identity has not been disclosed.
The investigation revealed that the truck had originated in Athens, highlighting the cross-border nature of drug smuggling operations.
The customs office has since transferred the case details to a prosecutor's office for further legal action.

Reports from European Union monitoring agencies suggest that Macedonia has become a key transit point for drug traffickers, particularly for the transportation of heroin from southwest Asia to Europe.
The recent surge in cannabis trafficking underscores the challenges faced by authorities in combating the illicit drug trade in the region.
The customs office said Tuesday that the drugs, bound for Western Europe, had an estimated street value of 800,000 euros ($990,000).
The 36-year-old Greek truck driver, whose name wasn't provided, was arrested on trafficking charges.
The office said the vehicle had started out in Athens and that details of the case had been forwarded to a prosecutor's office.

Macedonia is a major transit point for international drug traffickers, including the transport of heroin from southwest Asia to Europe, and has recently seen a spike in cannabis trafficking, according to reports from European Union monitoring agencies.

Follow CBSMIAMI.COM: Facebook | Twitter FORT LAUDERDALE (CBSMiami) — The South Florida Wildlife Center is nursing two baby Least Tern birds back to health after being displaced by the bad weather over the weekend.
These young birds, which are part of a threatened species, were found struggling to survive in the aftermath of the severe storms that hit the region.
The staff at the wildlife center are providing round-the-clock care to ensure the baby Least Terns have the best chance of recovery.
They are being fed a specialized diet and receiving medical attention to address any health issues caused by their exposure to the harsh weather conditions.
The ultimate goal is to nurse them back to full health so they can be released back into the wild.
Least Terns are small seabirds known for their distinctive black caps and white bodies.
They are typically found nesting in colonies along sandy beaches or in coastal areas.
However, habitat loss and human disturbance have threatened their populations in recent years.
Outside of Florida they can be found along the Atlantic Coast and all the way down to Argentina.
The good news is that Least Terns in some parts of the east are now nesting successfully on gravel roofs near the coast.

A former NFL agent has pleaded guilty to violating North Carolina's sports agent law by providing thousands of dollars in improper benefits to three former Tar Heels football players to entice them into signing contracts with him.
Terry Watson entered his plea Monday afternoon in a deal to resolve 3 ?-year-old felony charges.
Watson's guilty plea is a significant development in the multi-year UNC sports agent probe that has rocked the college football community.
The investigation revealed a pattern of illegal activities aimed at luring student-athletes into professional representation prematurely, violating NCAA regulations and state laws.
According to court documents, Watson admitted to providing cash, trips, and other benefits to the players in violation of the Uniform Athlete Agents Act.
These actions compromised the players' eligibility and tarnished the reputation of the university.

In response to Watson's plea, UNC officials have reaffirmed their commitment to upholding the highest standards of integrity in college athletics and vowed to cooperate fully with ongoing investigations to ensure such misconduct does not recur.
Watson is scheduled to be sentenced next month, facing potential fines and prison time for his role in the scandal.

WASHINGTON — A federal judge has ruled against the Trump administration’s decision to end a program protecting some young immigrants from deportation.
The judge's ruling mandates that the administration must resume accepting new applicants for the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program.
This decision marks a significant victory for immigrant rights advocates and DACA recipients who have been uncertain about their futures.
The DACA program, established in 2012, provides protections for undocumented immigrants who were brought to the United States as children.
The judge's ruling is seen as a rebuke to the administration's efforts to dismantle DACA, which has been a contentious issue since President Trump took office.
The ruling is expected to have far-reaching implications for thousands of young immigrants who may now have the opportunity to apply for protection under the program.
Independent probe launched into death of man arrested in Surrey, B.C.
RCMP say officers and Emergency Health Services were responding to reports of a man standing in the middle of an intersection yelling and in some type of distress on Monday afternoon.
Mounties say officers tried to speak to the man and, when he was taken into custody, he went into medical distress.
Despite help from paramedics, police say the man died soon after.
The Independent Investigation Office, the organization that probes all police-involved cases of death or serious injury, has taken over the case and is looking to speak with witnesses.
The coroner’s service has also been notified.
The incident has raised questions about the circumstances surrounding the man's death and the actions taken by the authorities.
The community is awaiting the findings of the independent investigation to shed light on what transpired during the arrest and subsequent medical emergency.
More updates are expected as the investigation unfolds.

HARTFORD, Conn. (AP) — A white former Connecticut university student accused of smearing body fluids on her black roommate's belongings is expected to ask for a probation program that could result in criminal charges being erased.
Eighteen-year-old Brianna Brochu is set to appear Tuesday in Hartford Superior Court.
Her lawyer, Tom Stevens, expects her to apply for accelerated rehabilitation.
The Harwinton resident is charged with misdemeanor criminal mischief and breach of peace.

Brochu's case gained national attention in 2017 after her former roommate, Chennel "Jazzy" Rowe, posted on social media about the incidents, including Brochu admitting to licking Rowe's dining utensils and rubbing used tampons on her backpack.
Rowe also shared that she experienced severe throat pain following the incidents.
Stevens says the roommates had a falling out and Brochu's actions were not racially motivated.

HOUSTON, TX – Daseke, one of the largest providers of open-deck capacity in North America, is preparing to trade on the NASDAQ stock exchange with the support of a merger with Hennessy Capital Acquisition Corp. Hennessy is described as a “blank check” company, and plans to take a minority position in Daseke.
This strategic move is expected to enhance Daseke's market presence and provide additional opportunities for growth and expansion in the transportation and logistics industry.
Daseke's decision to move to NASDAQ signifies a significant milestone in the company's journey towards further establishing itself as a key player in the sector.

The merger with Hennessy Capital Acquisition Corp. is seen as a positive step that will bring about synergies and benefits for both entities, setting the stage for increased competitiveness and profitability in the market.
The transaction is still subject to regulatory and stockholder approvals, but those involved in the merger believe it will be completed in the first quarter of this year.
Daseke has a fleet of more than 3,000 tractors and 6,000 flatbed and specialized trailers, providing truckload services, over-dimensional shipments, and full-service logistics.
After a brief return to Ottawa, Foreign Minister Chrystia Freeland is back in the thick of the action, leading Canada's charge against U.S. tariffs and trade disputes.
Despite her efforts, the full-court press on resolving these issues is far from over.
Freeland's return to Washington signals Canada's continued commitment to finding a resolution to the ongoing trade tensions with its southern neighbor.
With tariffs on steel and aluminum still in place, the pressure is on to secure a deal that will benefit both countries and alleviate the strain on businesses and consumers.
The negotiations have been intense, with both sides digging in their heels on key issues.
Freeland's diplomatic skills are being put to the test as she navigates the complex web of trade relations between Canada and the United States.
Meanwhile, U.S. Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer and Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross have headed to Paris to engage with European Union officials on tariff discussions.
Freeland left Washington empty-handed earlier today, while Lighthizer and Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross were off to Paris to talk tariffs with nervous European Union counterparts.
BA is, unsurprisingly, behind schedule with the roll out.
Last April, it said customers in all cabins would "shortly" have access to WiFi on long-haul flights.
However, after facing delays and setbacks, British Airways has finally announced the introduction of onboard WiFi, a long-awaited feature that many passengers have been eagerly anticipating.
The airline's decision to offer WiFi onboard comes as a response to the increasing demand for connectivity during flights.
With the rise of remote work and the need to stay connected at all times, passengers expect to have access to the internet even when flying at 30,000 feet.
By providing onboard WiFi, British Airways aims to enhance the overall travel experience for its customers and cater to their evolving needs.
Passengers will now be able to stay connected, browse the internet, check emails, and even stream their favorite movies or TV shows while flying with British Airways.
This move not only brings the airline in line with its competitors but also demonstrates its commitment to embracing new technologies and improving the passenger experience.
The introduction of onboard WiFi is a significant milestone for British Airways and is expected to be well-received by passengers.

As air travel continues to evolve, offering WiFi onboard has become a standard expectation, and British Airways' decision to finally implement this feature will undoubtedly enhance its competitiveness in the market and attract more tech-savvy travelers.
LOS ANGELES: A thief who made off with cell phones belonging to more than 100 people at the Coachella music festival in California may want to consider a new line of work.

Police said Reinaldo De Jesus Henao, of New York, was arrested on Friday with his booty in his backpack after dozens of festival-goers noticed that their phones were missing and activated their “Find My Phone” app.
The "Find My Phone" app led festival attendees and law enforcement directly to Henao, who was reportedly attempting to flee the scene.
Witnesses described a chaotic scene as festival-goers banded together to track down the thief, ultimately leading to his apprehension.
Henao's backpack was found to contain over 100 stolen cell phones, confirming suspicions of his involvement in the widespread theft.
He was subsequently arrested by police who found more than 100 cellphones in his backpack, officials said.
Henao was charged with grand theft and possession of stolen property and was released on $10,000 bail.
The Coachella festival is held annually in the desert of southern California and runs two consecutive weekends.
A specialized plane is set to join the search for a missing Richmond man in the Sierra Nevada mountains.
Mark Mullarkey, 30, was reported missing after failing to return from a skiing trip in the Bear Valley area.
Search and rescue teams have been combing the rugged terrain since his disappearance on Friday.
The search has been challenging due to recent heavy snowfall and dangerous avalanche conditions.
Despite the risks, teams have been working tirelessly to locate Mullarkey.

But due to extreme avalanche danger, they were not able to initiate search efforts.An intensive ground search of the Bear Valley inbound areas concluded Sunday and the efforts have been turned over to Bear Valley Ski Patrol.An RC-26 surveillance plane with infrared technology is due to arrive and aid in the search overnight.
Searchers will analyze the data images from that search in the hope of locating Mullarkey.

NEW ORLEANS — The New Orleans Pelicans say they've voided around 2,500 playoff tickets that were purchased improperly during a pre-sale event for the second round of the NBA playoffs.
The team announced that these tickets were bought through unauthorized means, leading to their cancellation to maintain the integrity of the ticketing process.
The Pelicans have issued refunds to the affected buyers and are working to prevent such incidents in the future.
This development has left many fans disappointed and frustrated, especially those who were looking forward to attending the playoff games to support their team.
The Pelicans organization has apologized for any inconvenience caused and reassured fans that steps are being taken to prevent similar issues from occurring again.
As the team progresses through the playoffs, they are focused on ensuring a fair and transparent ticketing system for all their supporters.

Please enable Javascript to watch this video AURORA, Colo. (AP) — Police in the Denver suburb of Aurora are searching for a 6-year-old boy who is believed to have wandered away from his home on New Year's Eve.
The FBI and other law enforcement agencies were helping search for David Puckett on Monday by going door-to-door within 2.5 miles of his home.
Bloodhounds are also searching for him.
Police say foul play isn't suspected, but they've asked for help to find David as quickly as possible partly because of coming cold weather.
His mother says he was only wearing a light jacket.
On Sunday night, she issued a tearful appeal for people to help find him.
Previous searches aided by a bloodhound and a helicopter didn't turn up any clues.
David was last seen at around 5:30 p.m. on Saturday in the 15700 block of East Amherst Place.
The search efforts have intensified as concerns grow for his safety, especially with the dropping temperatures.
Authorities are urging anyone with information about David's whereabouts to come forward and assist in the search.
Community members have also joined the search, distributing flyers and spreading the word on social media platforms in the hope of locating the missing boy.
As the search continues, the Aurora Police Department is asking the public to remain vigilant and report any potential leads that could help bring David home safely.
Archaeologists have made a remarkable discovery in London as they unearthed a secret tomb containing the remains of several archbishops.
The ancient tomb was uncovered during renovation work at a building in the city.
Builders stumbled upon the hidden crypt when they lifted some slabs, revealing a long-forgotten burial site.
The Garden Museum director, Christopher Woodward, revealed that the tomb held the remains of five archbishops, with one of them identified as Richard Bancroft.
Bancroft, who served as archbishop from 1604, played a crucial role in the production of the iconic King James Bible.
Despite Bancroft's identification, the other archbishops buried in the tomb remain a mystery, their identities lost to time.
This remarkable find sheds light on London's rich history and the prominent figures who shaped the city's religious landscape centuries ago.
The remains were found while builders were renovating the building.
They lifted some slabs to reveal a hidden crypt.
Garden Museum director Christopher Woodward says five archbishops were buried in the tomb, including Richard Bancroft.
Bancroft became archbishop in 1604 and played a major role in production of the King James Bible.
The remains of the others have not been identified.

Ayaan Hirsi Ali, once hailed as a crusading figure in the feminist movement, is now facing criticism and skepticism from within her own ranks.
Sadly, it no longer deserves the trust its crusading work once merited.
In recent... 'Wrong' kind of hero: Why feminists diss Hirsi Ali Ayaan Hirsi Ali should be the perfect feminist hero.
In theory, she fits the role on multiple levels: She’s an escapee from an abusive patriarchy.
Her personal story of overcoming oppression and fighting for women's rights should align perfectly with feminist values.
However, her controversial views on Islam and immigration have led some to question her feminist credentials.
Critics argue that Hirsi Ali's stance on these issues is divisive and Islamophobic, undermining the inclusive principles of feminism.
They accuse her of perpetuating harmful stereotypes and alienating marginalized communities.
Despite her past advocacy for women's rights, Hirsi Ali's current positions have created a rift within the feminist movement.

As the debate around Ayaan Hirsi Ali continues, it raises important questions about the complexities of feminist solidarity and the need for nuanced discussions about intersecting forms of oppression.

Junior forward Guilherme Guimaraes has been named to the CoSIDA First-Team Academic All-District, recognizing his outstanding performance both on the basketball court and in the classroom.
Guimaraes, a Chemistry major with a remarkable 3.89 cumulative GPA, has demonstrated excellence in academics and athletics throughout his college career.

In the current season, Guimaraes has been a key player in 21 out of 22 games, showcasing his versatility by averaging 8.6 points and 5.6 rebounds per game while maintaining an impressive 56.3% shooting accuracy from the field.

Notable highlights include a stellar performance of 30 points and 12 rebounds in an exhibition match against Longwood, a season-high 22 points against Messiah, and a double-double of 16 points and 10 rebounds against Washington and Lee.
Off the court, Guimaraes’ dedication to academic and extracurricular activities is equally commendable.
He is the recipient of prestigious awards such as the President’s Award for excellence of character and scholarship and the Omicron Delta Kappa Award.
Additionally, he actively contributes to campus life as a resident advisor, member of the Student Honor Court, Freshman Leadership Program, and Chi Beta Phi national honor society.
Guimaraes’ achievements extend beyond academics and sports as he has twice been recognized as one of eight recipients of the Roy B. Sears Endowment for Student Internships.
Head Coach Dee Vick praised Guimaraes for his self-motivation, determination, and commitment to excellence both on and off the court.
He now becomes eligible to be nominated for the CoSIDA Academic All-America team.

TORONTO — The Canada Border Services Agency says it has seized seven kilograms of suspected cocaine from the bottom of food trolleys on an airplane.
The agency says it made the discovery earlier this month while carrying out a routine inspection of an aircraft landing at Toronto's Pearson International Airport.
It says officers noticed something unusual about the catering trolleys on board and examined them more closely.
Officers eventually found seven brick-shaped packages on the bottom of the food carts that contained white powder wrapped in plastic.
The suspected cocaine has an estimated street value of millions of dollars.
The agency is working with law enforcement partners to investigate the incident further and determine how the illegal substance made its way onto the airplane.
The discovery highlights the ongoing challenges authorities face in combating drug trafficking through various means.
Passengers and crew on the flight are not believed to be involved in the smuggling operation.
The agency did not release details on where the packages originated from or if charges are pending.

Many living room media players support headphones to let one person watch videos without disrupting anyone.
However, Roku is taking this feature a step further by introducing private listening for multiple viewers.
With the latest Roku OS 8.1 update, the popular streaming platform now allows up to five people to listen privately through the Roku mobile app.
This update comes as a relief for households where multiple people want to watch content without disturbing others.
Whether it's a late-night movie session or a group of friends enjoying a series together, Roku's new feature ensures that everyone can listen to the audio without bothering those around them.

Residents in the downtown area should expect delays as road repairs are set to begin next week.
The City Public Works Department announced that a section of Main Street will be undergoing extensive repairs due to significant damage caused by recent heavy rains and flooding.
City spokesperson, Mr. Campbell, explained that the repairs are necessary to ensure the safety of motorists and pedestrians.
The roadwork is expected to last several weeks, and during this time, traffic flow will be restricted to one lane only.
“We are working on a design solution to fix the road,” he said.
“This is a complex process and may take some time.
“ While a solution is determined the road will remain open to one lane only, with traffic management in place.

Archeologists have made a significant discovery in Sudan as they recently opened burial chambers within a Sudanese pyramid.
The UNESCO world heritage site is home to pyramids ranging from six meters (20 feet) to 30 meters (100 feet) tall.
It says archeologists from a Qatari mission discovered artifacts, including human and animal bones, inside the chambers.
The pyramids, with narrow bases and steep angles on the sides, were built by the ancient Nubian civilization between 720 and 300 B.C.
Qatar has pledged $135 million to renovate and support Sudan's antiquities.
This latest exploration sheds light on the rich history of the region and provides valuable insights into the ancient Nubian culture and burial practices.
The discovery of these burial chambers marks a significant milestone in the ongoing efforts to unravel the mysteries of Sudan's ancient past.
Russell Westbrook won't face suspension for his involvement in a heated altercation during Game 4.
The incident occurred on Monday night when Westbrook found himself in a verbal exchange with Rudy Gobert.
The confusion arose as Westbrook was seen near the scorers table when Gobert clashed with Raymond Felton on the court.
The NBA has strict rules regarding players entering the playing area during altercations, with past instances resulting in suspensions.
However, Westbrook clarified that he was waiting to check in and was prompted by the sounding horn to do so.
The NBA reviewed the situation and determined that Westbrook's actions did not warrant a suspension.
Despite avoiding suspension, Westbrook will still face consequences from the league.
He is set to receive a significant fine and a technical foul as a form of punishment for his involvement in the incident.
Westbrook was involved in an altercation during Monday night’s Game 4, one which saw him jaw with Rudy Gobert.
The issue was that no one was sure if Westbrook was in the game or not at the time, as he was at the scorers table when Gobert got into it with Raymond Felton.
The NBA has made coming onto the floor in these situations a suspend-able offense, as fans of the 2007 Phoenix Suns will remind you.
Westbrook’s response was that the horn sounded and he was able to check in, upon which the NBA agreed.
He will, however, get punished by the league in the form of a hefty fine and a technical foul.

The team remains optimistic that Matz will recover in time for his next start.

BRAMPTON, Ont.
- Four people were stabbed on a Brampton transit bus on Tuesday evening, causing panic among passengers.
The incident occurred around 7 p.m. near Main Street and Queen Street.
Witnesses reported a verbal altercation escalating into a physical confrontation, resulting in the stabbings.
Emergency services quickly arrived at the scene and provided medical assistance to the victims.
Officers detained a suspect, identified as Jade Nelson, at the scene.
The motive behind the attack is currently under investigation.
Officers say a 49-year-old Brampton man was taken to a Toronto trauma centre, while three Brampton women aged 28, 19 and 18 respectively were taken to a local hospital.
Police say none of the injuries are life-threatening.
Police say Jade Nelson, 20, is being held in custody until a bail hearing scheduled to take place this morning.

Cristiano Ronaldo is facing up to the possibility of a 12-match ban after his shove on referee Ricardo de Burgos Bengoetxea during Real Madrid's 3-1 Supercopa de Espana win over Barcelona.
The Portugal star endured a dramatic outing at Camp Nou on Sunday, coming off the bench to score before getting booked for removing his shirt in celebration.

He took a tumble in the box soon after and earned a second yellow card for an apparent dive, but Ronaldo allowed his anger to get the better of him as he pushed the official, who then included the incident in his match report.
"Player: Cristiano Ronaldo Dos Santos Aveiro.
Once the red card was shown, the player pushed me slightly in a sign of disagreement," wrote the referee.

That leaves Ronaldo open to sanction under Article 96 of the Royal Spanish Football Federation's (RFEF) laws, which recommends a suspension of 4-12 matches for players found to "grab, push or shake" an official in a manner that is "slightly violent".
The 32-year-old is already due to serve a one-game ban following his dismissal.
If the RFEF's competition committee applies a suspension of five games or more it will apply to all domestic matches.
This incident has sparked widespread debate and controversy within the football community, with many questioning Ronaldo's actions and the potential impact on his team's upcoming fixtures.
Real Madrid is awaiting the decision of the RFEF, which will determine the extent of Ronaldo's ban and how it will affect the team's performance in the coming matches.
Ronaldo's actions have not only put his own career at risk but have also raised concerns about the importance of respecting match officials and upholding the spirit of fair play in football.

(AP) — Authorities are performing autopsies on two bodies found near a northern Indiana creek during a search for two missing 13-year-old girls.
State Police Sgt.
Kim Riley stated that the bodies were discovered along Deer Creek about a half-mile upstream from an abandoned railroad bridge where the girls were last seen.
The bodies were found by volunteers who had been participating in the search efforts for the missing girls.
The two girls, Liberty German and Abigail Williams, were reported missing hours later after they did not appear at a predetermined meeting place.
The search for the girls had intensified as the community rallied together to locate them.
The autopsies are expected to provide crucial information in determining the cause of death and shedding light on the tragic events that unfolded.
The investigation is ongoing as authorities work to piece together what happened to the two girls.

BERLIN (AP) — Scientists say they're several steps closer to perfecting a method for saving the northern white rhino from extinction.

By successfully creating hybrid embryos using eggs from the southern white rhino and sperm from the northern white rhino, researchers have made significant progress in their race against time to rescue this sub-species.
These hybrid embryos represent a crucial development in the quest to revive the dwindling northern white rhino population.
The next phase involves further refining the process to ensure the successful implantation and gestation of these embryos in surrogate rhinos.
They plan to harvest the females' egg cells soon and produce "pure" northern white rhinos to be borne by a southern white surrogate in three years.
They're also working on a second method that would see sperm and eggs produced from preserved cells of northern white rhinos.
Certain to sit second in the table no matter what the result at Pride Park, Neil Warnock's side appeared on course to open a four-point cushion over Fulham when it led at the halfway stage.

Barnsley, on the other hand, showed great determination and resilience, equalizing through a well-worked goal in the second half to deny Cardiff a crucial victory.
The result leaves Cardiff City frustrated as they missed out on the opportunity to extend their lead over Fulham in the race for automatic promotion.
Meanwhile, Barnsley's hard-fought draw keeps them in the relegation zone but provides a glimmer of hope as they continue their battle to avoid the drop.

Winter Phenomenon: 'Firefall' Returns to Light Up Yosemite National Park  Yosemite National Park is once again ablaze with the mesmerizing spectacle known as the firefall.

"Very surreal!"
The convergence of the setting sun's rays with the flowing water creates a stunning effect that resembles cascading fire, making it a sight to behold.
As the firefall captivates visitors with its ethereal beauty, it serves as a reminder of the wonders of nature and the importance of preserving our national parks for future generations to enjoy.

Montenegro's parliament has voted to lift the immunity of two alleged coup suspects, paving the way for their prosecution.
The suspects, identified as members of the Democratic Front opposition group, are accused of involvement in a failed coup attempt aimed at overthrowing the government in 2016.
The decision to strip their immunity was met with strong opposition from their supporters, who claim the move is politically motivated.
Several hundred opposition supporters protested outside the parliament building on Wednesday as lawmakers from the ruling coalition unanimously approved the motion.
Montenegro's special prosecutor said the two are suspected of criminal conspiracy and inciting "acts against constitutional order and security of Montenegro."
Some 20 people — including two Russian citizens — have been accused in the foiled coup said to be orchestrated by Russian and Serbian nationalists.
In a recent development, the Supreme Court has decided not to hear a dispute involving a North Carolina TV network.
The case stemmed from a lawsuit filed against the network by a former employee, alleging wrongful termination.

An RAF Mildenhall USAF squadron has marked the centenary of its founding members’ tragic first patrol in World War One.

Capt James Miller was shot down on March 9 1918 after he and two comrades borrowed SPAD VIIs from the French to fly their first patrol while waiting for machineguns for their own Nieuport 28 planes.

There are two lines of thoughts among MPs as to the motivation behind the Shapps plot.
Is it is an attempt by Remainers to disrupt Brexit and install a pro-Remain PM?
It is true that some arch-Remainers are on manoeuvres – Guido understands Anna Soubry texted the Chief Whip Gavin Williamson calling on May to go.
Yet most Tories don’t think it is a Remain/Leave issue and instead blame disgruntled former ministers who have one thing in common: they lost their jobs.
The recent revelation of a plot by sacked ministers to oust Prime Minister Theresa May has caused a stir within the Conservative Party.
The group, led by former party chairman Grant Shapps, reportedly has around 30 MPs backing their call for a leadership contest.
This move has been met with mixed reactions, with some seeing it as a necessary shake-up while others view it as a disruptive and self-serving act.
Critics of the plot argue that it is driven more by personal grievances than genuine concerns about the direction of the government.
Many of the sacked ministers involved in the scheme are known to have been unhappy with their dismissals and have been vocal about their discontent.
This has led to speculation that the plot is more about settling scores and seeking revenge rather than acting in the best interests of the party or the country.
Despite the controversy surrounding the plot, Prime Minister May has remained resolute, stating that she is focused on delivering Brexit and serving the interests of the British people.
The coming days are likely to be crucial in determining the future of May's leadership and the unity of the Conservative Party.

Instagram users can now breathe a sigh of relief as the popular social media platform introduces a much-awaited feature - the ability to organize saved posts into collections.
The new feature, which is being rolled out gradually, allows users to categorize their saved posts, providing a more streamlined and organized way to access content.
Until now, saving posts on Instagram was a simple process, but the lack of organization options meant that users were left with a cluttered collection of saved content.
With the introduction of collections, users can now create separate categories for their saved posts, making it easier to find and revisit specific content.
To utilize this new feature, users can simply tap and hold the bookmark-like save button on a post or tap the plus icon on the saved posts screen to add it to a collection.
This feature not only enhances user experience but also ensures that personal preferences and interests are easily accessible and well-organized.
Instagram only recently added the ability to save posts (and later, live video as well), but without a means of sorting or categorizing them you had a slowly growing pool of social effluent.
That dam has finally burst today as Instagram has started rolling out the new feature, giving us a means of individually adding each item into a collection.
Now, categories of interest can be separated, so you need not fear accidentally showing friends your appreciation for women's handbag design while you're looking for that sweet bike you saw.
To avail yourself of this new feature, one need only tap and hold the bookmark-esque save button or tap the plus icon on the saved posts screen.
We haven't seen the feature go live on our Android devices quite yet, although the relevant version (10.16) is out.
It could be a short period before that switch gets flipped, or the rollout may be gradual.

PARIS (AP) — French consumer fraud authorities are investigating a promotional campaign for Nutella that prompted scuffles in several supermarkets — and even a police intervention.
The Finance Ministry's fraud agency said Tuesday it will examine whether the campaign by the Intermarche supermarket chain violated pricing regulations.
An official with the agency would not give further details.
Intermarche drew big crowds at several stores last week after announcing sales of the chocolate and hazelnut spread for just 1.41 euros ($1.74), some 70 percent below the regular price.
Video circulated online of ensuing scuffles in some stores, drawing worldwide attention — and questions from authorities.
The deeply discounted Nutella promotion sparked chaos as customers rushed to grab jars at the reduced price, leading to altercations and confrontations in the aisles.
Images of shoppers jostling and fighting over the popular spread went viral on social media, raising concerns about the impact of such aggressive promotions on public order and safety.
Authorities are now delving into whether Intermarche's pricing strategy breached any laws or regulations, particularly regarding fair competition and consumer protection.

The investigation aims to shed light on the circumstances that led to the chaotic scenes in supermarkets across France, highlighting the potential risks associated with extreme discount campaigns on high-demand products like Nutella.
Music service Pandora has named Roger Lynch, the head of Dish's streaming video service, as its CEO as it wrestles with competition from Spotify and other newer music apps.
He'll take over Sept. 18.
Lynch's appointment comes as Pandora seeks to revitalize its position in the music streaming industry.
With his background in streaming services and digital media, Lynch is expected to bring fresh perspectives to Pandora's strategy to attract and retain users in a highly competitive market.
He is the founding CEO of Dish's Sling TV, one of the first apps to bundle live TV for the internet.
It launched in 2015.
The Oakland, California, company is also adding Michael Lynton, the chairman of Snapchat's owner Snap Inc. and former head of film studio Sony Pictures, to its board.
Most users listen to Pandora's internet radio for free, but it has newer subscription products too.
A 5000-strong crowd turned out at Gympie's ANZAC Day Dawn Service this morning to commemorate our fallen soldiers and those who have served and continue to serve.
The solemn ceremony began with a moving rendition of the Last Post, followed by a minute of silence that enveloped the crowd in reflection and gratitude.
Veterans of past conflicts stood alongside younger generations, united in remembrance and respect.
As the first light of dawn broke over the horizon, wreaths were laid at the foot of the cenotaph, each representing a heartfelt tribute to the sacrifices made for our freedom.
The haunting notes of the bugle playing the Reveille marked the end of the service, a poignant reminder of the duty to remember and honor those who have served.

"We honour the men and women who paid the ultimate sacrifice so we remain free.” Mayor Mick Curran echoed his sentiments: "That day at Gallipoli the Anzac spirit was born and is now part of our national identity,” Mr Curran said.
"I'm proud to say the Anzac spirit lives on in the Australian culture.”
Getty Image The Sixers and Heat are examples of two NBA teams that don’t seem to like each other all that much.

Their series has been defined by tough, physical play, as Miami is a team that like to grind out wins and Philadelphia is the kind of young team that will walk into any game and not be scared of anyone.
This has also meant that we’ve gotten some plays that can best be described as out of bounds.
For example, in Game 3, Dwyane Wade grabbed Sixers wing Justin Anderson by the arm and threw him out of bounds, which resulted Anderson getting in his face in technical fouls being doled out.
In Game 5, we had another one of these moments that resulted in someone picking up a tech.
Ben Simmons played some smother defense to force a Goran Dragic turnover in the third quarter and tried to spark a fast break.
However, as Simmons attempted to push the ball up the court, Dragic, frustrated by the turnover, smacked Simmons’ head in an attempt to disrupt the play.
The referees quickly blew the whistle and assessed a technical foul to Dragic for the unnecessary and unsportsmanlike action.
The incident added fuel to the already intense rivalry between the two teams, further escalating the physicality and tension on the court.
Both teams continued to battle fiercely, with the Heat ultimately coming out on top in a closely contested game.
As the series progresses, it will be interesting to see how the teams handle the heightened emotions and continue to compete at a high level.>
KOUGA Municipality has started drilling for water as drought conditions in the area prevail.
The persistent lack of rainfall has left residents and farmers in Kouga facing severe water shortages, prompting the local government to take proactive measures to secure alternative water sources.
The drilling initiative aims to tap into underground aquifers to supplement the dwindling surface water supplies.
With dams at critically low levels and rivers running dry, the municipality is racing against time to ensure a sustainable water supply for the community.
Mayor of Kouga, Sarah Baartman, emphasized the urgency of the situation, stating, "The current drought is one of the most severe we have experienced, and we must act swiftly to avoid a water crisis."
The drilling project is part of a broader strategy to enhance water resilience in the region, including water conservation campaigns and infrastructure upgrades.
Local residents have welcomed the initiative but remain cautious about the long-term effectiveness of groundwater extraction.
Many are calling for comprehensive water management policies to mitigate the impact of future droughts and ensure water security for generations to come.

New York City Ballet continues its first year without Peter Martins at the helm as our spring season opens tonight.
When he retired at the start of the new year, we plunged headfirst into unknown, murky waters.
Who would the new director be?
When would we know?
Would we dancers get some say in the decision?
Who would oversee the Balanchine ballets?
Who would be in charge of casting?
Would a new director bring along huge upheaval?
Could some of us be out of a job?
The dancers currently have little information about the search process and plans to move forward.
As the company navigates this transitional period, there's a palpable sense of uncertainty lingering in the air.
Rehearsals feel different, not just because of the absence of Martins, but also due to the looming question mark regarding the future direction of the company.
The dancers are giving their all on stage, but behind the scenes, there's a collective yearning for stability and clarity.
I've noticed it the most during dress rehearsals, particularly for Balanchine ballets.
Although he rarely attended daily rehearsals, he always supervised the final rehearsals before the ballets went before the audience.
Frequently, he had a nugget of wisdom to share, often from the mouth of Balanchine himself, to help us fix a tricky partnering maneuver, or a difficult sequence of turns.
Siemens has supplied four switchgear panels to Siemens Gamesa for the 28MW Nissum Bredning offshore wind farm demonstrator off Jutland in Denmark.
The 8VM1 gas-insulated SF6-free HV switchgear has capacity of 72.5kV and protects the wind turbines from overloads and short circuits.
Siemens said the 8VM1 has been specifically developed for use in offshore wind farms.
The switchgear panels are crucial components in ensuring the safe and efficient operation of the wind farm.
By utilizing advanced technology and innovative design, Siemens aims to enhance the performance and reliability of the wind turbines at Nissum Bredning.

This collaboration between Siemens and Siemens Gamesa represents a significant step towards sustainable energy production in Denmark and highlights the importance of cutting-edge equipment in offshore wind power projects.
The deployment of Siemens gear underscores the industry's commitment to advancing renewable energy solutions and reducing environmental impact.
