Washington Capitals' forward Nathan Walker is set to make history as the first Australian to play in the National Hockey League (NHL).
The 23-year-old left winger has been named to the Capitals' season-opening roster, solidifying his place in the prestigious league.
Walker's journey to the NHL has been nothing short of remarkable.
Born in Wales to Australian parents, he moved to Australia at a young age before discovering his passion for hockey.
After his brother Ryan introduced him to the sport, Nathan's talent became evident, prompting a move to the Czech Republic at the age of 13 to pursue his hockey dreams.
In 2014, the Capitals made history by selecting Walker in the third round of the NHL draft, making him the first Australian to be drafted into the league.
Despite facing challenges in the minor leagues, Walker's perseverance and dedication paid off as he honed his skills and emerged as a strong penalty killer.
With his hard work and determination, Nathan Walker has now earned a spot on the Capitals' roster, breaking barriers and inspiring aspiring hockey players in Australia and beyond.
After his brother Ryan was exposed to the sport, it became clear Nathan had pro potential and he moved to the Czech Republic at age 13 to play minor and then junior hockey.
The Capitals made Walker the first Australian selected in the NHL draft when they took him in the third round in 2014.
After a few seasons in the minors, the 23-year-old developed into a strong penalty killer and earned a spot on Washington’s season-opening roster.

Former "Deadliest Catch" skipper, Blake Painter, was tragically found dead in his home.
The 38-year-old fisherman gained fame for his appearances on the popular Discovery Channel series, which showcased the dangers and challenges faced by fishermen in the treacherous waters of Alaska.
Painter's sudden passing has shocked fans and colleagues alike, leaving many mourning the loss of a talented and dedicated individual.
Authorities discovered his body after a concerned friend contacted the police, prompting an investigation into the circumstances surrounding his death.
While the exact cause of Painter's passing remains unknown, authorities have ruled out foul play.
An official statement from Clatsop County Sheriff Tom Bergin confirmed that a toxicology report would be necessary to determine the cause of death.
Despite his untimely demise, Blake Painter's legacy in the fishing industry and on television will be remembered by many.
Bergin said a cause of death would not be released until a toxicology report had been completed, but there was no apparent evidence of foul play.

Painter rose to prominence after appearing on early seasons of the Discovery Channel series, which chronicles the lives and work of fishermen in Alaska waters, with an eye to the hazards of the profession.
Everest CC Masters continued their winning streak on their tour to Suriname by clinching their second victory against Snellen Park.

Bharat Dilshan claimed 3-20.
Snellen Park were bowled out for 75 in 19.5 overs in reply.

Mohamed was named man-of-the-match, while the visitors were presented with trophies compliments of Suriname Cricket Board.

The Dow Jones Industrial Average plummeted 665 points on Friday, marking the end of the worst week for the stock market in two years.
This massive drop was fueled by a stronger-than-expected jobs report that led to a surge in interest rates.
The market turmoil sent shockwaves throughout Wall Street, with investors grappling with the implications of rising borrowing costs.
The broader market indices also suffered significant losses, with the S&P 500 and the Nasdaq Composite both closing sharply lower.
The tech sector, in particular, took a hit as investors sought safer assets amid the market volatility.
Concerns about inflation and the pace of interest rate hikes by the Federal Reserve added to the uncertainty, contributing to the sell-off.
Analysts and investors are closely watching the Fed's next moves, as expectations grow for a more aggressive approach to monetary policy.
The prospect of multiple rate hikes this year has rattled the markets, with many fearing the impact on economic growth and corporate earnings.
As the week drew to a close, the outlook remained uncertain, with many bracing for further volatility in the days ahead.
<U.S.
U.S. stocks fell sharply on Friday after a stronger-than-expected jobs report sent interest rates higher, with major indexes on track for their worst weekly performance in two years, CNBC reported.
The Dow was down 665.75 points at the closing bell, with the 30-stock index falling below 26,000 to its lowest point since Jan. 16.
"The key for the market today is rising interest rates," said Mike Baele, managing director at U.S. Bank Wealth Management.
"The old adage is: 'Bull markets don't die of old age, they are killed by higher interest rates.'
That looms large."
The Federal Reserve has forecast three rate hikes for 2018, though market observers thought it was now possible the Fed could raise rates four times this year.
Rescue crews are searching the waters off Huntington Beach’s Tower 18 for a missing swimmer.

Eric Corbin said.

The companion immediately alerted lifeguards, prompting a swift response from the rescue teams.
Boats, Jet Skis, helicopters and divers are all helping in the search, Corbin said.
“The conditions are probably a little rougher than some days,” Corbin said, describing the waves and 3 to 5 feet and the conditions windy and choppy.

Palestinians are expressing confusion and concern over the United States' recent stance on the two-state solution.
The US view, which suggests that a two-state solution is optional, has left many Palestinians puzzled about the future of peace negotiations.

Zomlot spoke ahead of a White House meeting on Wednesday between President Donald Trump and Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu.
A White House official has said that it's up to Israelis and Palestinians to decide what peace will entail, and that peace, not a two-state solution, is the goal.
This shift in approach has raised questions about the US commitment to the long-standing framework for resolving the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.
The Palestinian leadership is now faced with the challenge of navigating this new dynamic in pursuit of a lasting and just resolution.

KASUKABE, Japan — The cavernous underground cisterns here north of Tokyo could hold the Statue of Liberty, a scale that underscores the site’s immense task: protecting the world’s most populous metropolis from flooding.

Linked by tunnels that divert water away from the region’s most vulnerable floodplains, the $2 billion underground anti-flood system, completed in 2006, is an extraordinary example of the defenses that global cities are readying as they face an era of extreme weather brought on by climate change.
As Tokyo braces itself for potential catastrophic flooding, authorities are ramping up their efforts to fortify the city against the looming threat.

With climate change intensifying the frequency and severity of natural disasters, including typhoons and heavy rainfall, the need for robust infrastructure like the underground cisterns in Kasukabe has become more urgent than ever before.
The city is implementing a multi-faceted approach that includes not only engineering solutions but also community preparedness and early warning systems to mitigate the impact of future floods.
“We’re preparing for flooding beyond anything we’ve seen,” said Kuniharu Abe, who heads up the underground site.
“Until now, at least, we’ve been successful.”

After quietly departing from his position as editor-in-chief of the Village Voice, Stephen Mooallem's exit has left many questioning the future direction of the iconic publication.
Mooallem, who took on the role in 2019, was known for his efforts to modernize the Voice and adapt it to the digital age.
His departure, however, has been met with speculation and uncertainty among staff and readers alike.
The circumstances surrounding Mooallem's exit remain shrouded in mystery, with no official statement from either him or the company.
Some insiders suggest that clashes over editorial direction and financial pressures may have played a role in his sudden departure.
Despite his relatively short tenure, Mooallem made significant strides in revamping the Voice's online presence and engaging with a new generation of readers.
The exit comes at a volatile time for the former alternative news leader, which closed the free weekly print edition last August.
Owner Peter Barbey has focused instead on the publication’s digital presence, but in a crowded landscape it has been difficult to retain its relevance.
Mooallem was the Voice’s third editor under Barbey, who in early 2016 replaced top editor with Will Bourne, who ran the paper for eight months before getting the boot.

MOSCOW (AP) — The Latest at the World Cup (all times local): 3:03 p.m. Russian police have briefly detained several activists protesting political repressions outside a World Cup arena.
Police moved quickly to round up four teenagers outside the stadium where Sweden knocked out Switzerland on Tuesday.
The four were released a few hours later.

Lika Petrovskaya, a 16-year-old who wore a bloodied white dress at the protest, said their goal was "to attract attention to the political repressions," including the imprisonment of Ukrainian filmmaker Oleg Sentsov.
Another five activists were also detained Tuesday while they were distributing leaflets calling for Sentsov's release.
Sentsov, a vocal opponent of Russia's annexation of Crimea, was sentenced in 2015 to 20 years for conspiracy to commit terror acts.
He denied the charges and has been on a hunger strike since mid-May.
The activists' brief detention highlights the ongoing tensions surrounding political dissent during the World Cup festivities.
While the tournament has been a celebration of international football, it has also drawn attention to various social and political issues.
Russian authorities have faced criticism for their handling of dissent during the World Cup, with some activists accusing them of using the tournament as a distraction from human rights abuses.
The detentions serve as a reminder of the complexities surrounding major international events, where the spotlight can both celebrate sporting achievements and shine a light on social injustices.

From his rough-hewn, rambling music, you wouldn’t immediately take Steve Gunn for a Smiths fan, but apparently he’s been a devotee since his days as an introspective adolescent in the Philadelphia suburbs.

The former Kurt Vile sideman recently tackled two songs by his teen heroes–“This Night Has Opened My Eyes” and “The Hand That Rocks the Cradle”–for Aquarium Drunkard’s “Lagniappe Sessions” series of low-key recordings.

It’s easier to imagine Gunn nerding out over Johnny Marr’s sparkly guitar arpeggios than it is to think about him tearfully reciting Morrissey lyrics, and Gunn’s performances here reveal Marr’s subtle influence on his own playing.
Gunn's minimal covers of these Smiths classics offer a fresh perspective on the iconic band's music.
Stripped down to their core elements, Gunn brings out the emotional depth and intricate melodies that have made the Smiths' songs timeless.
His delicate guitar work and understated vocals breathe new life into these tracks, showcasing his deep appreciation for the band's artistry.
Fans of both Steve Gunn and the Smiths will appreciate these intimate renditions, which highlight the enduring appeal of the Manchester band's music and Gunn's skillful interpretation of it.
This unexpected tribute serves as a testament to the lasting influence of the Smiths on musicians across genres and generations.
Roche's Genentech has announced that its groundbreaking drug for treating a complication of diabetes has received approval from the FDA.
The drug, known as Lucentis, is a significant advancement in the treatment of diabetic retinopathy, a serious condition that can lead to vision loss.
This approval marks a major milestone in the fight against diabetic macular edema, a common complication of diabetes that affects the eyes.
The drug, Lucentis, is the first approved for patients with or without swelling in the back of the eye called diabetic macular edema.
Genentech estimates that diabetic retinopathy affects nearly 7.7 million Americans, and said the condition is the leading cause of blindness among adults ages 20 to 74.
Roche shares have surged 9.4% over the last three months, compared with a 3.2% rise in the S&P 500 .

NEW YORK (AP) — A judge in New York has ruled against the makers of "Sesame Street" in a dispute with the distributor of the upcoming Melissa McCarthy movie, "The Happytime Murders."
U.S. District Judge Vernon Broderick ruled Wednesday that distributor STX Productions can continue to use the tagline "No sesame.
All street" in promoting the R-rated film, which features Muppet-like puppets in a comedic crime story.
Sesame Workshop sued last week, seeking to end the inclusion of the tagline in promotional materials ahead of the film's Aug. 17 release.
The company argued that the public would be confused and think the movie was supported by "Sesame Street."
Broderick heard oral arguments Wednesday before issuing his ruling.
The judge's decision comes as a relief to the makers of "The Happytime Murders," allowing them to proceed with their marketing campaign unhindered.
Fans of adult humor and puppetry can now look forward to the film's release without the cloud of legal uncertainty hanging over it.
This ruling sets a precedent for the entertainment industry, emphasizing the importance of distinguishing between different properties and avoiding potential confusion among audiences.

As the countdown to the movie's premiere continues, both sides will likely reflect on the significance of this legal battle and its impact on future collaborations between similar-sounding franchises.

The department asked California Palms to cease and desist those statements from its website.
WYTV 33 News is working to get a response from Rucci.

The move comes after Day's contract with TaylorMade-adidas Golf expired at the end of 2021.

This shift adds a significant boost to Nike's roster of professional golfers.

But while Nike’s current stable of pros go in search of new equipment — No Laying Up reported that Rory McIlroy, most recently, is on the verge of employing the use of some Callaway clubs — the company brought in the new year by welcoming World No 1 Jason Day onto its staff.
BERLIN — German authorities say they have deported 69 Afghans whose asylum requests were rejected back to their home country.
The deportation flight, carrying the individuals, took off from Frankfurt airport and landed in Kabul, Afghanistan.
This move comes amidst ongoing debates in Germany regarding the deportation of failed asylum-seekers to countries deemed unsafe.
The state interior minister of Bavaria, where 51 of the men had been living, welcomed the deportation flight.
Joachim Herrmann noted that unlimited deportations to Afghanistan had recently been approved by Germany’s federal authorities.
In recent years deportations to Afghanistan were limited to people with criminal convictions.

In the latest episode of the Autosport podcast, legendary Formula 1 journalist Nigel Roebuck takes a trip down memory lane to revisit the epic battle between Alain Prost and Niki Lauda during the 1984 F1 season.
As Roebuck reflects on this historic rivalry, he delves into the intricacies and drama that unfolded throughout the season, capturing the essence of one of the most memorable seasons in F1 history.
As well as the remarkable dominance of John Barnard's McLaren MP4/2, which won 12 out of 16 races, this was a year full of stories.
Ayrton Senna's rookie season with Toleman, and his controversial signing of a Lotus deal for 1985, is also a source of some fascinating reminiscences from Roebuck.

There's also a look at the struggles of Ferrari and Renault, how Lotus driver Nigel Mansell earned himself a Williams drive and tales of how fiction and reality came together at the Dallas Grand Prix.
As the stories flow, it becomes increasingly clear how important 1984 was at setting the tone for what happened in F1 over the years that followed.
The Autosport Podcast is available to subscribe to free via iTunes and most other podcast suppliers.
Tune in to immerse yourself in the nostalgia and drama of F1's golden era as Roebuck shares his unique perspective on the unforgettable 1984 season.
The Getty Museum has made a significant move by returning an ancient statuette to the Italian government.
The 29-inch-high statuette, believed to date from the 1st century BC, was acquired by the museum in 1992 from an American couple.
However, concerns were raised about the legality of the export of the artwork, as there was no documentation to support its legal acquisition.
The decision to return the ancient statue comes amidst a broader effort by the Getty Museum to address issues related to the provenance of its collection.

The museum's senior antiquities curator at the time of the purchase, Marion True, was later indicted by Italy for conspiracy to traffic in illegal antiquities, although the case was eventually dropped.
In recent years, the Getty Museum has proactively returned numerous artworks to Italy and Greece as part of its commitment to ethical acquisitions and preserving cultural heritage.
The 29-inch-high statuette is believed to date from the 1st century BC.
The museum bought the piece in 1992 from an American couple but the Los Angeles Times says ( http://lat.ms/2sAWgvn ) there's no documentation indicating it was legally exported.
At the time of purchase, the Getty's senior antiquities curator was Marion True.
Italy later indicted True for conspiracy to traffic in illegal antiquities but eventually dropped the case.
However, in the past decade, the Getty has returned dozens of artworks to Italy and Greece.
SILVERSTONE, England (AP) — Struggling Formula One outfit McLaren has accepted Eric Boullier's resignation as racing director and announced a restructure of its leadership.
Boullier, who joined the British team in 2014, had overseen its worst run across its 52-year history.
McLaren has not won a race since 2012 and hasn't landed a podium position in more than four years.
Boullier's departure comes amidst mounting pressure on McLaren as they continue to underperform in the highly competitive world of Formula One.
The team's failure to secure a victory or even a podium finish in recent years has been a source of frustration for fans and stakeholders alike.

In a statement released by McLaren, Boullier expressed his gratitude for the opportunity to work with the team but acknowledged that a change in leadership was necessary to revitalize the organization.
The team has announced that Gil de Ferran, a former IndyCar champion and McLaren advisor, will take on a newly created role as sporting director.
The decision to restructure the leadership at McLaren signals a commitment to turning around the team's fortunes and returning to the front of the grid.
With the mid-season break approaching, McLaren will be looking to regroup and make strategic changes to improve their performance for the remainder of the season.
Gov.
Eric Greitens of Missouri has resigned from office, leaving behind a trail of controversy and political turmoil.
His decision comes amidst mounting pressure and a looming impeachment process.
The top takeaways from his resignation include the allegations of sexual misconduct and misuse of charity resources that have plagued his tenure.
Greitens, a former Navy SEAL and political newcomer, had positioned himself as a conservative outsider ready to shake up the status quo.
However, his time in office was marred by scandal, including accusations of an extramarital affair and claims of blackmail.
The unfolding drama surrounding his personal conduct overshadowed his policy agenda and eroded public trust.
As the embattled governor faced calls for his resignation from both sides of the political aisle, the pressure became too much to bear.
In a statement announcing his decision to step down, Greitens maintained his innocence while acknowledging the toll the controversy had taken on his family and the state of Missouri.
His playbook sounded a lot like President Trump’s, except for one thing.
As he defended himself in recent months, Mr. Greitens chose his words carefully.
“Let’s call this what it is,” he said at a news conference last month.
“A political witch hunt.” An ad last week, paid for by the governor’s political operation, also used language that sounded borrowed from Mr. Trump.
Residents in parts of Kansas were rattled by two earthquakes originating in northern Oklahoma.
The seismic activity, with magnitudes of 3.2 and 3.3, occurred on Monday morning near Pawnee, a location situated approximately two hours south of Wichita.
Fortunately, no injuries or damages have been reported in connection with these back-to-back tremors.
This event comes in the wake of a significant 5.8 magnitude earthquake that struck the same region in September, causing extensive property damage.
Scientists have pointed to the correlation between Oklahoma's recent surge in seismic activity and the state's oil and gas production.
As a response, state regulators have imposed new regulations on the injection of wastewater into underground disposal wells.
The U.S. Geological Survey provided information on the recent earthquakes, highlighting the ongoing concerns surrounding these natural events and their potential causes.
The U.S. Geological Survey says the back-to-back earthquakes hit Monday morning near Pawnee, 2 hours south of Wichita.
The USGS says the quakes had magnitudes of 3.2 and 3.3 and there are no reports of injuries or damage.
In September, a 5.8 magnitude earthquake struck Pawnee and caused widespread property damage.

Scientists have linked Oklahoma’s recent spate of earthquakes to oil and gas production, and state regulators have issued new regulations on the practice of injecting wastewater into underground disposal wells.

Locked Mailboxes Broken Into in NE Portland  Several locked mailboxes in Northeast Portland have been broken into, causing concern among residents.
Until the boxes are fixed neighbors will have to drive three miles to the nearest Post Office to get their mail.
So far police have no suspect description.
Twice in the last month someone has broken into locked mailboxes in the area.
Image courtesy of KGW
Residents are urged to be vigilant and report any suspicious activity near mailboxes to the authorities.
The United States Postal Service is working to repair the damaged mailboxes as quickly as possible to prevent further incidents.
In the meantime, residents are advised to consider alternative ways to secure their mail, such as using a P.O.
box or requesting mail holds during extended periods away from home.
The community is encouraged to come together and look out for one another to ensure the safety and security of their mail.

MINNEAPOLIS (WCCO) – The Minnesota Timberwolves announced on Wednesday they’ve signed guard Derrick Rose for the 2018-19 season.
The Timberwolves reached an agreement to bring back Rose shortly after NBA free agency started earlier this week.
He was originally signed by the Timberwolves as a free agent for last season back on March 8.
Rose, a former league MVP, provided a significant boost off the bench for the Timberwolves last season.
Despite battling injuries throughout his career, Rose showcased flashes of his former self and proved to be a valuable asset for the team.
His experience and scoring ability were crucial for Minnesota, especially during the playoffs.
The 29-year-old guard will look to build on his solid performance from last season and continue to contribute to the Timberwolves' success in the upcoming campaign.
Rose’s familiarity with the team and coaching staff should help him seamlessly integrate into the roster for the upcoming season.
He averaged 8.4 points per game and shot 43.5 percent from the field.
He appeared in all five of the Timberwolves’ playoff games against the Houston Rockets and averaged 14.2 points off the bench while shooting nearly 51 percent from the field.
Rose is a three-time All-Star and had the best season of his career in 2010-11 under current Timberwolves coach Tom Thibodeau, when he earned the NBA MVP award.
Bayern Munich has confirmed that Manchester United submitted a substantial €100 million offer for their star forward, Thomas Muller.
The bid, which was reportedly made during the recent transfer window, has stirred up discussions within the football world.
Muller, a key player for Bayern Munich, has been a consistent performer for the club over the years.
The 27-year-old forward is known for his versatility, intelligence on the field, and clinical finishing.
His potential move to Manchester United would have undoubtedly been a significant transfer in the world of football.
While Bayern Munich has acknowledged the offer, it appears that Muller's future at the club remains uncertain.
The German international has been a loyal servant to Bayern, having risen through the ranks of the club's youth system.
However, with the lure of a move to the English Premier League and the opportunity to work under Jose Mourinho, Muller may be tempted to consider a transfer.

Muller is chasing a fifth consecutive Bundesliga title for Bayern this season but the 27-year-old has struggled for his best form under Carlo Ancelotti, scoring four goals in 26 appearances across all competitions and just one in Germany's top flight.

Authorities on the Greek island of Lesbos say they have blocked a ship carrying container homes for refugees and other migrants in protest at the refusal of the government and the European Union to move more people to Greece's mainland.
The decision to prevent the ship from docking has caused tensions as the island struggles to cope with the influx of migrants and the overcrowded living conditions in existing camps.
The mayor of Lesbos, along with other local officials, has been vocal about the urgent need for better support and distribution of migrants across the country.

The mayors of five Greek islands facing the coast of Turkey are demanding that the government and EU end a policy of containment for migrants — introduced last year as a deterrent against illegal migration — because living facilities are severely overcrowded.

ENGLEWOOD, Colo. (AP) Denver Broncos coach Gary Kubiak stepped down from his dream job on Monday because of health concerns, saying ”the demands of the job are no longer a good fit for me.” Kubiak missed a week of work in October after suffering a complex migraine, his second health scare in three years.
Kubiak missed a week of work in October after suffering a complex migraine, his second health scare in three years.
The 55-year-old coach, who led the Broncos to a Super Bowl victory last season, said he believed it was time to step away from coaching and focus on his health and family.
Kubiak's decision comes after the Broncos failed to make the playoffs for the first time since 2010.
General Manager John Elway praised Kubiak's contributions to the team and stated that they will begin their search for a new head coach immediately.
Kubiak's departure marks the end of an era for the Broncos, leaving fans and players alike with mixed emotions about his resignation.
Tens of thousands of residents who were evacuated due to the potential failure of the Oroville Dam spillway in Northern California have been given the green light to return home.
The evacuation orders were lifted as the authorities expressed confidence in the stability of the dam following intense repair efforts.
Officials stated that the massive operation to reinforce the dam involved the strategic placement of boulders and the constant movement of reinforcements via helicopters.
Bill Croyle, acting director of the California Department of Water Resources, assured the public that the dam was now safe and that reconstruction efforts were well underway.

Jim Urquhart / Reuters Since the threat of a spillway failure was identified, reinforcing boulders have been placed at the rate of 40 truckloads per hour, and helicopters also moved reinforcements every minute and a half, Croyle said.
Croyle added that design teams were in place to reconstruct parts of the spillway, which was built in the 1960s, and that there would be a seamless transition into rebuilding the infrastructure.
“There’s about 125 construction crews on point.
So there’s a lot of people, a lot of equipment.
… We’re not holding back on addressing this issue,” he said.

The Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) has announced a new plan to address contaminants from non-stick coatings.
These contaminants, known as perfluoroalkyls and polyfluoroalkyls (PFAs), have been used in various products for decades, including non-stick pans and food packaging.
Recent studies have linked long-term exposure to these industrial chemicals to serious health risks such as cancer and hormone disruptions.
Concerns have also been raised about the presence of these contaminants in water supplies across the country, potentially exposing millions of Americans to harmful levels.
In response to these findings, the EPA has committed to working with state officials to develop a comprehensive management plan for PFAs.
The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency said Monday it would hold a May summit with state officials.
The session will focus on a family of industrial chemicals used for decades in everything from non-stick pans to food wrappers to bags for microwaveable popcorn.
The chemicals are known as perfluoralkyls and polyfluoralkyls, or PFAs.
Studies now link long-term exposure to the industrial chemicals to increased risks of cancer, hormone changes and other disturbances.
Researchers say water supplies serving millions of Americans show potentially dangerous levels of the contaminants.
The EPA says it will use input from state officials to develop a new management plan for the chemicals this year.

Emergency response vehicles gather at Great Lakes Dragaway on Sunday, Aug. 13, 2017, near Union Grove, Wis. Three men were shot and killed during an auto racing event at the facility, a Wisconsin sheriff said.
The shooting occurred around 7 p.m. and the suspect remains at large.
Authorities are actively investigating the incident and have urged anyone with information to come forward.
The sheriff's office has not yet released the identities of the victims or the possible motive behind the shooting.
The drag racing event was abruptly halted after the tragic incident, leaving attendees shocked and saddened by the violence that unfolded.
Wells Fargo has agreed to pay a hefty fine of $1 billion for engaging in abusive practices related to its mortgage and auto lending businesses.
The settlement comes after the bank was found to have charged customers improper fees and forced unnecessary insurance policies on auto loan borrowers.

The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau and the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency led the investigation into Wells Fargo's misconduct, uncovering a pattern of deceptive practices that harmed consumers.
The $1 billion fine is split evenly between the two regulatory bodies, with $500 million going to each.

This significant penalty marks a notable move by Mick Mulvaney, the acting director of the CFPB appointed by President Trump, who has been criticized for his stance on consumer protection regulations.
It is the first major enforcement action taken by Mulvaney since assuming his role in late November.
This latest fine adds to Wells Fargo's previous penalties, including a $100 million fine imposed by the CFPB in 2016 for unauthorized account openings.
The bank has been under scrutiny for its business practices and faces ongoing investigations into other potential violations.
The bank will pay $500 million to the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency, its main bank regulator, as well as $500 million to the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau.
This is the first fine that Mick Mulvaney, appointed as acting director of the CFPB by President Trump, has imposed since he took over the bureau in late November.
Wells Fargo was fined $100 million by the CFPB in September 2016 after its employees opened as many as 3.5 million bank and credit card accounts without getting customers' authorization.
The bank has been under investigation for other practices since then.
NEW YORK (AP) -- Darren Baker got scooped up by dad's team again.
The son of Washington manager Dusty Baker was drafted by the Nationals in the 27th round of the Major League Baseball draft Wednesday - 15 years after he first made headlines on the baseball diamond.
The younger Baker, now an 18-year-old shortstop at Jesuit High School in California, was just 3 when he was a bat boy for the San Francisco Giants, managed by his father, in the 2002 World Series.
During Game 5 against the Angels, Darren Baker had run to the plate to pick up a bat when J.T.
Snow homered and headed home.
The Angels' David Bell, who was running at Baker, scooped him up to prevent a potential collision at the plate, a moment replayed constantly in the years since.
Darren Baker's baseball journey has come full circle as he now embarks on his own professional path with the Nationals, the same team his father manages.
Dusty Baker expressed his pride and excitement for his son's achievement, highlighting Darren's dedication and passion for the sport.
The young shortstop has shown promise and potential, and his draft selection marks a significant milestone in his budding baseball career.
With his family's baseball legacy and support behind him, Darren Baker is poised to make his mark in the world of professional baseball.
NEWNAN, Ga. — A Georgia restaurant owner says he is investigating after an employee called 911 on an African-American family who had stopped for dinner during a vacation.

WSB-TV reports that Felicia and Othniel Dobson of North Carolina on Monday had stopped for dinner at a Subway in Newnan with their four children, ages 8 to 19, when a restaurant employee called police.
The family was reportedly on their way back from a vacation in Florida when they decided to grab a meal at the Subway location.
The Dobsons were shocked and upset when police arrived in response to the employee's call, questioning them about their presence at the restaurant.
The incident has sparked outrage and renewed discussions about racial profiling and discrimination.
The restaurant owner has since issued a statement expressing regret over the incident and promising to take appropriate action.
The Dobson family hopes that their experience will lead to greater awareness and sensitivity in how individuals are treated based on their race.

Forensic teams have been examining the property for clues, and detectives are appealing to the public for any information that may help shed light on the circumstances surrounding the woman's death.
"At this stage her death is being treated as unexplained and inquiries are ongoing surrounding the circumstances of the incident."

Brazilian football star Neymar is making impressive strides towards regaining full fitness ahead of the upcoming World Cup, according to his teammate Danilo.
The talented forward has been recovering from a foot injury sustained earlier in the season, but his progress has been encouraging.
Danilo praised Neymar's dedication and determination, highlighting his commitment to returning to peak form in time for the tournament.
"He's on the fast track to full fitness," Danilo remarked, emphasizing Neymar's speed and agility on the field.
The Brazilian team is optimistic about Neymar's recovery and are hopeful that he will be fully prepared for the challenges ahead.
With important friendly matches lined up against Croatia and Austria before the World Cup kicks off, Neymar's presence and performance will be crucial for Brazil's success in the tournament.
"He's so fast you wouldn't know whether to go, left, right, forwards or backwards," Danilo said of Neymar's trickery.
"We hope he'll be 100% ready or as ready as is possible."
Brazil play Croatia at Liverpool June 3 and against Austria in Vienna on June 10 before their opening World Cup game with Switzerland June 17.
PORT BRUCE – A plan to remove a dump truck marooned on the collapsed Port Bruce bridge for nearly a month has been delayed.
The province’s Ministry of Labour first wants to approve the plan for removal of the truck, which was scheduled to go ahead today.
Elgin County Warden David Marr said the contractor and the insurance company were to submit a detailed plan today and if everything goes according to plan, the truck will be removed Wednesday.
Related Crews were out Friday removing the fuel from the truck.
The delay in removing the truck has caused frustration among local residents who have been eagerly awaiting the reopening of the bridge, a vital transportation link in the area.
The bridge collapsed on August 23 after the dump truck, carrying a load of stone, became stuck and caused a section of the bridge to give way.
The Ministry of Labour's insistence on approving the removal plan underscores the importance of safety in such operations.
While the delay is disappointing, ensuring that the removal process is carried out safely and effectively is paramount.
Residents are hopeful that the truck will be successfully removed on Wednesday, allowing for the necessary repairs to begin on the bridge and the restoration of normal traffic flow in the area.

Pressure continues to mount on Shamrock Rovers manager Stephen Bradley after his side were knocked out of the EA Sports Cup by to First Division side Longford Town.
Bradley made nine changes to the side that drew with Limerick on Friday night but the new-look line-up suffered a 0-1 defeat at Tallaght Stadium - the team's fifth game in a row without a victory.
The defeat highlights Rovers' struggles in front of goal, with their misfiring attack failing to break down Longford's defense.
Longford Town capitalized on Rovers' lackluster performance, with Aodh Dervin scoring the only goal of the game in the first half.
The defeat is a major setback for Rovers, who are now facing increasing scrutiny from fans and pundits alike.
With their form on a downward spiral, Bradley faces a challenging task to turn things around and restore confidence within the team.

WASHINGTON (AP) — A U.S. Navy commander says an Iranian naval patrol boat shined a laser at a U.S. Marine Corps helicopter flying over the Strait of Hormuz in what officials say was an unsafe encounter.
U.S. Navy Cmdr.
James Urban, a spokesman for U.S.
Naval Forces Central Command, described the incident as provocative and dangerous.
The Iranian boat's actions were deemed to be in violation of international maritime regulations, as shining lasers at aircraft can pose serious risks to the safety of pilots and crew.
Urban, a U.S. Fifth Fleet spokesman, says the Iranian boat came within 800 yards of the USS Bataan, scanned it from bow to stern with the spotlight and shined the light on the USS Cole.
The helicopter automatically fired flares in response.
Urban says the action was considered dangerous because shining lasers at a helicopter at night can impair pilots' vision and disorient them if they're wearing night vision goggles.
SMITHFIELD, N.C. — A North Carolina woman accused of hiding the remains of two infants under a house in 2016 has pleaded guilty to two counts of failure to report a death.
Bridgette Morgan Smith, 41, entered her plea in Johnston County Superior Court on Tuesday.
The case came to light when a contractor working on the property discovered the remains in a crawl space.
Smith, who lived in the home at the time, admitted to giving birth to the infants in 2015 and 2016.
She concealed their bodies under the house and kept their existence a secret.
The cause of death for the infants remains unknown.
Johnston County District Attorney Susan Doyle said DNA evidence showed that both infants were related to Smith and that Smith’s mother said they were her daughter’s children.
Smith had told investigators both children were stillborn.
Samsung and Hyundai Motor are facing increasing uncertainties as they navigate through the challenges of 2017.
Samsung, the tech giant, is currently under scrutiny due to the Galaxy Note 7 debacle that led to two global recalls and its eventual discontinuation.
The company is expected to reveal the findings of its investigation into the issue later this month.
On the other hand, Hyundai Motor, South Korea's largest automotive group, is striving to reach a sales target of 8.25 million vehicles this year.
The company, along with its sister company Kia Motors, fell short of their sales goal in 2016, selling 7.88 million cars.
These setbacks highlight the need for both companies to adapt and overcome the uncertainties they face in the upcoming year.
Samsung is expected to announce this month the findings of its investigation into the Galaxy Note 7 that caught fire and overheated, prompting two global recalls and its discontinuation last year.
Hyundai Motor Chair Chung Mong-koo said that South Korea’s largest automotive group aims to sell 8.25 million vehicles this year.
Hyundai Motor and its sister Kia Motors missed their sales target in 2016, selling 7.88 million cars.
The Crusaders have secured a major boost ahead of the upcoming Super Rugby season with the re-signing of 12 All Blacks players.

The powerhouse New Zealand franchise announced that Codie Taylor, Sam Whitelock, Kieran Read, Owen Franks, Israel Dagg, Joe Moody, Matt Todd, Ryan Crotty, Seta Tamanivalu, Wyatt Crockett, Scott Barrett, and Luke Romano have all agreed to new deals to remain with the team.
This retention of top-tier talent ensures continuity and strength for the Crusaders as they aim to defend their Super Rugby title in the highly competitive southern hemisphere competition.
The experience and skill brought by these All Blacks will be invaluable in guiding the team towards further success.
However, not all players have committed their futures to the Crusaders.

The 25-year-old Hall initially joined the Crusaders on a one-year deal from the Blues and is yet to re-sign with the franchise; while there is also uncertainty surrounding the future of Marty McKenzie, who only made five Super Rugby appearances this year.

The 12 All Blacks who have agreed new deals are: Codie Taylor, Sam Whitelock, Kieran Read, Owen Franks, Israel Dagg, Joe Moody, Matt Todd, Ryan Crotty, Seta Tamanivalu, Wyatt Crockett, Scott Barrett and Luke Romano.
The non-Test players include Richie Mo’unga, Mitchell Hunt, Ben Funnell, Mike Alaalatoa, Tim Perry and Oli Jager.

A mistaken shooter report led to a lockdown at a California Air Force base, causing panic and confusion among personnel and residents in the area.
The incident occurred when a false alarm was triggered, prompting authorities to take immediate action to secure the base and investigate the potential threat.
The lockdown was lifted after it was determined that there was no actual danger present.
The false alarm came on a day marked by violence.
In Virginia, a gunman wounded Rep. Steve Scalise and several others during practice for a baseball game featuring congressional Republicans.
This incident heightened tensions and raised concerns about the safety and security of public officials and military installations across the country.
Authorities are now working to determine the cause of the mistaken shooter report and prevent similar incidents from occurring in the future.

The incident serves as a reminder of the importance of maintaining vigilance and following proper protocols in response to potential threats, even in situations where the threat turns out to be unfounded.
Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) Administrator Scott Pruitt has signed a proposal that could significantly limit the scope of scientific research used in the agency's decision-making process.
The proposal aims to restrict the EPA from considering scientific studies unless the underlying data is made available for public scrutiny.
Pruitt argues that this change will enhance transparency within the agency and ensure that decisions are based on sound science that can be independently verified.
However, critics, including former EPA officials and scientists, have raised concerns about the potential implications of this move.
They argue that the proposal could hinder the EPA's ability to rely on critical public-health studies that use confidential patient medical records, as required by privacy laws.
The signing of the proposed order took place at the EPA headquarters, with the event livestreamed on the agency's website but closed to press coverage.
Pruitt says the change would increase transparency in the agency's decision-making by requiring all underlying data used in scientific studies to be made publicly available.

Critics, including former EPA administrators and scientists, say Pruitt's move is designed to restrict the agency from citing peer-reviewed public-health studies that use patient medical records required to be kept confidential under patient privacy laws.
The embattled EPA administrator signed the proposed order at EPA headquarters Tuesday in an event that was livestreamed on the agency's website but not open to press coverage.
NEW YORK - Police in New York are looking for a group of men who attacked a bodega clerk with avocados and bananas late last month.
According to the NYPD, a 21-year-old clerk was behind the counter at the Stadium Gourmet Deli when two suspects approached him angrily about a food order.
The men suddenly began throwing unripe avocados and bananas at the clerk, some of which ricochet off the clerk and across the room.
Surveillance video captured the shocking incident, showing the clerk attempting to shield himself from the flying fruits as the suspects continued their assault.
The clerk sustained minor injuries from the attack but did not require hospitalization.
Authorities are investigating the incident as a case of assault and are urging anyone with information to come forward.
The bodega clerk, who has chosen to remain anonymous, expressed shock and disbelief at the unprovoked attack, stating that he was simply trying to do his job when the suspects became aggressive.
As the search for the suspects continues, the community is rallying behind the clerk, offering support and condemning the senseless act of violence.

A Wall Street sign hangs near the New York Stock Exchange, Friday, July 22, 2016, in New York.
U.S. stocks pulled back on Monday as a decline in Facebook pressured the technology sector.
Wall Street also paid attention to Washington after a Twitter meltdown from President Donald Trump, CNBC reported.
The Nasdaq composite dropped 1.8 percent as Facebook dropped 6.8 percent.
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 335 points, with Caterpillar as the worst-performing stock in the index.
The broader market sentiment was impacted by concerns over data privacy issues following revelations about Facebook's handling of user data.
Tech stocks took a hit as investors worried about increased regulatory scrutiny on the sector.
The negative market reaction also reflected uncertainties surrounding trade tensions and geopolitical risks.
Analysts noted that the sell-off highlighted the vulnerability of the tech sector to sudden shifts in market sentiment and regulatory challenges.
Overall, the day's trading reflected a cautious tone among investors as they assessed the potential implications of recent developments on market stability.

Looking for the best places to ring in the New Year with a bang?
From vibrant city celebrations to picturesque beach parties, there are numerous fantastic destinations around the world to welcome the arrival of the new year.

As the clock ticks closer to midnight, cities like Sydney, New York City, and London come alive with dazzling fireworks displays, live music performances, and lively street parties that attract crowds from all over the globe.
However, it's important to note that New Year's Eve celebrations can come with a hefty price tag.
The cheapest hotel rates in New Orleans and Atlantic City, for instance, can rise in excess of 300 and 500 percent, respectively, on New Year’s Eve compared with their normal prices.
The last thing you want to do in the final hours of 2017 is ruin your finances over one night of entertainment.

Whether you're looking for a glamorous night out in a bustling metropolis or a more laid-back celebration by the beach, be sure to plan ahead and budget wisely to make the most of your New Year's Eve festivities.
Cheers to a joyful and prosperous New Year ahead!
In a surprising turn of events, suspected thieves at a Costco in Seattle found themselves walking straight into the arms of the police.
The daring duo, a man, and a woman, were reportedly seen shoplifting from the store earlier.
Unbeknownst to them, officers were already waiting for them as they brazenly kicked open the emergency fire doors with a haul of stolen goods.
Their escape plan quickly unraveled as police apprehended them on the spot.
To add to the drama, a woman sitting in a car parked by the store's emergency doors was also arrested, believed to be the duo's getaway driver.
This quick and decisive action by law enforcement highlights the importance of vigilance and coordination in combating theft and criminal activities.

They arrested a woman who was sitting in a car pulled up to the store's emergency fire doors.Police say it was the getaway car.Officers were waiting when a man and a woman loaded down with stolen property kicked the doors open.
The suspects tried to make a run for it but police nabbed them.Investigators say they had been spotted shoplifting from the store before.
Villarreal striker Roberto Soldado has recovered from an injury that kept him out for over six months.
The former Tottenham forward tore the anterior cruciate ligament and the lateral meniscus in his right knee in a friendly against Deportivo La Coruna in August.
After undergoing successful surgery and undergoing an intense rehabilitation program, Soldado has now been given the all-clear to return to training with the team.
The 35-year-old forward expressed his relief and gratitude for the support he received during his recovery journey.
Soldado's return is a significant boost for Villarreal as they enter a crucial phase of the season.
The experienced striker's goal-scoring prowess and leadership on the field will be invaluable as the team aims to secure a top-four finish in La Liga and make a deep run in the Europa League.
Fans are eagerly anticipating Soldado's comeback and are hopeful that he can make a strong impact in the remaining matches of the season.
Two women are fighting for their lives after their car crashed into a lake in Hamilton Township, New Jersey.
A 40-year-old woman was driving a 1998 Subaru Impreza eastbound on S. Broad Street near the Rt.
195 east exit ramp around 9 a.m. Saturday when she lost control and struck a guard rail.
After striking the rail, the vehicle continued to accelerate as it drove across the median, traveled across westbound S. Broad Street and into Gropps Lake where it submerged.
Emergency responders arrived at the scene shortly after the incident occurred.
They managed to extract the two women from the partially submerged vehicle.
Both victims were immediately rushed to the nearest hospital in critical condition.
The cause of the crash is currently under investigation by local authorities.
Eyewitnesses reported seeing the car swerve erratically before crashing into the lake.
The impact of the collision left the vehicle partially submerged, with the front end of the car visible above the water's surface.
The incident has left the community shocked and concerned for the well-being of the two women involved.
Stay tuned for further updates as more information becomes available.
Hundreds of citizens gathered in the Serbian capital, Belgrade, to rally for free and fair elections.
The demonstration, organized by opposition groups, aimed to voice concerns over the integrity of the democratic process in the country.
Opposition leaders have accused Vucic of stifling democratic freedoms, exerting pressure on the media and threating opponents.
Protesters on Friday put forward a set of demands, including equal treatment in the media and international observers at the Belgrade vote.
The atmosphere was charged with calls for transparency and accountability in the electoral system, as demonstrators expressed their determination to safeguard the principles of democracy in Serbia.
The rally underscored the growing public discontent with the current political climate and the pressing need for reforms to ensure a more inclusive and transparent electoral process.
Scientists say they're several steps closer to perfecting a method for saving the northern white rhino from extinction.

By successfully creating hybrid embryos using frozen sperm from northern white rhinos and eggs from their closely related southern white rhino cousins, researchers have made significant progress in their efforts to rescue this critically endangered sub-species.
The hybrids, known as northern-southern white rhinos, offer hope for the survival of the northern white rhino by introducing genetic diversity and increasing the chances of successful reproduction.
This innovative approach represents a crucial development in the race against time to prevent the complete loss of the northern white rhino population.
They're also working on a second method that would see sperm and eggs produced from preserved cells of northern white rhinos.
Buck the dog, who captured the hearts of many, has been transferred to a new home at a breed-specific animal shelter.
He was brought to the T. Russell Reitz Animal Shelter and was originally not allowed to be adopted again due to a city policy regarding animals that have a tendency to attack or cause injury.
However, after an outpour of public pressure commissioners changed their mind.
“We appreciate the community’s support during this decision period while selecting the best placement for Buck,” said Manhattan City Manager Ron Fehr.
According to the Manhattan City Manager’s Office, the rescue where Buck has been taken wishes to remain anonymous.
The decision to allow Buck to be adopted again comes as a relief to many who followed his story and rooted for his chance at a new beginning.
The breed-specific animal shelter is equipped to provide Buck with the specialized care and attention he needs to thrive in his new environment.
Residents are hopeful that Buck will find happiness and a loving family in his new home.
Police are continuing their search for two out of the three suspects involved in the armed robbery of a McDonald’s located off 152-Hwy and I-35.
The incident occurred late last night when three individuals entered the fast-food restaurant brandishing weapons and demanding cash from the employees.
Despite the swift response from local law enforcement, only one suspect was apprehended at the scene, leaving the hunt ongoing for the remaining two perpetrators.
Authorities have been reviewing surveillance footage and interviewing witnesses to gather more information about the suspects' identities and possible whereabouts.
The search has extended to nearby areas as police work tirelessly to track down the individuals responsible for the brazen robbery.
In a recent development, police observed a vehicle approaching the scene from the same direction as the suspects fled.
Upon running the license plate, it was discovered that the driver had outstanding warrants and was linked to the armed robbery.
The individual was promptly taken into custody for further questioning.
Fortunately, no physical injuries were reported among the customers or employees present during the robbery.
Police then noticed a vehicle with one person in it coming from the same direction so they checked the license plate, and it didn't match the vehicle.
Police said the driver had warrants and that he is connected to the armed robbery.
He was taken into custody for questioning.
It's not clear how many customers or employees were at the restaurant at the time.
Police have said no one was physically injured during the robbery.
Prime Minister of Canada Justin Trudeau will visit the University of Chicago on Feb. 7 as part of an event to celebrate the fifth anniversary of the Institute of Politics.

His presence at the Institute of Politics event is expected to draw a large and diverse audience eager to hear his insights on a range of topics.
The event will provide a unique opportunity for students, faculty, and the public to engage with Trudeau directly and gain valuable perspectives on Canadian politics and global affairs.
Trudeau's visit underscores the importance of fostering dialogue and understanding between nations, particularly in today's interconnected world.
Those interested in attending the event are encouraged to arrive early, as seating is expected to fill up quickly.
This rare opportunity to hear from Prime Minister Trudeau in person promises to be an enlightening and engaging experience for all in attendance.
Ogier has advised Serena Data Ventures, Europe’s first Big Data and AI-focused fund, on its investment in CybelAngel International.

An Ogier team, led by the firm’s head of Luxembourg corporate law advice Bertrand Geradin, provided Luxembourg legal advice on the investment to acquire a 17 per cent stake in the company by way of subscription of series A preference shares.
CybelAngel International, a leading digital risk protection platform, has welcomed this strategic investment from Serena Data Ventures.
This partnership is expected to fuel CybelAngel's growth and expansion efforts in the rapidly evolving Big Data and AI sector.
The deal showcases the confidence that Serena Data Ventures has in CybelAngel's innovative technology and market potential.
By securing this investment, CybelAngel is well-positioned to enhance its capabilities, strengthen its market presence, and drive further innovation in digital risk protection solutions.
Both companies are optimistic about the collaboration and the mutual benefits it will bring.
The successful completion of this investment underscores Ogier's expertise in facilitating complex transactions and further solidifies its reputation as a top legal advisor in the business of law.
Sheffield Eagles have secured the signing of George Milton on loan as the team gears up for an important match against Batley Bulldogs.
The 21-year-old forward joins the Eagles in a bid to bolster their squad and make an impact on the pitch.
Milton, who previously played for Hull Kingston Rovers, brings with him a wealth of potential and talent.
Despite limited game time at his previous club, Milton is eager to showcase his skills and contribute to Sheffield's success.
His arrival is timely as the Eagles look to strengthen their lineup and improve their performance in the upcoming fixtures.
With his smart play, intelligence on the field, and strong ball control, Milton is expected to make a positive impact on the team.
His addition to the squad has been welcomed by Eagles coach Mark Aston, who praised Milton's abilities and expressed his excitement about having him on board.
Milton, 21, will go straight into contention for the Eagles’ trip to Batley Bulldogs on Sunday.
Speaking about the signing, Eagles coach Mark Aston said: “It’s great to bring George in, he’s a smart, intelligent footballer with good ball control and skills for a forward.
“He’s a player we’ve looked at now for a couple of seasons and we tried to get him when he came out of the system at Leeds but we were unsuccessful.
“He has struggled slightly for game time at Hull KR but they have a large quality squad so it’s understandable.

“He’s still only 21 so he is still relatively young but needs game time to help his development which we can hopefully provide him.” The Eagles have also confirmed that half-back Remy Marginet landed in the UK yesterday evening and will also go into contention for this weekend’s match against Batley.
Miami (OH) showcased a dominant performance as they defeated Northern Illinois 81-65 in a thrilling college basketball matchup.
The Redhawks asserted their control early in the game and never relinquished their lead, setting the tone for the rest of the contest.
Miami (OH) got off to a strong start with a Sibande 3-pointer, quickly establishing a 33-16 lead with just over five minutes remaining in the first half.
Despite Northern Illinois making a push to narrow the gap to 38-28 by halftime, the Redhawks maintained their composure.
The second half saw Northern Illinois attempt to mount a comeback, closing the deficit to 58-49.
However, Miami (OH) responded with a barrage of 3-pointers, including three consecutive shots from Coleman-Lands, and a powerful dunk from Dalonte Brown.
This offensive surge extended the Redhawks' lead to 71-51 with 6:15 left on the clock, effectively sealing their victory.
Justin Thomas provided a bright spot for the Huskies with 14 points off the bench, but it was not enough to overcome Miami (OH)'s commanding performance.
Northern Illinois has now suffered three consecutive defeats, dropping their record to 10-13 overall and 3-7 in conference play.
The Redhawks opened the game on a Sibande 3-pointer and led all the way, building to a 33-16 advantage with 5:08 left and were up 38-28 at the break.

Northern Illinois closed to 58-49 midway through the second half, but Coleman-Lands replied with three 3s in the span of four possessions and Dalonte Brown included a dunk to help push it to 71-51 with 6:15 left and the RedHawks cruised from there.
Justin Thomas scored 14 points off the bench for the Huskies (10-13, 3-7) who have lost three straight.
The feature starts rolling out today for US users only, and YouTube cautions that there may be bumps in the road to its implementation: "We don't expect it to be perfect," the release said.
Eventually, the company plans to expand this feature.
In the meantime, users can use the "send feedback" option to flag imperfect implementation.
As the landscape between online news and ads becomes more muddled, increasing transparency is an important step to take.
YouTube has announced a new labeling feature for news videos that have received government funding.
This move aims to provide viewers with more context about the sources of news content they are consuming.
By labeling these videos, YouTube hopes to enhance transparency and help users make more informed decisions about the information they are exposed to.
The platform acknowledges the growing importance of understanding the funding sources behind news content in today's media landscape and is taking steps to address this issue.
The labeling of government-funded news videos is part of YouTube's broader efforts to combat misinformation and promote a more transparent news environment.
Get ready to kick up your heels and do-si-do at the upcoming Contra Dance event happening this Saturday at the local community center.
Contra dancing is a lively form of folk dance that is easy to learn and a lot of fun for all ages and skill levels.
Whether you're a seasoned dancer or a complete beginner, everyone is welcome to join in the merriment.
The event will feature live music from a talented folk band, creating a vibrant and energetic atmosphere that will have you moving and grooving all night long.

So grab your friends and family, or come solo and make new friends on the dance floor.
Don't miss this opportunity to experience the joy of Contra dancing in a welcoming and inclusive environment.
Wear comfortable, casual clothes and bring a separate pair of clean, soft-soled shoes for dancing.
Note: Boots or shoes with hard heels are not allowed on the dance floor.

Serbian police successfully thwarted attempts by far-right groups to disrupt the "Mirdita-Dobar Dan" festival in Belgrade.
The festival, aimed at fostering cultural exchange between Serbia and Kosovo, was targeted by members of the Serbian Radical Party led by Vojislav Seselj, a figure convicted of war crimes.
Police cordons were deployed to prevent any disturbances as the festival kicked off, showcasing films, exhibitions, and debates organized by liberal youth groups from both nations.
The event symbolizes efforts to bridge the divide between Serbia and Kosovo, essential for their progress towards EU membership.
Kosovo's declaration of independence in 2008 following the conflict in the late '90s necessitates normalization of relations between the two neighbors.
Despite opposition from far-right elements, the festival stands as a testament to the ongoing journey towards reconciliation and cooperation in the region.
Police cordons blocked several streets in central Belgrade on Wednesday as members of the Serbian Radical Party rallied against the opening of the "Mirdita-Dobar Dan" festival.
Party leader Vojislav Seselj, who was convicted of war crimes by a U.N. court, says the festival is a "shame" for Serbia.
The event is organized by liberal youth groups from Serbia and Kosovo to promote cultural exchange between the former war foes.
It features films, exhibitions and debates.
Serbia and Kosovo must normalize relations to advance toward membership in the European Union.
Kosovo declared independence in 2008 following the 1998-99 conflict.
In yet another blow to the injury-plagued Golden State Warriors, Draymond Green has become the latest player to join the growing list of sidelined stars.
The Warriors, who have already been struggling with a series of injuries to key players, had pinned their hopes on Green to lead the charge in their recent game against the San Antonio Spurs.
However, those hopes were dashed when Green suffered an injury that forced him to exit the game prematurely.
The incident occurred in the second quarter when Green attempted to contest a layup by the Spurs' Danny Green.
In the heat of the moment, Danny Green's knee made contact with Draymond Green's midsection, leaving the Warriors' forward visibly in pain.
The unfortunate injury adds to the mounting woes of the Warriors, who have been without several key players due to various ailments.
With Green now added to the injury report, the Warriors find themselves in an even more precarious position.
That doesn’t even include the six other players that joined them on Monday night’s injury report.
With all of the names sidelined, at least the Warriors could go into San Antonio on Monday knowing that they had Draymond Green to lead the charge.
Well, that was the case right up until Green suffered an injury that ended up causing him to leave the game early.
Green tried to contest a Danny Green layup in the second quarter of the game and took a shot to the midsection.
The Spurs’ Green appeared to lift his knee up, which caught the Warriors’ Green and put him in some obvious pain.

The prison inmate who murdered two police officers and a bystander in Belgium while on a two-day prison furlough was a “soldier of [ISIS’s] caliphate,” the terror group claimed on Wednesday.
ISIS’s Aamaq news agency said Benjamin Herman’s attack in Liège was an answer to its calls asking followers to target countries fighting against them.
The incident has raised concerns about the monitoring of individuals with extremist tendencies.
Belgian authorities are facing scrutiny for allowing Herman, who had shown signs of radicalization, to be released temporarily.
The attack has reignited fears of terrorism in Belgium and sparked discussions on improving counterterrorism measures.
In a move towards increasing safety standards for infant carriers, new warning labels are now required on sling baby carriers due to the alarming number of incidents reported.
According to recent data, slings have been linked to 17 deaths since 2003, prompting concerns about the safety of these popular baby-carrying devices.
Parents and caregivers are urged to be cautious when using sling carriers and to closely follow the updated safety guidelines.
The warning labels will provide essential information on proper usage, including how to position the baby securely and ensure proper breathing.
It is crucial for caregivers to be aware of the potential risks associated with sling carriers, such as falls and suffocation, and take necessary precautions to prevent accidents.
The Consumer Product Safety Commission received a total of 159 incident reports between 2003 and 2016, highlighting the need for increased awareness and vigilance when using sling carriers.
These incidents included 17 tragic deaths and 67 injuries related to falls and suffocation, underscoring the importance of adhering to safety guidelines and regulations.
Parents and caregivers reported 159 incidents to the Consumer Product Safety Commission between 2003 and 2016, including 17 deaths and 67 injuries related to falls and suffocation.
To report a dangerous product or a product-related injury go online to www.SaferProducts.gov or call CPSC's Hotline at 800-638-2772 or teletypewriter at 301-595-7054 for the hearing impaired.
WICHITA, Kan. (AP) — The husband of a woman killed in a Dillons parking lot is suing the grocery store for negligence.
The tragic incident occurred last week when Susan Thompson, a 42-year-old mother of two, was struck by a vehicle in the store's parking lot.
The family's attorney, John Michaels, stated that the accident could have been prevented if the store had taken proper safety measures.
According to eyewitnesses, the driver of the vehicle was speeding and failed to yield to pedestrians in the parking lot.
The lawsuit alleges that Dillons failed to provide adequate security and signage to ensure the safety of its customers.
The family is seeking compensation for the loss of their loved one and to hold the store accountable for their negligence.
Dillons has expressed condolences to the Thompson family but has not yet issued a formal statement regarding the lawsuit.
The tragic incident has raised concerns about pedestrian safety in parking lots and has prompted calls for increased safety measures to prevent similar accidents in the future.

(WFLA) — Apps have completely changed the way we work, live and play and today they are getting some recognition.
It’s National App Day!
Apps, which is short for “software application”, are the computer programs designed to run on your phone, tablet or watch.
Today there are over two million apps on both the Apple and Android platforms, and thousands more are introduced daily.
The latest is by main social media company Instagram, who plans to unveil a new app, called Direct, to enhance your one-on-one messaging experience.
The front facing camera will immediately appear on your screen when you open the Direct app, making it similar to rival app Snapchat.
Instagram's move to launch Direct is seen as a strategic step to surpass Snapchat in the messaging app arena.
The new app is expected to offer a seamless and engaging messaging experience, focusing on visual communication through photos and videos.

With the increasing popularity of messaging apps for personal and professional communication, Instagram aims to capture a larger share of the market by catering to users who prefer visual interactions.
The Direct app is anticipated to feature various filters, stickers, and editing tools to enhance the messaging experience and encourage creativity among users.
This development showcases Instagram's commitment to innovation and staying competitive in the ever-evolving social media landscape.
WASHINGTON - Thousands of children are heading to the White House for its biggest social event of the year: the annual Easter Egg Roll.
This year's event is special as it marks President Trump's first time hosting the traditional celebration dating back to 1878.
The Easter Egg Roll features various activities such as egg rolling, egg decorating, and the traditional egg hunt on the White House lawn.
President Trump and First Lady Melania Trump are set to welcome families from all over the country to join in the festivities.
The event will also include storytelling, musical performances, and the chance to meet the Easter Bunny.
This longstanding tradition brings together children and parents for a day of joy and celebration at the historic White House.
The first lady tweeted over the weekend that she’s looking forward to hosting the Easter Egg Roll.
The event was first held in 1878.
Lufthansa, the German airline giant, has successfully reached a wage agreement with its pilots, putting an end to a long-standing dispute that has plagued the company for years.
The agreement, which was finalized after months of negotiations, will see pilots receiving improved pay and benefits.
This development comes as a relief to both Lufthansa and its customers, as the ongoing conflicts have resulted in numerous flight disruptions and financial losses for the airline.
The new agreement will be in place until the end of 2019.
The Cockpit union had been staging strikes sporadically since April 2014, costing Lufthansa multiple millions, before the two sides agreed to arbitration on December.
Cockpit, which had no immediate comment, had sought raises of 3.66 percent a year going back 5 years.
Man Utd start 2017/18 campaign against West Ham Manchester United start their 2017/18 Premier League season with a home game against West Ham United at Old Trafford on August 12.
The highly anticipated match will mark the beginning of what promises to be an exciting season for both teams.
With new signings and high expectations, Manchester United will be looking to make a strong start and set the tone for their campaign.

The clash between these two teams is sure to be a thrilling encounter, with both sides boasting talented players and a strong desire to succeed.
Fans can expect an intense and competitive match as Manchester United and West Ham battle it out on the pitch in their season opener.
VIRGINIA BEACH, Va. — Televangelist Pat Robertson is recovering after suffering an embolic stroke.
The 91-year-old founder of the Christian Broadcasting Network was admitted to a hospital in Virginia Beach after experiencing symptoms consistent with a stroke.
Robertson's family released a statement expressing gratitude for the outpouring of support and prayers from well-wishers around the world.
Medical experts have indicated that Robertson's condition is stable, and he is responding well to treatment.
Robertson is known for his influential role in the religious broadcasting industry and his conservative political views.
He has been a prominent figure in American evangelicalism for decades, reaching millions of viewers through his television programs.
Fans and supporters are sending their thoughts and prayers for Robertson's swift and full recovery as he continues to receive medical care and rehabilitation.

In a bid to combat the rising trend of e-cigarette use among teenagers, a US agency has intensified its efforts to crack down on Juul, a popular e-cigarette brand known for its sleek design and high nicotine content.

The Food and Drug Administration (FDA) has launched an initiative to investigate Juul Labs, the company behind the controversial product, in an attempt to address the growing concerns over underage vaping.
Recent studies have shown a significant increase in the use of e-cigarettes among middle and high school students, with Juul being the most commonly used brand.
The agency's crackdown comes amidst mounting pressure to address the alarming rates of youth e-cigarette use, which many health experts fear could lead to a new generation of nicotine addiction.
Thanks in part to its resemblance to a small computer flash drive, Juul has become popular with some teenagers as a discrete way to vape at school and in public.
As part of the FDA initiative, regulators are asking Juul Labs to turn over documents about the design and marketing of its devices.
The San Francisco-based company says it monitors retailers to ensure they are following the law.
GARFIELD, N.J. (CBSNewYork) – A boy riding his bicycle was struck and killed by a truck in Bergen County.
It happened around 2 p.m. Tuesday near Lanza and Pleasant avenues in Garfield.
Investigators said the boy was between nine and 11 years old.
The tragic incident shook the local community, with residents expressing shock and sadness over the loss of a young life.
Emergency services rushed to the scene, but despite their efforts, the boy succumbed to his injuries.
Witnesses reported a heavy police presence in the area following the accident as authorities worked to piece together what led to the collision.
There’s a storage facility down there and a lot of factories that are down there, and the trucks come through here this way to get down there I guess,” one person said.
The driver remained on the scene before being brought to police headquarters for questioning.
WASHINGTON — Kellan Grady scored 23 points on 10 of 16 shooting, leading four into double-figure scoring and Davidson walloped George Washington 87-58 on Saturday, winning seven of its last nine.
Grady and Jon Axel Gudmundsson each pulled down eight rebounds as the Wildcats controlled the boards, 38-26.
Davidson shot 49 per cent from the floor (30 of 61), including 13 of 29 from behind the 3-point arc.
Peyton Aldridge and KiShawn Pritchett each made a trio of 3-pointers and scored 13 and 11 points, respectively.
Oskar Michelsen added 15 points, making 8 of 9 at the line.

Davidson (12-9, 7-3 Atlantic 10 Conference) had a five-game win streak interrupted by consecutive losses to Dayton and Richmond but, winning its last two, is alone in second place after Richmond was upset by George Mason.
The Wildcats were dominant from the opening tip, establishing a comfortable lead early in the game and never looking back.
Grady's scoring outburst, combined with a balanced offensive attack and stout defense, proved too much for George Washington to handle.
Davidson's sharpshooting from beyond the arc kept the pressure on throughout the contest, with multiple players contributing to the team's success.
Coach Bob McKillop praised his team's effort and execution, emphasizing the importance of maintaining consistency as they push towards the end of the season.
With key victories in recent games, Davidson has positioned itself as a strong contender in the Atlantic 10 Conference, poised to make a run towards the postseason.
Authorities have issued an Endangered Child Alert for two young children from Middle Tennessee.
Lillyanna and Ryder Benke, aged 5 and 2 respectively, were last seen with their non-custodial parents, Cory and Courtney Benke.
The parents are believed to have taken the children in violation of a court order.
Lillyanna is described as a white female with blonde hair and hazel eyes.
She stands 3 feet tall and weighs 50 pounds.
Ryder is a white male with brown hair and hazel eyes.
He is three feet tall and weighs 30 pounds.
The Benekes may be traveling in a green Buick Sedan or white van with South Carolina plates and may be in the area of Mt.
Juliet or Hermitage.
Anyone with information is urged to call the Cheatham County sheriff at (615) 792-2098 or TBI at 1-800-TBI-FIND.
