Democrats on the House Oversight and Reform Committee are pushing for a subpoena to obtain crucial information related to the 2020 Census.
The Department of Justice has been withholding documents requested by the committee, sparking concerns among Democrats about transparency and compliance with oversight efforts.
The Democrats argue that the withheld information is essential for understanding the decision-making process behind the Census and ensuring its accuracy.
The department has briefed lawmakers on the decision and promised some records, but the Democrats say the response is inadequate.
The Democrats are asking Rep. Trey Gowdy of South Carolina, the committee's chairman, to issue a subpoena or bring the matter before the entire committee if he declines to issue it himself.
They say the information is needed before a May committee hearing.

Upton, known for her striking beauty and confident presence, continues to captivate audiences with her stunning photoshoots and undeniable charisma.
Despite fierce competition, Upton's timeless appeal and undeniable charm have solidified her as a true icon in the world of modeling.

SKOPJE, Macedonia (AP) — A U.N. negotiator is due in Macedonia for talks with the country's leadership, in a revived effort to settle a peculiar but acrimonious dispute with neighboring Greece over Macedonia's name.
The long-standing disagreement stems from Greece's concerns that the name "Macedonia" implies territorial ambitions over its own province of Macedonia.
This has led to a diplomatic deadlock, stalling Macedonia's aspirations to join NATO.
The upcoming negotiations are seen as a crucial opportunity to break the impasse and find a mutually acceptable solution.
The dispute has frozen Macedonia's NATO accession hopes, as Greece, an alliance member, refuses to endorse its bid until a solution is found.
Greece says the country's name implies claims on its own adjoining province of Macedonia.
Skopje denies that.

The search for Pierre Agnes, the CEO of Quiksilver surfwear, has come to a solemn end as authorities suspended operations after an extensive search effort.
Agnes went missing after his boat, the Mascaret III, was found empty and washed ashore on an Atlantic beach near his hometown of Capbreton, France.
The search, which began early Tuesday following the discovery of the abandoned vessel, involved two Jet Skis and a coast guard vessel scouring the waters off the coast of Hossegor.
Despite the dedicated efforts of the search teams, the operation was called off at 2:35 p.m. local time on Wednesday, well past the anticipated survival time for someone in the water.
As the search was halted, local police took over patrol duties along the coastline while continuing to investigate any potential clues that may have washed up on the beaches.
Pierre Agnes was a prominent figure in the surfing industry, having served as the head of Quiksilver’s European headquarters before assuming the role of CEO for the entire company in 2015.
The brand, originally founded in Australia, is now part of Boardriders, an apparel group based in California.
The news of Agnes' disappearance has deeply impacted the surfing community, with Quiksilver expressing profound sorrow over the situation.

TESTEMALE / QUIKSILVER / HANDOUT / EPA Authorities were alerted early Tuesday when his empty boat Mascaret III washed ashore on an Atlantic beach at Hossegor, near his hometown of Capbreton, which is about 20 miles north of Biarritz.
The search was suspended at 2:35 p.m. local time (8:35 a.m.
ET) Wednesday — well beyond the theoretical survival time for someone in the water.
Two Jet Skis and a coast guard vessel involved in the hunt returned to port.
Local police will instead patrol the coastline.

Lt. Col. Christophe Triollet said teams were looking for “clues which could have washed up along the beaches.” He added: “Other than that, we also continue our investigation to try to understand … the circumstances of his disappearance ... and to reconstruct the timeline and the facts to better understand the situation."

In a tragic turn of events during the San Diego marathon, a wheelchair athlete was severely injured, leading to the end of his career.
The athlete, whose name has been withheld, was involved in a crash during the race that left him with critical injuries.
The incident resulted in a broken collarbone, multiple fractured ribs, a torn rotator cuff, and other significant injuries, ultimately putting an end to his days as an elite racer.
Following the accident, the athlete pursued legal action and has now been awarded a substantial $4 million settlement.
The compensation aims to cover medical expenses, ongoing rehabilitation, and loss of income due to the career-ending injuries sustained during the marathon.
Despite the settlement, the emotional and physical toll on the athlete is immeasurable.
The crash broke his collarbone and several ribs, tore his rotator cuff and ended his career as an elite racer.
A representative for the race organizer, Competitor Group Inc., told the Union-Tribune that the company doesn't comment on ongoing litigation.

Traffic may be affected by bridge work on Kell Freeway next week.
Beginning Monday, February 5, contractors will begin work on the bridges at Taft, Harrison and Brook Streets starting on the Eastbound side of Kell Freeway/US 82.
Once work is completed, they will move to the Westbound side and continue work.
According to TX-DOT, crews will begin work on the inside lanes.
Once those lanes are finished, they will close down the outside lanes and work on those.
The construction is expected to cause delays and lane closures, impacting traffic flow in the area.
Drivers are advised to plan for potential delays and consider alternate routes if possible.
The project is part of ongoing efforts to improve the infrastructure and safety of the bridges along Kell Freeway.
Stay tuned for updates on any changes or developments regarding the bridge work.

German Foreign Minister Sigmar Gabriel has expressed his support for the concept of a "United States of Europe," emphasizing that such a union would not undermine the importance of individual nations within the European framework.
Gabriel's remarks come in response to recent statements made by Martin Schulz, leader of the centre-left Social Democrats, regarding the establishment of a federal Europe by 2025.

Martin Schulz, who heads the centre-left Social Democrats, told a party meeting last week that countries refusing to sign a treaty establishing a federal “United States of Europe” by 2025 should leave the European Union.

Foreign Minister Sigmar Gabriel told German public broadcaster ARD on Sunday that the idea was “no contradiction to the Europe of fatherlands or motherlands.” Gabriel says European nations can’t defend their interests alone on the global stage and “unless we stand together, our children won’t have a voice in the world.” Talks between the Social Democrats and Chancellor Angela Merkel’s conservative Union on extending their “grand coalition” for a new government resume Monday.
He highlighted the necessity of a united front to ensure that future generations have a meaningful role in shaping the world's direction.
Talks between the Social Democrats and Chancellor Angela Merkel’s conservative Union on extending their “grand coalition” for a new government are set to resume Monday.
The ongoing discussions reflect the complex political landscape in Germany and the broader debates surrounding the future of European integration.
Eritrean President Isaias Afwerki has strongly criticized Israel's plan to deport Eritrean migrants, slamming it as unjust and inhumane.
Afwerki condemned the Israeli government for its decision to forcibly remove thousands of Eritrean asylum-seekers, many of whom fled their homeland in search of safety and a better life.
The Eritrean leader expressed his disappointment in Israel's lack of compassion towards the migrants, highlighting the difficult circumstances that forced them to leave Eritrea.
He emphasized that many Eritreans faced severe human rights abuses back home, including forced conscription and harsh living conditions.
Many leaving the east African nation claim they fled a restrictive Eritrean regime where men are often forced into a military service with slavery-like conditions.
Afwerki claims the Eritrean migrants were enticed abroad to organize an armed opposition but that the "subversive schemes" failed and the migrants have become a burden.
He says Eritrea has offered to register all its migrants but Israeli authorities refused.
Several Wisconsin property owners have decided to appeal a recent ruling in their lawsuit against Foxconn Technology Group.
The lawsuit stems from a dispute over the company's development in the area, which the property owners claim has caused property values to plummet.
The property owners argue that Foxconn's failure to follow through on its promises of building a massive factory has negatively impacted the surrounding properties.
They believe that the initial excitement and hope for economic growth in the region have now turned into disappointment and financial losses.
The appeal comes after a judge dismissed the property owners' initial lawsuit, stating that they failed to prove that Foxconn's actions directly caused the decline in property values.
The property owners are determined to fight this decision and seek justice for what they perceive as a breach of trust and economic harm.
Foxconn, on the other hand, maintains its position that it has not caused any harm to the property values and remains committed to its plans for development in the area.

General News of Monday, 2 January 2017 Source: 3news.com File photo The Sunyani Technical University (STU) has admitted 1,532 fresh students to pursue various programmes with a call to them to be disciplined and go the extra mile to achieve set goals.

The newly enrolled students were made up of 972 males and 560 females and would be pursuing degree and diploma programmes.
In his address to the new students during the matriculation ceremony, Professor Adinkrah-Appiah emphasized the importance of hard work and dedication in their academic pursuits.
He urged the students to take advantage of the opportunities available at STU to broaden their knowledge and skills, preparing them for the competitive job market.
The Vice-Chancellor also highlighted the university's commitment to providing quality education and support services to ensure the success of all students.
He encouraged the fresh students to actively participate in extracurricular activities, clubs, and societies to enhance their overall university experience.
The matriculation ceremony was attended by faculty members, staff, and senior university officials who welcomed the new students to the STU community.
The event concluded with a pledge ceremony where the students vowed to uphold the values of the institution and strive for excellence in their academic endeavors.
New York Governor Andrew Cuomo has finally signaled a 'surrender' in the ongoing highway-sign fight with the federal government.

For years, the state has been at odds with the Federal Highway Administration (FHA) over the controversial blue highway signs promoting New York tourism assets, which the FHA deemed distracting and noncompliant with federal regulations.
Indeed, the gov even kept adding more signs in what amounted to a dare to the feds to do something about it.
Dare accepted: The FHA has now given New York until Sept. 30 to choose among three options: bring the signs into compliance, remove them altogether or face a $14 million cut in federal road funding.
This ultimatum has forced Governor Cuomo to acknowledge the seriousness of the situation and the potential consequences of non-compliance.
The standoff between the state and federal authorities has been a long and contentious one, with both sides refusing to back down.
However, with the threat of a significant loss in federal funding looming, it appears that Governor Cuomo has no choice but to acquiesce to the demands of the FHA.

As the deadline approaches, all eyes will be on New York state officials to see how they navigate this challenging situation and whether they will ultimately comply with federal regulations or risk the financial consequences of defiance.

Amidst the controversy, the college stands by its decision, emphasizing the importance of providing students with unique opportunities for exposure and experience.
The upcoming performance is expected to draw significant attention and further discussions on the intersection of politics and the arts.

Researchers have declared the Miramichi River in New Brunswick as the focal point for studying the concerning decline in salmon population.

The University of New Brunswick has allocated $1.3 million towards the newly established Atlantic Salmon Research chair and four associated research projects aimed at accurately assessing salmon numbers and comprehending the impact of climate change on their population dynamics.
Tommi Linnansaari, the appointed Atlantic Salmon Research chair, emphasizes the urgency of taking immediate action to comprehend the ongoing situation and initiate measures to alleviate the losses.
The Miramichi River has become a critical research site to aid declining salmon stocks globally, according to Fred Whoriskey from the Canadian Rivers Institute.

One key project involves an innovative approach to enhance juvenile salmon numbers in the river system by introducing captive-reared adults into the natural habitat for spawning on an unprecedented scale.
Whoriskey highlights that the rapid pace of global warming outstrips the salmon's adaptive capabilities, underscoring the need for swift intervention.
Tommi Linnansaari, the new Atlantic Salmon Research chair at the University of New Brunswick, says immediate action is needed to understand what's happening — and to begin to mitigate the losses.
UNB has received $1.3 million in funding for the chair and four research projects to get accurate salmon population numbers and to understand how those numbers are affected by climate change.
Fred Whoriskey of the Canadian Rivers Institute says the Miramichi is now ground zero for research to help declining stocks around the world.

He says one project will try to boost the number of juveniles in the river system by introducing adults that have been reared in captivity and released into the river system to spawn, and doing this on a scale that's not been done before.
Whoriskey says global warming is happening at a rate faster than the salmon can adapt.
The Canadian Press
In a shocking incident at a popular tourist spot in Thailand, a French tourist was bitten by a crocodile while attempting to take a selfie near a crocodile pool.
The incident occurred at a wildlife park in the Khao Yai National Park, known for its diverse wildlife and natural beauty.
The tourist, whose identity has not been disclosed, was bitten on the leg by the crocodile when she ventured too close to the animal in an attempt to take a selfie.
Local media posted pictures of park rangers dressed in camouflage carrying the victim strapped to a stretcher, a thick bandage around her knee.
Another photo showed a ranger pointing to a pool of blood close to a sign saying in Thai and English "Danger Crocodile No Swimming".
The incident serves as a stark reminder of the dangers of approaching wild animals for the sake of a photo opportunity.
Authorities have warned visitors to follow safety guidelines and maintain a safe distance from wildlife while visiting the park.
The French tourist is currently receiving medical treatment, and her condition is reported to be stable.

Google Chrome's latest update now allows for more password-free sign-ins, making it easier and more secure for users to access their accounts.
By leveraging biometric authentication methods such as fingerprint scanners and facial recognition technology, users can now log in to websites without the hassle of remembering complex passwords.
Moreover, Chrome's improved security measures go beyond just biometrics.
If you're nervous about Spectre-style attacks, there's also wider use of site isolation to reduce the chances of a page swiping data from your other browser tabs.
All told, this may be one of the more quietly significant Chrome updates in recent months.
You'll have to wait for sites to support all the new features, but they could change how you interact with the web.
North Carolina based producer Hanz (aka Brandon Juhans) has shared “King Speed.” You can hear the song above.

Taken from his latest EP 'Plasty I', the track immerses listeners in a sonic landscape that is both experimental and captivating.
With intricate layers of sound woven together, Hanz creates a mesmerizing atmosphere that evolves throughout the song.
The use of the cut-up technique adds a sense of unpredictability to "King Speed," keeping listeners on their toes as they navigate through the intricate layers of beats and melodies.
Hanz's skillful manipulation of samples and textures demonstrates his keen ear for detail and his ability to push the boundaries of traditional hip-hop production.
As the song unfolds, it reveals a depth and complexity that invites repeated listens, with new details emerging with each playthrough.
"King Speed" is a testament to Hanz's creative vision and his willingness to experiment with different sounds and techniques.
It is a track that rewards attentive listeners and showcases the innovative spirit that defines Hanz's music.

Photo LONDON — In the latest in a series of gestures toward modernization that would once have seemed improbable, Saudi Arabia announced on Monday that it would allow commercial movie theaters to open for the first time in more than 35 years.

The moves to allow access by early 2018, part of a broad campaign by the crown prince, Mohammed bin Salman, to transform Saudi society, followed measures like giving women the right to drive and to attend soccer games, and allowing concerts and other forms of public entertainment.
The decision to allow movie theaters to operate is seen as a significant step in the country's efforts to diversify its economy and reduce its dependence on oil revenue.
The move is also expected to create new job opportunities and stimulate economic growth in the entertainment industry.
However, the announcement comes amidst a crackdown on dissent in the kingdom, with dozens of activists, clerics, and intellectuals being detained in recent months.
Critics say the detentions were intended to neutralize potential challengers.

The announcement on Monday is in keeping with a promise by the 32-year-old crown prince to return Saudi Arabia to a more tolerant version of Islam than the radical interpretation of the Muslim faith it adopted in 1979.
Advertisement Continue reading the main story In a statement, the Culture and Information Ministry said the government would begin within 90 days licensing movie houses to open.
It did not indicate what kind of movies the government might allow to be screened, but made clear that films would be governed by Islamic law.
Canadian e-commerce giant Shopify announced today that its payments platform, Shopify Payments, now allows payments made using Google Pay.
According to its website, Shopify is used by more than 600,000 businesses worldwide.
Among those businesses are familiar names like Penny Arcade and PooPouri.
It's worth noting that while 600,000 is certainly an impressive figure, not all payments made to Shopify merchants use Shopify Payments.
This new integration with Google Pay is expected to streamline the checkout process for customers, offering them a convenient and secure payment option.
With the increasing popularity of mobile payments, Shopify's decision to support Google Pay reflects its commitment to providing a seamless shopping experience for both merchants and customers.
The move is likely to attract more businesses to the platform and enhance the overall e-commerce ecosystem.
Shopify continues to innovate and adapt to the evolving needs of online businesses, solidifying its position as a leading e-commerce solution provider.
In an electrifying game at Knights Hall, Bellarmine University's men's basketball team extended their impressive home winning streak to 38 games.
The Knights displayed their dominance on the court, defeating their opponents with a final score of 72-60.
Senior forward Jake Smith led the charge for Bellarmine with a remarkable performance, scoring a game-high 20 points and grabbing 8 rebounds.

The team's solid defense and efficient offense were on full display throughout the game, showcasing their depth and skill.

Despite improvements in the labor market, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) reports that these gains have yet to translate into significant wage increases.
The OECD's recent analysis indicates that while employment rates have been rising in many countries, wage growth has remained relatively subdued.
This phenomenon has been particularly evident in advanced economies, where wage growth has not kept pace with the overall economic recovery.

The OECD suggests that this disconnect between labor-market improvements and wage gains could be attributed to various factors, including technological advancements, globalization, and changes in labor market structures.
Additionally, the organization points out that wage stagnation may also be influenced by factors such as job polarization and the prevalence of non-standard forms of employment.
To address these challenges, the OECD emphasizes the need for comprehensive structural reforms that go beyond short-term cyclical improvements.
According to the OECD, such reforms are essential to sustain stronger economic growth, create more high-quality jobs, enhance opportunities for workers, and promote greater social inclusion.
The organization highlights the importance of ongoing reforms in countries like Greece, Italy, France, Japan, India, and Argentina.
However, the OECD cautions that the overall pace of reforms has been relatively slow in recent years, underscoring the need for more concerted efforts to drive meaningful change.

Comprehensive structural reforms are needed to sustain stronger growth beyond the cyclical upswing, create more and better paying jobs, improve opportunities and strengthen inclusion.” Credit: OECD While the Paris-based institution highlighted reforms in Greece, Italy, France, Japan, India and Argentina over the past year, it noted that overall “the pace of reforms has remained similar to the relatively slow pace observed in the last two years and below the one observed in the direct aftermath of the crisis.”
Have your say Grantham’s Alive church staged its first ever lunch club in brand new facilitiues after 18 months of fundraising.

Researchers have announced a breakthrough in the development of a birth control pill for men, suggesting that it may soon become a reality.
The new pill, known as dimethandrolone undecanoate (DMAU), has shown promising results in a recent study conducted on a group of men.
The study revealed that DMAU effectively suppressed hormones responsible for sperm production without causing serious side effects.
Dr. Stephanie Page, a professor of medicine at the University of Washington, stated that the pill was well-tolerated by the participants and did not lead to significant reductions in their libido.

"Despite having low levels of circulating testosterone, very few subjects reported symptoms consistent with testosterone deficiency or excess," Page said.Researchers say longer term studies are currently underway to confirm that the pill can block sperm production so a man cannot get his partner pregnant.The study included 100 healthy men, ages 18 to 50 years old, and took place at the University of Washington Medical Center and at Harbor-UCLA Medical Center in Torrance, California.DMAU is being developed by the National Institutes of Health, Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Institute of Child Health and Human Development, which funded this study.

CASTINE — Historian Henry Cooke will offer a public lecture titled “Soldiers, Sailors and Loyal Citizens All: The Dress of Castine During the British Occupation, 1779-1783” on Friday, Aug. 18, from 7-9 p.m. at the Wilson Museum’s Hutchins Education Center.

Cooke, a renowned expert in colonial history, will delve into the intricate details of the clothing worn by various groups in Castine during the British occupation, shedding light on the social and cultural significance of their attire.
Attendees can expect a fascinating exploration of how fashion was used as a form of expression and identity during this tumultuous period in Castine's history.

Through a combination of historical accounts, visual aids, and artifact displays, Cooke will bring to life the vibrant and diverse clothing styles that characterized the town during the British occupation.
The lecture is free and open to the public.
For more information, call 326-9247 or email [email protected]

South Korean prosecutors said Monday that the daughter of the confidante of impeached President Park Geun-hye has been arrested in Denmark, and that authorities were working to get her returned home in connection with a huge corruption scandal.
The arrest of Chung Yoo-ra, the 20-year-old daughter of Choi Soon-sil, comes after South Korea's special prosecutors sought the assistance of Interpol to locate and apprehend her.
Chung is a key figure in the scandal that led to Park's impeachment and removal from office in 2017.
Chung's arrest in Denmark follows an international manhunt that lasted for months.
She had been living in Denmark since shortly after the scandal broke in South Korea.
South Korean authorities are now seeking her extradition to face charges related to her involvement in the corruption scandal that rocked the nation.
South Korea had asked Interpol to search for Chung because she didn’t return home to answer questions about the scandal.

South Korea’s Yonhap News Agency reported that Chung, a former member of the national equestrian team, allegedly took advantage of her mother’s relationship with Park to get unwarranted favors from Seoul’s Ewha Womans University.

ALBANY, N.Y. (AP) — A report from critics of Airbnb says the vacation rental website is driving up rental prices and reducing housing availability in New York City.
The analysis published Monday comes from a researcher at McGill University in Montreal and was commissioned by the Hotel Trades Council, a union of hotel workers.
Several local neighborhood organizations were co-sponsors.

The report highlights that the increasing popularity of Airbnb has led to a decrease in long-term rental units available to residents, as landlords find it more profitable to list their properties as short-term rentals.
This trend exacerbates the housing crisis in New York City, making it more difficult for residents to find affordable housing options.
Critics argue that Airbnb's impact on the housing market needs to be regulated to ensure that housing remains accessible and affordable for New Yorkers.
The report calls for stricter regulations and enforcement to address the growing concerns raised by the proliferation of short-term rentals in the city.

The September jobs report from the Labor Department comes out today, and hurricanes Harvey and Irma are likely to show up in the numbers in different ways.
In Texas and Florida, where the hurricanes did significant damage, employees couldn’t get to work, workplaces shut down, job interviews got cancelled.
As a result, economists expect the number of jobs created in September to be lower than usual, reflecting the temporary halt in economic activity caused by the storms.
However, the impact on the unemployment rate is less clear.
While some people may have been temporarily laid off due to the hurricanes, others could have been hired for rebuilding efforts, potentially offsetting the job losses.
This uncertainty makes it challenging to predict how the unemployment rate will be affected by the hurricanes.
But wages could look good and go up a bit because lower-wage hourly workers usually don’t get paid if they don’t work, while higher-income salaried workers do.
So, barring unforeseen events, the October numbers may give a better picture of how the whole economy’s doing.

BAGHDAD (AP) — An influential Iraqi Shiite cleric is urging his fighters to hand state-issued weapons back to the government following the declaration of victory against the Islamic State group.
Muqtada al-Sadr made the call during a televised speech on Monday, stating that the weapons should be surrendered to the authorities now that the immediate threat posed by IS has been eliminated.
Al-Sadr emphasized the importance of maintaining peace and stability in the country and called on his followers to support the government in its efforts to rebuild and secure the nation.
This move is seen as a significant step towards demilitarizing various factions that took up arms during the fight against IS.
Al-Sadr's speech was broadcast on Iraq television on Monday.
Prime Minister Haider al-Abadi declared victory over IS in a national address on Saturday evening, after Iraqi forces cleared the last IS strongholds from Iraq's western desert.
Al-Sadr's fighters took up arms against IS in the summer of 2014 after the fall of Mosul and are officially part of the government-sanctioned Popular Mobilization Forces.

HOCHFILZEN, Austria (AP) — Laura Dahlmeier won the women's individual competition Wednesday for her third gold medal and fourth overall at the biathlon world championships.

Both Dahlmeier and Koukalova missed one target in their first shooting stage but shot cleanly afterward.
Alexia Runggaldier of Italy hit all 20 targets and finished 1:45.6 behind to win bronze.
Dahlmeier showcased her exceptional skills and mental resilience, securing her dominance in the biathlon world.
Her precise shooting and impressive speed on the course allowed her to outperform her rivals and claim another well-deserved victory.
The intense competition and close finishes added to the excitement of the event, highlighting the remarkable talent and determination of these world-class athletes.
Dahlmeier's outstanding performance continues to solidify her reputation as one of the top biathletes in the world.

Sputnik Shook the Nation 60 Years Ago.
The idea of artificial satellites had been around for a while.
Indeed, sci-fi author Arthur C. Clarke had written up a prescient scheme predicting the use of geosynchronous satellites for communications as early as 1945.
The shock, of course, was because Sputnik was launched at the height of the Cold War.

Both the Americans and the Soviets had scooped up many of the German rocket scientists after World War II, and while most of their subsequent efforts were motivated by military programs, some rocket experts (including Wernher von Braun) anticipated a wondrous future of both robotic science and human spaceflight.
As von Braun famously wrote, he “aimed for the stars.”
It was the first artificial satellite to orbit the Earth, triggering a space race between the two superpowers.
The event had a profound impact on the world, sparking fear and fascination in equal measure.
Today, as tensions rise once again between nations and advancements in space technology continue to accelerate, the possibility of history repeating itself looms large.
With new players entering the arena, such as private space companies and emerging spacefaring nations, the potential for another seismic event akin to Sputnik is very real.
The question remains: Will we witness another Sputnik moment that shakes the world and propels us further into the cosmos?
USA Hockey has announced that they will not be naming a replacement for the late General Manager Jim Johannson.
Johannson, who passed away on January 21st, was set to lead the U.S. Olympic men's hockey team in the upcoming Winter Games in South Korea.
With Johannson's sudden and tragic death, the organization has decided to honor his work by not appointing a new general manager.

Executive director Pat Kelleher stated that Johannson had already selected the coaching staff and 25-man roster for the team, which will be the first U.S. Olympic men's hockey team without NHL players since 1994.
Kelleher emphasized that there will only be one general manager for the team, and director of player personnel Ben Smith will take on Johannson's duties during the Winter Games.
Johannson had been a prominent figure in USA Hockey for 17 years, overseeing various world junior and world championship teams during his tenure.
His sudden passing has left a void in the organization, but his legacy and contributions will undoubtedly be remembered and honored during the upcoming Winter Games in South Korea.

Executive director Pat Kelleher says "there will only be one general manager" of the team after Johannson selected the coaching staff and 25-man roster for the first U.S. Olympic men's hockey team without NHL players since 1994.
Kelleher says director of player personnel Ben Smith will fill Johannson's duties in South Korea.
Johannson was in the midst of his most high-profile role in his 17 years at USA Hockey when he died Jan. 21, less than three weeks after the roster was announced.
He has been responsible for many world junior and world championship teams in the past several years.

In a unique and unexpected twist, the Pennsylvania Ballet and Boston Ballet recently faced off in a friendly competition that had nothing to do with pirouettes or pliés.
As the Super Bowl fever swept the nation, these two renowned ballet companies decided to put their own spin on the big game.

With the Philadelphia Eagles representing Pennsylvania and the New England Patriots representing Boston, the dancers of Pennsylvania Ballet and Boston Ballet found a creative way to show their team spirit.
Taking a break from their rigorous rehearsals, the dancers showcased some Super Bowl-themed choreography that wowed fans and followers alike.

Dressed in their Eagles green, the dancers of Pennsylvania Ballet delivered a high-energy routine filled with impressive fouetté turns, sky-high jumps, and elegant swan arms—a playful nod to their team's avian mascot.

Not to be outdone, Boston Ballet, with their five Super Bowl wins under their belt, shared a video on Facebook featuring principal Paul Craig and soloist Derek Dunn incorporating Balanchine tricks with props from Prodigal Son.

To celebrate game day (and cheer on their region's respective teams), the dancers of Pennsylvania Ballet and Boston Ballet took a break from their usual rehearsals to perform some Super Bowl-themed choreography.
Dressed in their Eagles green, the PAB dancers performed a fast-paced routine full of fouetté turns, sky-high jumps and some swan arms (because they're known as the birds, get it?).
But Boston Ballet also decided to get in on the fun—with five Super Bowl wins, they're used to seeing their team in the big game.
Sharing their own video on Facebook, which stars principal Paul Craig and soloist Derek Dunn, Boston Ballet threw in a few Balanchine tricks thanks to some props from Prodigal Son.
This is officially our new favorite way to get in on the football fun.
An Israeli soldier stationed in Hevron is facing disciplinary action after being caught stealing fruit from a stand in the city.
The soldier, whose identity has not been disclosed, was observed taking oranges and apples without permission.
The incident was reported to the authorities, leading to an investigation into the soldier's actions.
The theft took place in broad daylight, sparking outrage among locals and prompting swift action by military officials.
The soldier has been given 20 days to reflect on his actions and face the consequences of his behavior.
The Israel Defense Forces Spokesman said, "The investigation conducted by the battalion commander revealed that the soldier's behavior was not consistent with IDF values."
In a tightly contested match, Thomas Agyiri emerged as the hero for Ilves as they secured a narrow victory over HIFK.
The thrilling encounter saw Agyiri showcase his talent by scoring a crucial goal to lead his team to success.
The 23-year-old midfielder displayed his prowess by swiftly responding to Pekka Sihvola's early goal with an equalizer just a minute later.
Agyiri's goal not only restored parity for Ilves but also ignited a spirited performance from his teammates.
Despite receiving a yellow card for an emotional celebration in front of their supporters, Agyiri's impact was undeniable.
His substitution paved the way for Cameroonian attacker Marius Noubissi to shine, grabbing a brace to seal the victory for Ilves.
Xhevdet Gela and Juho Makela also found the back of the net for the visitors, while Ariel Nguekam's winning goal ensured a memorable triumph.
Noteworthy performances from Baba Mensah and Reuben Ayarna, who played the entire match, further solidified Ilves' impressive display.
The 23-year-old restored parity for Ilves just a minute after going down by Pekka Sihvola’s 8th minute strike.

ISLAMABAD (AP) — Pakistan's Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif is appearing before a Supreme Court-appointed team investigating allegations against his family's offshore companies and money laundering.
Sharif's appearance before the panel marks a significant development in the ongoing probe, which has gripped the nation for months.
The investigation team is expected to question Sharif regarding the ownership of offshore companies linked to his family and the alleged transfer of money through these accounts.
The Prime Minister has consistently denied any wrongdoing and has vowed to cooperate fully with the investigative process.
His two sons have already testified and denied the allegations against their family's financial affairs.

Sharif, who says he never misused his authority to enrich himself, has been under pressure to resign since reports based on documents leaked from a Panama-based law firm indicated his sons owned offshore companies.

The Supreme Court, after hearing petitions for months against Sharif and his family, has ruled there was not enough evidence to remove him from office but ordered an investigation team to look further into the allegations.
Is Friends on Netflix?

It propelled its six main cast members Jennifer Aniston, Courtney Cox, David Schwimmer, Matt Le Blanc, Lisa Kudrow and Matthew Perry, to international stardom and continues to delight new generations of comedy fans with its strong characterisation and tightly written plots.

The adventures of Ross, Rachel, Chandler, Phoebe, Monica and Joey have gone onto inspire countless other comedy series in the US and across the globe, but for most it's the original and the best Friends that will always be there for them when they're looking for a laugh.

Although for many years in the UK Friends was shown on Channel 4 (and sister channel E4) Friends has switched broadcasters and is now available exclusively on Comedy Central (Sky channel 112, Virgin channel 132).
Fans of the hit sitcom Friends may be wondering if the show is available on Netflix.
Unfortunately, Friends is not currently available on Netflix.
However, viewers can still enjoy the beloved series on Comedy Central.
With its timeless humor and beloved characters, Friends continues to be a favorite for audiences around the world."

An 89-year-old pedestrian tragically lost their life after being struck by a pickup truck in Nova Scotia, as confirmed by local authorities.
The incident occurred in a residential area, highlighting the vulnerability of pedestrians, especially in adverse weather conditions.
Emergency services responded swiftly to the scene, but unfortunately, the pedestrian succumbed to their injuries.
The driver of the pickup truck remained at the scene and cooperated with law enforcement officials.
The collision serves as a stark reminder for drivers to exercise caution and be vigilant, particularly when road conditions are challenging.
The Nova Scotia community is mourning the loss of the pedestrian, and thoughts go out to their family and loved ones during this difficult time.
Colchester District RCMP say the roads were covered in snow at the time of the crash.
The investigation is ongoing.
London police dished out dozens of tickets and gave more than 200 warnings on St. Patrick’s Day.
Sunny skies and single-digit temperatures brought thousands of green-clad revellers onto the streets around Western University and downtown Saturday to celebrate the Irish-themed day of festivities.
Police arrested three people and laid one criminal charge in what turned out to be a low-key St. Patrick’s Day.
The police presence was noticeable throughout the day, with officers patrolling the streets to ensure safety and order among the crowds.
Despite the large number of people out celebrating, incidents were relatively low compared to previous years.
The majority of the tickets issued were for minor infractions such as public intoxication, jaywalking, and underage drinking.
One of the highlights of the day was the annual St. Patrick’s Day parade, which saw floats, bands, and marchers making their way through the city streets.
The parade was well-received by spectators who lined the route, cheering and waving Irish flags in the spirit of the holiday.
In addition to the police presence on the streets, emergency services were also on high alert to respond to any incidents.
Paramedics reported a few cases of alcohol-related illnesses, but overall, the day was relatively quiet in terms of medical emergencies.
As the sun set on St. Patrick’s Day, most revellers dispersed peacefully, heading home after a day of celebrating.
The police remained vigilant throughout the night to ensure that the festivities ended on a safe and orderly note.
Overall, London police deemed the day a success in terms of crowd control and public safety.

Image copyright Erika Tsang Image caption Witnesses said the smoke appeared to be coming from a care home complex A man's body has been found after emergency services forced their way into a barricaded property.
Police were called by ambulance crews to a flat in Devonshire Court, Oadby, in Leicestershire at about 17:50 BST.
Due to a fire at the scene, the fire service attended and gained entry to the premises.
The man, believed to be in his 50s, was pronounced dead at the scene.
Authorities are treating the death as unexplained and have launched an inquiry into the circumstances surrounding the incident.
The property was reportedly barricaded from the inside, causing challenges for emergency responders.
Investigators are working to determine the cause of the fire and the events leading up to the man's death.
Residents in the area expressed shock and concern over the tragic incident, with some noting that the smoke seemed to be originating from a nearby care home complex.
The community awaits further updates as the investigation unfolds.
In a cruel twist of fate, a group of lottery players in South Carolina were left disheartened when their Christmas glitch lottery win was denied due to what is being dubbed as a "Grinchy law."
The glitch, which occurred during a special holiday promotion, saw nine Christmas trees aligning on the ticket, a clear indication of a winning combination.
However, their joy quickly turned to disappointment as lottery officials invoked a state law that prohibits the payment of prizes resulting from a ticket printed in error.
Lottery officials have confirmed that the trees were indeed printed in all nine slots, but they are adamant about not awarding the prizes.
The decision has sparked outrage among the affected players, leading to two lawsuits being filed in response to the denial of their rightful winnings.
Lottery officials say trees were printed in all nine slots.
A statement from the lottery cited a South Carolina law that prizes resulting from a ticket printed in error must not be paid.
Two lawsuits have already been filed by players.
McDonald's has announced that its recent deals and introduction of $1 sodas have significantly contributed to boosting its key sales figure.
The fast-food giant revealed that these strategic initiatives have resonated well with customers, leading to an increase in sales across its various locations.
The company's focus on providing affordable options and enticing promotions has clearly paid off, as reflected in the positive sales results.
The Oak Brook, Illinois-based company also reported better-than expected earnings and revenue for the quarter.
The company posted net income of $698.7 million, or 87 cents per share.
Earnings, adjusted for non-recurring costs, were $1.71 per share, beating the $1.59 per share analysts expected, according to Zacks Investment Research.
This strong financial performance indicates that McDonald's is effectively navigating the challenging economic landscape and adapting to changing consumer preferences.
Overall, McDonald's success in driving sales growth and exceeding earnings expectations underscores its resilience and ability to innovate in the competitive fast-food industry.
The company's focus on value offerings and customer engagement continues to drive its momentum and position it for further success in the market.

A recent study has revealed that young millennials are the worst behaved drivers on the road.

The study, conducted by a leading research institute, analyzed driving habits of different age groups and found that individuals aged between 18 and 34 exhibited the highest rates of reckless driving, speeding, and traffic violations.
The study attributed this behavior to a combination of factors, including inexperience behind the wheel, overconfidence, and a propensity for risky behavior.
Young millennials were found to be more likely to engage in distracted driving, such as texting or using social media while driving, compared to older age groups.
Furthermore, the study highlighted that young millennials were also less likely to adhere to traffic laws and regulations, such as wearing seat belts and obeying speed limits.
These findings raise concerns about road safety and the need for targeted interventions to address the risky driving behaviors exhibited by this demographic.

In light of these findings, experts emphasize the importance of promoting responsible driving habits among young millennials through education, enforcement of traffic laws, and initiatives aimed at increasing awareness about the dangers of reckless driving.
By addressing these issues, it is hoped that road safety can be improved for all drivers.
